THACKERAY, ESQ.,\r\n\r\nThis Work\r\nIS RESPECTFULLY INSCRIBED\r\n\r\nBY\r\nTHE AUTHOR\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPREFACE\r\n\r\n\r\nA preface to the first edition of \xe2\x80\x9cJane Eyre\xe2\x80\x9d being unnecessary, I gave\r\nnone: this second edition demands a few words both of acknowledgment\r\nand miscellaneous remark.\r\n\r\nMy thanks are due in three quarters.\r\n\r\nTo the Public, for the indulgent ear it has inclined to a plain tale\r\nwith few pretensions.\r\n\r\nTo the Press, for the fair field its honest suffrage has opened to an\r\nobscure aspirant.\r\n\r\nTo my Publishers, for the aid their tact, their energy, their practical\r\nsense and frank liberality have afforded an unknown and unrecommended\r\nAuthor.\r\n\r\nThe Press and the Public are but vague personifications for me, and I\r\nmust thank them in vague terms; but my Publishers are definite: so are\r\ncertain generous critics who have encouraged me as only large-hearted\r\nand high-minded men know how to encourage a struggling stranger; to\r\nthem, _i.e._, to my Publishers and the select Reviewers, I say\r\ncordially, Gentlemen, I thank you from my heart.\r\n\r\nHaving thus acknowledged what I owe those who have aided and approved\r\nme, I turn to another class; a small one, so far as I know, but not,\r\ntherefore, to be overlooked. I mean the timorous or carping few who\r\ndoubt the tendency of such books as \xe2\x80\x9cJane Eyre:\xe2\x80\x9d in whose eyes whatever\r\nis unusual is wrong; whose ears detect in each protest against\r\nbigotry\xe2\x80\x94that parent of crime\xe2\x80\x94an insult to piety, that regent of God on\r\nearth. I would suggest to such doubters certain obvious distinctions; I\r\nwould remind them of certain simple truths.\r\n\r\nConventionality is not morality. Self-righteousness is not religion. To\r\nattack the first is not to assail the last. To pluck the mask from the\r\nface of the Pharisee, is not to lift an impious hand to the Crown of\r\nThorns.\r\n\r\nThese things and deeds are diametrically opposed: they are as distinct\r\nas is vice from virtue. Men too often confound them: they should not be\r\nconfounded: appearance should not be mistaken for truth; narrow human\r\ndoctrines, that only tend to elate and magnify a few, should not be\r\nsubstituted for the world-redeeming creed of Christ. There is\xe2\x80\x94I repeat\r\nit\xe2\x80\x94a difference; and it is a good, and not a bad action to mark broadly\r\nand clearly the line of separation between them.\r\n\r\nThe world may not like to see these ideas dissevered, for it has been\r\naccustomed to blend them; finding it convenient to make external show\r\npass for sterling worth\xe2\x80\x94to let white-washed walls vouch for clean\r\nshrines. It may hate him who dares to scrutinise and expose\xe2\x80\x94to rase the\r\ngilding, and show base metal under it\xe2\x80\x94to penetrate the sepulchre, and\r\nreveal charnel relics: but hate as it will, it is indebted to him.\r\n\r\nAhab did not like Micaiah, because he never prophesied good concerning\r\nhim, but evil; probably he liked the sycophant son of Chenaanah\r\nbetter; yet might Ahab have escaped a bloody death, had he but stopped\r\nhis ears to flattery, and opened them to faithful counsel.\r\n\r\nThere is a man in our own days whose words are not framed to tickle\r\ndelicate ears: who, to my thinking, comes before the great ones of\r\nsociety, much as the son of Imlah came before the throned Kings of\r\nJudah and Israel; and who speaks truth as deep, with a power as\r\nprophet-like and as vital\xe2\x80\x94a mien as dauntless and as daring. Is the\r\nsatirist of \xe2\x80\x9cVanity Fair\xe2\x80\x9d admired in high places? I cannot tell; but I\r\nthink if some of those amongst whom he hurls the Greek fire of his\r\nsarcasm, and over whom he flashes the levin-brand of his denunciation,\r\nwere to take his warnings in time\xe2\x80\x94they or their seed might yet escape a\r\nfatal Rimoth-Gilead.\r\n\r\nWhy have I alluded to this man? I have alluded to him, Reader, because\r\nI think I see in him an intellect profounder and more unique than his\r\ncontemporaries have yet recognised; because I regard him as the first\r\nsocial regenerator of the day\xe2\x80\x94as the very master of that working corps\r\nwho would restore to rectitude the warped system of things; because I\r\nthink no commentator on his writings has yet found the comparison that\r\nsuits him, the terms which rightly characterise his talent. They say he\r\nis like Fielding: they talk of his wit, humour, comic powers. He\r\nresembles Fielding as an eagle does a vulture: Fielding could stoop on\r\ncarrion, but Thackeray never does. His wit is bright, his humour\r\nattractive, but both bear the same relation to his serious genius that\r\nthe mere lambent sheet-lightning playing under the edge of the\r\nsummer-cloud does to the electric death-spark hid in its womb. Finally,\r\nI have alluded to Mr. Thackeray, because to him\xe2\x80\x94if he will accept the\r\ntribute of a total stranger\xe2\x80\x94I have dedicated this second edition of\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJANE EYRE.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCURRER BELL.\r\n\r\n_December_ 21_st_, 1847.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nNOTE TO THE THIRD EDITION\r\n\r\n\r\nI avail myself of the opportunity which a third edition of \xe2\x80\x9cJane Eyre\xe2\x80\x9d\r\naffords me, of again addressing a word to the Public, to explain that\r\nmy claim to the title of novelist rests on this one work alone. If,\r\ntherefore, the authorship of other works of fiction has been attributed\r\nto me, an honour is awarded where it is not merited; and consequently,\r\ndenied where it is justly due.\r\n\r\nThis explanation will serve to rectify mistakes which may already have\r\nbeen made, and to prevent future errors.\r\n\r\nCURRER BELL.\r\n\r\n_April_ 13_th_, 1848.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER I\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was no possibility of taking a walk that day. We had been\r\nwandering, indeed, in the leafless shrubbery an hour in the morning;\r\nbut since dinner (Mrs. Reed, when there was no company, dined early)\r\nthe cold winter wind had brought with it clouds so sombre, and a rain\r\nso penetrating, that further outdoor exercise was now out of the\r\nquestion.\r\n\r\nI was glad of it: I never liked long walks, especially on chilly\r\nafternoons: dreadful to me was the coming home in the raw twilight,\r\nwith nipped fingers and toes, and a heart saddened by the chidings of\r\nBessie, the nurse, and humbled by the consciousness of my physical\r\ninferiority to Eliza, John, and Georgiana Reed.\r\n\r\nThe said Eliza, John, and Georgiana were now clustered round their mama\r\nin the drawing-room: she lay reclined on a sofa by the fireside, and\r\nwith her darlings about her (for the time neither quarrelling nor\r\ncrying) looked perfectly happy. Me, she had dispensed from joining the\r\ngroup; saying, \xe2\x80\x9cShe regretted to be under the necessity of keeping me\r\nat a distance; but that until she heard from Bessie, and could discover\r\nby her own observation, that I was endeavouring in good earnest to\r\nacquire a more sociable and childlike disposition, a more attractive\r\nand sprightly manner\xe2\x80\x94something lighter, franker, more natural, as it\r\nwere\xe2\x80\x94she really must exclude me from privileges intended only for\r\ncontented, happy, little children.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does Bessie say I have done?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I don\xe2\x80\x99t like cavillers or questioners; besides, there is\r\nsomething truly forbidding in a child taking up her elders in that\r\nmanner. Be seated somewhere; and until you can speak pleasantly, remain\r\nsilent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA breakfast-room adjoined the drawing-room, I slipped in there. It\r\ncontained a bookcase: I soon possessed myself of a volume, taking care\r\nthat it should be one stored with pictures. I mounted into the\r\nwindow-seat: gathering up my feet, I sat cross-legged, like a Turk;\r\nand, having drawn the red moreen curtain nearly close, I was shrined in\r\ndouble retirement.\r\n\r\nFolds of scarlet drapery shut in my view to the right hand; to the left\r\nwere the clear panes of glass, protecting, but not separating me from\r\nthe drear November day. At intervals, while turning over the leaves of\r\nmy book, I studied the aspect of that winter afternoon. Afar, it\r\noffered a pale blank of mist and cloud; near a scene of wet lawn and\r\nstorm-beat shrub, with ceaseless rain sweeping away wildly before a\r\nlong and lamentable blast.\r\n\r\nI returned to my book\xe2\x80\x94Bewick\xe2\x80\x99s History of British Birds: the\r\nletterpress thereof I cared little for, generally speaking; and yet\r\nthere were certain introductory pages that, child as I was, I could not\r\npass quite as a blank. They were those which treat of the haunts of\r\nsea-fowl; of \xe2\x80\x9cthe solitary rocks and promontories\xe2\x80\x9d by them only\r\ninhabited; of the coast of Norway, studded with isles from its southern\r\nextremity, the Lindeness, or Naze, to the North Cape\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere the Northern Ocean, in vast whirls,\r\nBoils round the naked, melancholy isles\r\nOf farthest Thule; and the Atlantic surge\r\nPours in among the stormy Hebrides.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nNor could I pass unnoticed the suggestion of the bleak shores of\r\nLapland, Siberia, Spitzbergen, Nova Zembla, Iceland, Greenland, with\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe vast sweep of the Arctic Zone, and those forlorn regions of dreary\r\nspace,\xe2\x80\x94that reservoir of frost and snow, where firm fields of ice, the\r\naccumulation of centuries of winters, glazed in Alpine heights above\r\nheights, surround the pole, and concentre the multiplied rigours of\r\nextreme cold.\xe2\x80\x9d Of these death-white realms I formed an idea of my own:\r\nshadowy, like all the half-comprehended notions that float dim through\r\nchildren\xe2\x80\x99s brains, but strangely impressive. The words in these\r\nintroductory pages connected themselves with the succeeding vignettes,\r\nand gave significance to the rock standing up alone in a sea of billow\r\nand spray; to the broken boat stranded on a desolate coast; to the cold\r\nand ghastly moon glancing through bars of cloud at a wreck just\r\nsinking.\r\n\r\nI cannot tell what sentiment haunted the quite solitary churchyard,\r\nwith its inscribed headstone; its gate, its two trees, its low horizon,\r\ngirdled by a broken wall, and its newly-risen crescent, attesting the\r\nhour of eventide.\r\n\r\nThe two ships becalmed on a torpid sea, I believed to be marine\r\nphantoms.\r\n\r\nThe fiend pinning down the thief\xe2\x80\x99s pack behind him, I passed over\r\nquickly: it was an object of terror.\r\n\r\nSo was the black horned thing seated aloof on a rock, surveying a\r\ndistant crowd surrounding a gallows.\r\n\r\nEach picture told a story; mysterious often to my undeveloped\r\nunderstanding and imperfect feelings, yet ever profoundly interesting:\r\nas interesting as the tales Bessie sometimes narrated on winter\r\nevenings, when she chanced to be in good humour; and when, having\r\nbrought her ironing-table to the nursery hearth, she allowed us to sit\r\nabout it, and while she got up Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s lace frills, and crimped her\r\nnightcap borders, fed our eager attention with passages of love and\r\nadventure taken from old fairy tales and other ballads; or (as at a\r\nlater period I discovered) from the pages of Pamela, and Henry, Earl of\r\nMoreland.\r\n\r\nWith Bewick on my knee, I was then happy: happy at least in my way. I\r\nfeared nothing but interruption, and that came too soon. The\r\nbreakfast-room door opened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoh! Madam Mope!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the voice of John Reed; then he paused: he\r\nfound the room apparently empty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere the dickens is she!\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cLizzy! Georgy! (calling to\r\nhis sisters) Joan is not here: tell mama she is run out into the\r\nrain\xe2\x80\x94bad animal!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well I drew the curtain,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I; and I wished fervently he\r\nmight not discover my hiding-place: nor would John Reed have found it\r\nout himself; he was not quick either of vision or conception; but Eliza\r\njust put her head in at the door, and said at once\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is in the window-seat, to be sure, Jack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd I came out immediately, for I trembled at the idea of being dragged\r\nforth by the said Jack.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, with awkward diffidence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSay, \xe2\x80\x98What do you want, Master Reed?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer. \xe2\x80\x9cI want you to\r\ncome here;\xe2\x80\x9d and seating himself in an arm-chair, he intimated by a\r\ngesture that I was to approach and stand before him.\r\n\r\nJohn Reed was a schoolboy of fourteen years old; four years older than\r\nI, for I was but ten: large and stout for his age, with a dingy and\r\nunwholesome skin; thick lineaments in a spacious visage, heavy limbs\r\nand large extremities. He gorged himself habitually at table, which\r\nmade him bilious, and gave him a dim and bleared eye and flabby cheeks.\r\nHe ought now to have been at school; but his mama had taken him home\r\nfor a month or two, \xe2\x80\x9con account of his delicate health.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Miles, the\r\nmaster, affirmed that he would do very well if he had fewer cakes and\r\nsweetmeats sent him from home; but the mother\xe2\x80\x99s heart turned from an\r\nopinion so harsh, and inclined rather to the more refined idea that\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s sallowness was owing to over-application and, perhaps, to pining\r\nafter home.\r\n\r\nJohn had not much affection for his mother and sisters, and an\r\nantipathy to me. He bullied and punished me; not two or three times in\r\nthe week, nor once or twice in the day, but continually: every nerve I\r\nhad feared him, and every morsel of flesh in my bones shrank when he\r\ncame near. There were moments when I was bewildered by the terror he\r\ninspired, because I had no appeal whatever against either his menaces\r\nor his inflictions; the servants did not like to offend their young\r\nmaster by taking my part against him, and Mrs. Reed was blind and deaf\r\non the subject: she never saw him strike or heard him abuse me, though\r\nhe did both now and then in her very presence, more frequently,\r\nhowever, behind her back.\r\n\r\nHabitually obedient to John, I came up to his chair: he spent some\r\nthree minutes in thrusting out his tongue at me as far as he could\r\nwithout damaging the roots: I knew he would soon strike, and while\r\ndreading the blow, I mused on the disgusting and ugly appearance of him\r\nwho would presently deal it. I wonder if he read that notion in my\r\nface; for, all at once, without speaking, he struck suddenly and\r\nstrongly. I tottered, and on regaining my equilibrium retired back a\r\nstep or two from his chair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is for your impudence in answering mama awhile since,\xe2\x80\x9d said he,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand for your sneaking way of getting behind curtains, and for the look\r\nyou had in your eyes two minutes since, you rat!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAccustomed to John Reed\xe2\x80\x99s abuse, I never had an idea of replying to it;\r\nmy care was how to endure the blow which would certainly follow the\r\ninsult.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat were you doing behind the curtain?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was reading.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow the book.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI returned to the window and fetched it thence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no business to take our books; you are a dependent, mama\r\nsays; you have no money; your father left you none; you ought to beg,\r\nand not to live here with gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s children like us, and eat the\r\nsame meals we do, and wear clothes at our mama\xe2\x80\x99s expense. Now, I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nteach you to rummage my bookshelves: for they _are_ mine; all the house\r\nbelongs to me, or will do in a few years. Go and stand by the door, out\r\nof the way of the mirror and the windows.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did so, not at first aware what was his intention; but when I saw him\r\nlift and poise the book and stand in act to hurl it, I instinctively\r\nstarted aside with a cry of alarm: not soon enough, however; the volume\r\nwas flung, it hit me, and I fell, striking my head against the door and\r\ncutting it. The cut bled, the pain was sharp: my terror had passed its\r\nclimax; other feelings succeeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWicked and cruel boy!\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are like a murderer\xe2\x80\x94you are like a\r\nslave-driver\xe2\x80\x94you are like the Roman emperors!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had read Goldsmith\xe2\x80\x99s History of Rome, and had formed my opinion of\r\nNero, Caligula, &c. Also I had drawn parallels in silence, which I\r\nnever thought thus to have declared aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! what!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cDid she say that to me? Did you hear her,\r\nEliza and Georgiana? Won\xe2\x80\x99t I tell mama? but first\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe ran headlong at me: I felt him grasp my hair and my shoulder: he had\r\nclosed with a desperate thing. I really saw in him a tyrant, a\r\nmurderer. I felt a drop or two of blood from my head trickle down my\r\nneck, and was sensible of somewhat pungent suffering: these sensations\r\nfor the time predominated over fear, and I received him in frantic\r\nsort. I don\xe2\x80\x99t very well know what I did with my hands, but he called me\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRat! Rat!\xe2\x80\x9d and bellowed out aloud. Aid was near him: Eliza and\r\nGeorgiana had run for Mrs. Reed, who was gone upstairs: she now came\r\nupon the scene, followed by Bessie and her maid Abbot. We were parted:\r\nI heard the words\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear! dear! What a fury to fly at Master John!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid ever anybody see such a picture of passion!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen Mrs. Reed subjoined\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake her away to the red-room, and lock her in there.\xe2\x80\x9d Four hands were\r\nimmediately laid upon me, and I was borne upstairs.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER II\r\n\r\n\r\nI resisted all the way: a new thing for me, and a circumstance which\r\ngreatly strengthened the bad opinion Bessie and Miss Abbot were\r\ndisposed to entertain of me. The fact is, I was a trifle beside myself;\r\nor rather _out_ of myself, as the French would say: I was conscious\r\nthat a moment\xe2\x80\x99s mutiny had already rendered me liable to strange\r\npenalties, and, like any other rebel slave, I felt resolved, in my\r\ndesperation, to go all lengths.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold her arms, Miss Abbot: she\xe2\x80\x99s like a mad cat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor shame! for shame!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat shocking conduct,\r\nMiss Eyre, to strike a young gentleman, your benefactress\xe2\x80\x99s son! Your\r\nyoung master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMaster! How is he my master? Am I a servant?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you are less than a servant, for you do nothing for your keep.\r\nThere, sit down, and think over your wickedness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey had got me by this time into the apartment indicated by Mrs. Reed,\r\nand had thrust me upon a stool: my impulse was to rise from it like a\r\nspring; their two pair of hands arrested me instantly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you don\xe2\x80\x99t sit still, you must be tied down,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss\r\nAbbot, lend me your garters; she would break mine directly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Abbot turned to divest a stout leg of the necessary ligature. This\r\npreparation for bonds, and the additional ignominy it inferred, took a\r\nlittle of the excitement out of me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t take them off,\xe2\x80\x9d I cried; \xe2\x80\x9cI will not stir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn guarantee whereof, I attached myself to my seat by my hands.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMind you don\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie; and when she had ascertained that I was\r\nreally subsiding, she loosened her hold of me; then she and Miss Abbot\r\nstood with folded arms, looking darkly and doubtfully on my face, as\r\nincredulous of my sanity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe never did so before,\xe2\x80\x9d at last said Bessie, turning to the Abigail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut it was always in her,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve told Missis often my\r\nopinion about the child, and Missis agreed with me. She\xe2\x80\x99s an underhand\r\nlittle thing: I never saw a girl of her age with so much cover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie answered not; but ere long, addressing me, she said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ought to be aware, Miss, that you are under obligations to Mrs.\r\nReed: she keeps you: if she were to turn you off, you would have to go\r\nto the poorhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had nothing to say to these words: they were not new to me: my very\r\nfirst recollections of existence included hints of the same kind. This\r\nreproach of my dependence had become a vague sing-song in my ear: very\r\npainful and crushing, but only half intelligible. Miss Abbot joined in\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you ought not to think yourself on an equality with the Misses\r\nReed and Master Reed, because Missis kindly allows you to be brought up\r\nwith them. They will have a great deal of money, and you will have\r\nnone: it is your place to be humble, and to try to make yourself\r\nagreeable to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat we tell you is for your good,\xe2\x80\x9d added Bessie, in no harsh voice,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou should try to be useful and pleasant, then, perhaps, you would\r\nhave a home here; but if you become passionate and rude, Missis will\r\nsend you away, I am sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Abbot, \xe2\x80\x9cGod will punish her: He might strike her\r\ndead in the midst of her tantrums, and then where would she go? Come,\r\nBessie, we will leave her: I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t have her heart for anything. Say\r\nyour prayers, Miss Eyre, when you are by yourself; for if you don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nrepent, something bad might be permitted to come down the chimney and\r\nfetch you away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey went, shutting the door, and locking it behind them.\r\n\r\nThe red-room was a square chamber, very seldom slept in, I might say\r\nnever, indeed, unless when a chance influx of visitors at Gateshead\r\nHall rendered it necessary to turn to account all the accommodation it\r\ncontained: yet it was one of the largest and stateliest chambers in the\r\nmansion. A bed supported on massive pillars of mahogany, hung with\r\ncurtains of deep red damask, stood out like a tabernacle in the centre;\r\nthe two large windows, with their blinds always drawn down, were half\r\nshrouded in festoons and falls of similar drapery; the carpet was red;\r\nthe table at the foot of the bed was covered with a crimson cloth; the\r\nwalls were a soft fawn colour with a blush of pink in it; the wardrobe,\r\nthe toilet-table, the chairs were of darkly polished old mahogany. Out\r\nof these deep surrounding shades rose high, and glared white, the\r\npiled-up mattresses and pillows of the bed, spread with a snowy\r\nMarseilles counterpane. Scarcely less prominent was an ample cushioned\r\neasy-chair near the head of the bed, also white, with a footstool\r\nbefore it; and looking, as I thought, like a pale throne.\r\n\r\nThis room was chill, because it seldom had a fire; it was silent,\r\nbecause remote from the nursery and kitchen; solemn, because it was\r\nknown to be so seldom entered. The house-maid alone came here on\r\nSaturdays, to wipe from the mirrors and the furniture a week\xe2\x80\x99s quiet\r\ndust: and Mrs. Reed herself, at far intervals, visited it to review the\r\ncontents of a certain secret drawer in the wardrobe, where were stored\r\ndivers parchments, her jewel-casket, and a miniature of her deceased\r\nhusband; and in those last words lies the secret of the red-room\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nspell which kept it so lonely in spite of its grandeur.\r\n\r\nMr. Reed had been dead nine years: it was in this chamber he breathed\r\nhis last; here he lay in state; hence his coffin was borne by the\r\nundertaker\xe2\x80\x99s men; and, since that day, a sense of dreary consecration\r\nhad guarded it from frequent intrusion.\r\n\r\nMy seat, to which Bessie and the bitter Miss Abbot had left me riveted,\r\nwas a low ottoman near the marble chimney-piece; the bed rose before\r\nme; to my right hand there was the high, dark wardrobe, with subdued,\r\nbroken reflections varying the gloss of its panels; to my left were the\r\nmuffled windows; a great looking-glass between them repeated the vacant\r\nmajesty of the bed and room. I was not quite sure whether they had\r\nlocked the door; and when I dared move, I got up and went to see. Alas!\r\nyes: no jail was ever more secure. Returning, I had to cross before the\r\nlooking-glass; my fascinated glance involuntarily explored the depth it\r\nrevealed. All looked colder and darker in that visionary hollow than in\r\nreality: and the strange little figure there gazing at me, with a white\r\nface and arms specking the gloom, and glittering eyes of fear moving\r\nwhere all else was still, had the effect of a real spirit: I thought it\r\nlike one of the tiny phantoms, half fairy, half imp, Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s evening\r\nstories represented as coming out of lone, ferny dells in moors, and\r\nappearing before the eyes of belated travellers. I returned to my\r\nstool.\r\n\r\nSuperstition was with me at that moment; but it was not yet her hour\r\nfor complete victory: my blood was still warm; the mood of the revolted\r\nslave was still bracing me with its bitter vigour; I had to stem a\r\nrapid rush of retrospective thought before I quailed to the dismal\r\npresent.\r\n\r\nAll John Reed\xe2\x80\x99s violent tyrannies, all his sisters\xe2\x80\x99 proud indifference,\r\nall his mother\xe2\x80\x99s aversion, all the servants\xe2\x80\x99 partiality, turned up in\r\nmy disturbed mind like a dark deposit in a turbid well. Why was I\r\nalways suffering, always browbeaten, always accused, for ever\r\ncondemned? Why could I never please? Why was it useless to try to win\r\nany one\xe2\x80\x99s favour? Eliza, who was headstrong and selfish, was respected.\r\nGeorgiana, who had a spoiled temper, a very acrid spite, a captious and\r\ninsolent carriage, was universally indulged. Her beauty, her pink\r\ncheeks and golden curls, seemed to give delight to all who looked at\r\nher, and to purchase indemnity for every fault. John no one thwarted,\r\nmuch less punished; though he twisted the necks of the pigeons, killed\r\nthe little pea-chicks, set the dogs at the sheep, stripped the hothouse\r\nvines of their fruit, and broke the buds off the choicest plants in the\r\nconservatory: he called his mother \xe2\x80\x9cold girl,\xe2\x80\x9d too; sometimes reviled\r\nher for her dark skin, similar to his own; bluntly disregarded her\r\nwishes; not unfrequently tore and spoiled her silk attire; and he was\r\nstill \xe2\x80\x9cher own darling.\xe2\x80\x9d I dared commit no fault: I strove to fulfil\r\nevery duty; and I was termed naughty and tiresome, sullen and sneaking,\r\nfrom morning to noon, and from noon to night.\r\n\r\nMy head still ached and bled with the blow and fall I had received: no\r\none had reproved John for wantonly striking me; and because I had\r\nturned against him to avert farther irrational violence, I was loaded\r\nwith general opprobrium.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnjust!\xe2\x80\x94unjust!\xe2\x80\x9d said my reason, forced by the agonising stimulus into\r\nprecocious though transitory power: and Resolve, equally wrought up,\r\ninstigated some strange expedient to achieve escape from insupportable\r\noppression\xe2\x80\x94as running away, or, if that could not be effected, never\r\neating or drinking more, and letting myself die.\r\n\r\nWhat a consternation of soul was mine that dreary afternoon! How all my\r\nbrain was in tumult, and all my heart in insurrection! Yet in what\r\ndarkness, what dense ignorance, was the mental battle fought! I could\r\nnot answer the ceaseless inward question\xe2\x80\x94_why_ I thus suffered; now, at\r\nthe distance of\xe2\x80\x94I will not say how many years, I see it clearly.\r\n\r\nI was a discord in Gateshead Hall: I was like nobody there; I had\r\nnothing in harmony with Mrs. Reed or her children, or her chosen\r\nvassalage. If they did not love me, in fact, as little did I love them.\r\nThey were not bound to regard with affection a thing that could not\r\nsympathise with one amongst them; a heterogeneous thing, opposed to\r\nthem in temperament, in capacity, in propensities; a useless thing,\r\nincapable of serving their interest, or adding to their pleasure; a\r\nnoxious thing, cherishing the germs of indignation at their treatment,\r\nof contempt of their judgment. I know that had I been a sanguine,\r\nbrilliant, careless, exacting, handsome, romping child\xe2\x80\x94though equally\r\ndependent and friendless\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Reed would have endured my presence more\r\ncomplacently; her children would have entertained for me more of the\r\ncordiality of fellow-feeling; the servants would have been less prone\r\nto make me the scapegoat of the nursery.\r\n\r\nDaylight began to forsake the red-room; it was past four o\xe2\x80\x99clock, and\r\nthe beclouded afternoon was tending to drear twilight. I heard the rain\r\nstill beating continuously on the staircase window, and the wind\r\nhowling in the grove behind the hall; I grew by degrees cold as a\r\nstone, and then my courage sank. My habitual mood of humiliation,\r\nself-doubt, forlorn depression, fell damp on the embers of my decaying\r\nire. All said I was wicked, and perhaps I might be so; what thought had\r\nI been but just conceiving of starving myself to death? That certainly\r\nwas a crime: and was I fit to die? Or was the vault under the chancel\r\nof Gateshead Church an inviting bourne? In such vault I had been told\r\ndid Mr. Reed lie buried; and led by this thought to recall his idea, I\r\ndwelt on it with gathering dread. I could not remember him; but I knew\r\nthat he was my own uncle\xe2\x80\x94my mother\xe2\x80\x99s brother\xe2\x80\x94that he had taken me when\r\na parentless infant to his house; and that in his last moments he had\r\nrequired a promise of Mrs. Reed that she would rear and maintain me as\r\none of her own children. Mrs. Reed probably considered she had kept\r\nthis promise; and so she had, I dare say, as well as her nature would\r\npermit her; but how could she really like an interloper not of her\r\nrace, and unconnected with her, after her husband\xe2\x80\x99s death, by any tie?\r\nIt must have been most irksome to find herself bound by a hard-wrung\r\npledge to stand in the stead of a parent to a strange child she could\r\nnot love, and to see an uncongenial alien permanently intruded on her\r\nown family group.\r\n\r\nA singular notion dawned upon me. I doubted not\xe2\x80\x94never doubted\xe2\x80\x94that if\r\nMr. Reed had been alive he would have treated me kindly; and now, as I\r\nsat looking at the white bed and overshadowed walls\xe2\x80\x94occasionally also\r\nturning a fascinated eye towards the dimly gleaming mirror\xe2\x80\x94I began to\r\nrecall what I had heard of dead men, troubled in their graves by the\r\nviolation of their last wishes, revisiting the earth to punish the\r\nperjured and avenge the oppressed; and I thought Mr. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s spirit,\r\nharassed by the wrongs of his sister\xe2\x80\x99s child, might quit its\r\nabode\xe2\x80\x94whether in the church vault or in the unknown world of the\r\ndeparted\xe2\x80\x94and rise before me in this chamber. I wiped my tears and\r\nhushed my sobs, fearful lest any sign of violent grief might waken a\r\npreternatural voice to comfort me, or elicit from the gloom some haloed\r\nface, bending over me with strange pity. This idea, consolatory in\r\ntheory, I felt would be terrible if realised: with all my might I\r\nendeavoured to stifle it\xe2\x80\x94I endeavoured to be firm. Shaking my hair from\r\nmy eyes, I lifted my head and tried to look boldly round the dark room;\r\nat this moment a light gleamed on the wall. Was it, I asked myself, a\r\nray from the moon penetrating some aperture in the blind? No; moonlight\r\nwas still, and this stirred; while I gazed, it glided up to the ceiling\r\nand quivered over my head. I can now conjecture readily that this\r\nstreak of light was, in all likelihood, a gleam from a lantern carried\r\nby some one across the lawn: but then, prepared as my mind was for\r\nhorror, shaken as my nerves were by agitation, I thought the swift\r\ndarting beam was a herald of some coming vision from another world. My\r\nheart beat thick, my head grew hot; a sound filled my ears, which I\r\ndeemed the rushing of wings; something seemed near me; I was oppressed,\r\nsuffocated: endurance broke down; I rushed to the door and shook the\r\nlock in desperate effort. Steps came running along the outer passage;\r\nthe key turned, Bessie and Abbot entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eyre, are you ill?\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a dreadful noise! it went quite through me!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Abbot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake me out! Let me go into the nursery!\xe2\x80\x9d was my cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for? Are you hurt? Have you seen something?\xe2\x80\x9d again demanded\r\nBessie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I saw a light, and I thought a ghost would come.\xe2\x80\x9d I had now got\r\nhold of Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s hand, and she did not snatch it from me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has screamed out on purpose,\xe2\x80\x9d declared Abbot, in some disgust.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what a scream! If she had been in great pain one would have\r\nexcused it, but she only wanted to bring us all here: I know her\r\nnaughty tricks.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is all this?\xe2\x80\x9d demanded another voice peremptorily; and Mrs. Reed\r\ncame along the corridor, her cap flying wide, her gown rustling\r\nstormily. \xe2\x80\x9cAbbot and Bessie, I believe I gave orders that Jane Eyre\r\nshould be left in the red-room till I came to her myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Jane screamed so loud, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d pleaded Bessie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her go,\xe2\x80\x9d was the only answer. \xe2\x80\x9cLoose Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s hand, child: you\r\ncannot succeed in getting out by these means, be assured. I abhor\r\nartifice, particularly in children; it is my duty to show you that\r\ntricks will not answer: you will now stay here an hour longer, and it\r\nis only on condition of perfect submission and stillness that I shall\r\nliberate you then.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO aunt! have pity! Forgive me! I cannot endure it\xe2\x80\x94let me be punished\r\nsome other way! I shall be killed if\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence! This violence is all most repulsive:\xe2\x80\x9d and so, no doubt, she\r\nfelt it. I was a precocious actress in her eyes; she sincerely looked\r\non me as a compound of virulent passions, mean spirit, and dangerous\r\nduplicity.\r\n\r\nBessie and Abbot having retreated, Mrs. Reed, impatient of my now\r\nfrantic anguish and wild sobs, abruptly thrust me back and locked me\r\nin, without farther parley. I heard her sweeping away; and soon after\r\nshe was gone, I suppose I had a species of fit: unconsciousness closed\r\nthe scene.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER III\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next thing I remember is, waking up with a feeling as if I had had\r\na frightful nightmare, and seeing before me a terrible red glare,\r\ncrossed with thick black bars. I heard voices, too, speaking with a\r\nhollow sound, and as if muffled by a rush of wind or water: agitation,\r\nuncertainty, and an all-predominating sense of terror confused my\r\nfaculties. Ere long, I became aware that some one was handling me;\r\nlifting me up and supporting me in a sitting posture, and that more\r\ntenderly than I had ever been raised or upheld before. I rested my head\r\nagainst a pillow or an arm, and felt easy.\r\n\r\nIn five minutes more the cloud of bewilderment dissolved: I knew quite\r\nwell that I was in my own bed, and that the red glare was the nursery\r\nfire. It was night: a candle burnt on the table; Bessie stood at the\r\nbed-foot with a basin in her hand, and a gentleman sat in a chair near\r\nmy pillow, leaning over me.\r\n\r\nI felt an inexpressible relief, a soothing conviction of protection and\r\nsecurity, when I knew that there was a stranger in the room, an\r\nindividual not belonging to Gateshead, and not related to Mrs. Reed.\r\nTurning from Bessie (though her presence was far less obnoxious to me\r\nthan that of Abbot, for instance, would have been), I scrutinised the\r\nface of the gentleman: I knew him; it was Mr. Lloyd, an apothecary,\r\nsometimes called in by Mrs. Reed when the servants were ailing: for\r\nherself and the children she employed a physician.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, who am I?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\nI pronounced his name, offering him at the same time my hand: he took\r\nit, smiling and saying, \xe2\x80\x9cWe shall do very well by-and-by.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he laid\r\nme down, and addressing Bessie, charged her to be very careful that I\r\nwas not disturbed during the night. Having given some further\r\ndirections, and intimated that he should call again the next day, he\r\ndeparted; to my grief: I felt so sheltered and befriended while he sat\r\nin the chair near my pillow; and as he closed the door after him, all\r\nthe room darkened and my heart again sank: inexpressible sadness\r\nweighed it down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you feel as if you should sleep, Miss?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Bessie, rather\r\nsoftly.\r\n\r\nScarcely dared I answer her; for I feared the next sentence might be\r\nrough. \xe2\x80\x9cI will try.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to drink, or could you eat anything?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, thank you, Bessie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I think I shall go to bed, for it is past twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock; but you\r\nmay call me if you want anything in the night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWonderful civility this! It emboldened me to ask a question.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessie, what is the matter with me? Am I ill?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou fell sick, I suppose, in the red-room with crying; you\xe2\x80\x99ll be\r\nbetter soon, no doubt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie went into the housemaid\xe2\x80\x99s apartment, which was near. I heard her\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSarah, come and sleep with me in the nursery; I daren\xe2\x80\x99t for my life be\r\nalone with that poor child to-night: she might die; it\xe2\x80\x99s such a strange\r\nthing she should have that fit: I wonder if she saw anything. Missis\r\nwas rather too hard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSarah came back with her; they both went to bed; they were whispering\r\ntogether for half-an-hour before they fell asleep. I caught scraps of\r\ntheir conversation, from which I was able only too distinctly to infer\r\nthe main subject discussed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSomething passed her, all dressed in white, and vanished\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA great\r\nblack dog behind him\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cThree loud raps on the chamber door\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cA light in\r\nthe churchyard just over his grave,\xe2\x80\x9d &c., &c.\r\n\r\nAt last both slept: the fire and the candle went out. For me, the\r\nwatches of that long night passed in ghastly wakefulness; ear, eye, and\r\nmind were alike strained by dread: such dread as children only can\r\nfeel.\r\n\r\nNo severe or prolonged bodily illness followed this incident of the\r\nred-room; it only gave my nerves a shock of which I feel the\r\nreverberation to this day. Yes, Mrs. Reed, to you I owe some fearful\r\npangs of mental suffering, but I ought to forgive you, for you knew not\r\nwhat you did: while rending my heart-strings, you thought you were only\r\nuprooting my bad propensities.\r\n\r\nNext day, by noon, I was up and dressed, and sat wrapped in a shawl by\r\nthe nursery hearth. I felt physically weak and broken down: but my\r\nworse ailment was an unutterable wretchedness of mind: a wretchedness\r\nwhich kept drawing from me silent tears; no sooner had I wiped one salt\r\ndrop from my cheek than another followed. Yet, I thought, I ought to\r\nhave been happy, for none of the Reeds were there, they were all gone\r\nout in the carriage with their mama. Abbot, too, was sewing in another\r\nroom, and Bessie, as she moved hither and thither, putting away toys\r\nand arranging drawers, addressed to me every now and then a word of\r\nunwonted kindness. This state of things should have been to me a\r\nparadise of peace, accustomed as I was to a life of ceaseless reprimand\r\nand thankless fagging; but, in fact, my racked nerves were now in such\r\na state that no calm could soothe, and no pleasure excite them\r\nagreeably.\r\n\r\nBessie had been down into the kitchen, and she brought up with her a\r\ntart on a certain brightly painted china plate, whose bird of paradise,\r\nnestling in a wreath of convolvuli and rosebuds, had been wont to stir\r\nin me a most enthusiastic sense of admiration; and which plate I had\r\noften petitioned to be allowed to take in my hand in order to examine\r\nit more closely, but had always hitherto been deemed unworthy of such a\r\nprivilege. This precious vessel was now placed on my knee, and I was\r\ncordially invited to eat the circlet of delicate pastry upon it. Vain\r\nfavour! coming, like most other favours long deferred and often wished\r\nfor, too late! I could not eat the tart; and the plumage of the bird,\r\nthe tints of the flowers, seemed strangely faded: I put both plate and\r\ntart away. Bessie asked if I would have a book: the word _book_ acted\r\nas a transient stimulus, and I begged her to fetch Gulliver\xe2\x80\x99s Travels\r\nfrom the library. This book I had again and again perused with delight.\r\nI considered it a narrative of facts, and discovered in it a vein of\r\ninterest deeper than what I found in fairy tales: for as to the elves,\r\nhaving sought them in vain among foxglove leaves and bells, under\r\nmushrooms and beneath the ground-ivy mantling old wall-nooks, I had at\r\nlength made up my mind to the sad truth, that they were all gone out of\r\nEngland to some savage country where the woods were wilder and thicker,\r\nand the population more scant; whereas, Lilliput and Brobdignag being,\r\nin my creed, solid parts of the earth\xe2\x80\x99s surface, I doubted not that I\r\nmight one day, by taking a long voyage, see with my own eyes the little\r\nfields, houses, and trees, the diminutive people, the tiny cows, sheep,\r\nand birds of the one realm; and the corn-fields forest-high, the mighty\r\nmastiffs, the monster cats, the tower-like men and women, of the other.\r\nYet, when this cherished volume was now placed in my hand\xe2\x80\x94when I turned\r\nover its leaves, and sought in its marvellous pictures the charm I had,\r\ntill now, never failed to find\xe2\x80\x94all was eerie and dreary; the giants\r\nwere gaunt goblins, the pigmies malevolent and fearful imps, Gulliver a\r\nmost desolate wanderer in most dread and dangerous regions. I closed\r\nthe book, which I dared no longer peruse, and put it on the table,\r\nbeside the untasted tart.\r\n\r\nBessie had now finished dusting and tidying the room, and having washed\r\nher hands, she opened a certain little drawer, full of splendid shreds\r\nof silk and satin, and began making a new bonnet for Georgiana\xe2\x80\x99s doll.\r\nMeantime she sang: her song was\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the days when we went gipsying,\r\n    A long time ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nI had often heard the song before, and always with lively delight; for\r\nBessie had a sweet voice,\xe2\x80\x94at least, I thought so. But now, though her\r\nvoice was still sweet, I found in its melody an indescribable sadness.\r\nSometimes, preoccupied with her work, she sang the refrain very low,\r\nvery lingeringly; \xe2\x80\x9cA long time ago\xe2\x80\x9d came out like the saddest cadence\r\nof a funeral hymn. She passed into another ballad, this time a really\r\ndoleful one.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy feet they are sore, and my limbs they are weary;\r\n    Long is the way, and the mountains are wild;\r\nSoon will the twilight close moonless and dreary\r\n    Over the path of the poor orphan child.\r\n\r\nWhy did they send me so far and so lonely,\r\n    Up where the moors spread and grey rocks are piled?\r\nMen are hard-hearted, and kind angels only\r\n    Watch o\xe2\x80\x99er the steps of a poor orphan child.\r\n\r\nYet distant and soft the night breeze is blowing,\r\n    Clouds there are none, and clear stars beam mild,\r\nGod, in His mercy, protection is showing,\r\n    Comfort and hope to the poor orphan child.\r\n\r\nEv\xe2\x80\x99n should I fall o\xe2\x80\x99er the broken bridge passing,\r\n    Or stray in the marshes, by false lights beguiled,\r\nStill will my Father, with promise and blessing,\r\n    Take to His bosom the poor orphan child.\r\n\r\nThere is a thought that for strength should avail me,\r\n    Though both of shelter and kindred despoiled;\r\nHeaven is a home, and a rest will not fail me;\r\n    God is a friend to the poor orphan child.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Miss Jane, don\xe2\x80\x99t cry,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie as she finished. She might as\r\nwell have said to the fire, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t burn!\xe2\x80\x9d but how could she divine the\r\nmorbid suffering to which I was a prey? In the course of the morning\r\nMr. Lloyd came again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, already up!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he entered the nursery. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, nurse,\r\nhow is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie answered that I was doing very well.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen she ought to look more cheerful. Come here, Miss Jane: your name\r\nis Jane, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, Jane Eyre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you have been crying, Miss Jane Eyre; can you tell me what\r\nabout? Have you any pain?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I daresay she is crying because she could not go out with Missis\r\nin the carriage,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Bessie.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely not! why, she is too old for such pettishness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought so too; and my self-esteem being wounded by the false charge,\r\nI answered promptly, \xe2\x80\x9cI never cried for such a thing in my life: I hate\r\ngoing out in the carriage. I cry because I am miserable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh fie, Miss!\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie.\r\n\r\nThe good apothecary appeared a little puzzled. I was standing before\r\nhim; he fixed his eyes on me very steadily: his eyes were small and\r\ngrey; not very bright, but I dare say I should think them shrewd now:\r\nhe had a hard-featured yet good-natured looking face. Having considered\r\nme at leisure, he said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat made you ill yesterday?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had a fall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie, again putting in her word.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFall! why, that is like a baby again! Can\xe2\x80\x99t she manage to walk at her\r\nage? She must be eight or nine years old.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was knocked down,\xe2\x80\x9d was the blunt explanation, jerked out of me by\r\nanother pang of mortified pride; \xe2\x80\x9cbut that did not make me ill,\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nadded; while Mr. Lloyd helped himself to a pinch of snuff.\r\n\r\nAs he was returning the box to his waistcoat pocket, a loud bell rang\r\nfor the servants\xe2\x80\x99 dinner; he knew what it was. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s for you, nurse,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid he; \xe2\x80\x9cyou can go down; I\xe2\x80\x99ll give Miss Jane a lecture till you come\r\nback.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie would rather have stayed, but she was obliged to go, because\r\npunctuality at meals was rigidly enforced at Gateshead Hall.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fall did not make you ill; what did, then?\xe2\x80\x9d pursued Mr. Lloyd when\r\nBessie was gone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was shut up in a room where there is a ghost till after dark.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI saw Mr. Lloyd smile and frown at the same time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGhost! What, you are a baby after all! You are afraid of ghosts?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf Mr. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s ghost I am: he died in that room, and was laid out\r\nthere. Neither Bessie nor any one else will go into it at night, if\r\nthey can help it; and it was cruel to shut me up alone without a\r\ncandle,\xe2\x80\x94so cruel that I think I shall never forget it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! And is it that makes you so miserable? Are you afraid now in\r\ndaylight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo: but night will come again before long: and besides,\xe2\x80\x94I am\r\nunhappy,\xe2\x80\x94very unhappy, for other things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat other things? Can you tell me some of them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHow much I wished to reply fully to this question! How difficult it was\r\nto frame any answer! Children can feel, but they cannot analyse their\r\nfeelings; and if the analysis is partially effected in thought, they\r\nknow not how to express the result of the process in words. Fearful,\r\nhowever, of losing this first and only opportunity of relieving my\r\ngrief by imparting it, I, after a disturbed pause, contrived to frame a\r\nmeagre, though, as far as it went, true response.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor one thing, I have no father or mother, brothers or sisters.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a kind aunt and cousins.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain I paused; then bunglingly enounced\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut John Reed knocked me down, and my aunt shut me up in the\r\nred-room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Lloyd a second time produced his snuff-box.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you think Gateshead Hall a very beautiful house?\xe2\x80\x9d asked he. \xe2\x80\x9cAre\r\nyou not very thankful to have such a fine place to live at?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not my house, sir; and Abbot says I have less right to be here\r\nthan a servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! you can\xe2\x80\x99t be silly enough to wish to leave such a splendid\r\nplace?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I had anywhere else to go, I should be glad to leave it; but I can\r\nnever get away from Gateshead till I am a woman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you may\xe2\x80\x94who knows? Have you any relations besides Mrs. Reed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think not, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNone belonging to your father?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know: I asked Aunt Reed once, and she said possibly I might\r\nhave some poor, low relations called Eyre, but she knew nothing about\r\nthem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you had such, would you like to go to them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI reflected. Poverty looks grim to grown people; still more so to\r\nchildren: they have not much idea of industrious, working, respectable\r\npoverty; they think of the word only as connected with ragged clothes,\r\nscanty food, fireless grates, rude manners, and debasing vices: poverty\r\nfor me was synonymous with degradation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I should not like to belong to poor people,\xe2\x80\x9d was my reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot even if they were kind to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI shook my head: I could not see how poor people had the means of being\r\nkind; and then to learn to speak like them, to adopt their manners, to\r\nbe uneducated, to grow up like one of the poor women I saw sometimes\r\nnursing their children or washing their clothes at the cottage doors of\r\nthe village of Gateshead: no, I was not heroic enough to purchase\r\nliberty at the price of caste.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut are your relatives so very poor? Are they working people?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell; Aunt Reed says if I have any, they must be a beggarly\r\nset: I should not like to go a begging.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould you like to go to school?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain I reflected: I scarcely knew what school was: Bessie sometimes\r\nspoke of it as a place where young ladies sat in the stocks, wore\r\nbackboards, and were expected to be exceedingly genteel and precise:\r\nJohn Reed hated his school, and abused his master; but John Reed\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntastes were no rule for mine, and if Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s accounts of\r\nschool-discipline (gathered from the young ladies of a family where she\r\nhad lived before coming to Gateshead) were somewhat appalling, her\r\ndetails of certain accomplishments attained by these same young ladies\r\nwere, I thought, equally attractive. She boasted of beautiful paintings\r\nof landscapes and flowers by them executed; of songs they could sing\r\nand pieces they could play, of purses they could net, of French books\r\nthey could translate; till my spirit was moved to emulation as I\r\nlistened. Besides, school would be a complete change: it implied a long\r\njourney, an entire separation from Gateshead, an entrance into a new\r\nlife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should indeed like to go to school,\xe2\x80\x9d was the audible conclusion of\r\nmy musings.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, well! who knows what may happen?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Lloyd, as he got up.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child ought to have change of air and scene,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, speaking\r\nto himself; \xe2\x80\x9cnerves not in a good state.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie now returned; at the same moment the carriage was heard rolling\r\nup the gravel-walk.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that your mistress, nurse?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mr. Lloyd. \xe2\x80\x9cI should like to\r\nspeak to her before I go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie invited him to walk into the breakfast-room, and led the way\r\nout. In the interview which followed between him and Mrs. Reed, I\r\npresume, from after-occurrences, that the apothecary ventured to\r\nrecommend my being sent to school; and the recommendation was no doubt\r\nreadily enough adopted; for as Abbot said, in discussing the subject\r\nwith Bessie when both sat sewing in the nursery one night, after I was\r\nin bed, and, as they thought, asleep, \xe2\x80\x9cMissis was, she dared say, glad\r\nenough to get rid of such a tiresome, ill-conditioned child, who always\r\nlooked as if she were watching everybody, and scheming plots\r\nunderhand.\xe2\x80\x9d Abbot, I think, gave me credit for being a sort of\r\ninfantine Guy Fawkes.\r\n\r\nOn that same occasion I learned, for the first time, from Miss Abbot\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncommunications to Bessie, that my father had been a poor clergyman;\r\nthat my mother had married him against the wishes of her friends, who\r\nconsidered the match beneath her; that my grandfather Reed was so\r\nirritated at her disobedience, he cut her off without a shilling; that\r\nafter my mother and father had been married a year, the latter caught\r\nthe typhus fever while visiting among the poor of a large manufacturing\r\ntown where his curacy was situated, and where that disease was then\r\nprevalent: that my mother took the infection from him, and both died\r\nwithin a month of each other.\r\n\r\nBessie, when she heard this narrative, sighed and said, \xe2\x80\x9cPoor Miss Jane\r\nis to be pitied, too, Abbot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Abbot; \xe2\x80\x9cif she were a nice, pretty child, one might\r\ncompassionate her forlornness; but one really cannot care for such a\r\nlittle toad as that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a great deal, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d agreed Bessie: \xe2\x80\x9cat any rate, a beauty\r\nlike Miss Georgiana would be more moving in the same condition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I doat on Miss Georgiana!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the fervent Abbot. \xe2\x80\x9cLittle\r\ndarling!\xe2\x80\x94with her long curls and her blue eyes, and such a sweet colour\r\nas she has; just as if she were painted!\xe2\x80\x94Bessie, I could fancy a Welsh\r\nrabbit for supper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo could I\xe2\x80\x94with a roast onion. Come, we\xe2\x80\x99ll go down.\xe2\x80\x9d They went.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER IV\r\n\r\n\r\nFrom my discourse with Mr. Lloyd, and from the above reported\r\nconference between Bessie and Abbot, I gathered enough of hope to\r\nsuffice as a motive for wishing to get well: a change seemed near,\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ndesired and waited it in silence. It tarried, however: days and weeks\r\npassed: I had regained my normal state of health, but no new allusion\r\nwas made to the subject over which I brooded. Mrs. Reed surveyed me at\r\ntimes with a severe eye, but seldom addressed me: since my illness, she\r\nhad drawn a more marked line of separation than ever between me and her\r\nown children; appointing me a small closet to sleep in by myself,\r\ncondemning me to take my meals alone, and pass all my time in the\r\nnursery, while my cousins were constantly in the drawing-room. Not a\r\nhint, however, did she drop about sending me to school: still I felt an\r\ninstinctive certainty that she would not long endure me under the same\r\nroof with her; for her glance, now more than ever, when turned on me,\r\nexpressed an insuperable and rooted aversion.\r\n\r\nEliza and Georgiana, evidently acting according to orders, spoke to me\r\nas little as possible: John thrust his tongue in his cheek whenever he\r\nsaw me, and once attempted chastisement; but as I instantly turned\r\nagainst him, roused by the same sentiment of deep ire and desperate\r\nrevolt which had stirred my corruption before, he thought it better to\r\ndesist, and ran from me uttering execrations, and vowing I had burst\r\nhis nose. I had indeed levelled at that prominent feature as hard a\r\nblow as my knuckles could inflict; and when I saw that either that or\r\nmy look daunted him, I had the greatest inclination to follow up my\r\nadvantage to purpose; but he was already with his mama. I heard him in\r\na blubbering tone commence the tale of how \xe2\x80\x9cthat nasty Jane Eyre\xe2\x80\x9d had\r\nflown at him like a mad cat: he was stopped rather harshly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk to me about her, John: I told you not to go near her; she\r\nis not worthy of notice; I do not choose that either you or your\r\nsisters should associate with her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere, leaning over the banister, I cried out suddenly, and without at\r\nall deliberating on my words\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are not fit to associate with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed was rather a stout woman; but, on hearing this strange and\r\naudacious declaration, she ran nimbly up the stair, swept me like a\r\nwhirlwind into the nursery, and crushing me down on the edge of my\r\ncrib, dared me in an emphatic voice to rise from that place, or utter\r\none syllable during the remainder of the day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat would Uncle Reed say to you, if he were alive?\xe2\x80\x9d was my scarcely\r\nvoluntary demand. I say scarcely voluntary, for it seemed as if my\r\ntongue pronounced words without my will consenting to their utterance:\r\nsomething spoke out of me over which I had no control.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Reed under her breath: her usually cold composed grey\r\neye became troubled with a look like fear; she took her hand from my\r\narm, and gazed at me as if she really did not know whether I were child\r\nor fiend. I was now in for it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy Uncle Reed is in heaven, and can see all you do and think; and so\r\ncan papa and mama: they know how you shut me up all day long, and how\r\nyou wish me dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed soon rallied her spirits: she shook me most soundly, she\r\nboxed both my ears, and then left me without a word. Bessie supplied\r\nthe hiatus by a homily of an hour\xe2\x80\x99s length, in which she proved beyond\r\na doubt that I was the most wicked and abandoned child ever reared\r\nunder a roof. I half believed her; for I felt indeed only bad feelings\r\nsurging in my breast.\r\n\r\nNovember, December, and half of January passed away. Christmas and the\r\nNew Year had been celebrated at Gateshead with the usual festive cheer;\r\npresents had been interchanged, dinners and evening parties given. From\r\nevery enjoyment I was, of course, excluded: my share of the gaiety\r\nconsisted in witnessing the daily apparelling of Eliza and Georgiana,\r\nand seeing them descend to the drawing-room, dressed out in thin muslin\r\nfrocks and scarlet sashes, with hair elaborately ringletted; and\r\nafterwards, in listening to the sound of the piano or the harp played\r\nbelow, to the passing to and fro of the butler and footman, to the\r\njingling of glass and china as refreshments were handed, to the broken\r\nhum of conversation as the drawing-room door opened and closed. When\r\ntired of this occupation, I would retire from the stairhead to the\r\nsolitary and silent nursery: there, though somewhat sad, I was not\r\nmiserable. To speak truth, I had not the least wish to go into company,\r\nfor in company I was very rarely noticed; and if Bessie had but been\r\nkind and companionable, I should have deemed it a treat to spend the\r\nevenings quietly with her, instead of passing them under the formidable\r\neye of Mrs. Reed, in a room full of ladies and gentlemen. But Bessie,\r\nas soon as she had dressed her young ladies, used to take herself off\r\nto the lively regions of the kitchen and housekeeper\xe2\x80\x99s room, generally\r\nbearing the candle along with her. I then sat with my doll on my knee\r\ntill the fire got low, glancing round occasionally to make sure that\r\nnothing worse than myself haunted the shadowy room; and when the embers\r\nsank to a dull red, I undressed hastily, tugging at knots and strings\r\nas I best might, and sought shelter from cold and darkness in my crib.\r\nTo this crib I always took my doll; human beings must love something,\r\nand, in the dearth of worthier objects of affection, I contrived to\r\nfind a pleasure in loving and cherishing a faded graven image, shabby\r\nas a miniature scarecrow. It puzzles me now to remember with what\r\nabsurd sincerity I doated on this little toy, half fancying it alive\r\nand capable of sensation. I could not sleep unless it was folded in my\r\nnight-gown; and when it lay there safe and warm, I was comparatively\r\nhappy, believing it to be happy likewise.\r\n\r\nLong did the hours seem while I waited the departure of the company,\r\nand listened for the sound of Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s step on the stairs: sometimes\r\nshe would come up in the interval to seek her thimble or her scissors,\r\nor perhaps to bring me something by way of supper\xe2\x80\x94a bun or a\r\ncheese-cake\xe2\x80\x94then she would sit on the bed while I ate it, and when I\r\nhad finished, she would tuck the clothes round me, and twice she kissed\r\nme, and said, \xe2\x80\x9cGood night, Miss Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d When thus gentle, Bessie seemed\r\nto me the best, prettiest, kindest being in the world; and I wished\r\nmost intensely that she would always be so pleasant and amiable, and\r\nnever push me about, or scold, or task me unreasonably, as she was too\r\noften wont to do. Bessie Lee must, I think, have been a girl of good\r\nnatural capacity, for she was smart in all she did, and had a\r\nremarkable knack of narrative; so, at least, I judge from the\r\nimpression made on me by her nursery tales. She was pretty too, if my\r\nrecollections of her face and person are correct. I remember her as a\r\nslim young woman, with black hair, dark eyes, very nice features, and\r\ngood, clear complexion; but she had a capricious and hasty temper, and\r\nindifferent ideas of principle or justice: still, such as she was, I\r\npreferred her to any one else at Gateshead Hall.\r\n\r\nIt was the fifteenth of January, about nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the morning:\r\nBessie was gone down to breakfast; my cousins had not yet been summoned\r\nto their mama; Eliza was putting on her bonnet and warm garden-coat to\r\ngo and feed her poultry, an occupation of which she was fond: and not\r\nless so of selling the eggs to the housekeeper and hoarding up the\r\nmoney she thus obtained. She had a turn for traffic, and a marked\r\npropensity for saving; shown not only in the vending of eggs and\r\nchickens, but also in driving hard bargains with the gardener about\r\nflower-roots, seeds, and slips of plants; that functionary having\r\norders from Mrs. Reed to buy of his young lady all the products of her\r\nparterre she wished to sell: and Eliza would have sold the hair off her\r\nhead if she could have made a handsome profit thereby. As to her money,\r\nshe first secreted it in odd corners, wrapped in a rag or an old\r\ncurl-paper; but some of these hoards having been discovered by the\r\nhousemaid, Eliza, fearful of one day losing her valued treasure,\r\nconsented to intrust it to her mother, at a usurious rate of\r\ninterest\xe2\x80\x94fifty or sixty per cent.; which interest she exacted every\r\nquarter, keeping her accounts in a little book with anxious accuracy.\r\n\r\nGeorgiana sat on a high stool, dressing her hair at the glass, and\r\ninterweaving her curls with artificial flowers and faded feathers, of\r\nwhich she had found a store in a drawer in the attic. I was making my\r\nbed, having received strict orders from Bessie to get it arranged\r\nbefore she returned (for Bessie now frequently employed me as a sort of\r\nunder-nurserymaid, to tidy the room, dust the chairs, &c.). Having\r\nspread the quilt and folded my night-dress, I went to the window-seat\r\nto put in order some picture-books and doll\xe2\x80\x99s house furniture scattered\r\nthere; an abrupt command from Georgiana to let her playthings alone\r\n(for the tiny chairs and mirrors, the fairy plates and cups, were her\r\nproperty) stopped my proceedings; and then, for lack of other\r\noccupation, I fell to breathing on the frost-flowers with which the\r\nwindow was fretted, and thus clearing a space in the glass through\r\nwhich I might look out on the grounds, where all was still and\r\npetrified under the influence of a hard frost.\r\n\r\nFrom this window were visible the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge and the carriage-road,\r\nand just as I had dissolved so much of the silver-white foliage veiling\r\nthe panes as left room to look out, I saw the gates thrown open and a\r\ncarriage roll through. I watched it ascending the drive with\r\nindifference; carriages often came to Gateshead, but none ever brought\r\nvisitors in whom I was interested; it stopped in front of the house,\r\nthe door-bell rang loudly, the new-comer was admitted. All this being\r\nnothing to me, my vacant attention soon found livelier attraction in\r\nthe spectacle of a little hungry robin, which came and chirruped on the\r\ntwigs of the leafless cherry-tree nailed against the wall near the\r\ncasement. The remains of my breakfast of bread and milk stood on the\r\ntable, and having crumbled a morsel of roll, I was tugging at the sash\r\nto put out the crumbs on the window-sill, when Bessie came running\r\nupstairs into the nursery.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Jane, take off your pinafore; what are you doing there? Have you\r\nwashed your hands and face this morning?\xe2\x80\x9d I gave another tug before I\r\nanswered, for I wanted the bird to be secure of its bread: the sash\r\nyielded; I scattered the crumbs, some on the stone sill, some on the\r\ncherry-tree bough, then, closing the window, I replied\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Bessie; I have only just finished dusting.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTroublesome, careless child! and what are you doing now? You look\r\nquite red, as if you had been about some mischief: what were you\r\nopening the window for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was spared the trouble of answering, for Bessie seemed in too great a\r\nhurry to listen to explanations; she hauled me to the washstand,\r\ninflicted a merciless, but happily brief scrub on my face and hands\r\nwith soap, water, and a coarse towel; disciplined my head with a\r\nbristly brush, denuded me of my pinafore, and then hurrying me to the\r\ntop of the stairs, bid me go down directly, as I was wanted in the\r\nbreakfast-room.\r\n\r\nI would have asked who wanted me: I would have demanded if Mrs. Reed\r\nwas there; but Bessie was already gone, and had closed the nursery-door\r\nupon me. I slowly descended. For nearly three months, I had never been\r\ncalled to Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s presence; restricted so long to the nursery, the\r\nbreakfast, dining, and drawing-rooms were become for me awful regions,\r\non which it dismayed me to intrude.\r\n\r\nI now stood in the empty hall; before me was the breakfast-room door,\r\nand I stopped, intimidated and trembling. What a miserable little\r\npoltroon had fear, engendered of unjust punishment, made of me in those\r\ndays! I feared to return to the nursery, and feared to go forward to\r\nthe parlour; ten minutes I stood in agitated hesitation; the vehement\r\nringing of the breakfast-room bell decided me; I _must_ enter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho could want me?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked inwardly, as with both hands I turned the\r\nstiff door-handle, which, for a second or two, resisted my efforts.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat should I see besides Aunt Reed in the apartment?\xe2\x80\x94a man or a\r\nwoman?\xe2\x80\x9d The handle turned, the door unclosed, and passing through and\r\ncurtseying low, I looked up at\xe2\x80\x94a black pillar!\xe2\x80\x94such, at least, appeared\r\nto me, at first sight, the straight, narrow, sable-clad shape standing\r\nerect on the rug: the grim face at the top was like a carved mask,\r\nplaced above the shaft by way of capital.\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed occupied her usual seat by the fireside; she made a signal to\r\nme to approach; I did so, and she introduced me to the stony stranger\r\nwith the words: \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the little girl respecting whom I applied to\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n_He_, for it was a man, turned his head slowly towards where I stood,\r\nand having examined me with the two inquisitive-looking grey eyes which\r\ntwinkled under a pair of bushy brows, said solemnly, and in a bass\r\nvoice, \xe2\x80\x9cHer size is small: what is her age?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTen years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSo much?\xe2\x80\x9d was the doubtful answer; and he prolonged his scrutiny for\r\nsome minutes. Presently he addressed me\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYour name, little girl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane Eyre, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn uttering these words I looked up: he seemed to me a tall gentleman;\r\nbut then I was very little; his features were large, and they and all\r\nthe lines of his frame were equally harsh and prim.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Jane Eyre, and are you a good child?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nImpossible to reply to this in the affirmative: my little world held a\r\ncontrary opinion: I was silent. Mrs. Reed answered for me by an\r\nexpressive shake of the head, adding soon, \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps the less said on\r\nthat subject the better, Mr. Brocklehurst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSorry indeed to hear it! she and I must have some talk;\xe2\x80\x9d and bending\r\nfrom the perpendicular, he installed his person in the arm-chair\r\nopposite Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s. \xe2\x80\x9cCome here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nI stepped across the rug; he placed me square and straight before him.\r\nWhat a face he had, now that it was almost on a level with mine! what a\r\ngreat nose! and what a mouth! and what large prominent teeth!\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo sight so sad as that of a naughty child,\xe2\x80\x9d he began, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially a\r\nnaughty little girl. Do you know where the wicked go after death?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey go to hell,\xe2\x80\x9d was my ready and orthodox answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is hell? Can you tell me that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA pit full of fire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd should you like to fall into that pit, and to be burning there for\r\never?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat must you do to avoid it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI deliberated a moment; my answer, when it did come, was objectionable:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must keep in good health, and not die.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can you keep in good health? Children younger than you die daily.\r\nI buried a little child of five years old only a day or two since,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngood little child, whose soul is now in heaven. It is to be feared the\r\nsame could not be said of you were you to be called hence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNot being in a condition to remove his doubt, I only cast my eyes down\r\non the two large feet planted on the rug, and sighed, wishing myself\r\nfar enough away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope that sigh is from the heart, and that you repent of ever having\r\nbeen the occasion of discomfort to your excellent benefactress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBenefactress! benefactress!\xe2\x80\x9d said I inwardly: \xe2\x80\x9cthey all call Mrs. Reed\r\nmy benefactress; if so, a benefactress is a disagreeable thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you say your prayers night and morning?\xe2\x80\x9d continued my interrogator.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you read your Bible?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith pleasure? Are you fond of it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like Revelations, and the book of Daniel, and Genesis and Samuel,\r\nand a little bit of Exodus, and some parts of Kings and Chronicles, and\r\nJob and Jonah.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the Psalms? I hope you like them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo? oh, shocking! I have a little boy, younger than you, who knows six\r\nPsalms by heart: and when you ask him which he would rather have, a\r\ngingerbread-nut to eat or a verse of a Psalm to learn, he says: \xe2\x80\x98Oh!\r\nthe verse of a Psalm! angels sing Psalms;\xe2\x80\x99 says he, \xe2\x80\x98I wish to be a\r\nlittle angel here below;\xe2\x80\x99 he then gets two nuts in recompense for his\r\ninfant piety.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPsalms are not interesting,\xe2\x80\x9d I remarked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat proves you have a wicked heart; and you must pray to God to\r\nchange it: to give you a new and clean one: to take away your heart of\r\nstone and give you a heart of flesh.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was about to propound a question, touching the manner in which that\r\noperation of changing my heart was to be performed, when Mrs. Reed\r\ninterposed, telling me to sit down; she then proceeded to carry on the\r\nconversation herself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Brocklehurst, I believe I intimated in the letter which I wrote to\r\nyou three weeks ago, that this little girl has not quite the character\r\nand disposition I could wish: should you admit her into Lowood school,\r\nI should be glad if the superintendent and teachers were requested to\r\nkeep a strict eye on her, and, above all, to guard against her worst\r\nfault, a tendency to deceit. I mention this in your hearing, Jane, that\r\nyou may not attempt to impose on Mr. Brocklehurst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWell might I dread, well might I dislike Mrs. Reed; for it was her\r\nnature to wound me cruelly; never was I happy in her presence; however\r\ncarefully I obeyed, however strenuously I strove to please her, my\r\nefforts were still repulsed and repaid by such sentences as the above.\r\nNow, uttered before a stranger, the accusation cut me to the heart; I\r\ndimly perceived that she was already obliterating hope from the new\r\nphase of existence which she destined me to enter; I felt, though I\r\ncould not have expressed the feeling, that she was sowing aversion and\r\nunkindness along my future path; I saw myself transformed under Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst\xe2\x80\x99s eye into an artful, noxious child, and what could I do\r\nto remedy the injury?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing, indeed,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, as I struggled to repress a sob, and\r\nhastily wiped away some tears, the impotent evidences of my anguish.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeceit is, indeed, a sad fault in a child,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Brocklehurst; \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nis akin to falsehood, and all liars will have their portion in the lake\r\nburning with fire and brimstone; she shall, however, be watched, Mrs.\r\nReed. I will speak to Miss Temple and the teachers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should wish her to be brought up in a manner suiting her prospects,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncontinued my benefactress; \xe2\x80\x9cto be made useful, to be kept humble: as\r\nfor the vacations, she will, with your permission, spend them always at\r\nLowood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour decisions are perfectly judicious, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst. \xe2\x80\x9cHumility is a Christian grace, and one peculiarly\r\nappropriate to the pupils of Lowood; I, therefore, direct that especial\r\ncare shall be bestowed on its cultivation amongst them. I have studied\r\nhow best to mortify in them the worldly sentiment of pride; and, only\r\nthe other day, I had a pleasing proof of my success. My second\r\ndaughter, Augusta, went with her mama to visit the school, and on her\r\nreturn she exclaimed: \xe2\x80\x98Oh, dear papa, how quiet and plain all the girls\r\nat Lowood look, with their hair combed behind their ears, and their\r\nlong pinafores, and those little holland pockets outside their\r\nfrocks\xe2\x80\x94they are almost like poor people\xe2\x80\x99s children! and,\xe2\x80\x99 said she,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98they looked at my dress and mama\xe2\x80\x99s, as if they had never seen a silk\r\ngown before.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is the state of things I quite approve,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mrs. Reed; \xe2\x80\x9chad\r\nI sought all England over, I could scarcely have found a system more\r\nexactly fitting a child like Jane Eyre. Consistency, my dear Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst; I advocate consistency in all things.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cConsistency, madam, is the first of Christian duties; and it has been\r\nobserved in every arrangement connected with the establishment of\r\nLowood: plain fare, simple attire, unsophisticated accommodations,\r\nhardy and active habits; such is the order of the day in the house and\r\nits inhabitants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite right, sir. I may then depend upon this child being received as\r\na pupil at Lowood, and there being trained in conformity to her\r\nposition and prospects?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam, you may: she shall be placed in that nursery of chosen plants,\r\nand I trust she will show herself grateful for the inestimable\r\nprivilege of her election.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will send her, then, as soon as possible, Mr. Brocklehurst; for, I\r\nassure you, I feel anxious to be relieved of a responsibility that was\r\nbecoming too irksome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt, no doubt, madam; and now I wish you good morning.
