I shall\r\nreturn to Brocklehurst Hall in the course of a week or two: my good\r\nfriend, the Archdeacon, will not permit me to leave him sooner. I shall\r\nsend Miss Temple notice that she is to expect a new girl, so that there\r\nwill be no difficulty about receiving her. Good-bye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, Mr. Brocklehurst; remember me to Mrs. and Miss Brocklehurst,\r\nand to Augusta and Theodore, and Master Broughton Brocklehurst.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will, madam. Little girl, here is a book entitled the \xe2\x80\x98Child\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nGuide\xe2\x80\x99; read it with prayer, especially that part containing \xe2\x80\x98An\r\naccount of the awfully sudden death of Martha G\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, a naughty child\r\naddicted to falsehood and deceit.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWith these words Mr. Brocklehurst put into my hand a thin pamphlet sewn\r\nin a cover, and having rung for his carriage, he departed.\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed and I were left alone: some minutes passed in silence; she\r\nwas sewing, I was watching her. Mrs. Reed might be at that time some\r\nsix or seven and thirty; she was a woman of robust frame,\r\nsquare-shouldered and strong-limbed, not tall, and, though stout, not\r\nobese: she had a somewhat large face, the under jaw being much\r\ndeveloped and very solid; her brow was low, her chin large and\r\nprominent, mouth and nose sufficiently regular; under her light\r\neyebrows glimmered an eye devoid of ruth; her skin was dark and opaque,\r\nher hair nearly flaxen; her constitution was sound as a bell\xe2\x80\x94illness\r\nnever came near her; she was an exact, clever manager; her household\r\nand tenantry were thoroughly under her control; her children only at\r\ntimes defied her authority and laughed it to scorn; she dressed well,\r\nand had a presence and port calculated to set off handsome attire.\r\n\r\nSitting on a low stool, a few yards from her arm-chair, I examined her\r\nfigure; I perused her features. In my hand I held the tract containing\r\nthe sudden death of the Liar, to which narrative my attention had been\r\npointed as to an appropriate warning. What had just passed; what Mrs.\r\nReed had said concerning me to Mr. Brocklehurst; the whole tenor of\r\ntheir conversation, was recent, raw, and stinging in my mind; I had\r\nfelt every word as acutely as I had heard it plainly, and a passion of\r\nresentment fomented now within me.\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed looked up from her work; her eye settled on mine, her fingers\r\nat the same time suspended their nimble movements.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo out of the room; return to the nursery,\xe2\x80\x9d was her mandate. My look\r\nor something else must have struck her as offensive, for she spoke with\r\nextreme though suppressed irritation. I got up, I went to the door; I\r\ncame back again; I walked to the window, across the room, then close up\r\nto her.\r\n\r\n_Speak_ I must: I had been trodden on severely, and _must_ turn: but\r\nhow? What strength had I to dart retaliation at my antagonist? I\r\ngathered my energies and launched them in this blunt sentence\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not deceitful: if I were, I should say I loved _you;_ but I\r\ndeclare I do not love you: I dislike you the worst of anybody in the\r\nworld except John Reed; and this book about the liar, you may give to\r\nyour girl, Georgiana, for it is she who tells lies, and not I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s hands still lay on her work inactive: her eye of ice\r\ncontinued to dwell freezingly on mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat more have you to say?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, rather in the tone in which a\r\nperson might address an opponent of adult age than such as is\r\nordinarily used to a child.\r\n\r\nThat eye of hers, that voice stirred every antipathy I had. Shaking\r\nfrom head to foot, thrilled with ungovernable excitement, I continued\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am glad you are no relation of mine: I will never call you aunt\r\nagain as long as I live. I will never come to see you when I am grown\r\nup; and if any one asks me how I liked you, and how you treated me, I\r\nwill say the very thought of you makes me sick, and that you treated me\r\nwith miserable cruelty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dare you affirm that, Jane Eyre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow dare I, Mrs. Reed? How dare I? Because it is the _truth_. You\r\nthink I have no feelings, and that I can do without one bit of love or\r\nkindness; but I cannot live so: and you have no pity. I shall remember\r\nhow you thrust me back\xe2\x80\x94roughly and violently thrust me back\xe2\x80\x94into the\r\nred-room, and locked me up there, to my dying day; though I was in\r\nagony; though I cried out, while suffocating with distress, \xe2\x80\x98Have\r\nmercy! Have mercy, Aunt Reed!\xe2\x80\x99 And that punishment you made me suffer\r\nbecause your wicked boy struck me\xe2\x80\x94knocked me down for nothing. I will\r\ntell anybody who asks me questions, this exact tale. People think you a\r\ngood woman, but you are bad, hard-hearted. _You_ are deceitful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nHow dare I, Mrs. Reed? How dare I? Because it is the truth\r\n\r\nEre I had finished this reply, my soul began to expand, to exult, with\r\nthe strangest sense of freedom, of triumph, I ever felt. It seemed as\r\nif an invisible bond had burst, and that I had struggled out into\r\nunhoped-for liberty. Not without cause was this sentiment: Mrs. Reed\r\nlooked frightened; her work had slipped from her knee; she was lifting\r\nup her hands, rocking herself to and fro, and even twisting her face as\r\nif she would cry.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, you are under a mistake: what is the matter with you? Why do you\r\ntremble so violently? Would you like to drink some water?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Mrs. Reed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there anything else you wish for, Jane? I assure you, I desire to\r\nbe your friend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot you. You told Mr. Brocklehurst I had a bad character, a deceitful\r\ndisposition; and I\xe2\x80\x99ll let everybody at Lowood know what you are, and\r\nwhat you have done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, you don\xe2\x80\x99t understand these things: children must be corrected\r\nfor their faults.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDeceit is not my fault!\xe2\x80\x9d I cried out in a savage, high voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you are passionate, Jane, that you must allow: and now return to\r\nthe nursery\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s a dear\xe2\x80\x94and lie down a little.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not your dear; I cannot lie down: send me to school soon, Mrs.\r\nReed, for I hate to live here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will indeed send her to school soon,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mrs. Reed _sotto\r\nvoce_; and gathering up her work, she abruptly quitted the apartment.\r\n\r\nI was left there alone\xe2\x80\x94winner of the field. It was the hardest battle I\r\nhad fought, and the first victory I had gained: I stood awhile on the\r\nrug, where Mr. Brocklehurst had stood, and I enjoyed my conqueror\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsolitude. First, I smiled to myself and felt elate; but this fierce\r\npleasure subsided in me as fast as did the accelerated throb of my\r\npulses. A child cannot quarrel with its elders, as I had done; cannot\r\ngive its furious feelings uncontrolled play, as I had given mine,\r\nwithout experiencing afterwards the pang of remorse and the chill of\r\nreaction. A ridge of lighted heath, alive, glancing, devouring, would\r\nhave been a meet emblem of my mind when I accused and menaced Mrs.\r\nReed: the same ridge, black and blasted after the flames are dead,\r\nwould have represented as meetly my subsequent condition, when\r\nhalf-an-hour\xe2\x80\x99s silence and reflection had shown me the madness of my\r\nconduct, and the dreariness of my hated and hating position.\r\n\r\nSomething of vengeance I had tasted for the first time; as aromatic\r\nwine it seemed, on swallowing, warm and racy: its after-flavour,\r\nmetallic and corroding, gave me a sensation as if I had been poisoned.\r\nWillingly would I now have gone and asked Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s pardon; but I\r\nknew, partly from experience and partly from instinct, that was the way\r\nto make her repulse me with double scorn, thereby re-exciting every\r\nturbulent impulse of my nature.\r\n\r\nI would fain exercise some better faculty than that of fierce speaking;\r\nfain find nourishment for some less fiendish feeling than that of\r\nsombre indignation. I took a book\xe2\x80\x94some Arabian tales; I sat down and\r\nendeavoured to read. I could make no sense of the subject; my own\r\nthoughts swam always between me and the page I had usually found\r\nfascinating. I opened the glass-door in the breakfast-room: the\r\nshrubbery was quite still: the black frost reigned, unbroken by sun or\r\nbreeze, through the grounds. I covered my head and arms with the skirt\r\nof my frock, and went out to walk in a part of the plantation which was\r\nquite sequestrated; but I found no pleasure in the silent trees, the\r\nfalling fir-cones, the congealed relics of autumn, russet leaves, swept\r\nby past winds in heaps, and now stiffened together. I leaned against a\r\ngate, and looked into an empty field where no sheep were feeding, where\r\nthe short grass was nipped and blanched. It was a very grey day; a most\r\nopaque sky, \xe2\x80\x9conding on snaw,\xe2\x80\x9d canopied all; thence flakes fell at\r\nintervals, which settled on the hard path and on the hoary lea without\r\nmelting. I stood, a wretched child enough, whispering to myself over\r\nand over again, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat shall I do?\xe2\x80\x94what shall I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll at once I heard a clear voice call, \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Jane! where are you? Come\r\nto lunch!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was Bessie, I knew well enough; but I did not stir; her light step\r\ncame tripping down the path.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou naughty little thing!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you come when you are\r\ncalled?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie\xe2\x80\x99s presence, compared with the thoughts over which I had been\r\nbrooding, seemed cheerful; even though, as usual, she was somewhat\r\ncross. The fact is, after my conflict with and victory over Mrs. Reed,\r\nI was not disposed to care much for the nursemaid\xe2\x80\x99s transitory anger;\r\nand I _was_ disposed to bask in her youthful lightness of heart. I just\r\nput my two arms round her and said, \xe2\x80\x9cCome, Bessie! don\xe2\x80\x99t scold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe action was more frank and fearless than any I was habituated to\r\nindulge in: somehow it pleased her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a strange child, Miss Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, as she looked down at\r\nme; \xe2\x80\x9ca little roving, solitary thing: and you are going to school, I\r\nsuppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd won\xe2\x80\x99t you be sorry to leave poor Bessie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does Bessie care for me? She is always scolding me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you\xe2\x80\x99re such a queer, frightened, shy little thing. You should\r\nbe bolder.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! to get more knocks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! But you are rather put upon, that\xe2\x80\x99s certain. My mother said,\r\nwhen she came to see me last week, that she would not like a little one\r\nof her own to be in your place.\xe2\x80\x94Now, come in, and I\xe2\x80\x99ve some good news\r\nfor you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think you have, Bessie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChild! what do you mean? What sorrowful eyes you fix on me! Well, but\r\nMissis and the young ladies and Master John are going out to tea this\r\nafternoon, and you shall have tea with me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll ask cook to bake you a\r\nlittle cake, and then you shall help me to look over your drawers; for\r\nI am soon to pack your trunk. Missis intends you to leave Gateshead in\r\na day or two, and you shall choose what toys you like to take with\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBessie, you must promise not to scold me any more till I go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I will; but mind you are a very good girl, and don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid\r\nof me. Don\xe2\x80\x99t start when I chance to speak rather sharply; it\xe2\x80\x99s so\r\nprovoking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think I shall ever be afraid of you again, Bessie, because I\r\nhave got used to you, and I shall soon have another set of people to\r\ndread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you dread them they\xe2\x80\x99ll dislike you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs you do, Bessie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t dislike you, Miss; I believe I am fonder of you than of all\r\nthe others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t show it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou little sharp thing! you\xe2\x80\x99ve got quite a new way of talking. What\r\nmakes you so venturesome and hardy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I shall soon be away from you, and besides\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94I was going to say\r\nsomething about what had passed between me and Mrs. Reed, but on second\r\nthoughts I considered it better to remain silent on that head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so you\xe2\x80\x99re glad to leave me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, Bessie; indeed, just now I\xe2\x80\x99m rather sorry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust now! and rather! How coolly my little lady says it! I dare say\r\nnow if I were to ask you for a kiss you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t give it me: you\xe2\x80\x99d say\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x99d _rather_ not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll kiss you and welcome: bend your head down.\xe2\x80\x9d Bessie stooped; we\r\nmutually embraced, and I followed her into the house quite comforted.\r\nThat afternoon lapsed in peace and harmony; and in the evening Bessie\r\ntold me some of her most enchanting stories, and sang me some of her\r\nsweetest songs. Even for me life had its gleams of sunshine.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER V\r\n\r\n\r\nFive o\xe2\x80\x99clock had hardly struck on the morning of the 19th of January,\r\nwhen Bessie brought a candle into my closet and found me already up and\r\nnearly dressed. I had risen half-an-hour before her entrance, and had\r\nwashed my face, and put on my clothes by the light of a half-moon just\r\nsetting, whose rays streamed through the narrow window near my crib. I\r\nwas to leave Gateshead that day by a coach which passed the lodge gates\r\nat six A.M. Bessie was the only person yet risen; she had lit a fire in\r\nthe nursery, where she now proceeded to make my breakfast. Few children\r\ncan eat when excited with the thoughts of a journey; nor could I.\r\nBessie, having pressed me in vain to take a few spoonfuls of the boiled\r\nmilk and bread she had prepared for me, wrapped up some biscuits in a\r\npaper and put them into my bag; then she helped me on with my pelisse\r\nand bonnet, and wrapping herself in a shawl, she and I left the\r\nnursery. As we passed Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s bedroom, she said, \xe2\x80\x9cWill you go in\r\nand bid Missis good-bye?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Bessie: she came to my crib last night when you were gone down to\r\nsupper, and said I need not disturb her in the morning, or my cousins\r\neither; and she told me to remember that she had always been my best\r\nfriend, and to speak of her and be grateful to her accordingly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you say, Miss?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing: I covered my face with the bedclothes, and turned from her to\r\nthe wall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat was wrong, Miss Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was quite right, Bessie. Your Missis has not been my friend: she\r\nhas been my foe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cO Miss Jane! don\xe2\x80\x99t say so!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye to Gateshead!\xe2\x80\x9d cried I, as we passed through the hall and\r\nwent out at the front door.\r\n\r\nThe moon was set, and it was very dark; Bessie carried a lantern, whose\r\nlight glanced on wet steps and gravel road sodden by a recent thaw. Raw\r\nand chill was the winter morning: my teeth chattered as I hastened down\r\nthe drive. There was a light in the porter\xe2\x80\x99s lodge: when we reached it,\r\nwe found the porter\xe2\x80\x99s wife just kindling her fire: my trunk, which had\r\nbeen carried down the evening before, stood corded at the door. It\r\nwanted but a few minutes of six, and shortly after that hour had\r\nstruck, the distant roll of wheels announced the coming coach; I went\r\nto the door and watched its lamps approach rapidly through the gloom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs she going by herself?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the porter\xe2\x80\x99s wife.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how far is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFifty miles.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a long way! I wonder Mrs. Reed is not afraid to trust her so far\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe coach drew up; there it was at the gates with its four horses and\r\nits top laden with passengers: the guard and coachman loudly urged\r\nhaste; my trunk was hoisted up; I was taken from Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s neck, to\r\nwhich I clung with kisses.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe sure and take good care of her,\xe2\x80\x9d cried she to the guard, as he\r\nlifted me into the inside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy, ay!\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer: the door was slapped to, a voice exclaimed\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll right,\xe2\x80\x9d and on we drove. Thus was I severed from Bessie and\r\nGateshead; thus whirled away to unknown, and, as I then deemed, remote\r\nand mysterious regions.\r\n\r\nI remember but little of the journey; I only know that the day seemed\r\nto me of a preternatural length, and that we appeared to travel over\r\nhundreds of miles of road. We passed through several towns, and in one,\r\na very large one, the coach stopped; the horses were taken out, and the\r\npassengers alighted to dine. I was carried into an inn, where the guard\r\nwanted me to have some dinner; but, as I had no appetite, he left me in\r\nan immense room with a fireplace at each end, a chandelier pendent from\r\nthe ceiling, and a little red gallery high up against the wall filled\r\nwith musical instruments. Here I walked about for a long time, feeling\r\nvery strange, and mortally apprehensive of some one coming in and\r\nkidnapping me; for I believed in kidnappers, their exploits having\r\nfrequently figured in Bessie\xe2\x80\x99s fireside chronicles. At last the guard\r\nreturned; once more I was stowed away in the coach, my protector\r\nmounted his own seat, sounded his hollow horn, and away we rattled over\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cstony street\xe2\x80\x9d of L\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94.\r\n\r\nThe afternoon came on wet and somewhat misty: as it waned into dusk, I\r\nbegan to feel that we were getting very far indeed from Gateshead: we\r\nceased to pass through towns; the country changed; great grey hills\r\nheaved up round the horizon: as twilight deepened, we descended a\r\nvalley, dark with wood, and long after night had overclouded the\r\nprospect, I heard a wild wind rushing amongst trees.\r\n\r\nLulled by the sound, I at last dropped asleep; I had not long slumbered\r\nwhen the sudden cessation of motion awoke me; the coach-door was open,\r\nand a person like a servant was standing at it: I saw her face and\r\ndress by the light of the lamps.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there a little girl called Jane Eyre here?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. I answered\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d and was then lifted out; my trunk was handed down, and the coach\r\ninstantly drove away.\r\n\r\nI was stiff with long sitting, and bewildered with the noise and motion\r\nof the coach: gathering my faculties, I looked about me. Rain, wind,\r\nand darkness filled the air; nevertheless, I dimly discerned a wall\r\nbefore me and a door open in it; through this door I passed with my new\r\nguide: she shut and locked it behind her. There was now visible a house\r\nor houses\xe2\x80\x94for the building spread far\xe2\x80\x94with many windows, and lights\r\nburning in some; we went up a broad pebbly path, splashing wet, and\r\nwere admitted at a door; then the servant led me through a passage into\r\na room with a fire, where she left me alone.\r\n\r\nI stood and warmed my numbed fingers over the blaze, then I looked\r\nround; there was no candle, but the uncertain light from the hearth\r\nshowed, by intervals, papered walls, carpet, curtains, shining mahogany\r\nfurniture: it was a parlour, not so spacious or splendid as the\r\ndrawing-room at Gateshead, but comfortable enough. I was puzzling to\r\nmake out the subject of a picture on the wall, when the door opened,\r\nand an individual carrying a light entered; another followed close\r\nbehind.\r\n\r\nThe first was a tall lady with dark hair, dark eyes, and a pale and\r\nlarge forehead; her figure was partly enveloped in a shawl, her\r\ncountenance was grave, her bearing erect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe child is very young to be sent alone,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, putting her\r\ncandle down on the table. She considered me attentively for a minute or\r\ntwo, then further added\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had better be put to bed soon; she looks tired: are you tired?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe asked, placing her hand on my shoulder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd hungry too, no doubt: let her have some supper before she goes to\r\nbed, Miss Miller. Is this the first time you have left your parents to\r\ncome to school, my little girl?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI explained to her that I had no parents. She inquired how long they\r\nhad been dead: then how old I was, what was my name, whether I could\r\nread, write, and sew a little: then she touched my cheek gently with\r\nher forefinger, and saying, \xe2\x80\x9cShe hoped I should be a good child,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ndismissed me along with Miss Miller.\r\n\r\nThe lady I had left might be about twenty-nine; the one who went with\r\nme appeared some years younger: the first impressed me by her voice,\r\nlook, and air. Miss Miller was more ordinary; ruddy in complexion,\r\nthough of a careworn countenance; hurried in gait and action, like one\r\nwho had always a multiplicity of tasks on hand: she looked, indeed,\r\nwhat I afterwards found she really was, an under-teacher. Led by her, I\r\npassed from compartment to compartment, from passage to passage, of a\r\nlarge and irregular building; till, emerging from the total and\r\nsomewhat dreary silence pervading that portion of the house we had\r\ntraversed, we came upon the hum of many voices, and presently entered a\r\nwide, long room, with great deal tables, two at each end, on each of\r\nwhich burnt a pair of candles, and seated all round on benches, a\r\ncongregation of girls of every age, from nine or ten to twenty. Seen by\r\nthe dim light of the dips, their number to me appeared countless,\r\nthough not in reality exceeding eighty; they were uniformly dressed in\r\nbrown stuff frocks of quaint fashion, and long holland pinafores. It\r\nwas the hour of study; they were engaged in conning over their\r\nto-morrow\xe2\x80\x99s task, and the hum I had heard was the combined result of\r\ntheir whispered repetitions.\r\n\r\nMiss Miller signed to me to sit on a bench near the door, then walking\r\nup to the top of the long room she cried out\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonitors, collect the lesson-books and put them away!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nFour tall girls arose from different tables, and going round, gathered\r\nthe books and removed them. Miss Miller again gave the word of command\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonitors, fetch the supper-trays!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe tall girls went out and returned presently, each bearing a tray,\r\nwith portions of something, I knew not what, arranged thereon, and a\r\npitcher of water and mug in the middle of each tray. The portions were\r\nhanded round; those who liked took a draught of the water, the mug\r\nbeing common to all. When it came to my turn, I drank, for I was\r\nthirsty, but did not touch the food, excitement and fatigue rendering\r\nme incapable of eating: I now saw, however, that it was a thin oaten\r\ncake shared into fragments.\r\n\r\nThe meal over, prayers were read by Miss Miller, and the classes filed\r\noff, two and two, upstairs. Overpowered by this time with weariness, I\r\nscarcely noticed what sort of a place the bedroom was, except that,\r\nlike the schoolroom, I saw it was very long. To-night I was to be Miss\r\nMiller\xe2\x80\x99s bed-fellow; she helped me to undress: when laid down I glanced\r\nat the long rows of beds, each of which was quickly filled with two\r\noccupants; in ten minutes the single light was extinguished, and amidst\r\nsilence and complete darkness I fell asleep.\r\n\r\nThe night passed rapidly: I was too tired even to dream; I only once\r\nawoke to hear the wind rave in furious gusts, and the rain fall in\r\ntorrents, and to be sensible that Miss Miller had taken her place by my\r\nside. When I again unclosed my eyes, a loud bell was ringing; the girls\r\nwere up and dressing; day had not yet begun to dawn, and a rushlight or\r\ntwo burned in the room. I too rose reluctantly; it was bitter cold, and\r\nI dressed as well as I could for shivering, and washed when there was a\r\nbasin at liberty, which did not occur soon, as there was but one basin\r\nto six girls, on the stands down the middle of the room. Again the bell\r\nrang: all formed in file, two and two, and in that order descended the\r\nstairs and entered the cold and dimly lit schoolroom: here prayers were\r\nread by Miss Miller; afterwards she called out\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cForm classes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA great tumult succeeded for some minutes, during which Miss Miller\r\nrepeatedly exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cOrder!\xe2\x80\x9d When it subsided, I saw\r\nthem all drawn up in four semicircles, before four chairs, placed at\r\nthe four tables; all held books in their hands, and a great book, like\r\na Bible, lay on each table, before the vacant seat. A pause of some\r\nseconds succeeded, filled up by the low, vague hum of numbers; Miss\r\nMiller walked from class to class, hushing this indefinite sound.\r\n\r\nA distant bell tinkled: immediately three ladies entered the room, each\r\nwalked to a table and took her seat; Miss Miller assumed the fourth\r\nvacant chair, which was that nearest the door, and around which the\r\nsmallest of the children were assembled: to this inferior class I was\r\ncalled, and placed at the bottom of it.\r\n\r\nBusiness now began: the day\xe2\x80\x99s Collect was repeated, then certain texts\r\nof Scripture were said, and to these succeeded a protracted reading of\r\nchapters in the Bible, which lasted an hour. By the time that exercise\r\nwas terminated, day had fully dawned. The indefatigable bell now\r\nsounded for the fourth time: the classes were marshalled and marched\r\ninto another room to breakfast: how glad I was to behold a prospect of\r\ngetting something to eat! I was now nearly sick from inanition, having\r\ntaken so little the day before.\r\n\r\nThe refectory was a great, low-ceiled, gloomy room; on two long tables\r\nsmoked basins of something hot, which, however, to my dismay, sent\r\nforth an odour far from inviting. I saw a universal manifestation of\r\ndiscontent when the fumes of the repast met the nostrils of those\r\ndestined to swallow it; from the van of the procession, the tall girls\r\nof the first class, rose the whispered words\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDisgusting! The porridge is burnt again!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated a voice; not that of Miss Miller, but one of the\r\nupper teachers, a little and dark personage, smartly dressed, but of\r\nsomewhat morose aspect, who installed herself at the top of one table,\r\nwhile a more buxom lady presided at the other. I looked in vain for her\r\nI had first seen the night before; she was not visible: Miss Miller\r\noccupied the foot of the table where I sat, and a strange,\r\nforeign-looking, elderly lady, the French teacher, as I afterwards\r\nfound, took the corresponding seat at the other board. A long grace was\r\nsaid and a hymn sung; then a servant brought in some tea for the\r\nteachers, and the meal began.\r\n\r\nRavenous, and now very faint, I devoured a spoonful or two of my\r\nportion without thinking of its taste; but the first edge of hunger\r\nblunted, I perceived I had got in hand a nauseous mess; burnt porridge\r\nis almost as bad as rotten potatoes; famine itself soon sickens over\r\nit. The spoons were moved slowly: I saw each girl taste her food and\r\ntry to swallow it; but in most cases the effort was soon relinquished.\r\nBreakfast was over, and none had breakfasted. Thanks being returned for\r\nwhat we had not got, and a second hymn chanted, the refectory was\r\nevacuated for the schoolroom. I was one of the last to go out, and in\r\npassing the tables, I saw one teacher take a basin of the porridge and\r\ntaste it; she looked at the others; all their countenances expressed\r\ndispleasure, and one of them, the stout one, whispered\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbominable stuff! How shameful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA quarter of an hour passed before lessons again began, during which\r\nthe schoolroom was in a glorious tumult; for that space of time it\r\nseemed to be permitted to talk loud and more freely, and they used\r\ntheir privilege. The whole conversation ran on the breakfast, which one\r\nand all abused roundly. Poor things! it was the sole consolation they\r\nhad. Miss Miller was now the only teacher in the room: a group of great\r\ngirls standing about her spoke with serious and sullen gestures. I\r\nheard the name of Mr. Brocklehurst pronounced by some lips; at which\r\nMiss Miller shook her head disapprovingly; but she made no great effort\r\nto check the general wrath; doubtless she shared in it.\r\n\r\nA clock in the schoolroom struck nine; Miss Miller left her circle, and\r\nstanding in the middle of the room, cried\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSilence! To your seats!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDiscipline prevailed: in five minutes the confused throng was resolved\r\ninto order, and comparative silence quelled the Babel clamour of\r\ntongues. The upper teachers now punctually resumed their posts: but\r\nstill, all seemed to wait. Ranged on benches down the sides of the\r\nroom, the eighty girls sat motionless and erect; a quaint assemblage\r\nthey appeared, all with plain locks combed from their faces, not a curl\r\nvisible; in brown dresses, made high and surrounded by a narrow tucker\r\nabout the throat, with little pockets of holland (shaped something like\r\na Highlander\xe2\x80\x99s purse) tied in front of their frocks, and destined to\r\nserve the purpose of a work-bag: all, too, wearing woollen stockings\r\nand country-made shoes, fastened with brass buckles. Above twenty of\r\nthose clad in this costume were full-grown girls, or rather young\r\nwomen; it suited them ill, and gave an air of oddity even to the\r\nprettiest.\r\n\r\nI was still looking at them, and also at intervals examining the\r\nteachers\xe2\x80\x94none of whom precisely pleased me; for the stout one was a\r\nlittle coarse, the dark one not a little fierce, the foreigner harsh\r\nand grotesque, and Miss Miller, poor thing! looked purple,\r\nweather-beaten, and over-worked\xe2\x80\x94when, as my eye wandered from face to\r\nface, the whole school rose simultaneously, as if moved by a common\r\nspring.\r\n\r\nWhat was the matter? I had heard no order given: I was puzzled. Ere I\r\nhad gathered my wits, the classes were again seated: but as all eyes\r\nwere now turned to one point, mine followed the general direction, and\r\nencountered the personage who had received me last night. She stood at\r\nthe bottom of the long room, on the hearth; for there was a fire at\r\neach end; she surveyed the two rows of girls silently and gravely. Miss\r\nMiller approaching, seemed to ask her a question, and having received\r\nher answer, went back to her place, and said aloud\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMonitor of the first class, fetch the globes!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhile the direction was being executed, the lady consulted moved slowly\r\nup the room. I suppose I have a considerable organ of veneration, for I\r\nretain yet the sense of admiring awe with which my eyes traced her\r\nsteps. Seen now, in broad daylight, she looked tall, fair, and shapely;\r\nbrown eyes with a benignant light in their irids, and a fine pencilling\r\nof long lashes round, relieved the whiteness of her large front; on\r\neach of her temples her hair, of a very dark brown, was clustered in\r\nround curls, according to the fashion of those times, when neither\r\nsmooth bands nor long ringlets were in vogue; her dress, also in the\r\nmode of the day, was of purple cloth, relieved by a sort of Spanish\r\ntrimming of black velvet; a gold watch (watches were not so common then\r\nas now) shone at her girdle. Let the reader add, to complete the\r\npicture, refined features; a complexion, if pale, clear; and a stately\r\nair and carriage, and he will have, at least, as clearly as words can\r\ngive it, a correct idea of the exterior of Miss Temple\xe2\x80\x94Maria Temple, as\r\nI afterwards saw the name written in a prayer-book intrusted to me to\r\ncarry to church.\r\n\r\nThe superintendent of Lowood (for such was this lady) having taken her\r\nseat before a pair of globes placed on one of the tables, summoned the\r\nfirst class round her, and commenced giving a lesson on geography; the\r\nlower classes were called by the teachers: repetitions in history,\r\ngrammar, &c., went on for an hour; writing and arithmetic succeeded,\r\nand music lessons were given by Miss Temple to some of the elder girls.\r\nThe duration of each lesson was measured by the clock, which at last\r\nstruck twelve. The superintendent rose\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a word to address to the pupils,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\nThe tumult of cessation from lessons was already breaking forth, but it\r\nsank at her voice. She went on\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had this morning a breakfast which you could not eat; you must be\r\nhungry:\xe2\x80\x94I have ordered that a lunch of bread and cheese shall be served\r\nto all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe teachers looked at her with a sort of surprise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is to be done on my responsibility,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, in an explanatory\r\ntone to them, and immediately afterwards left the room.\r\n\r\nThe bread and cheese was presently brought in and distributed, to the\r\nhigh delight and refreshment of the whole school. The order was now\r\ngiven \xe2\x80\x9cTo the garden!\xe2\x80\x9d Each put on a coarse straw bonnet, with strings\r\nof coloured calico, and a cloak of grey frieze. I was similarly\r\nequipped, and, following the stream, I made my way into the open air.\r\n\r\nThe garden was a wide inclosure, surrounded with walls so high as to\r\nexclude every glimpse of prospect; a covered verandah ran down one\r\nside, and broad walks bordered a middle space divided into scores of\r\nlittle beds: these beds were assigned as gardens for the pupils to\r\ncultivate, and each bed had an owner. When full of flowers they would\r\ndoubtless look pretty; but now, at the latter end of January, all was\r\nwintry blight and brown decay. I shuddered as I stood and looked round\r\nme: it was an inclement day for outdoor exercise; not positively rainy,\r\nbut darkened by a drizzling yellow fog; all under foot was still\r\nsoaking wet with the floods of yesterday. The stronger among the girls\r\nran about and engaged in active games, but sundry pale and thin ones\r\nherded together for shelter and warmth in the verandah; and amongst\r\nthese, as the dense mist penetrated to their shivering frames, I heard\r\nfrequently the sound of a hollow cough.\r\n\r\nAs yet I had spoken to no one, nor did anybody seem to take notice of\r\nme; I stood lonely enough: but to that feeling of isolation I was\r\naccustomed; it did not oppress me much. I leant against a pillar of the\r\nverandah, drew my grey mantle close about me, and, trying to forget the\r\ncold which nipped me without, and the unsatisfied hunger which gnawed\r\nme within, delivered myself up to the employment of watching and\r\nthinking. My reflections were too undefined and fragmentary to merit\r\nrecord: I hardly yet knew where I was; Gateshead and my past life\r\nseemed floated away to an immeasurable distance; the present was vague\r\nand strange, and of the future I could form no conjecture. I looked\r\nround the convent-like garden, and then up at the house\xe2\x80\x94a large\r\nbuilding, half of which seemed grey and old, the other half quite new.\r\nThe new part, containing the schoolroom and dormitory, was lit by\r\nmullioned and latticed windows, which gave it a church-like aspect; a\r\nstone tablet over the door bore this inscription:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nLOWOOD INSTITUTION.\r\n\r\nThis portion was rebuilt A.D. \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, by Naomi Brocklehurst,\r\nof Brocklehurst Hall, in this county.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet your light so shine before men, that they may see your good works,\r\nand glorify your Father which is in heaven.\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94St. Matt. v. 16.\r\n\r\n\r\nI read these words over and over again: I felt that an explanation\r\nbelonged to them, and was unable fully to penetrate their import. I was\r\nstill pondering the signification of \xe2\x80\x9cInstitution,\xe2\x80\x9d and endeavouring to\r\nmake out a connection between the first words and the verse of\r\nScripture, when the sound of a cough close behind me made me turn my\r\nhead. I saw a girl sitting on a stone bench near; she was bent over a\r\nbook, on the perusal of which she seemed intent: from where I stood I\r\ncould see the title\xe2\x80\x94it was \xe2\x80\x9cRasselas;\xe2\x80\x9d a name that struck me as\r\nstrange, and consequently attractive. In turning a leaf she happened to\r\nlook up, and I said to her directly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs your book interesting?\xe2\x80\x9d I had already formed the intention of\r\nasking her to lend it to me some day.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like it,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered, after a pause of a second or two, during\r\nwhich she examined me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it about?\xe2\x80\x9d I continued. I hardly know where I found the\r\nhardihood thus to open a conversation with a stranger; the step was\r\ncontrary to my nature and habits: but I think her occupation touched a\r\nchord of sympathy somewhere; for I too liked reading, though of a\r\nfrivolous and childish kind; I could not digest or comprehend the\r\nserious or substantial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may look at it,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the girl, offering me the book.\r\n\r\nI did so; a brief examination convinced me that the contents were less\r\ntaking than the title: \xe2\x80\x9cRasselas\xe2\x80\x9d looked dull to my trifling taste; I\r\nsaw nothing about fairies, nothing about genii; no bright variety\r\nseemed spread over the closely-printed pages. I returned it to her; she\r\nreceived it quietly, and without saying anything she was about to\r\nrelapse into her former studious mood: again I ventured to disturb her\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you tell me what the writing on that stone over the door means?\r\nWhat is Lowood Institution?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis house where you are come to live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd why do they call it Institution? Is it in any way different from\r\nother schools?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is partly a charity-school: you and I, and all the rest of us, are\r\ncharity-children. I suppose you are an orphan: are not either your\r\nfather or your mother dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBoth died before I can remember.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, all the girls here have lost either one or both parents, and\r\nthis is called an institution for educating orphans.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo we pay no money? Do they keep us for nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe pay, or our friends pay, fifteen pounds a year for each.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen why do they call us charity-children?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause fifteen pounds is not enough for board and teaching, and the\r\ndeficiency is supplied by subscription.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho subscribes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDifferent benevolent-minded ladies and gentlemen in this neighbourhood\r\nand in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was Naomi Brocklehurst?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe lady who built the new part of this house as that tablet records,\r\nand whose son overlooks and directs everything here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause he is treasurer and manager of the establishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen this house does not belong to that tall lady who wears a watch,\r\nand who said we were to have some bread and cheese?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo Miss Temple? Oh, no! I wish it did: she has to answer to Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst for all she does. Mr. Brocklehurst buys all our food and\r\nall our clothes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he live here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94two miles off, at a large hall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he a good man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a clergyman, and is said to do a great deal of good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you say that tall lady was called Miss Temple?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what are the other teachers called?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe one with red cheeks is called Miss Smith; she attends to the work,\r\nand cuts out\xe2\x80\x94for we make our own clothes, our frocks, and pelisses, and\r\neverything; the little one with black hair is Miss Scatcherd; she\r\nteaches history and grammar, and hears the second class repetitions;\r\nand the one who wears a shawl, and has a pocket-handkerchief tied to\r\nher side with a yellow ribband, is Madame Pierrot: she comes from\r\nLisle, in France, and teaches French.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like the teachers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell enough.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like the little black one, and the Madame \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94?\xe2\x80\x94I cannot\r\npronounce her name as you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Scatcherd is hasty\xe2\x80\x94you must take care not to offend her; Madame\r\nPierrot is not a bad sort of person.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Miss Temple is the best\xe2\x80\x94isn\xe2\x80\x99t she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Temple is very good and very clever; she is above the rest,\r\nbecause she knows far more than they do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you been long here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwo years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you an orphan?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you happy here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou ask rather too many questions. I have given you answers enough for\r\nthe present: now I want to read.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut at that moment the summons sounded for dinner; all re-entered the\r\nhouse. The odour which now filled the refectory was scarcely more\r\nappetising than that which had regaled our nostrils at breakfast: the\r\ndinner was served in two huge tin-plated vessels, whence rose a strong\r\nsteam redolent of rancid fat. I found the mess to consist of\r\nindifferent potatoes and strange shreds of rusty meat, mixed and cooked\r\ntogether. Of this preparation a tolerably abundant plateful was\r\napportioned to each pupil. I ate what I could, and wondered within\r\nmyself whether every day\xe2\x80\x99s fare would be like this.\r\n\r\nAfter dinner, we immediately adjourned to the schoolroom: lessons\r\nrecommenced, and were continued till five o\xe2\x80\x99clock.\r\n\r\nThe only marked event of the afternoon was, that I saw the girl with\r\nwhom I had conversed in the verandah dismissed in disgrace by Miss\r\nScatcherd from a history class, and sent to stand in the middle of the\r\nlarge schoolroom. The punishment seemed to me in a high degree\r\nignominious, especially for so great a girl\xe2\x80\x94she looked thirteen or\r\nupwards. I expected she would show signs of great distress and shame;\r\nbut to my surprise she neither wept nor blushed: composed, though\r\ngrave, she stood, the central mark of all eyes. \xe2\x80\x9cHow can she bear it so\r\nquietly\xe2\x80\x94so firmly?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked of myself. \xe2\x80\x9cWere I in her place, it seems\r\nto me I should wish the earth to open and swallow me up. She looks as\r\nif she were thinking of something beyond her punishment\xe2\x80\x94beyond her\r\nsituation: of something not round her nor before her. I have heard of\r\nday-dreams\xe2\x80\x94is she in a day-dream now? Her eyes are fixed on the floor,\r\nbut I am sure they do not see it\xe2\x80\x94her sight seems turned in, gone down\r\ninto her heart: she is looking at what she can remember, I believe; not\r\nat what is really present. I wonder what sort of a girl she is\xe2\x80\x94whether\r\ngood or naughty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSoon after five P.M. we had another meal, consisting of a small mug of\r\ncoffee, and half-a-slice of brown bread. I devoured my bread and drank\r\nmy coffee with relish; but I should have been glad of as much more\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nwas still hungry. Half-an-hour\xe2\x80\x99s recreation succeeded, then study; then\r\nthe glass of water and the piece of oat-cake, prayers, and bed. Such\r\nwas my first day at Lowood.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VI\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next day commenced as before, getting up and dressing by rushlight;\r\nbut this morning we were obliged to dispense with the ceremony of\r\nwashing; the water in the pitchers was frozen. A change had taken place\r\nin the weather the preceding evening, and a keen north-east wind,\r\nwhistling through the crevices of our bedroom windows all night long,\r\nhad made us shiver in our beds, and turned the contents of the ewers to\r\nice.\r\n\r\nBefore the long hour and a half of prayers and Bible-reading was over,\r\nI felt ready to perish with cold. Breakfast-time came at last, and this\r\nmorning the porridge was not burnt; the quality was eatable, the\r\nquantity small. How small my portion seemed! I wished it had been\r\ndoubled.\r\n\r\nIn the course of the day I was enrolled a member of the fourth class,\r\nand regular tasks and occupations were assigned me: hitherto, I had\r\nonly been a spectator of the proceedings at Lowood; I was now to become\r\nan actor therein. At first, being little accustomed to learn by heart,\r\nthe lessons appeared to me both long and difficult; the frequent change\r\nfrom task to task, too, bewildered me; and I was glad when, about three\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon, Miss Smith put into my hands a border of\r\nmuslin two yards long, together with needle, thimble, &c., and sent me\r\nto sit in a quiet corner of the schoolroom, with directions to hem the\r\nsame. At that hour most of the others were sewing likewise; but one\r\nclass still stood round Miss Scatcherd\xe2\x80\x99s chair reading, and as all was\r\nquiet, the subject of their lessons could be heard, together with the\r\nmanner in which each girl acquitted herself, and the animadversions or\r\ncommendations of Miss Scatcherd on the performance. It was English\r\nhistory: among the readers I observed my acquaintance of the verandah:\r\nat the commencement of the lesson, her place had been at the top of the\r\nclass, but for some error of pronunciation, or some inattention to\r\nstops, she was suddenly sent to the very bottom. Even in that obscure\r\nposition, Miss Scatcherd continued to make her an object of constant\r\nnotice: she was continually addressing to her such phrases as the\r\nfollowing:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBurns\xe2\x80\x9d (such it seems was her name: the girls here were all called by\r\ntheir surnames, as boys are elsewhere), \xe2\x80\x9cBurns, you are standing on the\r\nside of your shoe; turn your toes out immediately.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBurns, you poke\r\nyour chin most unpleasantly; draw it in.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBurns, I insist on your\r\nholding your head up; I will not have you before me in that attitude,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n&c. &c.\r\n\r\nA chapter having been read through twice, the books were closed and the\r\ngirls examined. The lesson had comprised part of the reign of Charles\r\nI., and there were sundry questions about tonnage and poundage and\r\nship-money, which most of them appeared unable to answer; still, every\r\nlittle difficulty was solved instantly when it reached Burns: her\r\nmemory seemed to have retained the substance of the whole lesson, and\r\nshe was ready with answers on every point. I kept expecting that Miss\r\nScatcherd would praise her attention; but, instead of that, she\r\nsuddenly cried out\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou dirty, disagreeable girl! you have never cleaned your nails this\r\nmorning!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBurns made no answer: I wondered at her silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, \xe2\x80\x9cdoes she not explain that she could neither clean\r\nher nails nor wash her face, as the water was frozen?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy attention was now called off by Miss Smith desiring me to hold a\r\nskein of thread: while she was winding it, she talked to me from time\r\nto time, asking whether I had ever been at school before, whether I\r\ncould mark, stitch, knit, &c.; till she dismissed me, I could not\r\npursue my observations on Miss Scatcherd\xe2\x80\x99s movements. When I returned\r\nto my seat, that lady was just delivering an order of which I did not\r\ncatch the import; but Burns immediately left the class, and going into\r\nthe small inner room where the books were kept, returned in half a\r\nminute, carrying in her hand a bundle of twigs tied together at one\r\nend. This ominous tool she presented to Miss Scatcherd with a\r\nrespectful curtesy; then she quietly, and without being told, unloosed\r\nher pinafore, and the teacher instantly and sharply inflicted on her\r\nneck a dozen strokes with the bunch of twigs. Not a tear rose to Burns\xe2\x80\x99\r\neye; and, while I paused from my sewing, because my fingers quivered at\r\nthis spectacle with a sentiment of unavailing and impotent anger, not a\r\nfeature of her pensive face altered its ordinary expression.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHardened girl!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Miss Scatcherd; \xe2\x80\x9cnothing can correct you of\r\nyour slatternly habits: carry the rod away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBurns obeyed: I looked at her narrowly as she emerged from the\r\nbook-closet; she was just putting back her handkerchief into her\r\npocket, and the trace of a tear glistened on her thin cheek.\r\n\r\nThe play-hour in the evening I thought the pleasantest fraction of the\r\nday at Lowood: the bit of bread, the draught of coffee swallowed at\r\nfive o\xe2\x80\x99clock had revived vitality, if it had not satisfied hunger: the\r\nlong restraint of the day was slackened; the schoolroom felt warmer\r\nthan in the morning\xe2\x80\x94its fires being allowed to burn a little more\r\nbrightly, to supply, in some measure, the place of candles, not yet\r\nintroduced: the ruddy gloaming, the licensed uproar, the confusion of\r\nmany voices gave one a welcome sense of liberty.\r\n\r\nOn the evening of the day on which I had seen Miss Scatcherd flog her\r\npupil, Burns, I wandered as usual among the forms and tables and\r\nlaughing groups without a companion, yet not feeling lonely: when I\r\npassed the windows, I now and then lifted a blind, and looked out; it\r\nsnowed fast, a drift was already forming against the lower panes;\r\nputting my ear close to the window, I could distinguish from the\r\ngleeful tumult within, the disconsolate moan of the wind outside.\r\n\r\nProbably, if I had lately left a good home and kind parents, this would\r\nhave been the hour when I should most keenly have regretted the\r\nseparation; that wind would then have saddened my heart; this obscure\r\nchaos would have disturbed my peace! as it was, I derived from both a\r\nstrange excitement, and reckless and feverish, I wished the wind to\r\nhowl more wildly, the gloom to deepen to darkness, and the confusion to\r\nrise to clamour.\r\n\r\nJumping over forms, and creeping under tables, I made my way to one of\r\nthe fire-places; there, kneeling by the high wire fender, I found\r\nBurns, absorbed, silent, abstracted from all round her by the\r\ncompanionship of a book, which she read by the dim glare of the embers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it still \xe2\x80\x98Rasselas\xe2\x80\x99?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, coming behind her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I have just finished it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd in five minutes more she shut it up. I was glad of this.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, \xe2\x80\x9cI can perhaps get her to talk.\xe2\x80\x9d I sat down by her on\r\nthe floor.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your name besides Burns?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you come a long way from here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI come from a place farther north, quite on the borders of Scotland.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you ever go back?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope so; but nobody can be sure of the future.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must wish to leave Lowood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! why should I? I was sent to Lowood to get an education; and it\r\nwould be of no use going away until I have attained that object.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut that teacher, Miss Scatcherd, is so cruel to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCruel? Not at all! She is severe: she dislikes my faults.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I were in your place I should dislike her; I should resist her.\r\nIf she struck me with that rod, I should get it from her hand; I should\r\nbreak it under her nose.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProbably you would do nothing of the sort: but if you did, Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst would expel you from the school; that would be a great\r\ngrief to your relations. It is far better to endure patiently a smart\r\nwhich nobody feels but yourself, than to commit a hasty action whose\r\nevil consequences will extend to all connected with you; and besides,\r\nthe Bible bids us return good for evil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut then it seems disgraceful to be flogged, and to be sent to stand\r\nin the middle of a room full of people; and you are such a great girl:\r\nI am far younger than you, and I could not bear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet it would be your duty to bear it, if you could not avoid it: it is\r\nweak and silly to say you _cannot bear_ what it is your fate to be\r\nrequired to bear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI heard her with wonder: I could not comprehend this doctrine of\r\nendurance; and still less could I understand or sympathise with the\r\nforbearance she expressed for her chastiser. Still I felt that Helen\r\nBurns considered things by a light invisible to my eyes. I suspected\r\nshe might be right and I wrong; but I would not ponder the matter\r\ndeeply; like Felix, I put it off to a more convenient season.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say you have faults, Helen: what are they? To me you seem very\r\ngood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen learn from me, not to judge by appearances: I am, as Miss\r\nScatcherd said, slatternly; I seldom put, and never keep, things in\r\norder; I am careless; I forget rules; I read when I should learn my\r\nlessons; I have no method; and sometimes I say, like you, I cannot\r\n_bear_ to be subjected to systematic arrangements. This is all very\r\nprovoking to Miss Scatcherd, who is naturally neat, punctual, and\r\nparticular.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd cross and cruel,\xe2\x80\x9d I added; but Helen Burns would not admit my\r\naddition: she kept silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Miss Temple as severe to you as Miss Scatcherd?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt the utterance of Miss Temple\xe2\x80\x99s name, a soft smile flitted over her\r\ngrave face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Temple is full of goodness; it pains her to be severe to any one,\r\neven the worst in the school: she sees my errors, and tells me of them\r\ngently; and, if I do anything worthy of praise, she gives me my meed\r\nliberally. One strong proof of my wretchedly defective nature is, that\r\neven her expostulations, so mild, so rational, have not influence to\r\ncure me of my faults; and even her praise, though I value it most\r\nhighly, cannot stimulate me to continued care and foresight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is curious,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cit is so easy to be careful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor _you_ I have no doubt it is. I observed you in your class this\r\nmorning, and saw you were closely attentive: your thoughts never seemed\r\nto wander while Miss Miller explained the lesson and questioned you.\r\nNow, mine continually rove away; when I should be listening to Miss\r\nScatcherd, and collecting all she says with assiduity, often I lose the\r\nvery sound of her voice; I fall into a sort of dream. Sometimes I think\r\nI am in Northumberland, and that the noises I hear round me are the\r\nbubbling of a little brook which runs through Deepden, near our\r\nhouse;\xe2\x80\x94then, when it comes to my turn to reply, I have to be awakened;\r\nand having heard nothing of what was read for listening to the\r\nvisionary brook, I have no answer ready.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet how well you replied this afternoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was mere chance; the subject on which we had been reading had\r\ninterested me. This afternoon, instead of dreaming of Deepden, I was\r\nwondering how a man who wished to do right could act so unjustly and\r\nunwisely as Charles the First sometimes did; and I thought what a pity\r\nit was that, with his integrity and conscientiousness, he could see no\r\nfarther than the prerogatives of the crown. If he had but been able to\r\nlook to a distance, and see how what they call the spirit of the age\r\nwas tending! Still, I like Charles\xe2\x80\x94I respect him\xe2\x80\x94I pity him, poor\r\nmurdered king! Yes, his enemies were the worst: they shed blood they\r\nhad no right to shed. How dared they kill him!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHelen was talking to herself now: she had forgotten I could not very\r\nwell understand her\xe2\x80\x94that I was ignorant, or nearly so, of the subject\r\nshe discussed. I recalled her to my level.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when Miss Temple teaches you, do your thoughts wander then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, certainly, not often; because Miss Temple has generally something\r\nto say which is newer than my own reflections; her language is\r\nsingularly agreeable to me, and the information she communicates is\r\noften just what I wished to gain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then, with Miss Temple you are good?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, in a passive way: I make no effort; I follow as inclination\r\nguides me. There is no merit in such goodness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA great deal: you are good to those who are good to you. It is all I\r\never desire to be. If people were always kind and obedient to those who\r\nare cruel and unjust, the wicked people would have it all their own\r\nway: they would never feel afraid, and so they would never alter, but\r\nwould grow worse and worse. When we are struck at without a reason, we\r\nshould strike back again very hard; I am sure we should\xe2\x80\x94so hard as to\r\nteach the person who struck us never to do it again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will change your mind, I hope, when you grow older: as yet you are\r\nbut a little untaught girl.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I feel this, Helen; I must dislike those who, whatever I do to\r\nplease them, persist in disliking me; I must resist those who punish me\r\nunjustly. It is as natural as that I should love those who show me\r\naffection, or submit to punishment when I feel it is deserved.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHeathens and savage tribes hold that doctrine, but Christians and\r\ncivilised nations disown it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow? I don\xe2\x80\x99t understand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not violence that best overcomes hate\xe2\x80\x94nor vengeance that most\r\ncertainly heals injury.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRead the New Testament, and observe what Christ says, and how He acts;\r\nmake His word your rule, and His conduct your example.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does He say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove your enemies; bless them that curse you; do good to them that\r\nhate you and despitefully use you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I should love Mrs. Reed, which I cannot do; I should bless her\r\nson John, which is impossible.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn her turn, Helen Burns asked me to explain, and I proceeded forthwith\r\nto pour out, in my own way, the tale of my sufferings and resentments.\r\nBitter and truculent when excited, I spoke as I felt, without reserve\r\nor softening.\r\n\r\nHelen heard me patiently to the end: I expected she would then make a\r\nremark, but she said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d I asked impatiently, \xe2\x80\x9cis not Mrs. Reed a hard-hearted, bad\r\nwoman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has been unkind to you, no doubt; because you see, she dislikes\r\nyour cast of character, as Miss Scatcherd does mine; but how minutely\r\nyou remember all she has done and said to you! What a singularly deep\r\nimpression her injustice seems to have made on your heart! No ill-usage\r\nso brands its record on my feelings. Would you not be happier if you\r\ntried to forget her severity, together with the passionate emotions it\r\nexcited? Life appears to me too short to be spent in nursing animosity\r\nor registering wrongs. We are, and must be, one and all, burdened with\r\nfaults in this world: but the time will soon come when, I trust, we\r\nshall put them off in putting off our corruptible bodies; when\r\ndebasement and sin will fall from us with this cumbrous frame of flesh,\r\nand only the spark of the spirit will remain,\xe2\x80\x94the impalpable principle\r\nof light and thought, pure as when it left the Creator to inspire the\r\ncreature: whence it came it will return; perhaps again to be\r\ncommunicated to some being higher than man\xe2\x80\x94perhaps to pass through\r\ngradations of glory, from the pale human soul to brighten to the\r\nseraph! Surely it will never, on the contrary, be suffered to\r\ndegenerate from man to fiend? No; I cannot believe that: I hold another\r\ncreed: which no one ever taught me, and which I seldom mention; but in\r\nwhich I delight, and to which I cling: for it extends hope to all: it\r\nmakes Eternity a rest\xe2\x80\x94a mighty home, not a terror and an abyss.\r\nBesides, with this creed, I can so clearly distinguish between the\r\ncriminal and his crime; I can so sincerely forgive the first while I\r\nabhor the last: with this creed revenge never worries my heart,\r\ndegradation never too deeply disgusts me, injustice never crushes me\r\ntoo low: I live in calm, looking to the end.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHelen\xe2\x80\x99s head, always drooping, sank a little lower as she finished this\r\nsentence. I saw by her look she wished no longer to talk to me, but\r\nrather to converse with her own thoughts. She was not allowed much time\r\nfor meditation: a monitor, a great rough girl, presently came up,\r\nexclaiming in a strong Cumberland accent\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelen Burns, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t go and put your drawer in order, and fold up\r\nyour work this minute, I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell Miss Scatcherd to come and look at\r\nit!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHelen sighed as her reverie fled, and getting up, obeyed the monitor\r\nwithout reply as without delay.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER VII\r\n\r\n\r\nMy first quarter at Lowood seemed an age; and not the golden age\r\neither; it comprised an irksome struggle with difficulties in\r\nhabituating myself to new rules and unwonted tasks. The fear of failure\r\nin these points harassed me worse than the physical hardships of my\r\nlot; though these were no trifles.\r\n\r\nDuring January, February, and part of March, the deep snows, and, after\r\ntheir melting, the almost impassable roads, prevented our stirring\r\nbeyond the garden walls, except to go to church; but within these\r\nlimits we had to pass an hour every day in the open air. Our clothing\r\nwas insufficient to protect us from the severe cold: we had no boots,\r\nthe snow got into our shoes and melted there: our ungloved hands became\r\nnumbed and covered with chilblains, as were our feet: I remember well\r\nthe distracting irritation I endured from this cause every evening,\r\nwhen my feet inflamed; and the torture of thrusting the swelled, raw,\r\nand stiff toes into my shoes in the morning. Then the scanty supply of\r\nfood was distressing: with the keen appetites of growing children, we\r\nhad scarcely sufficient to keep alive a delicate invalid. From this\r\ndeficiency of nourishment resulted an abuse, which pressed hardly on\r\nthe younger pupils: whenever the famished great girls had an\r\nopportunity, they would coax or menace the little ones out of their\r\nportion. Many a time I have shared between two claimants the precious\r\nmorsel of brown bread distributed at tea-time; and after relinquishing\r\nto a third half the contents of my mug of coffee, I have swallowed the\r\nremainder with an accompaniment of secret tears, forced from me by the\r\nexigency of hunger.\r\n\r\nSundays were dreary days in that wintry season. We had to walk two\r\nmiles to Brocklebridge Church, where our patron officiated. We set out\r\ncold, we arrived at church colder: during the morning service we became\r\nalmost paralysed. It was too far to return to dinner, and an allowance\r\nof cold meat and bread, in the same penurious proportion observed in\r\nour ordinary meals, was served round between the services.\r\n\r\nAt the close of the afternoon service we returned by an exposed and\r\nhilly road, where the bitter winter wind, blowing over a range of snowy\r\nsummits to the north, almost flayed the skin from our faces.\r\n\r\nI can remember Miss Temple walking lightly and rapidly along our\r\ndrooping line, her plaid cloak, which the frosty wind fluttered,\r\ngathered close about her, and encouraging us, by precept and example,\r\nto keep up our spirits, and march forward, as she said, \xe2\x80\x9clike stalwart\r\nsoldiers.\xe2\x80\x9d The other teachers, poor things, were generally themselves\r\ntoo much dejected to attempt the task of cheering others.\r\n\r\nHow we longed for the light and heat of a blazing fire when we got\r\nback! But, to the little ones at least, this was denied: each hearth in\r\nthe schoolroom was immediately surrounded by a double row of great\r\ngirls, and behind them the younger children crouched in groups,\r\nwrapping their starved arms in their pinafores.\r\n\r\nA little solace came at tea-time, in the shape of a double ration of\r\nbread\xe2\x80\x94a whole, instead of a half, slice\xe2\x80\x94with the delicious addition of\r\na thin scrape of butter: it was the hebdomadal treat to which we all\r\nlooked forward from Sabbath to Sabbath. I generally contrived to\r\nreserve a moiety of this bounteous repast for myself; but the remainder\r\nI was invariably obliged to part with.\r\n\r\nThe Sunday evening was spent in repeating, by heart, the Church\r\nCatechism, and the fifth, sixth, and seventh chapters of St. Matthew;\r\nand in listening to a long sermon, read by Miss Miller, whose\r\nirrepressible yawns attested her weariness. A frequent interlude of\r\nthese performances was the enactment of the part of Eutychus by some\r\nhalf-dozen of little girls, who, overpowered with sleep, would fall\r\ndown, if not out of the third loft, yet off the fourth form, and be\r\ntaken up half dead. The remedy was, to thrust them forward into the\r\ncentre of the schoolroom, and oblige them to stand there till the\r\nsermon was finished. Sometimes their feet failed them, and they sank\r\ntogether in a heap; they were then propped up with the monitors\xe2\x80\x99 high\r\nstools.\r\n\r\nI have not yet alluded to the visits of Mr. Brocklehurst; and indeed\r\nthat gentleman was from home during the greater part of the first month\r\nafter my arrival; perhaps prolonging his stay with his friend the\r\narchdeacon: his absence was a relief to me. I need not say that I had\r\nmy own reasons for dreading his coming: but come he did at last.\r\n\r\nOne afternoon (I had then been three weeks at Lowood), as I was sitting\r\nwith a slate in my hand, puzzling over a sum in long division, my eyes,\r\nraised in abstraction to the window, caught sight of a figure just\r\npassing: I recognised almost instinctively that gaunt outline; and\r\nwhen, two minutes after, all the school, teachers included, rose _en\r\nmasse_, it was not necessary for me to look up in order to ascertain\r\nwhose entrance they thus greeted. A long stride measured the\r\nschoolroom, and presently beside Miss Temple, who herself had risen,\r\nstood the same black column which had frowned on me so ominously from\r\nthe hearthrug of Gateshead. I now glanced sideways at this piece of\r\narchitecture. Yes, I was right: it was Mr. Brocklehurst, buttoned up in\r\na surtout, and looking longer, narrower, and more rigid than ever.\r\n\r\nI had my own reasons for being dismayed at this apparition; too well I\r\nremembered the perfidious hints given by Mrs. Reed about my\r\ndisposition, &c.; the promise pledged by Mr. Brocklehurst to apprise\r\nMiss Temple and the teachers of my vicious nature. All along I had been\r\ndreading the fulfilment of this promise,\xe2\x80\x94I had been looking out daily\r\nfor the \xe2\x80\x9cComing Man,\xe2\x80\x9d whose information respecting my past life and\r\nconversation was to brand me as a bad child for ever: now there he was.\r\n\r\nHe stood at Miss Temple\xe2\x80\x99s side; he was speaking low in her ear: I did\r\nnot doubt he was making disclosures of my villainy; and I watched her\r\neye with painful anxiety, expecting every moment to see its dark orb\r\nturn on me a glance of repugnance and contempt. I listened too; and as\r\nI happened to be seated quite at the top of the room, I caught most of\r\nwhat he said: its import relieved me from immediate apprehension.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose, Miss Temple, the thread I bought at Lowton will do; it\r\nstruck me that it would be just of the quality for the calico chemises,\r\nand I sorted the needles to match. You may tell Miss Smith that I\r\nforgot to make a memorandum of the darning needles, but she shall have\r\nsome papers sent in next week; and she is not, on any account, to give\r\nout more than one at a time to each pupil: if they have more, they are\r\napt to be careless and lose them. And, O ma\xe2\x80\x99am! I wish the woollen\r\nstockings were better looked to!\xe2\x80\x94when I was here last, I went into the\r\nkitchen-garden and examined the clothes drying on the line; there was a\r\nquantity of black hose in a very bad state of repair: from the size of\r\nthe holes in them I was sure they had not been well mended from time to\r\ntime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour directions shall be attended to, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Temple.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cthe laundress tells me some of the girls\r\nhave two clean tuckers in the week: it is too much; the rules limit\r\nthem to one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I can explain that circumstance, sir. Agnes and Catherine\r\nJohnstone were invited to take tea with some friends at Lowton last\r\nThursday, and I gave them leave to put on clean tuckers for the\r\noccasion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brocklehurst nodded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, for once it may pass; but please not to let the circumstance\r\noccur too often. And there is another thing which surprised me; I find,\r\nin settling accounts with the housekeeper, that a lunch, consisting of\r\nbread and cheese, has twice been served out to the girls during the\r\npast fortnight. How is this? I looked over the regulations, and I find\r\nno such meal as lunch mentioned. Who introduced this innovation? and by\r\nwhat authority?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must be responsible for the circumstance, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Miss Temple:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe breakfast was so ill prepared that the pupils could not possibly\r\neat it; and I dared not allow them to remain fasting till dinner-time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam, allow me an instant. You are aware that my plan in bringing up\r\nthese girls is, not to accustom them to habits of luxury and\r\nindulgence, but to render them hardy, patient, self-denying. Should any\r\nlittle accidental disappointment of the appetite occur, such as the\r\nspoiling of a meal, the under or the over dressing of a dish, the\r\nincident ought not to be neutralised by replacing with something more\r\ndelicate the comfort lost, thus pampering the body and obviating the\r\naim of this institution; it ought to be improved to the spiritual\r\nedification of the pupils, by encouraging them to evince fortitude\r\nunder the temporary privation. A brief address on those occasions would\r\nnot be mistimed, wherein a judicious instructor would take the\r\nopportunity of referring to the sufferings of the primitive Christians;\r\nto the torments of martyrs; to the exhortations of our blessed Lord\r\nHimself, calling upon His disciples to take up their cross and follow\r\nHim; to His warnings that man shall not live by bread alone, but by\r\nevery word that proceedeth out of the mouth of God; to His divine\r\nconsolations, \xe2\x80\x98If ye suffer hunger or thirst for My sake, happy are\r\nye.\xe2\x80\x99 Oh, madam, when you put bread and cheese, instead of burnt\r\nporridge, into these children\xe2\x80\x99s mouths, you may indeed feed their vile\r\nbodies, but you little think how you starve their immortal souls!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brocklehurst again paused\xe2\x80\x94perhaps overcome by his feelings. Miss\r\nTemple had looked down when he first began to speak to her; but she now\r\ngazed straight before her, and her face, naturally pale as marble,\r\nappeared to be assuming also the coldness and fixity of that material;\r\nespecially her mouth, closed as if it would have required a sculptor\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nchisel to open it, and her brow settled gradually into petrified\r\nseverity.\r\n\r\nMeantime, Mr. Brocklehurst, standing on the hearth with his hands\r\nbehind his back, majestically surveyed the whole school. Suddenly his\r\neye gave a blink, as if it had met something that either dazzled or\r\nshocked its pupil; turning, he said in more rapid accents than he had\r\nhitherto used\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Temple, Miss Temple, what\xe2\x80\x94_what_ is that girl with curled hair?\r\nRed hair, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, curled\xe2\x80\x94curled all over?\xe2\x80\x9d And extending his cane he\r\npointed to the awful object, his hand shaking as he did so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Julia Severn,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Miss Temple, very quietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJulia Severn, ma\xe2\x80\x99am! And why has she, or any other, curled hair? Why,\r\nin defiance of every precept and principle of this house, does she\r\nconform to the world so openly\xe2\x80\x94here in an evangelical, charitable\r\nestablishment\xe2\x80\x94as to wear her hair one mass of curls?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJulia\xe2\x80\x99s hair curls naturally,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Miss Temple, still more\r\nquietly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNaturally! Yes, but we are not to conform to nature; I wish these\r\ngirls to be the children of Grace: and why that abundance? I have again\r\nand again intimated that I desire the hair to be arranged closely,\r\nmodestly, plainly. Miss Temple, that girl\xe2\x80\x99s hair must be cut off\r\nentirely; I will send a barber to-morrow: and I see others who have far\r\ntoo much of the excrescence\xe2\x80\x94that tall girl, tell her to turn round.\r\nTell all the first form to rise up and direct their faces to the wall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Temple passed her handkerchief over her lips, as if to smooth away\r\nthe involuntary smile that curled them; she gave the order, however,\r\nand when the first class could take in what was required of them, they\r\nobeyed. Leaning a little back on my bench, I could see the looks and\r\ngrimaces with which they commented on this manoeuvre: it was a pity Mr.\r\nBrocklehurst could not see them too; he would perhaps have felt that,\r\nwhatever he might do with the outside of the cup and platter, the\r\ninside was further beyond his interference than he imagined.\r\n\r\nHe scrutinised the reverse of these living medals some five minutes,\r\nthen pronounced sentence. These words fell like the knell of doom\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll those top-knots must be cut off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Temple seemed to remonstrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam,\xe2\x80\x9d he pursued, \xe2\x80\x9cI have a Master to serve whose kingdom is not of\r\nthis world: my mission is to mortify in these girls the lusts of the\r\nflesh; to teach them to clothe themselves with shame-facedness and\r\nsobriety, not with braided hair and costly apparel; and each of the\r\nyoung persons before us has a string of hair twisted in plaits which\r\nvanity itself might have woven; these, I repeat, must be cut off; think\r\nof the time wasted, of\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Brocklehurst was here interrupted: three other visitors, ladies,\r\nnow entered the room. They ought to have come a little sooner to have\r\nheard his lecture on dress, for they were splendidly attired in velvet,\r\nsilk, and furs. The two younger of the trio (fine girls of sixteen and\r\nseventeen) had grey beaver hats, then in fashion, shaded with ostrich\r\nplumes, and from under the brim of this graceful head-dress fell a\r\nprofusion of light tresses, elaborately curled; the elder lady was\r\nenveloped in a costly velvet shawl, trimmed with ermine, and she wore a\r\nfalse front of French curls.\r\n\r\nThese ladies were deferentially received by Miss Temple, as Mrs. and\r\nthe Misses Brocklehurst, and conducted to seats of honour at the top of\r\nthe room. It seems they had come in the carriage with their reverend\r\nrelative, and had been conducting a rummaging scrutiny of the room\r\nupstairs, while he transacted business with the housekeeper, questioned\r\nthe laundress, and lectured the superintendent.
