Will you let me have another cup?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was about again to revert to the probability of a union between Mr.\r\nRochester and the beautiful Blanche; but Ad\xc3\xa8le came in, and the\r\nconversation was turned into another channel.\r\n\r\nWhen once more alone, I reviewed the information I had got; looked into\r\nmy heart, examined its thoughts and feelings, and endeavoured to bring\r\nback with a strict hand such as had been straying through imagination\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nboundless and trackless waste, into the safe fold of common sense.\r\n\r\nArraigned at my own bar, Memory having given her evidence of the hopes,\r\nwishes, sentiments I had been cherishing since last night\xe2\x80\x94of the\r\ngeneral state of mind in which I had indulged for nearly a fortnight\r\npast; Reason having come forward and told, in her own quiet way, a\r\nplain, unvarnished tale, showing how I had rejected the real, and\r\nrabidly devoured the ideal;\xe2\x80\x94I pronounced judgment to this effect:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\nThat a greater fool than Jane Eyre had never breathed the breath of\r\nlife; that a more fantastic idiot had never surfeited herself on sweet\r\nlies, and swallowed poison as if it were nectar.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_You_,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9ca favourite with Mr. Rochester? _You_ gifted with the\r\npower of pleasing him? _You_ of importance to him in any way? Go! your\r\nfolly sickens me. And you have derived pleasure from occasional tokens\r\nof preference\xe2\x80\x94equivocal tokens shown by a gentleman of family and a man\r\nof the world to a dependent and a novice. How dared you? Poor stupid\r\ndupe!\xe2\x80\x94Could not even self-interest make you wiser? You repeated to\r\nyourself this morning the brief scene of last night?\xe2\x80\x94Cover your face\r\nand be ashamed! He said something in praise of your eyes, did he? Blind\r\npuppy! Open their bleared lids and look on your own accursed\r\nsenselessness! It does good to no woman to be flattered by her\r\nsuperior, who cannot possibly intend to marry her; and it is madness in\r\nall women to let a secret love kindle within them, which, if unreturned\r\nand unknown, must devour the life that feeds it; and, if discovered and\r\nresponded to, must lead, _ignis-fatuus_-like, into miry wilds whence\r\nthere is no extrication.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, then, Jane Eyre, to your sentence: to-morrow, place the glass\r\nbefore you, and draw in chalk your own picture, faithfully, without\r\nsoftening one defect; omit no harsh line, smooth away no displeasing\r\nirregularity; write under it, \xe2\x80\x98Portrait of a Governess, disconnected,\r\npoor, and plain.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfterwards, take a piece of smooth ivory\xe2\x80\x94you have one prepared in your\r\ndrawing-box: take your palette, mix your freshest, finest, clearest\r\ntints; choose your most delicate camel-hair pencils; delineate\r\ncarefully the loveliest face you can imagine; paint it in your softest\r\nshades and sweetest lines, according to the description given by Mrs.\r\nFairfax of Blanche Ingram; remember the raven ringlets, the oriental\r\neye;\xe2\x80\x94What! you revert to Mr. Rochester as a model! Order! No snivel!\xe2\x80\x94no\r\nsentiment!\xe2\x80\x94no regret! I will endure only sense and resolution. Recall\r\nthe august yet harmonious lineaments, the Grecian neck and bust; let\r\nthe round and dazzling arm be visible, and the delicate hand; omit\r\nneither diamond ring nor gold bracelet; portray faithfully the attire,\r\na\xc3\xabrial lace and glistening satin, graceful scarf and golden rose; call\r\nit \xe2\x80\x98Blanche, an accomplished lady of rank.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever, in future, you should chance to fancy Mr. Rochester thinks\r\nwell of you, take out these two pictures and compare them: say, \xe2\x80\x98Mr.\r\nRochester might probably win that noble lady\xe2\x80\x99s love, if he chose to\r\nstrive for it; is it likely he would waste a serious thought on this\r\nindigent and insignificant plebeian?\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll do it,\xe2\x80\x9d I resolved: and having framed this determination, I grew\r\ncalm, and fell asleep.\r\n\r\nI kept my word. An hour or two sufficed to sketch my own portrait in\r\ncrayons; and in less than a fortnight I had completed an ivory\r\nminiature of an imaginary Blanche Ingram. It looked a lovely face\r\nenough, and when compared with the real head in chalk, the contrast was\r\nas great as self-control could desire. I derived benefit from the task:\r\nit had kept my head and hands employed, and had given force and\r\nfixedness to the new impressions I wished to stamp indelibly on my\r\nheart.\r\n\r\nEre long, I had reason to congratulate myself on the course of\r\nwholesome discipline to which I had thus forced my feelings to submit.\r\nThanks to it, I was able to meet subsequent occurrences with a decent\r\ncalm, which, had they found me unprepared, I should probably have been\r\nunequal to maintain, even externally.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVII\r\n\r\n\r\nA week passed, and no news arrived of Mr. Rochester: ten days, and\r\nstill he did not come. Mrs. Fairfax said she should not be surprised if\r\nhe were to go straight from the Leas to London, and thence to the\r\nContinent, and not show his face again at Thornfield for a year to\r\ncome; he had not unfrequently quitted it in a manner quite as abrupt\r\nand unexpected. When I heard this, I was beginning to feel a strange\r\nchill and failing at the heart. I was actually permitting myself to\r\nexperience a sickening sense of disappointment; but rallying my wits,\r\nand recollecting my principles, I at once called my sensations to\r\norder; and it was wonderful how I got over the temporary blunder\xe2\x80\x94how I\r\ncleared up the mistake of supposing Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s movements a matter\r\nin which I had any cause to take a vital interest. Not that I humbled\r\nmyself by a slavish notion of inferiority: on the contrary, I just\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have nothing to do with the master of Thornfield, further than to\r\nreceive the salary he gives you for teaching his prot\xc3\xa9g\xc3\xa9e, and to be\r\ngrateful for such respectful and kind treatment as, if you do your\r\nduty, you have a right to expect at his hands. Be sure that is the only\r\ntie he seriously acknowledges between you and him; so don\xe2\x80\x99t make him\r\nthe object of your fine feelings, your raptures, agonies, and so forth.\r\nHe is not of your order: keep to your caste, and be too self-respecting\r\nto lavish the love of the whole heart, soul, and strength, where such a\r\ngift is not wanted and would be despised.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI went on with my day\xe2\x80\x99s business tranquilly; but ever and anon vague\r\nsuggestions kept wandering across my brain of reasons why I should quit\r\nThornfield; and I kept involuntarily framing advertisements and\r\npondering conjectures about new situations: these thoughts I did not\r\nthink to check; they might germinate and bear fruit if they could.\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester had been absent upwards of a fortnight, when the post\r\nbrought Mrs. Fairfax a letter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is from the master,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, as she looked at the direction. \xe2\x80\x9cNow\r\nI suppose we shall know whether we are to expect his return or not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd while she broke the seal and perused the document, I went on taking\r\nmy coffee (we were at breakfast): it was hot, and I attributed to that\r\ncircumstance a fiery glow which suddenly rose to my face. Why my hand\r\nshook, and why I involuntarily spilt half the contents of my cup into\r\nmy saucer, I did not choose to consider.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I sometimes think we are too quiet; but we run a chance of being\r\nbusy enough now: for a little while at least,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Fairfax, still\r\nholding the note before her spectacles.\r\n\r\nEre I permitted myself to request an explanation, I tied the string of\r\nAd\xc3\xa8le\xe2\x80\x99s pinafore, which happened to be loose: having helped her also to\r\nanother bun and refilled her mug with milk, I said, nonchalantly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester is not likely to return soon, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed he is\xe2\x80\x94in three days, he says: that will be next Thursday; and\r\nnot alone either. I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how many of the fine people at the Leas\r\nare coming with him: he sends directions for all the best bedrooms to\r\nbe prepared; and the library and drawing-rooms are to be cleaned out; I\r\nam to get more kitchen hands from the George Inn, at Millcote, and from\r\nwherever else I can; and the ladies will bring their maids and the\r\ngentlemen their valets: so we shall have a full house of it.\xe2\x80\x9d And Mrs.\r\nFairfax swallowed her breakfast and hastened away to commence\r\noperations.\r\n\r\nThe three days were, as she had foretold, busy enough. I had thought\r\nall the rooms at Thornfield beautifully clean and well arranged; but it\r\nappears I was mistaken. Three women were got to help; and such\r\nscrubbing, such brushing, such washing of paint and beating of carpets,\r\nsuch taking down and putting up of pictures, such polishing of mirrors\r\nand lustres, such lighting of fires in bedrooms, such airing of sheets\r\nand feather-beds on hearths, I never beheld, either before or since.\r\nAd\xc3\xa8le ran quite wild in the midst of it: the preparations for company\r\nand the prospect of their arrival, seemed to throw her into ecstasies.\r\nShe would have Sophie to look over all her \xe2\x80\x9ctoilettes,\xe2\x80\x9d as she called\r\nfrocks; to furbish up any that were \xe2\x80\x9c_pass\xc3\xa9es_,\xe2\x80\x9d and to air and arrange\r\nthe new. For herself, she did nothing but caper about in the front\r\nchambers, jump on and off the bedsteads, and lie on the mattresses and\r\npiled-up bolsters and pillows before the enormous fires roaring in the\r\nchimneys. From school duties she was exonerated: Mrs. Fairfax had\r\npressed me into her service, and I was all day in the storeroom,\r\nhelping (or hindering) her and the cook; learning to make custards and\r\ncheese-cakes and French pastry, to truss game and garnish\r\ndesert-dishes.\r\n\r\nThe party were expected to arrive on Thursday afternoon, in time for\r\ndinner at six. During the intervening period I had no time to nurse\r\nchimeras; and I believe I was as active and gay as anybody\xe2\x80\x94Ad\xc3\xa8le\r\nexcepted. Still, now and then, I received a damping check to my\r\ncheerfulness; and was, in spite of myself, thrown back on the region of\r\ndoubts and portents, and dark conjectures. This was when I chanced to\r\nsee the third-storey staircase door (which of late had always been kept\r\nlocked) open slowly, and give passage to the form of Grace Poole, in\r\nprim cap, white apron, and handkerchief; when I watched her glide along\r\nthe gallery, her quiet tread muffled in a list slipper; when I saw her\r\nlook into the bustling, topsy-turvy bedrooms,\xe2\x80\x94just say a word, perhaps,\r\nto the charwoman about the proper way to polish a grate, or clean a\r\nmarble mantelpiece, or take stains from papered walls, and then pass\r\non. She would thus descend to the kitchen once a day, eat her dinner,\r\nsmoke a moderate pipe on the hearth, and go back, carrying her pot of\r\nporter with her, for her private solace, in her own gloomy, upper\r\nhaunt. Only one hour in the twenty-four did she pass with her\r\nfellow-servants below; all the rest of her time was spent in some\r\nlow-ceiled, oaken chamber of the second storey: there she sat and\r\nsewed\xe2\x80\x94and probably laughed drearily to herself,\xe2\x80\x94as companionless as a\r\nprisoner in his dungeon.\r\n\r\nThe strangest thing of all was, that not a soul in the house, except\r\nme, noticed her habits, or seemed to marvel at them: no one discussed\r\nher position or employment; no one pitied her solitude or isolation. I\r\nonce, indeed, overheard part of a dialogue between Leah and one of the\r\ncharwomen, of which Grace formed the subject. Leah had been saying\r\nsomething I had not caught, and the charwoman remarked\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe gets good wages, I guess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Leah; \xe2\x80\x9cI wish I had as good; not that mine are to complain\r\nof,\xe2\x80\x94there\xe2\x80\x99s no stinginess at Thornfield; but they\xe2\x80\x99re not one fifth of\r\nthe sum Mrs. Poole receives. And she is laying by: she goes every\r\nquarter to the bank at Millcote. I should not wonder but she has saved\r\nenough to keep her independent if she liked to leave; but I suppose\r\nshe\xe2\x80\x99s got used to the place; and then she\xe2\x80\x99s not forty yet, and strong\r\nand able for anything. It is too soon for her to give up business.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is a good hand, I daresay,\xe2\x80\x9d said the charwoman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x94she understands what she has to do,\xe2\x80\x94nobody better,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined Leah\r\nsignificantly; \xe2\x80\x9cand it is not every one could fill her shoes\xe2\x80\x94not for\r\nall the money she gets.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat it is not!\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply. \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder whether the master\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe charwoman was going on; but here Leah turned and perceived me, and\r\nshe instantly gave her companion a nudge.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoesn\xe2\x80\x99t she know?\xe2\x80\x9d I heard the woman whisper.\r\n\r\nLeah shook her head, and the conversation was of course dropped. All I\r\nhad gathered from it amounted to this,\xe2\x80\x94that there was a mystery at\r\nThornfield; and that from participation in that mystery I was purposely\r\nexcluded.\r\n\r\nThursday came: all work had been completed the previous evening;\r\ncarpets were laid down, bed-hangings festooned, radiant white\r\ncounterpanes spread, toilet tables arranged, furniture rubbed, flowers\r\npiled in vases: both chambers and saloons looked as fresh and bright as\r\nhands could make them. The hall, too, was scoured; and the great carved\r\nclock, as well as the steps and banisters of the staircase, were\r\npolished to the brightness of glass; in the dining-room, the sideboard\r\nflashed resplendent with plate; in the drawing-room and boudoir, vases\r\nof exotics bloomed on all sides.\r\n\r\nAfternoon arrived: Mrs. Fairfax assumed her best black satin gown, her\r\ngloves, and her gold watch; for it was her part to receive the\r\ncompany,\xe2\x80\x94to conduct the ladies to their rooms, &c. Ad\xc3\xa8le, too, would be\r\ndressed: though I thought she had little chance of being introduced to\r\nthe party that day at least. However, to please her, I allowed Sophie\r\nto apparel her in one of her short, full muslin frocks. For myself, I\r\nhad no need to make any change; I should not be called upon to quit my\r\nsanctum of the schoolroom; for a sanctum it was now become to me,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ca\r\nvery pleasant refuge in time of trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt had been a mild, serene spring day\xe2\x80\x94one of those days which, towards\r\nthe end of March or the beginning of April, rise shining over the earth\r\nas heralds of summer. It was drawing to an end now; but the evening was\r\neven warm, and I sat at work in the schoolroom with the window open.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt gets late,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mrs. Fairfax, entering in rustling state. \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nglad I ordered dinner an hour after the time Mr. Rochester mentioned;\r\nfor it is past six now. I have sent John down to the gates to see if\r\nthere is anything on the road: one can see a long way from thence in\r\nthe direction of Millcote.\xe2\x80\x9d She went to the window. \xe2\x80\x9cHere he is!\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nshe. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, John\xe2\x80\x9d (leaning out), \xe2\x80\x9cany news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99re coming, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer. \xe2\x80\x9cThey\xe2\x80\x99ll be here in ten\r\nminutes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAd\xc3\xa8le flew to the window. I followed, taking care to stand on one side,\r\nso that, screened by the curtain, I could see without being seen.\r\n\r\nThe ten minutes John had given seemed very long, but at last wheels\r\nwere heard; four equestrians galloped up the drive, and after them came\r\ntwo open carriages. Fluttering veils and waving plumes filled the\r\nvehicles; two of the cavaliers were young, dashing-looking gentlemen;\r\nthe third was Mr. Rochester, on his black horse, Mesrour, Pilot\r\nbounding before him; at his side rode a lady, and he and she were the\r\nfirst of the party. Her purple riding-habit almost swept the ground,\r\nher veil streamed long on the breeze; mingling with its transparent\r\nfolds, and gleaming through them, shone rich raven ringlets.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Ingram!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Fairfax, and away she hurried to her post\r\nbelow.\r\n\r\nThe cavalcade, following the sweep of the drive, quickly turned the\r\nangle of the house, and I lost sight of it. Ad\xc3\xa8le now petitioned to go\r\ndown; but I took her on my knee, and gave her to understand that she\r\nmust not on any account think of venturing in sight of the ladies,\r\neither now or at any other time, unless expressly sent for: that Mr.\r\nRochester would be very angry, &c. \xe2\x80\x9cSome natural tears she shed\xe2\x80\x9d on\r\nbeing told this; but as I began to look very grave, she consented at\r\nlast to wipe them.\r\n\r\nA joyous stir was now audible in the hall: gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s deep tones and\r\nladies\xe2\x80\x99 silvery accents blent harmoniously together, and\r\ndistinguishable above all, though not loud, was the sonorous voice of\r\nthe master of Thornfield Hall, welcoming his fair and gallant guests\r\nunder its roof. Then light steps ascended the stairs; and there was a\r\ntripping through the gallery, and soft cheerful laughs, and opening and\r\nclosing doors, and, for a time, a hush.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cElles changent de toilettes,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ad\xc3\xa8le; who, listening attentively,\r\nhad followed every movement; and she sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChez maman,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cquand il y avait du monde, je le suivais\r\npartout, au salon et \xc3\xa0 leurs chambres; souvent je regardais les femmes\r\nde chambre coiffer et habiller les dames, et c\xe2\x80\x99\xc3\xa9tait si amusant: comme\r\ncela on apprend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t you feel hungry, Ad\xc3\xa8le?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMais oui, mademoiselle: voil\xc3\xa0 cinq ou six heures que nous n\xe2\x80\x99avons pas\r\nmang\xc3\xa9.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell now, while the ladies are in their rooms, I will venture down and\r\nget you something to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd issuing from my asylum with precaution, I sought a back-stairs\r\nwhich conducted directly to the kitchen. All in that region was fire\r\nand commotion; the soup and fish were in the last stage of projection,\r\nand the cook hung over her crucibles in a frame of mind and body\r\nthreatening spontaneous combustion. In the servants\xe2\x80\x99 hall two coachmen\r\nand three gentlemen\xe2\x80\x99s gentlemen stood or sat round the fire; the\r\nabigails, I suppose, were upstairs with their mistresses; the new\r\nservants, that had been hired from Millcote, were bustling about\r\neverywhere. Threading this chaos, I at last reached the larder; there I\r\ntook possession of a cold chicken, a roll of bread, some tarts, a plate\r\nor two and a knife and fork: with this booty I made a hasty retreat. I\r\nhad regained the gallery, and was just shutting the back-door behind\r\nme, when an accelerated hum warned me that the ladies were about to\r\nissue from their chambers. I could not proceed to the schoolroom\r\nwithout passing some of their doors, and running the risk of being\r\nsurprised with my cargo of victualage; so I stood still at this end,\r\nwhich, being windowless, was dark: quite dark now, for the sun was set\r\nand twilight gathering.\r\n\r\nPresently the chambers gave up their fair tenants one after another:\r\neach came out gaily and airily, with dress that gleamed lustrous\r\nthrough the dusk. For a moment they stood grouped together at the other\r\nextremity of the gallery, conversing in a key of sweet subdued\r\nvivacity: they then descended the staircase almost as noiselessly as a\r\nbright mist rolls down a hill. Their collective appearance had left on\r\nme an impression of high-born elegance, such as I had never before\r\nreceived.\r\n\r\nI found Ad\xc3\xa8le peeping through the schoolroom door, which she held ajar.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat beautiful ladies!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she in English. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, I wish I might go\r\nto them! Do you think Mr. Rochester will send for us by-and-bye, after\r\ndinner?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed, I don\xe2\x80\x99t; Mr. Rochester has something else to think about.\r\nNever mind the ladies to-night; perhaps you will see them to-morrow:\r\nhere is your dinner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was really hungry, so the chicken and tarts served to divert her\r\nattention for a time. It was well I secured this forage, or both she,\r\nI, and Sophie, to whom I conveyed a share of our repast, would have run\r\na chance of getting no dinner at all: every one downstairs was too much\r\nengaged to think of us. The dessert was not carried out till after\r\nnine; and at ten footmen were still running to and fro with trays and\r\ncoffee-cups. I allowed Ad\xc3\xa8le to sit up much later than usual; for she\r\ndeclared she could not possibly go to sleep while the doors kept\r\nopening and shutting below, and people bustling about. Besides, she\r\nadded, a message might possibly come from Mr. Rochester when she was\r\nundressed; \xe2\x80\x9cet alors quel dommage!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI told her stories as long as she would listen to them; and then for a\r\nchange I took her out into the gallery. The hall lamp was now lit, and\r\nit amused her to look over the balustrade and watch the servants\r\npassing backwards and forwards. When the evening was far advanced, a\r\nsound of music issued from the drawing-room, whither the piano had been\r\nremoved; Ad\xc3\xa8le and I sat down on the top step of the stairs to listen.\r\nPresently a voice blent with the rich tones of the instrument; it was a\r\nlady who sang, and very sweet her notes were. The solo over, a duet\r\nfollowed, and then a glee: a joyous conversational murmur filled up the\r\nintervals. I listened long: suddenly I discovered that my ear was\r\nwholly intent on analysing the mingled sounds, and trying to\r\ndiscriminate amidst the confusion of accents those of Mr. Rochester;\r\nand when it caught them, which it soon did, it found a further task in\r\nframing the tones, rendered by distance inarticulate, into words.\r\n\r\nThe clock struck eleven. I looked at Ad\xc3\xa8le, whose head leant against my\r\nshoulder; her eyes were waxing heavy, so I took her up in my arms and\r\ncarried her off to bed. It was near one before the gentlemen and ladies\r\nsought their chambers.\r\n\r\nThe next day was as fine as its predecessor: it was devoted by the\r\nparty to an excursion to some site in the neighbourhood. They set out\r\nearly in the forenoon, some on horseback, the rest in carriages; I\r\nwitnessed both the departure and the return. Miss Ingram, as before,\r\nwas the only lady equestrian; and, as before, Mr. Rochester galloped at\r\nher side; the two rode a little apart from the rest. I pointed out this\r\ncircumstance to Mrs. Fairfax, who was standing at the window with me\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said it was not likely they should think of being married,\xe2\x80\x9d said\r\nI, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you see Mr. Rochester evidently prefers her to any of the other\r\nladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, I daresay: no doubt he admires her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd she him,\xe2\x80\x9d I added; \xe2\x80\x9clook how she leans her head towards him as if\r\nshe were conversing confidentially; I wish I could see her face; I have\r\nnever had a glimpse of it yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will see her this evening,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Mrs. Fairfax. \xe2\x80\x9cI happened to\r\nremark to Mr. Rochester how much Ad\xc3\xa8le wished to be introduced to the\r\nladies, and he said: \xe2\x80\x98Oh! let her come into the drawing-room after\r\ndinner; and request Miss Eyre to accompany her.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; he said that from mere politeness: I need not go, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nanswered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I observed to him that as you were unused to company, I did not\r\nthink you would like appearing before so gay a party\xe2\x80\x94all strangers; and\r\nhe replied, in his quick way\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Nonsense! If she objects, tell her it is\r\nmy particular wish; and if she resists, say I shall come and fetch her\r\nin case of contumacy.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will not give him that trouble,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered. \xe2\x80\x9cI will go, if no\r\nbetter may be; but I don\xe2\x80\x99t like it. Shall you be there, Mrs. Fairfax?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; I pleaded off, and he admitted my plea. I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you how to\r\nmanage so as to avoid the embarrassment of making a formal entrance,\r\nwhich is the most disagreeable part of the business. You must go into\r\nthe drawing-room while it is empty, before the ladies leave the\r\ndinner-table; choose your seat in any quiet nook you like; you need not\r\nstay long after the gentlemen come in, unless you please: just let Mr.\r\nRochester see you are there and then slip away\xe2\x80\x94nobody will notice you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill these people remain long, do you think?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps two or three weeks, certainly not more. After the Easter\r\nrecess, Sir George Lynn, who was lately elected member for Millcote,\r\nwill have to go up to town and take his seat; I daresay Mr. Rochester\r\nwill accompany him: it surprises me that he has already made so\r\nprotracted a stay at Thornfield.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was with some trepidation that I perceived the hour approach when I\r\nwas to repair with my charge to the drawing-room. Ad\xc3\xa8le had been in a\r\nstate of ecstasy all day, after hearing she was to be presented to the\r\nladies in the evening; and it was not till Sophie commenced the\r\noperation of dressing her that she sobered down. Then the importance of\r\nthe process quickly steadied her, and by the time she had her curls\r\narranged in well-smoothed, drooping clusters, her pink satin frock put\r\non, her long sash tied, and her lace mittens adjusted, she looked as\r\ngrave as any judge. No need to warn her not to disarrange her attire:\r\nwhen she was dressed, she sat demurely down in her little chair, taking\r\ncare previously to lift up the satin skirt for fear she should crease\r\nit, and assured me she would not stir thence till I was ready. This I\r\nquickly was: my best dress (the silver-grey one, purchased for Miss\r\nTemple\xe2\x80\x99s wedding, and never worn since) was soon put on; my hair was\r\nsoon smoothed; my sole ornament, the pearl brooch, soon assumed. We\r\ndescended.\r\n\r\nFortunately there was another entrance to the drawing-room than that\r\nthrough the saloon where they were all seated at dinner. We found the\r\napartment vacant; a large fire burning silently on the marble hearth,\r\nand wax candles shining in bright solitude, amid the exquisite flowers\r\nwith which the tables were adorned. The crimson curtain hung before the\r\narch: slight as was the separation this drapery formed from the party\r\nin the adjoining saloon, they spoke in so low a key that nothing of\r\ntheir conversation could be distinguished beyond a soothing murmur.\r\n\r\nAd\xc3\xa8le, who appeared to be still under the influence of a most\r\nsolemnising impression, sat down, without a word, on the footstool I\r\npointed out to her. I retired to a window-seat, and taking a book from\r\na table near, endeavoured to read. Ad\xc3\xa8le brought her stool to my feet;\r\nere long she touched my knee.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is it, Ad\xc3\xa8le?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEst-ce que je ne puis pas prendre une seule de ces fleurs magnifiques,\r\nmademoiselle? Seulement pour completer ma toilette.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou think too much of your \xe2\x80\x98toilette,\xe2\x80\x99 Ad\xc3\xa8le: but you may have a\r\nflower.\xe2\x80\x9d And I took a rose from a vase and fastened it in her sash. She\r\nsighed a sigh of ineffable satisfaction, as if her cup of happiness\r\nwere now full. I turned my face away to conceal a smile I could not\r\nsuppress: there was something ludicrous as well as painful in the\r\nlittle Parisienne\xe2\x80\x99s earnest and innate devotion to matters of dress.\r\n\r\nA soft sound of rising now became audible; the curtain was swept back\r\nfrom the arch; through it appeared the dining-room, with its lit lustre\r\npouring down light on the silver and glass of a magnificent\r\ndessert-service covering a long table; a band of ladies stood in the\r\nopening; they entered, and the curtain fell behind them.\r\n\r\nThere were but eight; yet, somehow, as they flocked in, they gave the\r\nimpression of a much larger number. Some of them were very tall; many\r\nwere dressed in white; and all had a sweeping amplitude of array that\r\nseemed to magnify their persons as a mist magnifies the moon. I rose\r\nand curtseyed to them: one or two bent their heads in return, the\r\nothers only stared at me.\r\n\r\nThey dispersed about the room, reminding me, by the lightness and\r\nbuoyancy of their movements, of a flock of white plumy birds. Some of\r\nthem threw themselves in half-reclining positions on the sofas and\r\nottomans: some bent over the tables and examined the flowers and books:\r\nthe rest gathered in a group round the fire: all talked in a low but\r\nclear tone which seemed habitual to them. I knew their names\r\nafterwards, and may as well mention them now.\r\n\r\nFirst, there was Mrs. Eshton and two of her daughters. She had\r\nevidently been a handsome woman, and was well preserved still. Of her\r\ndaughters, the eldest, Amy, was rather little: na\xc3\xafve, and child-like in\r\nface and manner, and piquant in form; her white muslin dress and blue\r\nsash became her well. The second, Louisa, was taller and more elegant\r\nin figure; with a very pretty face, of that order the French term\r\n_minois chiffon\xc3\xa9_: both sisters were fair as lilies.\r\n\r\nLady Lynn was a large and stout personage of about forty, very erect,\r\nvery haughty-looking, richly dressed in a satin robe of changeful\r\nsheen: her dark hair shone glossily under the shade of an azure plume,\r\nand within the circlet of a band of gems.\r\n\r\nMrs. Colonel Dent was less showy; but, I thought, more lady-like. She\r\nhad a slight figure, a pale, gentle face, and fair hair. Her black\r\nsatin dress, her scarf of rich foreign lace, and her pearl ornaments,\r\npleased me better than the rainbow radiance of the titled dame.\r\n\r\nBut the three most distinguished\xe2\x80\x94partly, perhaps, because the tallest\r\nfigures of the band\xe2\x80\x94were the Dowager Lady Ingram and her daughters,\r\nBlanche and Mary. They were all three of the loftiest stature of women.\r\nThe Dowager might be between forty and fifty: her shape was still fine;\r\nher hair (by candle-light at least) still black; her teeth, too, were\r\nstill apparently perfect. Most people would have termed her a splendid\r\nwoman of her age: and so she was, no doubt, physically speaking; but\r\nthen there was an expression of almost insupportable haughtiness in her\r\nbearing and countenance. She had Roman features and a double chin,\r\ndisappearing into a throat like a pillar: these features appeared to me\r\nnot only inflated and darkened, but even furrowed with pride; and the\r\nchin was sustained by the same principle, in a position of almost\r\npreternatural erectness. She had, likewise, a fierce and a hard eye: it\r\nreminded me of Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s; she mouthed her words in speaking; her\r\nvoice was deep, its inflections very pompous, very dogmatical,\xe2\x80\x94very\r\nintolerable, in short. A crimson velvet robe, and a shawl turban of\r\nsome gold-wrought Indian fabric, invested her (I suppose she thought)\r\nwith a truly imperial dignity.\r\n\r\nBlanche and Mary were of equal stature,\xe2\x80\x94straight and tall as poplars.\r\nMary was too slim for her height, but Blanche was moulded like a Dian.\r\nI regarded her, of course, with special interest. First, I wished to\r\nsee whether her appearance accorded with Mrs. Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s description;\r\nsecondly, whether it at all resembled the fancy miniature I had painted\r\nof her; and thirdly\xe2\x80\x94it will out!\xe2\x80\x94whether it were such as I should fancy\r\nlikely to suit Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s taste.\r\n\r\nAs far as person went, she answered point for point, both to my picture\r\nand Mrs. Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s description. The noble bust, the sloping shoulders,\r\nthe graceful neck, the dark eyes and black ringlets were all there;\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nher face? Her face was like her mother\xe2\x80\x99s; a youthful unfurrowed\r\nlikeness: the same low brow, the same high features, the same pride. It\r\nwas not, however, so saturnine a pride! she laughed continually; her\r\nlaugh was satirical, and so was the habitual expression of her arched\r\nand haughty lip.\r\n\r\nGenius is said to be self-conscious. I cannot tell whether Miss Ingram\r\nwas a genius, but she was self-conscious\xe2\x80\x94remarkably self-conscious\r\nindeed. She entered into a discourse on botany with the gentle Mrs.\r\nDent. It seemed Mrs. Dent had not studied that science: though, as she\r\nsaid, she liked flowers, \xe2\x80\x9cespecially wild ones;\xe2\x80\x9d Miss Ingram had, and\r\nshe ran over its vocabulary with an air. I presently perceived she was\r\n(what is vernacularly termed) _trailing_ Mrs. Dent; that is, playing on\r\nher ignorance; her _trail_ might be clever, but it was decidedly not\r\ngood-natured. She played: her execution was brilliant; she sang: her\r\nvoice was fine; she talked French apart to her mamma; and she talked it\r\nwell, with fluency and with a good accent.\r\n\r\nMary had a milder and more open countenance than Blanche; softer\r\nfeatures too, and a skin some shades fairer (Miss Ingram was dark as a\r\nSpaniard)\xe2\x80\x94but Mary was deficient in life: her face lacked expression,\r\nher eye lustre; she had nothing to say, and having once taken her seat,\r\nremained fixed like a statue in its niche. The sisters were both\r\nattired in spotless white.\r\n\r\nAnd did I now think Miss Ingram such a choice as Mr. Rochester would be\r\nlikely to make? I could not tell\xe2\x80\x94I did not know his taste in female\r\nbeauty. If he liked the majestic, she was the very type of majesty:\r\nthen she was accomplished, sprightly. Most gentlemen would admire her,\r\nI thought; and that he _did_ admire her, I already seemed to have\r\nobtained proof: to remove the last shade of doubt, it remained but to\r\nsee them together.\r\n\r\nYou are not to suppose, reader, that Ad\xc3\xa8le has all this time been\r\nsitting motionless on the stool at my feet: no; when the ladies\r\nentered, she rose, advanced to meet them, made a stately reverence, and\r\nsaid with gravity\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBon jour, mesdames.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd Miss Ingram had looked down at her with a mocking air, and\r\nexclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cOh, what a little puppet!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nLady Lynn had remarked, \xe2\x80\x9cIt is Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s ward, I suppose\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nlittle French girl he was speaking of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Dent had kindly taken her hand, and given her a kiss. Amy and\r\nLouisa Eshton had cried out simultaneously\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat a love of a child!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then they had called her to a sofa, where she now sat, ensconced\r\nbetween them, chattering alternately in French and broken English;\r\nabsorbing not only the young ladies\xe2\x80\x99 attention, but that of Mrs. Eshton\r\nand Lady Lynn, and getting spoilt to her heart\xe2\x80\x99s content.\r\n\r\nAt last coffee is brought in, and the gentlemen are summoned. I sit in\r\nthe shade\xe2\x80\x94if any shade there be in this brilliantly-lit apartment; the\r\nwindow-curtain half hides me. Again the arch yawns; they come. The\r\ncollective appearance of the gentlemen, like that of the ladies, is\r\nvery imposing: they are all costumed in black; most of them are tall,\r\nsome young. Henry and Frederick Lynn are very dashing sparks indeed;\r\nand Colonel Dent is a fine soldierly man. Mr. Eshton, the magistrate of\r\nthe district, is gentleman-like: his hair is quite white, his eyebrows\r\nand whiskers still dark, which gives him something of the appearance of\r\na \xe2\x80\x9cp\xc3\xa8re noble de th\xc3\xa9\xc3\xa2tre.\xe2\x80\x9d Lord Ingram, like his sisters, is very tall;\r\nlike them, also, he is handsome; but he shares Mary\xe2\x80\x99s apathetic and\r\nlistless look: he seems to have more length of limb than vivacity of\r\nblood or vigour of brain.\r\n\r\nAnd where is Mr. Rochester?\r\n\r\nHe comes in last: I am not looking at the arch, yet I see him enter. I\r\ntry to concentrate my attention on those netting-needles, on the meshes\r\nof the purse I am forming\xe2\x80\x94I wish to think only of the work I have in my\r\nhands, to see only the silver beads and silk threads that lie in my\r\nlap; whereas, I distinctly behold his figure, and I inevitably recall\r\nthe moment when I last saw it; just after I had rendered him, what he\r\ndeemed, an essential service, and he, holding my hand, and looking down\r\non my face, surveyed me with eyes that revealed a heart full and eager\r\nto overflow; in whose emotions I had a part. How near had I approached\r\nhim at that moment! What had occurred since, calculated to change his\r\nand my relative positions? Yet now, how distant, how far estranged we\r\nwere! So far estranged, that I did not expect him to come and speak to\r\nme. I did not wonder, when, without looking at me, he took a seat at\r\nthe other side of the room, and began conversing with some of the\r\nladies.\r\n\r\nNo sooner did I see that his attention was riveted on them, and that I\r\nmight gaze without being observed, than my eyes were drawn\r\ninvoluntarily to his face; I could not keep their lids under control:\r\nthey would rise, and the irids would fix on him. I looked, and had an\r\nacute pleasure in looking,\xe2\x80\x94a precious yet poignant pleasure; pure gold,\r\nwith a steely point of agony: a pleasure like what the thirst-perishing\r\nman might feel who knows the well to which he has crept is poisoned,\r\nyet stoops and drinks divine draughts nevertheless.\r\n\r\nMost true is it that \xe2\x80\x9cbeauty is in the eye of the gazer.\xe2\x80\x9d My master\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncolourless, olive face, square, massive brow, broad and jetty eyebrows,\r\ndeep eyes, strong features, firm, grim mouth,\xe2\x80\x94all energy, decision,\r\nwill,\xe2\x80\x94were not beautiful, according to rule; but they were more than\r\nbeautiful to me; they were full of an interest, an influence that quite\r\nmastered me,\xe2\x80\x94that took my feelings from my own power and fettered them\r\nin his. I had not intended to love him; the reader knows I had wrought\r\nhard to extirpate from my soul the germs of love there detected; and\r\nnow, at the first renewed view of him, they spontaneously arrived,\r\ngreen and strong! He made me love him without looking at me.\r\n\r\nI compared him with his guests. What was the gallant grace of the\r\nLynns, the languid elegance of Lord Ingram,\xe2\x80\x94even the military\r\ndistinction of Colonel Dent, contrasted with his look of native pith\r\nand genuine power? I had no sympathy in their appearance, their\r\nexpression: yet I could imagine that most observers would call them\r\nattractive, handsome, imposing; while they would pronounce Mr.\r\nRochester at once harsh-featured and melancholy-looking. I saw them\r\nsmile, laugh\xe2\x80\x94it was nothing; the light of the candles had as much soul\r\nin it as their smile; the tinkle of the bell as much significance as\r\ntheir laugh. I saw Mr. Rochester smile:\xe2\x80\x94his stern features softened;\r\nhis eye grew both brilliant and gentle, its ray both searching and\r\nsweet. He was talking, at the moment, to Louisa and Amy Eshton. I\r\nwondered to see them receive with calm that look which seemed to me so\r\npenetrating: I expected their eyes to fall, their colour to rise under\r\nit; yet I was glad when I found they were in no sense moved. \xe2\x80\x9cHe is not\r\nto them what he is to me,\xe2\x80\x9d I thought: \xe2\x80\x9che is not of their kind. I\r\nbelieve he is of mine;\xe2\x80\x94I am sure he is\xe2\x80\x94I feel akin to him\xe2\x80\x94I understand\r\nthe language of his countenance and movements: though rank and wealth\r\nsever us widely, I have something in my brain and heart, in my blood\r\nand nerves, that assimilates me mentally to him. Did I say, a few days\r\nsince, that I had nothing to do with him but to receive my salary at\r\nhis hands? Did I forbid myself to think of him in any other light than\r\nas a paymaster? Blasphemy against nature! Every good, true, vigorous\r\nfeeling I have gathers impulsively round him. I know I must conceal my\r\nsentiments: I must smother hope; I must remember that he cannot care\r\nmuch for me. For when I say that I am of his kind, I do not mean that I\r\nhave his force to influence, and his spell to attract; I mean only that\r\nI have certain tastes and feelings in common with him. I must, then,\r\nrepeat continually that we are for ever sundered:\xe2\x80\x94and yet, while I\r\nbreathe and think, I must love him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nCoffee is handed. The ladies, since the gentlemen entered, have become\r\nlively as larks; conversation waxes brisk and merry. Colonel Dent and\r\nMr. Eshton argue on politics; their wives listen. The two proud\r\ndowagers, Lady Lynn and Lady Ingram, confabulate together. Sir\r\nGeorge\xe2\x80\x94whom, by-the-bye, I have forgotten to describe,\xe2\x80\x94a very big, and\r\nvery fresh-looking country gentleman, stands before their sofa,\r\ncoffee-cup in hand, and occasionally puts in a word. Mr. Frederick Lynn\r\nhas taken a seat beside Mary Ingram, and is showing her the engravings\r\nof a splendid volume: she looks, smiles now and then, but apparently\r\nsays little. The tall and phlegmatic Lord Ingram leans with folded arms\r\non the chair-back of the little and lively Amy Eshton; she glances up\r\nat him, and chatters like a wren: she likes him better than she does\r\nMr. Rochester. Henry Lynn has taken possession of an ottoman at the\r\nfeet of Louisa: Ad\xc3\xa8le shares it with him: he is trying to talk French\r\nwith her, and Louisa laughs at his blunders. With whom will Blanche\r\nIngram pair? She is standing alone at the table, bending gracefully\r\nover an album. She seems waiting to be sought; but she will not wait\r\ntoo long: she herself selects a mate.\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester, having quitted the Eshtons, stands on the hearth as\r\nsolitary as she stands by the table: she confronts him, taking her\r\nstation on the opposite side of the mantelpiece.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, I thought you were not fond of children?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNor am I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, what induced you to take charge of such a little doll as that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(pointing to Ad\xc3\xa8le). \xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you pick her up?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not pick her up; she was left on my hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have sent her to school.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI could not afford it: schools are so dear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, I suppose you have a governess for her: I saw a person with her\r\njust now\xe2\x80\x94is she gone? Oh, no! there she is still, behind the\r\nwindow-curtain. You pay her, of course; I should think it quite as\r\nexpensive,\xe2\x80\x94more so; for you have them both to keep in addition.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI feared\xe2\x80\x94or should I say, hoped?\xe2\x80\x94the allusion to me would make Mr.\r\nRochester glance my way; and I involuntarily shrank farther into the\r\nshade: but he never turned his eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have not considered the subject,\xe2\x80\x9d said he indifferently, looking\r\nstraight before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you men never do consider economy and common sense. You should\r\nhear mama on the chapter of governesses: Mary and I have had, I should\r\nthink, a dozen at least in our day; half of them detestable and the\r\nrest ridiculous, and all incubi\xe2\x80\x94were they not, mama?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you speak, my own?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe young lady thus claimed as the dowager\xe2\x80\x99s special property,\r\nreiterated her question with an explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dearest, don\xe2\x80\x99t mention governesses; the word makes me nervous. I\r\nhave suffered a martyrdom from their incompetency and caprice. I thank\r\nHeaven I have now done with them!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMrs. Dent here bent over to the pious lady and whispered something in\r\nher ear; I suppose, from the answer elicited, it was a reminder that\r\none of the anathematised race was present.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTant pis!\xe2\x80\x9d said her Ladyship, \xe2\x80\x9cI hope it may do her good!\xe2\x80\x9d Then, in a\r\nlower tone, but still loud enough for me to hear, \xe2\x80\x9cI noticed her; I am\r\na judge of physiognomy, and in hers I see all the faults of her class.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat are they, madam?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr. Rochester aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will tell you in your private ear,\xe2\x80\x9d replied she, wagging her turban\r\nthree times with portentous significancy.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut my curiosity will be past its appetite; it craves food now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAsk Blanche; she is nearer you than I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, don\xe2\x80\x99t refer him to me, mama! I have just one word to say of the\r\nwhole tribe; they are a nuisance. Not that I ever suffered much from\r\nthem; I took care to turn the tables. What tricks Theodore and I used\r\nto play on our Miss Wilsons, and Mrs. Greys, and Madame Jouberts! Mary\r\nwas always too sleepy to join in a plot with spirit. The best fun was\r\nwith Madame Joubert: Miss Wilson was a poor sickly thing, lachrymose\r\nand low-spirited, not worth the trouble of vanquishing, in short; and\r\nMrs. Grey was coarse and insensible; no blow took effect on her. But\r\npoor Madame Joubert! I see her yet in her raging passions, when we had\r\ndriven her to extremities\xe2\x80\x94spilt our tea, crumbled our bread and butter,\r\ntossed our books up to the ceiling, and played a charivari with the\r\nruler and desk, the fender and fire-irons. Theodore, do you remember\r\nthose merry days?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYaas, to be sure I do,\xe2\x80\x9d drawled Lord Ingram; \xe2\x80\x9cand the poor old stick\r\nused to cry out \xe2\x80\x98Oh you villains childs!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and then we sermonised her on\r\nthe presumption of attempting to teach such clever blades as we were,\r\nwhen she was herself so ignorant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe did; and, Tedo, you know, I helped you in prosecuting (or\r\npersecuting) your tutor, whey-faced Mr. Vining\xe2\x80\x94the parson in the pip,\r\nas we used to call him. He and Miss Wilson took the liberty of falling\r\nin love with each other\xe2\x80\x94at least Tedo and I thought so; we surprised\r\nsundry tender glances and sighs which we interpreted as tokens of \xe2\x80\x98la\r\nbelle passion,\xe2\x80\x99 and I promise you the public soon had the benefit of\r\nour discovery; we employed it as a sort of lever to hoist our\r\ndead-weights from the house. Dear mama, there, as soon as she got an\r\ninkling of the business, found out that it was of an immoral tendency.\r\nDid you not, my lady-mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly, my best. And I was quite right: depend on that: there are a\r\nthousand reasons why liaisons between governesses and tutors should\r\nnever be tolerated a moment in any well-regulated house; firstly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, gracious, mama! Spare us the enumeration! _Au reste_, we all know\r\nthem: danger of bad example to innocence of childhood; distractions and\r\nconsequent neglect of duty on the part of the attached\xe2\x80\x94mutual alliance\r\nand reliance; confidence thence resulting\xe2\x80\x94insolence accompanying\xe2\x80\x94mutiny\r\nand general blow-up. Am I right, Baroness Ingram, of Ingram Park?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy lily-flower, you are right now, as always.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen no more need be said: change the subject.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAmy Eshton, not hearing or not heeding this dictum, joined in with her\r\nsoft, infantine tone: \xe2\x80\x9cLouisa and I used to quiz our governess too; but\r\nshe was such a good creature, she would bear anything: nothing put her\r\nout. She was never cross with us; was she, Louisa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, never: we might do what we pleased; ransack her desk and her\r\nworkbox, and turn her drawers inside out; and she was so good-natured,\r\nshe would give us anything we asked for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose, now,\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ingram, curling her lip sarcastically, \xe2\x80\x9cwe\r\nshall have an abstract of the memoirs of all the governesses extant: in\r\norder to avert such a visitation, I again move the introduction of a\r\nnew topic. Mr. Rochester, do you second my motion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMadam, I support you on this point, as on every other.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen on me be the onus of bringing it forward. Signior Eduardo, are\r\nyou in voice to-night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDonna Bianca, if you command it, I will be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, signior, I lay on you my sovereign behest to furbish up your\r\nlungs and other vocal organs, as they will be wanted on my royal\r\nservice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho would not be the Rizzio of so divine a Mary?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA fig for Rizzio!\xe2\x80\x9d cried she, tossing her head with all its curls, as\r\nshe moved to the piano. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is my opinion the fiddler David must have\r\nbeen an insipid sort of fellow; I like black Bothwell better: to my\r\nmind a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him; and history\r\nmay say what it will of James Hepburn, but I have a notion, he was just\r\nthe sort of wild, fierce, bandit hero whom I could have consented to\r\ngift with my hand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGentlemen, you hear! Now which of you most resembles Bothwell?\xe2\x80\x9d cried\r\nMr. Rochester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI should say the preference lies with you,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Colonel Dent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn my honour, I am much obliged to you,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\nMiss Ingram, who had now seated herself with proud grace at the piano,\r\nspreading out her snowy robes in queenly amplitude, commenced a\r\nbrilliant prelude; talking meantime. She appeared to be on her high\r\nhorse to-night; both her words and her air seemed intended to excite\r\nnot only the admiration, but the amazement of her auditors: she was\r\nevidently bent on striking them as something very dashing and daring\r\nindeed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am so sick of the young men of the present day!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed she,\r\nrattling away at the instrument. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor, puny things, not fit to stir a\r\nstep beyond papa\xe2\x80\x99s park gates: nor to go even so far without mama\xe2\x80\x99s\r\npermission and guardianship! Creatures so absorbed in care about their\r\npretty faces, and their white hands, and their small feet; as if a man\r\nhad anything to do with beauty! As if loveliness were not the special\r\nprerogative of woman\xe2\x80\x94her legitimate appanage and heritage! I grant an\r\nugly _woman_ is a blot on the fair face of creation; but as to the\r\n_gentlemen_, let them be solicitous to possess only strength and\r\nvalour: let their motto be:\xe2\x80\x94Hunt, shoot, and fight: the rest is not\r\nworth a fillip. Such should be my device, were I a man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever I marry,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued after a pause which none interrupted,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am resolved my husband shall not be a rival, but a foil to me. I\r\nwill suffer no competitor near the throne; I shall exact an undivided\r\nhomage: his devotions shall not be shared between me and the shape he\r\nsees in his mirror. Mr. Rochester, now sing, and I will play for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am all obedience,\xe2\x80\x9d was the response.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere then is a Corsair-song. Know that I doat on Corsairs; and for\r\nthat reason, sing it _con spirito_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCommands from Miss Ingram\xe2\x80\x99s lips would put spirit into a mug of milk\r\nand water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care, then: if you don\xe2\x80\x99t please me, I will shame you by showing\r\nhow such things _should_ be done.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is offering a premium on incapacity: I shall now endeavour to\r\nfail.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGardez-vous en bien! If you err wilfully, I shall devise a\r\nproportionate punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Ingram ought to be clement, for she has it in her power to\r\ninflict a chastisement beyond mortal endurance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHa! explain!\xe2\x80\x9d commanded the lady.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPardon me, madam: no need of explanation; your own fine sense must\r\ninform you that one of your frowns would be a sufficient substitute for\r\ncapital punishment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSing!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, and again touching the piano, she commenced an\r\naccompaniment in spirited style.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow is my time to slip away,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I: but the tones that then\r\nsevered the air arrested me. Mrs. Fairfax had said Mr. Rochester\r\npossessed a fine voice: he did\xe2\x80\x94a mellow, powerful bass, into which he\r\nthrew his own feeling, his own force; finding a way through the ear to\r\nthe heart, and there waking sensation strangely. I waited till the last\r\ndeep and full vibration had expired\xe2\x80\x94till the tide of talk, checked an\r\ninstant, had resumed its flow; I then quitted my sheltered corner and\r\nmade my exit by the side-door, which was fortunately near. Thence a\r\nnarrow passage led into the hall: in crossing it, I perceived my sandal\r\nwas loose; I stopped to tie it, kneeling down for that purpose on the\r\nmat at the foot of the staircase. I heard the dining-room door unclose;\r\na gentleman came out; rising hastily, I stood face to face with him: it\r\nwas Mr. Rochester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you do?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very well, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did you not come and speak to me in the room?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought I might have retorted the question on him who put it: but I\r\nwould not take that freedom. I answered\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did not wish to disturb you, as you seemed engaged, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have you been doing during my absence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing particular; teaching Ad\xc3\xa8le as usual.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd getting a good deal paler than you were\xe2\x80\x94as I saw at first sight.\r\nWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing at all, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you take any cold that night you half drowned me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReturn to the drawing-room: you are deserting too early.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am tired, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at me for a minute.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd a little depressed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat about? Tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x94nothing, sir. I am not depressed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I affirm that you are: so much depressed that a few more words\r\nwould bring tears to your eyes\xe2\x80\x94indeed, they are there now, shining and\r\nswimming; and a bead has slipped from the lash and fallen on to the\r\nflag. If I had time, and was not in mortal dread of some prating prig\r\nof a servant passing, I would know what all this means. Well, to-night\r\nI excuse you; but understand that so long as my visitors stay, I expect\r\nyou to appear in the drawing-room every evening; it is my wish; don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nneglect it. Now go, and send Sophie for Ad\xc3\xa8le. Good-night, my\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He\r\nstopped, bit his lip, and abruptly left me.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nMerry days were these at Thornfield Hall; and busy days too: how\r\ndifferent from the first three months of stillness, monotony, and\r\nsolitude I had passed beneath its roof! All sad feelings seemed now\r\ndriven from the house, all gloomy associations forgotten: there was\r\nlife everywhere, movement all day long. You could not now traverse the\r\ngallery, once so hushed, nor enter the front chambers, once so\r\ntenantless, without encountering a smart lady\xe2\x80\x99s-maid or a dandy valet.\r\n\r\nThe kitchen, the butler\xe2\x80\x99s pantry, the servants\xe2\x80\x99 hall, the entrance\r\nhall, were equally alive; and the saloons were only left void and still\r\nwhen the blue sky and halcyon sunshine of the genial spring weather\r\ncalled their occupants out into the grounds. Even when that weather was\r\nbroken, and continuous rain set in for some days, no damp seemed cast\r\nover enjoyment: indoor amusements only became more lively and varied,\r\nin consequence of the stop put to outdoor gaiety.\r\n\r\nI wondered what they were going to do the first evening a change of\r\nentertainment was proposed: they spoke of \xe2\x80\x9cplaying charades,\xe2\x80\x9d but in my\r\nignorance I did not understand the term. The servants were called in,\r\nthe dining-room tables wheeled away, the lights otherwise disposed, the\r\nchairs placed in a semicircle opposite the arch. While Mr. Rochester\r\nand the other gentlemen directed these alterations, the ladies were\r\nrunning up and down stairs ringing for their maids. Mrs. Fairfax was\r\nsummoned to give information respecting the resources of the house in\r\nshawls, dresses, draperies of any kind; and certain wardrobes of the\r\nthird storey were ransacked, and their contents, in the shape of\r\nbrocaded and hooped petticoats, satin sacques, black modes, lace\r\nlappets, &c., were brought down in armfuls by the abigails; then a\r\nselection was made, and such things as were chosen were carried to the\r\nboudoir within the drawing-room.\r\n\r\nMeantime, Mr. Rochester had again summoned the ladies round him, and\r\nwas selecting certain of their number to be of his party. \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Ingram\r\nis mine, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d said he: afterwards he named the two Misses\r\nEshton, and Mrs. Dent. He looked at me: I happened to be near him, as I\r\nhad been fastening the clasp of Mrs. Dent\xe2\x80\x99s bracelet, which had got\r\nloose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you play?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. I shook my head. He did not insist, which I\r\nrather feared he would have done; he allowed me to return quietly to my\r\nusual seat.\r\n\r\nHe and his aids now withdrew behind the curtain: the other party, which\r\nwas headed by Colonel Dent, sat down on the crescent of chairs. One of\r\nthe gentlemen, Mr. Eshton, observing me, seemed to propose that I\r\nshould be asked to join them; but Lady Ingram instantly negatived the\r\nnotion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d I heard her say: \xe2\x80\x9cshe looks too stupid for any game of the sort.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nEre long a bell tinkled, and the curtain drew up. Within the arch, the\r\nbulky figure of Sir George Lynn, whom Mr. Rochester had likewise\r\nchosen, was seen enveloped in a white sheet: before him, on a table,\r\nlay open a large book; and at his side stood Amy Eshton, draped in Mr.\r\nRochester\xe2\x80\x99s cloak, and holding a book in her hand. Somebody, unseen,\r\nrang the bell merrily; then Ad\xc3\xa8le (who had insisted on being one of her\r\nguardian\xe2\x80\x99s party), bounded forward, scattering round her the contents\r\nof a basket of flowers she carried on her arm. Then appeared the\r\nmagnificent figure of Miss Ingram, clad in white, a long veil on her\r\nhead, and a wreath of roses round her brow; by her side walked Mr.\r\nRochester, and together they drew near the table. They knelt; while\r\nMrs. Dent and Louisa Eshton, dressed also in white, took up their\r\nstations behind them. A ceremony followed, in dumb show, in which it\r\nwas easy to recognise the pantomime of a marriage. At its termination,\r\nColonel Dent and his party consulted in whispers for two minutes, then\r\nthe Colonel called out\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBride!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Rochester bowed, and the curtain fell.\r\n\r\nA considerable interval elapsed before it again rose. Its second rising\r\ndisplayed a more elaborately prepared scene than the last. The\r\ndrawing-room, as I have before observed, was raised two steps above the\r\ndining-room, and on the top of the upper step, placed a yard or two\r\nback within the room, appeared a large marble basin, which I recognised\r\nas an ornament of the conservatory\xe2\x80\x94where it usually stood, surrounded\r\nby exotics, and tenanted by gold fish\xe2\x80\x94and whence it must have been\r\ntransported with some trouble, on account of its size and weight.\r\n\r\nSeated on the carpet, by the side of this basin, was seen Mr.\r\nRochester, costumed in shawls, with a turban on his head. His dark eyes\r\nand swarthy skin and Paynim features suited the costume exactly: he\r\nlooked the very model of an Eastern emir, an agent or a victim of the\r\nbowstring. Presently advanced into view Miss Ingram. She, too, was\r\nattired in oriental fashion: a crimson scarf tied sash-like round the\r\nwaist: an embroidered handkerchief knotted about her temples; her\r\nbeautifully-moulded arms bare, one of them upraised in the act of\r\nsupporting a pitcher, poised gracefully on her head. Both her cast of\r\nform and feature, her complexion and her general air, suggested the\r\nidea of some Israelitish princess of the patriarchal days; and such was\r\ndoubtless the character she intended to represent.\r\n\r\nShe approached the basin, and bent over it as if to fill her pitcher;\r\nshe again lifted it to her head. The personage on the well-brink now\r\nseemed to accost her; to make some request:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cShe hasted, let down her\r\npitcher on her hand, and gave him to drink.\xe2\x80\x9d From the bosom of his robe\r\nhe then produced a casket, opened it and showed magnificent bracelets\r\nand earrings; she acted astonishment and admiration; kneeling, he laid\r\nthe treasure at her feet; incredulity and delight were expressed by her\r\nlooks and gestures; the stranger fastened the bracelets on her arms and\r\nthe rings in her ears. It was Eliezer and Rebecca: the camels only were\r\nwanting.\r\n\r\nThe divining party again laid their heads together: apparently they\r\ncould not agree about the word or syllable the scene illustrated.\r\nColonel Dent, their spokesman, demanded \xe2\x80\x9cthe tableau of the whole;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwhereupon the curtain again descended.\r\n\r\nOn its third rising only a portion of the drawing-room was disclosed;\r\nthe rest being concealed by a screen, hung with some sort of dark and\r\ncoarse drapery. The marble basin was removed; in its place, stood a\r\ndeal table and a kitchen chair: these objects were visible by a very\r\ndim light proceeding from a horn lantern, the wax candles being all\r\nextinguished.\r\n\r\nAmidst this sordid scene, sat a man with his clenched hands resting on\r\nhis knees, and his eyes bent on the ground. I knew Mr. Rochester;\r\nthough the begrimed face, the disordered dress (his coat hanging loose\r\nfrom one arm, as if it had been almost torn from his back in a\r\nscuffle), the desperate and scowling countenance, the rough, bristling\r\nhair might well have disguised him. As he moved, a chain clanked; to\r\nhis wrists were attached fetters.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBridewell!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Colonel Dent, and the charade was solved.\r\n\r\nA sufficient interval having elapsed for the performers to resume their\r\nordinary costume, they re-entered the dining-room. Mr. Rochester led in\r\nMiss Ingram; she was complimenting him on his acting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cthat, of the three characters, I liked you in\r\nthe last best? Oh, had you but lived a few years earlier, what a\r\ngallant gentleman-highwayman you would have made!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs all the soot washed from my face?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, turning it towards\r\nher.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAlas! yes: the more\xe2\x80\x99s the pity! Nothing could be more becoming to your\r\ncomplexion than that ruffian\xe2\x80\x99s rouge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would like a hero of the road then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAn English hero of the road would be the next best thing to an Italian\r\nbandit; and that could only be surpassed by a Levantine pirate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, whatever I am, remember you are my wife; we were married an hour\r\nsince, in the presence of all these witnesses.\xe2\x80\x9d She giggled, and her\r\ncolour rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Dent,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Rochester, \xe2\x80\x9cit is your turn.\xe2\x80\x9d And as the\r\nother party withdrew, he and his band took the vacated seats. Miss\r\nIngram placed herself at her leader\xe2\x80\x99s right hand; the other diviners\r\nfilled the chairs on each side of him and her. I did not now watch the\r\nactors; I no longer waited with interest for the curtain to rise; my\r\nattention was absorbed by the spectators; my eyes, erewhile fixed on\r\nthe arch, were now irresistibly attracted to the semicircle of chairs.\r\nWhat charade Colonel Dent and his party played, what word they chose,\r\nhow they acquitted themselves, I no longer remember; but I still see\r\nthe consultation which followed each scene: I see Mr. Rochester turn to\r\nMiss Ingram, and Miss Ingram to him; I see her incline her head towards\r\nhim, till the jetty curls almost touch his shoulder and wave against\r\nhis cheek; I hear their mutual whisperings; I recall their interchanged\r\nglances; and something even of the feeling roused by the spectacle\r\nreturns in memory at this moment.\r\n\r\nI have told you, reader, that I had learnt to love Mr. Rochester: I\r\ncould not unlove him now, merely because I found that he had ceased to\r\nnotice me\xe2\x80\x94because I might pass hours in his presence, and he would\r\nnever once turn his eyes in my direction\xe2\x80\x94because I saw all his\r\nattentions appropriated by a great lady, who scorned to touch me with\r\nthe hem of her robes as she passed; who, if ever her dark and imperious\r\neye fell on me by chance, would withdraw it instantly as from an object\r\ntoo mean to merit observation. I could not unlove him, because I felt\r\nsure he would soon marry this very lady\xe2\x80\x94because I read daily in her a\r\nproud security in his intentions respecting her\xe2\x80\x94because I witnessed\r\nhourly in him a style of courtship which, if careless and choosing\r\nrather to be sought than to seek, was yet, in its very carelessness,\r\ncaptivating, and in its very pride, irresistible.\r\n\r\nThere was nothing to cool or banish love in these circumstances, though\r\nmuch to create despair. Much too, you will think, reader, to engender\r\njealousy: if a woman, in my position, could presume to be jealous of a\r\nwoman in Miss Ingram\xe2\x80\x99s. But I was not jealous: or very rarely;\xe2\x80\x94the\r\nnature of the pain I suffered could not be explained by that word. Miss\r\nIngram was a mark beneath jealousy: she was too inferior to excite the\r\nfeeling. Pardon the seeming paradox; I mean what I say. She was very\r\nshowy, but she was not genuine: she had a fine person, many brilliant\r\nattainments; but her mind was poor, her heart barren by nature: nothing\r\nbloomed spontaneously on that soil; no unforced natural fruit delighted\r\nby its freshness. She was not good; she was not original: she used to\r\nrepeat sounding phrases from books: she never offered, nor had, an\r\nopinion of her own. She advocated a high tone of sentiment; but she did\r\nnot know the sensations of sympathy and pity; tenderness and truth were\r\nnot in her. Too often she betrayed this, by the undue vent she gave to\r\na spiteful antipathy she had conceived against little Ad\xc3\xa8le: pushing\r\nher away with some contumelious epithet if she happened to approach\r\nher; sometimes ordering her from the room, and always treating her with\r\ncoldness and acrimony. Other eyes besides mine watched these\r\nmanifestations of character\xe2\x80\x94watched them closely, keenly, shrewdly.\r\nYes; the future bridegroom, Mr. Rochester himself, exercised over his\r\nintended a ceaseless surveillance; and it was from this sagacity\xe2\x80\x94this\r\nguardedness of his\xe2\x80\x94this perfect, clear consciousness of his fair one\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndefects\xe2\x80\x94this obvious absence of passion in his sentiments towards her,\r\nthat my ever-torturing pain arose.\r\n\r\nI saw he was going to marry her, for family, perhaps political reasons,\r\nbecause her rank and connections suited him; I felt he had not given\r\nher his love, and that her qualifications were ill adapted to win from\r\nhim that treasure. This was the point\xe2\x80\x94this was where the nerve was\r\ntouched and teased\xe2\x80\x94this was where the fever was sustained and fed: _she\r\ncould not charm him_.\r\n\r\nIf she had managed the victory at once, and he had yielded and\r\nsincerely laid his heart at her feet, I should have covered my face,\r\nturned to the wall, and (figuratively) have died to them. If Miss\r\nIngram had been a good and noble woman, endowed with force, fervour,\r\nkindness, sense, I should have had one vital struggle with two\r\ntigers\xe2\x80\x94jealousy and despair: then, my heart torn out and devoured, I\r\nshould have admired her\xe2\x80\x94acknowledged her excellence, and been quiet for\r\nthe rest of my days: and the more absolute her superiority, the deeper\r\nwould have been my admiration\xe2\x80\x94the more truly tranquil my quiescence.\r\nBut as matters really stood, to watch Miss Ingram\xe2\x80\x99s efforts at\r\nfascinating Mr. Rochester, to witness their repeated failure\xe2\x80\x94herself\r\nunconscious that they did fail; vainly fancying that each shaft\r\nlaunched hit the mark, and infatuatedly pluming herself on success,\r\nwhen her pride and self-complacency repelled further and further what\r\nshe wished to allure\xe2\x80\x94to witness _this_, was to be at once under\r\nceaseless excitation and ruthless restraint.\r\n\r\nBecause, when she failed, I saw how she might have succeeded. Arrows\r\nthat continually glanced off from Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s breast and fell\r\nharmless at his feet, might, I knew, if shot by a surer hand, have\r\nquivered keen in his proud heart\xe2\x80\x94have called love into his stern eye,\r\nand softness into his sardonic face; or, better still, without weapons\r\na silent conquest might have been won.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy can she not influence him more, when she is privileged to draw so\r\nnear to him?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked myself. \xe2\x80\x9cSurely she cannot truly like him, or not\r\nlike him with true affection! If she did, she need not coin her smiles\r\nso lavishly, flash her glances so unremittingly, manufacture airs so\r\nelaborate, graces so multitudinous. It seems to me that she might, by\r\nmerely sitting quietly at his side, saying little and looking less, get\r\nnigher his heart. I have seen in his face a far different expression\r\nfrom that which hardens it now while she is so vivaciously accosting\r\nhim; but then it came of itself: it was not elicited by meretricious\r\narts and calculated manoeuvres; and one had but to accept it\xe2\x80\x94to answer\r\nwhat he asked without pretension, to address him when needful without\r\ngrimace\xe2\x80\x94and it increased and grew kinder and more genial, and warmed\r\none like a fostering sunbeam. How will she manage to please him when\r\nthey are married? I do not think she will manage it; and yet it might\r\nbe managed; and his wife might, I verily believe, be the very happiest\r\nwoman the sun shines on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI have not yet said anything condemnatory of Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s project of\r\nmarrying for interest and connections. It surprised me when I first\r\ndiscovered that such was his intention: I had thought him a man\r\nunlikely to be influenced by motives so commonplace in his choice of a\r\nwife; but the longer I considered the position, education, &c., of the\r\nparties, the less I felt justified in judging and blaming either him or\r\nMiss Ingram for acting in conformity to ideas and principles instilled\r\ninto them, doubtless, from their childhood. All their class held these\r\nprinciples: I supposed, then, they had reasons for holding them such as\r\nI could not fathom. It seemed to me that, were I a gentleman like him,\r\nI would take to my bosom only such a wife as I could love; but the very\r\nobviousness of the advantages to the husband\xe2\x80\x99s own happiness offered by\r\nthis plan convinced me that there must be arguments against its general\r\nadoption of which I was quite ignorant: otherwise I felt sure all the\r\nworld would act as I wished to act.\r\n\r\nBut in other points, as well as this, I was growing very lenient to my\r\nmaster: I was forgetting all his faults, for which I had once kept a\r\nsharp look-out. It had formerly been my endeavour to study all sides of\r\nhis character: to take the bad with the good; and from the just\r\nweighing of both, to form an equitable judgment. Now I saw no bad. The\r\nsarcasm that had repelled, the harshness that had startled me once,\r\nwere only like keen condiments in a choice dish: their presence was\r\npungent, but their absence would be felt as comparatively insipid. And\r\nas for the vague something\xe2\x80\x94was it a sinister or a sorrowful, a\r\ndesigning or a desponding expression?\xe2\x80\x94that opened upon a careful\r\nobserver, now and then, in his eye, and closed again before one could\r\nfathom the strange depth partially disclosed; that something which used\r\nto make me fear and shrink, as if I had been wandering amongst\r\nvolcanic-looking hills, and had suddenly felt the ground quiver and\r\nseen it gape: that something, I, at intervals, beheld still; and with\r\nthrobbing heart, but not with palsied nerves. Instead of wishing to\r\nshun, I longed only to dare\xe2\x80\x94to divine it; and I thought Miss Ingram\r\nhappy, because one day she might look into the abyss at her leisure,\r\nexplore its secrets and analyse their nature.\r\n\r\nMeantime, while I thought only of my master and his future bride\xe2\x80\x94saw\r\nonly them, heard only their discourse, and considered only their\r\nmovements of importance\xe2\x80\x94the rest of the party were occupied with their\r\nown separate interests and pleasures. The Ladies Lynn and Ingram\r\ncontinued to consort in solemn conferences, where they nodded their two\r\nturbans at each other, and held up their four hands in confronting\r\ngestures of surprise, or mystery, or horror, according to the theme on\r\nwhich their gossip ran, like a pair of magnified puppets. Mild Mrs.\r\nDent talked with good-natured Mrs. Eshton; and the two sometimes\r\nbestowed a courteous word or smile on me. Sir George Lynn, Colonel\r\nDent, and Mr. Eshton discussed politics, or county affairs, or justice\r\nbusiness. Lord Ingram flirted with Amy Eshton; Louisa played and sang\r\nto and with one of the Messrs. Lynn; and Mary Ingram listened languidly\r\nto the gallant speeches of the other. Sometimes all, as with one\r\nconsent, suspended their by-play to observe and listen to the principal\r\nactors: for, after all, Mr. Rochester and\xe2\x80\x94because closely connected\r\nwith him\xe2\x80\x94Miss Ingram were the life and soul of the party. If he was\r\nabsent from the room an hour, a perceptible dulness seemed to steal\r\nover the spirits of his guests; and his re-entrance was sure to give a\r\nfresh impulse to the vivacity of conversation.\r\n\r\nThe want of his animating influence appeared to be peculiarly felt one\r\nday that he had been summoned to Millcote on business, and was not\r\nlikely to return till late. The afternoon was wet: a walk the party had\r\nproposed to take to see a gipsy camp, lately pitched on a common beyond\r\nHay, was consequently deferred. Some of the gentlemen were gone to the\r\nstables: the younger ones, together with the younger ladies, were\r\nplaying billiards in the billiard-room. The dowagers Ingram and Lynn\r\nsought solace in a quiet game at cards. Blanche Ingram, after having\r\nrepelled, by supercilious taciturnity, some efforts of Mrs. Dent and\r\nMrs. Eshton to draw her into conversation, had first murmured over some\r\nsentimental tunes and airs on the piano, and then, having fetched a\r\nnovel from the library, had flung herself in haughty listlessness on a\r\nsofa, and prepared to beguile, by the spell of fiction, the tedious\r\nhours of absence. The room and the house were silent: only now and then\r\nthe merriment of the billiard-players was heard from above.\r\n\r\nIt was verging on dusk, and the clock had already given warning of the\r\nhour to dress for dinner, when little Ad\xc3\xa8le, who knelt by me in the\r\ndrawing-room window-seat, suddenly exclaimed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVoil\xc3\xa0 Monsieur Rochester, qui revient!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI turned, and Miss Ingram darted forwards from her sofa: the others,\r\ntoo, looked up from their several occupations; for at the same time a\r\ncrunching of wheels and a splashing tramp of horse-hoofs became audible\r\non the wet gravel. A post-chaise was approaching.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat can possess him to come home in that style?\xe2\x80\x9d said Miss Ingram.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe rode Mesrour (the black horse), did he not, when he went out? and\r\nPilot was with him:\xe2\x80\x94what has he done with the animals?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she said this, she approached her tall person and ample garments so\r\nnear the window, that I was obliged to bend back almost to the breaking\r\nof my spine: in her eagerness she did not observe me at first, but when\r\nshe did, she curled her lip and moved to another casement.
