The\r\npost-chaise stopped; the driver rang the door-bell, and a gentleman\r\nalighted attired in travelling garb; but it was not Mr. Rochester; it\r\nwas a tall, fashionable-looking man, a stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow provoking!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Miss Ingram: \xe2\x80\x9cyou tiresome monkey!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(apostrophising Ad\xc3\xa8le), \xe2\x80\x9cwho perched you up in the window to give false\r\nintelligence?\xe2\x80\x9d and she cast on me an angry glance, as if I were in\r\nfault.\r\n\r\nSome parleying was audible in the hall, and soon the new-comer entered.\r\nHe bowed to Lady Ingram, as deeming her the eldest lady present.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt appears I come at an inopportune time, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen my\r\nfriend, Mr. Rochester, is from home; but I arrive from a very long\r\njourney, and I think I may presume so far on old and intimate\r\nacquaintance as to instal myself here till he returns.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis manner was polite; his accent, in speaking, struck me as being\r\nsomewhat unusual,\xe2\x80\x94not precisely foreign, but still not altogether\r\nEnglish: his age might be about Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s,\xe2\x80\x94between thirty and\r\nforty; his complexion was singularly sallow: otherwise he was a\r\nfine-looking man, at first sight especially. On closer examination, you\r\ndetected something in his face that displeased, or rather that failed\r\nto please. His features were regular, but too relaxed: his eye was\r\nlarge and well cut, but the life looking out of it was a tame, vacant\r\nlife\xe2\x80\x94at least so I thought.\r\n\r\nThe sound of the dressing-bell dispersed the party. It was not till\r\nafter dinner that I saw him again: he then seemed quite at his ease.\r\nBut I liked his physiognomy even less than before: it struck me as\r\nbeing at the same time unsettled and inanimate. His eye wandered, and\r\nhad no meaning in its wandering: this gave him an odd look, such as I\r\nnever remembered to have seen. For a handsome and not an\r\nunamiable-looking man, he repelled me exceedingly: there was no power\r\nin that smooth-skinned face of a full oval shape: no firmness in that\r\naquiline nose and small cherry mouth; there was no thought on the low,\r\neven forehead; no command in that blank, brown eye.\r\n\r\nAs I sat in my usual nook, and looked at him with the light of the\r\ngirandoles on the mantelpiece beaming full over him\xe2\x80\x94for he occupied an\r\narm-chair drawn close to the fire, and kept shrinking still nearer, as\r\nif he were cold, I compared him with Mr. Rochester. I think (with\r\ndeference be it spoken) the contrast could not be much greater between\r\na sleek gander and a fierce falcon: between a meek sheep and the\r\nrough-coated keen-eyed dog, its guardian.\r\n\r\nHe had spoken of Mr. Rochester as an old friend. A curious friendship\r\ntheirs must have been: a pointed illustration, indeed, of the old adage\r\nthat \xe2\x80\x9cextremes meet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTwo or three of the gentlemen sat near him, and I caught at times\r\nscraps of their conversation across the room. At first I could not make\r\nmuch sense of what I heard; for the discourse of Louisa Eshton and Mary\r\nIngram, who sat nearer to me, confused the fragmentary sentences that\r\nreached me at intervals. These last were discussing the stranger; they\r\nboth called him \xe2\x80\x9ca beautiful man.\xe2\x80\x9d Louisa said he was \xe2\x80\x9ca love of a\r\ncreature,\xe2\x80\x9d and she \xe2\x80\x9cadored him;\xe2\x80\x9d and Mary instanced his \xe2\x80\x9cpretty little\r\nmouth, and nice nose,\xe2\x80\x9d as her ideal of the charming.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what a sweet-tempered forehead he has!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Louisa,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cso\r\nsmooth\xe2\x80\x94none of those frowning irregularities I dislike so much; and\r\nsuch a placid eye and smile!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then, to my great relief, Mr. Henry Lynn summoned them to the other\r\nside of the room, to settle some point about the deferred excursion to\r\nHay Common.\r\n\r\nI was now able to concentrate my attention on the group by the fire,\r\nand I presently gathered that the new-comer was called Mr. Mason; then\r\nI learned that he was but just arrived in England, and that he came\r\nfrom some hot country: which was the reason, doubtless, his face was so\r\nsallow, and that he sat so near the hearth, and wore a surtout in the\r\nhouse. Presently the words Jamaica, Kingston, Spanish Town, indicated\r\nthe West Indies as his residence; and it was with no little surprise I\r\ngathered, ere long, that he had there first seen and become acquainted\r\nwith Mr. Rochester. He spoke of his friend\xe2\x80\x99s dislike of the burning\r\nheats, the hurricanes, and rainy seasons of that region. I knew Mr.\r\nRochester had been a traveller: Mrs. Fairfax had said so; but I thought\r\nthe continent of Europe had bounded his wanderings; till now I had\r\nnever heard a hint given of visits to more distant shores.\r\n\r\nI was pondering these things, when an incident, and a somewhat\r\nunexpected one, broke the thread of my musings. Mr. Mason, shivering as\r\nsome one chanced to open the door, asked for more coal to be put on the\r\nfire, which had burnt out its flame, though its mass of cinder still\r\nshone hot and red. The footman who brought the coal, in going out,\r\nstopped near Mr. Eshton\xe2\x80\x99s chair, and said something to him in a low\r\nvoice, of which I heard only the words, \xe2\x80\x9cold woman,\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cquite\r\ntroublesome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her she shall be put in the stocks if she does not take herself\r\noff,\xe2\x80\x9d replied the magistrate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94stop!\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted Colonel Dent. \xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t send her away, Eshton; we\r\nmight turn the thing to account; better consult the ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nspeaking aloud, he continued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLadies, you talked of going to Hay Common\r\nto visit the gipsy camp; Sam here says that one of the old Mother\r\nBunches is in the servants\xe2\x80\x99 hall at this moment, and insists upon being\r\nbrought in before \xe2\x80\x98the quality,\xe2\x80\x99 to tell them their fortunes. Would you\r\nlike to see her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely, colonel,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Lady Ingram, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would not encourage such a\r\nlow impostor? Dismiss her, by all means, at once!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I cannot persuade her to go away, my lady,\xe2\x80\x9d said the footman; \xe2\x80\x9cnor\r\ncan any of the servants: Mrs. Fairfax is with her just now, entreating\r\nher to be gone; but she has taken a chair in the chimney-corner, and\r\nsays nothing shall stir her from it till she gets leave to come in\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat does she want?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mrs. Eshton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98To tell the gentry their fortunes,\xe2\x80\x99 she says, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; and she swears\r\nshe must and will do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is she like?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired the Misses Eshton, in a breath.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA shockingly ugly old creature, miss; almost as black as a crock.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, she\xe2\x80\x99s a real sorceress!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Frederick Lynn. \xe2\x80\x9cLet us have her\r\nin, of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d rejoined his brother; \xe2\x80\x9cit would be a thousand pities to\r\nthrow away such a chance of fun.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear boys, what are you thinking about?\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Lynn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot possibly countenance any such inconsistent proceeding,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nchimed in the Dowager Ingram.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, mama, but you can\xe2\x80\x94and will,\xe2\x80\x9d pronounced the haughty voice of\r\nBlanche, as she turned round on the piano-stool; where till now she had\r\nsat silent, apparently examining sundry sheets of music. \xe2\x80\x9cI have a\r\ncuriosity to hear my fortune told: therefore, Sam, order the beldame\r\nforward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy darling Blanche! recollect\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do\xe2\x80\x94I recollect all you can suggest; and I must have my will\xe2\x80\x94quick,\r\nSam!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94yes\xe2\x80\x94yes!\xe2\x80\x9d cried all the juveniles, both ladies and gentlemen. \xe2\x80\x9cLet\r\nher come\xe2\x80\x94it will be excellent sport!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe footman still lingered. \xe2\x80\x9cShe looks such a rough one,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated Miss Ingram, and the man went.\r\n\r\nExcitement instantly seized the whole party: a running fire of raillery\r\nand jests was proceeding when Sam returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe won\xe2\x80\x99t come now,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cShe says it\xe2\x80\x99s not her mission to appear\r\nbefore the \xe2\x80\x98vulgar herd\xe2\x80\x99 (them\xe2\x80\x99s her words). I must show her into a\r\nroom by herself, and then those who wish to consult her must go to her\r\none by one.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see now, my queenly Blanche,\xe2\x80\x9d began Lady Ingram, \xe2\x80\x9cshe encroaches.\r\nBe advised, my angel girl\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShow her into the library, of course,\xe2\x80\x9d cut in the \xe2\x80\x9cangel girl.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cIt is\r\nnot my mission to listen to her before the vulgar herd either: I mean\r\nto have her all to myself. Is there a fire in the library?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x94but she looks such a tinkler.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCease that chatter, blockhead! and do my bidding.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain Sam vanished; and mystery, animation, expectation rose to full\r\nflow once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s ready now,\xe2\x80\x9d said the footman, as he reappeared. \xe2\x80\x9cShe wishes to\r\nknow who will be her first visitor.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I had better just look in upon her before any of the ladies\r\ngo,\xe2\x80\x9d said Colonel Dent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her, Sam, a gentleman is coming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSam went and returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe says, sir, that she\xe2\x80\x99ll have no gentlemen; they need not trouble\r\nthemselves to come near her; nor,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, with difficulty\r\nsuppressing a titter, \xe2\x80\x9cany ladies either, except the young, and\r\nsingle.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBy Jove, she has taste!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Henry Lynn.\r\n\r\nMiss Ingram rose solemnly: \xe2\x80\x9cI go first,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a tone which\r\nmight have befitted the leader of a forlorn hope, mounting a breach in\r\nthe van of his men.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, my best! oh, my dearest! pause\xe2\x80\x94reflect!\xe2\x80\x9d was her mama\xe2\x80\x99s cry; but\r\nshe swept past her in stately silence, passed through the door which\r\nColonel Dent held open, and we heard her enter the library.\r\n\r\nA comparative silence ensued. Lady Ingram thought it \xe2\x80\x9cle cas\xe2\x80\x9d to wring\r\nher hands: which she did accordingly. Miss Mary declared she felt, for\r\nher part, she never dared venture. Amy and Louisa Eshton tittered under\r\ntheir breath, and looked a little frightened.\r\n\r\nThe minutes passed very slowly: fifteen were counted before the\r\nlibrary-door again opened. Miss Ingram returned to us through the arch.\r\n\r\nWould she laugh? Would she take it as a joke? All eyes met her with a\r\nglance of eager curiosity, and she met all eyes with one of rebuff and\r\ncoldness; she looked neither flurried nor merry: she walked stiffly to\r\nher seat, and took it in silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Blanche?\xe2\x80\x9d said Lord Ingram.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did she say, sister?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did you think? How do you feel? Is she a real fortune-teller?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ndemanded the Misses Eshton.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, now, good people,\xe2\x80\x9d returned Miss Ingram, \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t press upon me.\r\nReally your organs of wonder and credulity are easily excited: you\r\nseem, by the importance of you all\xe2\x80\x94my good mama included\xe2\x80\x94ascribe to\r\nthis matter, absolutely to believe we have a genuine witch in the\r\nhouse, who is in close alliance with the old gentleman. I have seen a\r\ngipsy vagabond; she has practised in hackneyed fashion the science of\r\npalmistry and told me what such people usually tell. My whim is\r\ngratified; and now I think Mr. Eshton will do well to put the hag in\r\nthe stocks to-morrow morning, as he threatened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMiss Ingram took a book, leant back in her chair, and so declined\r\nfurther conversation. I watched her for nearly half-an-hour: during all\r\nthat time she never turned a page, and her face grew momently darker,\r\nmore dissatisfied, and more sourly expressive of disappointment. She\r\nhad obviously not heard anything to her advantage: and it seemed to me,\r\nfrom her prolonged fit of gloom and taciturnity, that she herself,\r\nnotwithstanding her professed indifference, attached undue importance\r\nto whatever revelations had been made her.\r\n\r\n\r\nDuring all that time she never turned a page\r\n\r\nMeantime, Mary Ingram, Amy and Louisa Eshton, declared they dared not\r\ngo alone; and yet they all wished to go. A negotiation was opened\r\nthrough the medium of the ambassador, Sam; and after much pacing to and\r\nfro, till, I think, the said Sam\xe2\x80\x99s calves must have ached with the\r\nexercise, permission was at last, with great difficulty, extorted from\r\nthe rigorous Sibyl, for the three to wait upon her in a body.\r\n\r\nTheir visit was not so still as Miss Ingram\xe2\x80\x99s had been: we heard\r\nhysterical giggling and little shrieks proceeding from the library; and\r\nat the end of about twenty minutes they burst the door open, and came\r\nrunning across the hall, as if they were half-scared out of their wits.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure she is something not right!\xe2\x80\x9d they cried, one and all. \xe2\x80\x9cShe\r\ntold us such things! She knows all about us!\xe2\x80\x9d and they sank breathless\r\ninto the various seats the gentlemen hastened to bring them.\r\n\r\nPressed for further explanation, they declared she had told them of\r\nthings they had said and done when they were mere children; described\r\nbooks and ornaments they had in their boudoirs at home: keepsakes that\r\ndifferent relations had presented to them. They affirmed that she had\r\neven divined their thoughts, and had whispered in the ear of each the\r\nname of the person she liked best in the world, and informed them of\r\nwhat they most wished for.\r\n\r\nHere the gentlemen interposed with earnest petitions to be further\r\nenlightened on these two last-named points; but they got only blushes,\r\nejaculations, tremors, and titters, in return for their importunity.\r\nThe matrons, meantime, offered vinaigrettes and wielded fans; and again\r\nand again reiterated the expression of their concern that their warning\r\nhad not been taken in time; and the elder gentlemen laughed, and the\r\nyounger urged their services on the agitated fair ones.\r\n\r\nIn the midst of the tumult, and while my eyes and ears were fully\r\nengaged in the scene before me, I heard a hem close at my elbow: I\r\nturned, and saw Sam.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, miss, the gipsy declares that there is another young\r\nsingle lady in the room who has not been to her yet, and she swears she\r\nwill not go till she has seen all. I thought it must be you: there is\r\nno one else for it. What shall I tell her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I will go by all means,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered: and I was glad of the\r\nunexpected opportunity to gratify my much-excited curiosity. I slipped\r\nout of the room, unobserved by any eye\xe2\x80\x94for the company were gathered in\r\none mass about the trembling trio just returned\xe2\x80\x94and I closed the door\r\nquietly behind me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you like, miss,\xe2\x80\x9d said Sam, \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll wait in the hall for you; and if\r\nshe frightens you, just call and I\xe2\x80\x99ll come in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Sam, return to the kitchen: I am not in the least afraid.\xe2\x80\x9d Nor was\r\nI; but I was a good deal interested and excited.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XIX\r\n\r\n\r\nThe library looked tranquil enough as I entered it, and the Sibyl\xe2\x80\x94if\r\nSibyl she were\xe2\x80\x94was seated snugly enough in an easy-chair at the\r\nchimney-corner. She had on a red cloak and a black bonnet: or rather, a\r\nbroad-brimmed gipsy hat, tied down with a striped handkerchief under\r\nher chin. An extinguished candle stood on the table; she was bending\r\nover the fire, and seemed reading in a little black book, like a\r\nprayer-book, by the light of the blaze: she muttered the words to\r\nherself, as most old women do, while she read; she did not desist\r\nimmediately on my entrance: it appeared she wished to finish a\r\nparagraph.\r\n\r\nI stood on the rug and warmed my hands, which were rather cold with\r\nsitting at a distance from the drawing-room fire. I felt now as\r\ncomposed as ever I did in my life: there was nothing indeed in the\r\ngipsy\xe2\x80\x99s appearance to trouble one\xe2\x80\x99s calm. She shut her book and slowly\r\nlooked up; her hat-brim partially shaded her face, yet I could see, as\r\nshe raised it, that it was a strange one. It looked all brown and\r\nblack: elf-locks bristled out from beneath a white band which passed\r\nunder her chin, and came half over her cheeks, or rather jaws: her eye\r\nconfronted me at once, with a bold and direct gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, and you want your fortune told?\xe2\x80\x9d she said, in a voice as decided\r\nas her glance, as harsh as her features.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care about it, mother; you may please yourself: but I ought to\r\nwarn you, I have no faith.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s like your impudence to say so: I expected it of you; I heard it\r\nin your step as you crossed the threshold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you? You\xe2\x80\x99ve a quick ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have; and a quick eye and a quick brain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need them all in your trade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do; especially when I\xe2\x80\x99ve customers like you to deal with. Why don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou tremble?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not cold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you turn pale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not sick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy don\xe2\x80\x99t you consult my art?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m not silly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe old crone \xe2\x80\x9cnichered\xe2\x80\x9d a laugh under her bonnet and bandage; she then\r\ndrew out a short black pipe, and lighting it began to smoke. Having\r\nindulged a while in this sedative, she raised her bent body, took the\r\npipe from her lips, and while gazing steadily at the fire, said very\r\ndeliberately\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are cold; you are sick; and you are silly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProve it,\xe2\x80\x9d I rejoined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will, in few words. You are cold, because you are alone: no contact\r\nstrikes the fire from you that is in you. You are sick; because the\r\nbest of feelings, the highest and the sweetest given to man, keeps far\r\naway from you. You are silly, because, suffer as you may, you will not\r\nbeckon it to approach, nor will you stir one step to meet it where it\r\nwaits you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe again put her short black pipe to her lips, and renewed her smoking\r\nwith vigour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might say all that to almost any one who you knew lived as a\r\nsolitary dependent in a great house.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI might say it to almost any one: but would it be true of almost any\r\none?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn my circumstances.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; just so, in _your_ circumstances: but find me another precisely\r\nplaced as you are.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be easy to find you thousands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou could scarcely find me one. If you knew it, you are peculiarly\r\nsituated: very near happiness; yes, within reach of it. The materials\r\nare all prepared; there only wants a movement to combine them. Chance\r\nlaid them somewhat apart; let them be once approached and bliss\r\nresults.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t understand enigmas. I never could guess a riddle in my life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you wish me to speak more plainly, show me your palm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I must cross it with silver, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI gave her a shilling: she put it into an old stocking-foot which she\r\ntook out of her pocket, and having tied it round and returned it, she\r\ntold me to hold out my hand. I did. She approached her face to the\r\npalm, and pored over it without touching it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is too fine,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cI can make nothing of such a hand as that;\r\nalmost without lines: besides, what is in a palm? Destiny is not\r\nwritten there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you,\xe2\x80\x9d said I.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cit is in the face: on the forehead, about the\r\neyes, in the lines of the mouth. Kneel, and lift up your head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! now you are coming to reality,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, as I obeyed her. \xe2\x80\x9cI shall\r\nbegin to put some faith in you presently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI knelt within half a yard of her. She stirred the fire, so that a\r\nripple of light broke from the disturbed coal: the glare, however, as\r\nshe sat, only threw her face into deeper shadow: mine, it illumined.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wonder with what feelings you came to me to-night,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, when\r\nshe had examined me a while. \xe2\x80\x9cI wonder what thoughts are busy in your\r\nheart during all the hours you sit in yonder room with the fine people\r\nflitting before you like shapes in a magic-lantern: just as little\r\nsympathetic communion passing between you and them as if they were\r\nreally mere shadows of human forms, and not the actual substance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel tired often, sleepy sometimes, but seldom sad.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you have some secret hope to buoy you up and please you with\r\nwhispers of the future?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot I. The utmost I hope is, to save money enough out of my earnings\r\nto set up a school some day in a little house rented by myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mean nutriment for the spirit to exist on: and sitting in that\r\nwindow-seat (you see I know your habits)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have learned them from the servants.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! you think yourself sharp. Well, perhaps I have: to speak truth, I\r\nhave an acquaintance with one of them, Mrs. Poole\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI started to my feet when I heard the name.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have\xe2\x80\x94have you?\xe2\x80\x9d thought I; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is diablerie in the business\r\nafter all, then!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t be alarmed,\xe2\x80\x9d continued the strange being; \xe2\x80\x9cshe\xe2\x80\x99s a safe hand is\r\nMrs. Poole: close and quiet; any one may repose confidence in her. But,\r\nas I was saying: sitting in that window-seat, do you think of nothing\r\nbut your future school? Have you no present interest in any of the\r\ncompany who occupy the sofas and chairs before you? Is there not one\r\nface you study? one figure whose movements you follow with at least\r\ncuriosity?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like to observe all the faces and all the figures.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut do you never single one from the rest\xe2\x80\x94or it may be, two?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do frequently; when the gestures or looks of a pair seem telling a\r\ntale: it amuses me to watch them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat tale do you like best to hear?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I have not much choice! They generally run on the same\r\ntheme\xe2\x80\x94courtship; and promise to end in the same catastrophe\xe2\x80\x94marriage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd do you like that monotonous theme?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPositively, I don\xe2\x80\x99t care about it: it is nothing to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing to you? When a lady, young and full of life and health,\r\ncharming with beauty and endowed with the gifts of rank and fortune,\r\nsits and smiles in the eyes of a gentleman you\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI what?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know\xe2\x80\x94and perhaps think well of.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know the gentlemen here. I have scarcely interchanged a\r\nsyllable with one of them; and as to thinking well of them, I consider\r\nsome respectable, and stately, and middle-aged, and others young,\r\ndashing, handsome, and lively: but certainly they are all at liberty to\r\nbe the recipients of whose smiles they please, without my feeling\r\ndisposed to consider the transaction of any moment to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know the gentlemen here? You have not exchanged a syllable\r\nwith one of them? Will you say that of the master of the house!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not at home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA profound remark! A most ingenious quibble! He went to Millcote this\r\nmorning, and will be back here to-night or to-morrow: does that\r\ncircumstance exclude him from the list of your acquaintance\xe2\x80\x94blot him,\r\nas it were, out of existence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; but I can scarcely see what Mr. Rochester has to do with the theme\r\nyou had introduced.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was talking of ladies smiling in the eyes of gentlemen; and of late\r\nso many smiles have been shed into Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s eyes that they\r\noverflow like two cups filled above the brim: have you never remarked\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester has a right to enjoy the society of his guests.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo question about his right: but have you never observed that, of all\r\nthe tales told here about matrimony, Mr. Rochester has been favoured\r\nwith the most lively and the most continuous?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe eagerness of a listener quickens the tongue of a narrator.\xe2\x80\x9d I said\r\nthis rather to myself than to the gipsy, whose strange talk, voice,\r\nmanner, had by this time wrapped me in a kind of dream. One unexpected\r\nsentence came from her lips after another, till I got involved in a web\r\nof mystification; and wondered what unseen spirit had been sitting for\r\nweeks by my heart watching its workings and taking record of every\r\npulse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEagerness of a listener!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated she: \xe2\x80\x9cyes; Mr. Rochester has sat by\r\nthe hour, his ear inclined to the fascinating lips that took such\r\ndelight in their task of communicating; and Mr. Rochester was so\r\nwilling to receive and looked so grateful for the pastime given him;\r\nyou have noticed this?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGrateful! I cannot remember detecting gratitude in his face.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDetecting! You have analysed, then. And what did you detect, if not\r\ngratitude?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said nothing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have seen love: have you not?\xe2\x80\x94and, looking forward, you have seen\r\nhim married, and beheld his bride happy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph! Not exactly. Your witch\xe2\x80\x99s skill is rather at fault sometimes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat the devil have you seen, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever mind: I came here to inquire, not to confess. Is it known that\r\nMr. Rochester is to be married?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and to the beautiful Miss Ingram.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShortly?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAppearances would warrant that conclusion: and, no doubt (though, with\r\nan audacity that wants chastising out of you, you seem to question it),\r\nthey will be a superlatively happy pair. He must love such a handsome,\r\nnoble, witty, accomplished lady; and probably she loves him, or, if not\r\nhis person, at least his purse. I know she considers the Rochester\r\nestate eligible to the last degree; though (God pardon me!) I told her\r\nsomething on that point about an hour ago which made her look wondrous\r\ngrave: the corners of her mouth fell half an inch. I would advise her\r\nblackaviced suitor to look out: if another comes, with a longer or\r\nclearer rent-roll,\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s dished\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, mother, I did not come to hear Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s fortune: I came to\r\nhear my own; and you have told me nothing of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour fortune is yet doubtful: when I examined your face, one trait\r\ncontradicted another. Chance has meted you a measure of happiness: that\r\nI know. I knew it before I came here this evening. She has laid it\r\ncarefully on one side for you. I saw her do it. It depends on yourself\r\nto stretch out your hand, and take it up: but whether you will do so,\r\nis the problem I study. Kneel again on the rug.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t keep me long; the fire scorches me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nShe did not stoop towards me, but only gazed, leaning back in her chair\r\n\r\nI knelt. She did not stoop towards me, but only gazed, leaning back in\r\nher chair. She began muttering,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe flame flickers in the eye; the eye shines like dew; it looks soft\r\nand full of feeling; it smiles at my jargon: it is susceptible;\r\nimpression follows impression through its clear sphere; where it ceases\r\nto smile, it is sad; an unconscious lassitude weighs on the lid: that\r\nsignifies melancholy resulting from loneliness. It turns from me; it\r\nwill not suffer further scrutiny; it seems to deny, by a mocking\r\nglance, the truth of the discoveries I have already made,\xe2\x80\x94to disown the\r\ncharge both of sensibility and chagrin: its pride and reserve only\r\nconfirm me in my opinion. The eye is favourable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs to the mouth, it delights at times in laughter; it is disposed to\r\nimpart all that the brain conceives; though I daresay it would be\r\nsilent on much the heart experiences. Mobile and flexible, it was never\r\nintended to be compressed in the eternal silence of solitude: it is a\r\nmouth which should speak much and smile often, and have human affection\r\nfor its interlocutor. That feature too is propitious.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI see no enemy to a fortunate issue but in the brow; and that brow\r\nprofesses to say,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I can live alone, if self-respect, and circumstances\r\nrequire me so to do. I need not sell my soul to buy bliss. I have an\r\ninward treasure born with me, which can keep me alive if all extraneous\r\ndelights should be withheld, or offered only at a price I cannot afford\r\nto give.\xe2\x80\x99 The forehead declares, \xe2\x80\x98Reason sits firm and holds the reins,\r\nand she will not let the feelings burst away and hurry her to wild\r\nchasms. The passions may rage furiously, like true heathens, as they\r\nare; and the desires may imagine all sorts of vain things: but judgment\r\nshall still have the last word in every argument, and the casting vote\r\nin every decision. Strong wind, earthquake-shock, and fire may pass by:\r\nbut I shall follow the guiding of that still small voice which\r\ninterprets the dictates of conscience.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell said, forehead; your declaration shall be respected. I have\r\nformed my plans\xe2\x80\x94right plans I deem them\xe2\x80\x94and in them I have attended to\r\nthe claims of conscience, the counsels of reason. I know how soon youth\r\nwould fade and bloom perish, if, in the cup of bliss offered, but one\r\ndreg of shame, or one flavour of remorse were detected; and I do not\r\nwant sacrifice, sorrow, dissolution\xe2\x80\x94such is not my taste. I wish to\r\nfoster, not to blight\xe2\x80\x94to earn gratitude, not to wring tears of\r\nblood\xe2\x80\x94no, nor of brine: my harvest must be in smiles, in endearments,\r\nin sweet\xe2\x80\x94That will do. I think I rave in a kind of exquisite delirium.\r\nI should wish now to protract this moment _ad infinitum_; but I dare\r\nnot. So far I have governed myself thoroughly. I have acted as I\r\ninwardly swore I would act; but further might try me beyond my\r\nstrength. Rise, Miss Eyre: leave me; the play is played out\xe2\x80\x99.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhere was I? Did I wake or sleep? Had I been dreaming? Did I dream\r\nstill? The old woman\xe2\x80\x99s voice had changed: her accent, her gesture, and\r\nall were familiar to me as my own face in a glass\xe2\x80\x94as the speech of my\r\nown tongue. I got up, but did not go. I looked; I stirred the fire, and\r\nI looked again: but she drew her bonnet and her bandage closer about\r\nher face, and again beckoned me to depart. The flame illuminated her\r\nhand stretched out: roused now, and on the alert for discoveries, I at\r\nonce noticed that hand. It was no more the withered limb of eld than my\r\nown; it was a rounded supple member, with smooth fingers, symmetrically\r\nturned; a broad ring flashed on the little finger, and stooping\r\nforward, I looked at it, and saw a gem I had seen a hundred times\r\nbefore. Again I looked at the face; which was no longer turned from\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94on the contrary, the bonnet was doffed, the bandage displaced, the\r\nhead advanced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Jane, do you know me?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the familiar voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly take off the red cloak, sir, and then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the string is in a knot\xe2\x80\x94help me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBreak it, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, then\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Off, ye lendings!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d And Mr. Rochester stepped out of his\r\ndisguise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, what a strange idea!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut well carried out, eh? Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith the ladies you must have managed well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut not with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did not act the character of a gipsy with me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat character did I act? I knew gipsies and\r\nfortune-tellers did not express themselves as this seeming old woman\r\nhad expressed herself; besides I had noted her feigned voice, her\r\nanxiety to conceal her features. I found all the party in the dining-room at supper, as Mr.\r\nRochester had said; they were not seated at table,\xe2\x80\x94the supper was\r\narranged on the sideboard; each had taken what he chose, and they stood\r\nabout here and there in groups, their plates and glasses in their\r\nhands.
