The company all stared at me as I passed straight\r\namong them. I sought Mr. Mason, delivered the message, and preceded him\r\nfrom the room: I ushered him into the library, and then I went\r\nupstairs.\r\n\r\nAt a late hour, after I had been in bed some time, I heard the visitors\r\nrepair to their chambers: I distinguished Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s voice, and\r\nheard him say, \xe2\x80\x9cThis way, Mason; this is your room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe spoke cheerfully: the gay tones set my heart at ease. I was soon\r\nasleep.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XX\r\n\r\n\r\nI had forgotten to draw my curtain, which I usually did, and also to\r\nlet down my window-blind. The consequence was, that when the moon,\r\nwhich was full and bright (for the night was fine), came in her course\r\nto that space in the sky opposite my casement, and looked in at me\r\nthrough the unveiled panes, her glorious gaze roused me. Awaking in the\r\ndead of night, I opened my eyes on her disk\xe2\x80\x94silver-white and crystal\r\nclear. It was beautiful, but too solemn: I half rose, and stretched my\r\narm to draw the curtain.\r\n\r\nGood God! What a cry!\r\n\r\nThe night\xe2\x80\x94its silence\xe2\x80\x94its rest, was rent in twain by a savage, a sharp,\r\na shrilly sound that ran from end to end of Thornfield Hall.\r\n\r\nMy pulse stopped: my heart stood still; my stretched arm was paralysed.\r\nThe cry died, and was not renewed. Indeed, whatever being uttered that\r\nfearful shriek could not soon repeat it: not the widest-winged condor\r\non the Andes could, twice in succession, send out such a yell from the\r\ncloud shrouding his eyrie. The thing delivering such utterance must\r\nrest ere it could repeat the effort.\r\n\r\nIt came out of the third storey; for it passed overhead. And\r\noverhead\xe2\x80\x94yes, in the room just above my chamber-ceiling\xe2\x80\x94I now heard a\r\nstruggle: a deadly one it seemed from the noise; and a half-smothered\r\nvoice shouted\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHelp! help! help!\xe2\x80\x9d three times rapidly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill no one come?\xe2\x80\x9d it cried; and then, while the staggering and\r\nstamping went on wildly, I distinguished through plank and plaster:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRochester! Rochester! for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, come!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA chamber-door opened: some one ran, or rushed, along the gallery.\r\nAnother step stamped on the flooring above and something fell; and\r\nthere was silence.\r\n\r\nI had put on some clothes, though horror shook all my limbs; I issued\r\nfrom my apartment. The sleepers were all aroused: ejaculations,\r\nterrified murmurs sounded in every room; door after door unclosed; one\r\nlooked out and another looked out; the gallery filled. Gentlemen and\r\nladies alike had quitted their beds; and \xe2\x80\x9cOh! what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWho is\r\nhurt?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat has happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cFetch a light!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cIs it fire?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAre there\r\nrobbers?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhere shall we run?\xe2\x80\x9d was demanded confusedly on all hands.\r\nBut for the moonlight they would have been in complete darkness. They\r\nran to and fro; they crowded together: some sobbed, some stumbled: the\r\nconfusion was inextricable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere the devil is Rochester?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Colonel Dent. \xe2\x80\x9cI cannot find him\r\nin his bed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere! here!\xe2\x80\x9d was shouted in return. \xe2\x80\x9cBe composed, all of you: I\xe2\x80\x99m\r\ncoming.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the door at the end of the gallery opened, and Mr. Rochester\r\nadvanced with a candle: he had just descended from the upper storey.\r\nOne of the ladies ran to him directly; she seized his arm: it was Miss\r\nIngram.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat awful event has taken place?\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9cSpeak! let us know the\r\nworst at once!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut don\xe2\x80\x99t pull me down or strangle me,\xe2\x80\x9d he replied: for the Misses\r\nEshton were clinging about him now; and the two dowagers, in vast white\r\nwrappers, were bearing down on him like ships in full sail.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll\xe2\x80\x99s right!\xe2\x80\x94all\xe2\x80\x99s right!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s a mere rehearsal of Much\r\nAdo about Nothing. Ladies, keep off, or I shall wax dangerous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd dangerous he looked: his black eyes darted sparks. Calming himself\r\nby an effort, he added\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA servant has had the nightmare; that is all. She\xe2\x80\x99s an excitable,\r\nnervous person: she construed her dream into an apparition, or\r\nsomething of that sort, no doubt; and has taken a fit with fright. Now,\r\nthen, I must see you all back into your rooms; for, till the house is\r\nsettled, she cannot be looked after. Gentlemen, have the goodness to\r\nset the ladies the example. Miss Ingram, I am sure you will not fail in\r\nevincing superiority to idle terrors. Amy and Louisa, return to your\r\nnests like a pair of doves, as you are. Mesdames\xe2\x80\x9d (to the dowagers),\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cyou will take cold to a dead certainty, if you stay in this chill\r\ngallery any longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd so, by dint of alternate coaxing and commanding, he contrived to\r\nget them all once more enclosed in their separate dormitories. I did\r\nnot wait to be ordered back to mine, but retreated unnoticed, as\r\nunnoticed I had left it.\r\n\r\nNot, however, to go to bed: on the contrary, I began and dressed myself\r\ncarefully. The sounds I had heard after the scream, and the words that\r\nhad been uttered, had probably been heard only by me; for they had\r\nproceeded from the room above mine: but they assured me that it was not\r\na servant\xe2\x80\x99s dream which had thus struck horror through the house; and\r\nthat the explanation Mr. Rochester had given was merely an invention\r\nframed to pacify his guests. I dressed, then, to be ready for\r\nemergencies. When dressed, I sat a long time by the window looking out\r\nover the silent grounds and silvered fields and waiting for I knew not\r\nwhat. It seemed to me that some event must follow the strange cry,\r\nstruggle, and call.\r\n\r\nNo: stillness returned: each murmur and movement ceased gradually, and\r\nin about an hour Thornfield Hall was again as hushed as a desert. It\r\nseemed that sleep and night had resumed their empire. Meantime the moon\r\ndeclined: she was about to set. Not liking to sit in the cold and\r\ndarkness, I thought I would lie down on my bed, dressed as I was. I\r\nleft the window, and moved with little noise across the carpet; as I\r\nstooped to take off my shoes, a cautious hand tapped low at the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I wanted?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you up?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the voice I expected to hear, viz., my master\xe2\x80\x99s.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd dressed?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome out, then, quietly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI obeyed. Mr. Rochester stood in the gallery holding a light.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want you,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9ccome this way: take your time, and make no\r\nnoise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy slippers were thin: I could walk the matted floor as softly as a\r\ncat. He glided up the gallery and up the stairs, and stopped in the\r\ndark, low corridor of the fateful third storey: I had followed and\r\nstood at his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you a sponge in your room?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked in a whisper.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any salts\xe2\x80\x94volatile salts?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo back and fetch both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI returned, sought the sponge on the washstand, the salts in my drawer,\r\nand once more retraced my steps. He still waited; he held a key in his\r\nhand: approaching one of the small, black doors, he put it in the lock;\r\nhe paused, and addressed me again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t turn sick at the sight of blood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think I shall not: I have never been tried yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt a thrill while I answered him; but no coldness, and no\r\nfaintness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust give me your hand,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9cit will not do to risk a fainting\r\nfit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI put my fingers into his. \xe2\x80\x9cWarm and steady,\xe2\x80\x9d was his remark: he turned\r\nthe key and opened the door.\r\n\r\nI saw a room I remembered to have seen before, the day Mrs. Fairfax\r\nshowed me over the house: it was hung with tapestry; but the tapestry\r\nwas now looped up in one part, and there was a door apparent, which had\r\nthen been concealed. This door was open; a light shone out of the room\r\nwithin: I heard thence a snarling, snatching sound, almost like a dog\r\nquarrelling. Mr. Rochester, putting down his candle, said to me, \xe2\x80\x9cWait\r\na minute,\xe2\x80\x9d and he went forward to the inner apartment. A shout of\r\nlaughter greeted his entrance; noisy at first, and terminating in Grace\r\nPoole\xe2\x80\x99s own goblin ha! ha! _She_ then was there. He made some sort of\r\narrangement without speaking, though I heard a low voice address him:\r\nhe came out and closed the door behind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHere, Jane!\xe2\x80\x9d he said; and I walked round to the other side of a large\r\nbed, which with its drawn curtains concealed a considerable portion of\r\nthe chamber. An easy-chair was near the bed-head: a man sat in it,\r\ndressed with the exception of his coat; he was still; his head leant\r\nback; his eyes were closed. Mr. Rochester held the candle over him; I\r\nrecognised in his pale and seemingly lifeless face\xe2\x80\x94the stranger, Mason:\r\nI saw too that his linen on one side, and one arm, was almost soaked in\r\nblood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHold the candle,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester, and I took it: he fetched a\r\nbasin of water from the washstand: \xe2\x80\x9cHold that,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. I obeyed. He\r\ntook the sponge, dipped it in, and moistened the corpse-like face; he\r\nasked for my smelling-bottle, and applied it to the nostrils. Mr. Mason\r\nshortly unclosed his eyes; he groaned. Mr. Rochester opened the shirt\r\nof the wounded man, whose arm and shoulder were bandaged: he sponged\r\naway blood, trickling fast down.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there immediate danger?\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mr. Mason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPooh! No\xe2\x80\x94a mere scratch. Don\xe2\x80\x99t be so overcome, man: bear up! I\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\nfetch a surgeon for you now, myself: you\xe2\x80\x99ll be able to be removed by\r\nmorning, I hope. Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall have to leave you in this room with this gentleman, for an\r\nhour, or perhaps two hours: you will sponge the blood as I do when it\r\nreturns: if he feels faint, you will put the glass of water on that\r\nstand to his lips, and your salts to his nose. You will not speak to\r\nhim on any pretext\xe2\x80\x94and\xe2\x80\x94Richard, it will be at the peril of your life if\r\nyou speak to her: open your lips\xe2\x80\x94agitate yourself\xe2\x80\x94and I\xe2\x80\x99ll not answer\r\nfor the consequences.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain the poor man groaned; he looked as if he dared not move; fear,\r\neither of death or of something else, appeared almost to paralyse him.\r\nMr. Rochester put the now bloody sponge into my hand, and I proceeded\r\nto use it as he had done. He watched me a second, then saying,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRemember!\xe2\x80\x94No conversation,\xe2\x80\x9d he left the room. I experienced a strange\r\nfeeling as the key grated in the lock, and the sound of his retreating\r\nstep ceased to be heard.\r\n\r\nHere then I was in the third storey, fastened into one of its mystic\r\ncells; night around me; a pale and bloody spectacle under my eyes and\r\nhands; a murderess hardly separated from me by a single door: yes\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nwas appalling\xe2\x80\x94the rest I could bear; but I shuddered at the thought of\r\nGrace Poole bursting out upon me.\r\n\r\nI must keep to my post, however. I must watch this ghastly\r\ncountenance\xe2\x80\x94these blue, still lips forbidden to unclose\xe2\x80\x94these eyes now\r\nshut, now opening, now wandering through the room, now fixing on me,\r\nand ever glazed with the dulness of horror. I must dip my hand again\r\nand again in the basin of blood and water, and wipe away the trickling\r\ngore. I must see the light of the unsnuffed candle wane on my\r\nemployment; the shadows darken on the wrought, antique tapestry round\r\nme, and grow black under the hangings of the vast old bed, and quiver\r\nstrangely over the doors of a great cabinet opposite\xe2\x80\x94whose front,\r\ndivided into twelve panels, bore, in grim design, the heads of the\r\ntwelve apostles, each enclosed in its separate panel as in a frame;\r\nwhile above them at the top rose an ebon crucifix and a dying Christ.\r\n\r\nAccording as the shifting obscurity and flickering gleam hovered here\r\nor glanced there, it was now the bearded physician, Luke, that bent his\r\nbrow; now St. John\xe2\x80\x99s long hair that waved; and anon the devilish face\r\nof Judas, that grew out of the panel, and seemed gathering life and\r\nthreatening a revelation of the arch-traitor\xe2\x80\x94of Satan himself\xe2\x80\x94in his\r\nsubordinate\xe2\x80\x99s form.\r\n\r\nAmidst all this, I had to listen as well as watch: to listen for the\r\nmovements of the wild beast or the fiend in yonder side den. But since\r\nMr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s visit it seemed spellbound: all the night I heard but\r\nthree sounds at three long intervals,\xe2\x80\x94a step creak, a momentary renewal\r\nof the snarling, canine noise, and a deep human groan.\r\n\r\nThen my own thoughts worried me. What crime was this, that lived\r\nincarnate in this sequestered mansion, and could neither be expelled\r\nnor subdued by the owner?\xe2\x80\x94what mystery, that broke out now in fire and\r\nnow in blood, at the deadest hours of night? What creature was it,\r\nthat, masked in an ordinary woman\xe2\x80\x99s face and shape, uttered the voice,\r\nnow of a mocking demon, and anon of a carrion-seeking bird of prey?\r\n\r\nAnd this man I bent over\xe2\x80\x94this commonplace, quiet stranger\xe2\x80\x94how had he\r\nbecome involved in the web of horror? and why had the Fury flown at\r\nhim? What made him seek this quarter of the house at an untimely\r\nseason, when he should have been asleep in bed? I had heard Mr.\r\nRochester assign him an apartment below\xe2\x80\x94what brought him here! And why,\r\nnow, was he so tame under the violence or treachery done him? Why did\r\nhe so quietly submit to the concealment Mr. Rochester enforced? Why\r\n_did_ Mr. Rochester enforce this concealment? His guest had been\r\noutraged, his own life on a former occasion had been hideously plotted\r\nagainst; and both attempts he smothered in secrecy and sank in\r\noblivion! Lastly, I saw Mr. Mason was submissive to Mr. Rochester; that\r\nthe impetuous will of the latter held complete sway over the inertness\r\nof the former: the few words which had passed between them assured me\r\nof this. It was evident that in their former intercourse, the passive\r\ndisposition of the one had been habitually influenced by the active\r\nenergy of the other: whence then had arisen Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s dismay when\r\nhe heard of Mr. Mason\xe2\x80\x99s arrival? Why had the mere name of this\r\nunresisting individual\xe2\x80\x94whom his word now sufficed to control like a\r\nchild\xe2\x80\x94fallen on him, a few hours since, as a thunderbolt might fall on\r\nan oak?\r\n\r\nOh! I could not forget his look and his paleness when he whispered:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I have got a blow\xe2\x80\x94I have got a blow, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d I could not forget\r\nhow the arm had trembled which he rested on my shoulder: and it was no\r\nlight matter which could thus bow the resolute spirit and thrill the\r\nvigorous frame of Fairfax Rochester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen will he come? When will he come?\xe2\x80\x9d I cried inwardly, as the night\r\nlingered and lingered\xe2\x80\x94as my bleeding patient drooped, moaned, sickened:\r\nand neither day nor aid arrived. I had, again and again, held the water\r\nto Mason\xe2\x80\x99s white lips; again and again offered him the stimulating\r\nsalts: my efforts seemed ineffectual: either bodily or mental\r\nsuffering, or loss of blood, or all three combined, were fast\r\nprostrating his strength. He moaned so, and looked so weak, wild, and\r\nlost, I feared he was dying; and I might not even speak to him.\r\n\r\nThe candle, wasted at last, went out; as it expired, I perceived\r\nstreaks of grey light edging the window curtains: dawn was then\r\napproaching. Presently I heard Pilot bark far below, out of his distant\r\nkennel in the courtyard: hope revived. Nor was it unwarranted: in five\r\nminutes more the grating key, the yielding lock, warned me my watch was\r\nrelieved. It could not have lasted more than two hours: many a week has\r\nseemed shorter.\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester entered, and with him the surgeon he had been to fetch.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Carter, be on the alert,\xe2\x80\x9d he said to this last: \xe2\x80\x9cI give you but\r\nhalf-an-hour for dressing the wound, fastening the bandages, getting\r\nthe patient downstairs and all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut is he fit to move, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo doubt of it; it is nothing serious; he is nervous, his spirits must\r\nbe kept up. Come, set to work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester drew back the thick curtain, drew up the holland blind,\r\nlet in all the daylight he could; and I was surprised and cheered to\r\nsee how far dawn was advanced: what rosy streaks were beginning to\r\nbrighten the east. Then he approached Mason, whom the surgeon was\r\nalready handling.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my good fellow, how are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s done for me, I fear,\xe2\x80\x9d was the faint reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a whit!\xe2\x80\x94courage! This day fortnight you\xe2\x80\x99ll hardly be a pin the\r\nworse of it: you\xe2\x80\x99ve lost a little blood; that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Carter, assure him\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x99s no danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can do that conscientiously,\xe2\x80\x9d said Carter, who had now undone the\r\nbandages; \xe2\x80\x9conly I wish I could have got here sooner: he would not have\r\nbled so much\xe2\x80\x94but how is this? The flesh on the shoulder is torn as well\r\nas cut. This wound was not done with a knife: there have been teeth\r\nhere!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe bit me,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cShe worried me like a tigress, when\r\nRochester got the knife from her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should not have yielded: you should have grappled with her at\r\nonce,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut under such circumstances, what could one do?\xe2\x80\x9d returned Mason. \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\nit was frightful!\xe2\x80\x9d he added, shuddering. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd I did not expect it: she\r\nlooked so quiet at first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI warned you,\xe2\x80\x9d was his friend\xe2\x80\x99s answer; \xe2\x80\x9cI said\xe2\x80\x94be on your guard when\r\nyou go near her. Besides, you might have waited till to-morrow, and had\r\nme with you: it was mere folly to attempt the interview to-night, and\r\nalone.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought I could have done some good.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou thought! you thought! Yes, it makes me impatient to hear you: but,\r\nhowever, you have suffered, and are likely to suffer enough for not\r\ntaking my advice; so I\xe2\x80\x99ll say no more. Carter\xe2\x80\x94hurry!\xe2\x80\x94hurry! The sun\r\nwill soon rise, and I must have him off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDirectly, sir; the shoulder is just bandaged. I must look to this\r\nother wound in the arm: she has had her teeth here too, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe sucked the blood: she said she\xe2\x80\x99d drain my heart,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mason.\r\n\r\nI saw Mr. Rochester shudder: a singularly marked expression of disgust,\r\nhorror, hatred, warped his countenance almost to distortion; but he\r\nonly said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, be silent, Richard, and never mind her gibberish: don\xe2\x80\x99t repeat\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish I could forget it,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will when you are out of the country: when you get back to Spanish\r\nTown, you may think of her as dead and buried\xe2\x80\x94or rather, you need not\r\nthink of her at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpossible to forget this night!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not impossible: have some energy, man. You thought you were as\r\ndead as a herring two hours since, and you are all alive and talking\r\nnow. There!\xe2\x80\x94Carter has done with you or nearly so; I\xe2\x80\x99ll make you decent\r\nin a trice. Jane\xe2\x80\x9d (he turned to me for the first time since his\r\nre-entrance), \xe2\x80\x9ctake this key: go down into my bedroom, and walk\r\nstraight forward into my dressing-room: open the top drawer of the\r\nwardrobe and take out a clean shirt and neck-handkerchief: bring them\r\nhere; and be nimble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI went; sought the repository he had mentioned, found the articles\r\nnamed, and returned with them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cgo to the other side of the bed while I order his\r\ntoilet; but don\xe2\x80\x99t leave the room: you may be wanted again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI retired as directed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas anybody stirring below when you went down, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired Mr.\r\nRochester presently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; all was very still.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall get you off cannily, Dick: and it will be better, both for\r\nyour sake, and for that of the poor creature in yonder. I have striven\r\nlong to avoid exposure, and I should not like it to come at last. Here,\r\nCarter, help him on with his waist-coat. Where did you leave your\r\nfurred cloak? You can\xe2\x80\x99t travel a mile without that, I know, in this\r\ndamned cold climate. In your room?\xe2\x80\x94Jane, run down to Mr. Mason\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nroom,\xe2\x80\x94the one next mine,\xe2\x80\x94and fetch a cloak you will see there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain I ran, and again returned, bearing an immense mantle lined and\r\nedged with fur.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, I\xe2\x80\x99ve another errand for you,\xe2\x80\x9d said my untiring master; \xe2\x80\x9cyou must\r\naway to my room again. What a mercy you are shod with velvet, Jane!\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nclod-hopping messenger would never do at this juncture. You must open\r\nthe middle drawer of my toilet-table and take out a little phial and a\r\nlittle glass you will find there,\xe2\x80\x94quick!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI flew thither and back, bringing the desired vessels.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s well! Now, doctor, I shall take the liberty of administering a\r\ndose myself, on my own responsibility. I got this cordial at Rome, of\r\nan Italian charlatan\xe2\x80\x94a fellow you would have kicked, Carter. It is not\r\na thing to be used indiscriminately, but it is good upon occasion: as\r\nnow, for instance. Jane, a little water.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe held out the tiny glass, and I half filled it from the water-bottle\r\non the washstand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do;\xe2\x80\x94now wet the lip of the phial.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did so; he measured twelve drops of a crimson liquid, and presented\r\nit to Mason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink, Richard: it will give you the heart you lack, for an hour or\r\nso.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut will it hurt me?\xe2\x80\x94is it inflammatory?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDrink! drink! drink!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Mason obeyed, because it was evidently useless to resist. He was\r\ndressed now: he still looked pale, but he was no longer gory and\r\nsullied. Mr. Rochester let him sit three minutes after he had swallowed\r\nthe liquid; he then took his arm\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow I am sure you can get on your feet,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9ctry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe patient rose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCarter, take him under the other shoulder. Be of good cheer, Richard;\r\nstep out\xe2\x80\x94that\xe2\x80\x99s it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do feel better,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Mr. Mason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sure you do. Now, Jane, trip on before us away to the backstairs;\r\nunbolt the side-passage door, and tell the driver of the post-chaise\r\nyou will see in the yard\xe2\x80\x94or just outside, for I told him not to drive\r\nhis rattling wheels over the pavement\xe2\x80\x94to be ready; we are coming: and,\r\nJane, if any one is about, come to the foot of the stairs and hem.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was by this time half-past five, and the sun was on the point of\r\nrising; but I found the kitchen still dark and silent. The side-passage\r\ndoor was fastened; I opened it with as little noise as possible: all\r\nthe yard was quiet; but the gates stood wide open, and there was a\r\npost-chaise, with horses ready harnessed, and driver seated on the box,\r\nstationed outside. I approached him, and said the gentlemen were\r\ncoming; he nodded: then I looked carefully round and listened. The\r\nstillness of early morning slumbered everywhere; the curtains were yet\r\ndrawn over the servants\xe2\x80\x99 chamber windows; little birds were just\r\ntwittering in the blossom-blanched orchard trees, whose boughs drooped\r\nlike white garlands over the wall enclosing one side of the yard; the\r\ncarriage horses stamped from time to time in their closed stables: all\r\nelse was still.\r\n\r\nThe gentlemen now appeared. Mason, supported by Mr. Rochester and the\r\nsurgeon, seemed to walk with tolerable ease: they assisted him into the\r\nchaise; Carter followed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care of him,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester to the latter, \xe2\x80\x9cand keep him at\r\nyour house till he is quite well: I shall ride over in a day or two to\r\nsee how he gets on. Richard, how is it with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe fresh air revives me, Fairfax.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave the window open on his side, Carter; there is no wind\xe2\x80\x94good-bye,\r\nDick.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFairfax\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell what is it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet her be taken care of; let her be treated as tenderly as may be:\r\nlet her\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d he stopped and burst into tears.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do my best; and have done it, and will do it,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer: he\r\nshut up the chaise door, and the vehicle drove away.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet would to God there was an end of all this!\xe2\x80\x9d added Mr. Rochester,\r\nas he closed and barred the heavy yard-gates.\r\n\r\nThis done, he moved with slow step and abstracted air towards a door in\r\nthe wall bordering the orchard. I, supposing he had done with me,\r\nprepared to return to the house; again, however, I heard him call\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane!\xe2\x80\x9d He had opened the portal and stood at it, waiting for me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome where there is some freshness, for a few moments,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nhouse is a mere dungeon: don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel it so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe glamour of inexperience is over your eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered; \xe2\x80\x9cand you\r\nsee it through a charmed medium: you cannot discern that the gilding is\r\nslime and the silk draperies cobwebs; that the marble is sordid slate,\r\nand the polished woods mere refuse chips and scaly bark. Now _here_\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(he pointed to the leafy enclosure we had entered) \xe2\x80\x9call is real, sweet,\r\nand pure.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe strayed down a walk edged with box, with apple trees, pear trees,\r\nand cherry trees on one side, and a border on the other full of all\r\nsorts of old-fashioned flowers, stocks, sweet-williams, primroses,\r\npansies, mingled with southernwood, sweet-briar, and various fragrant\r\nherbs. They were fresh now as a succession of April showers and gleams,\r\nfollowed by a lovely spring morning, could make them: the sun was just\r\nentering the dappled east, and his light illumined the wreathed and\r\ndewy orchard trees and shone down the quiet walks under them.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, will you have a flower?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe gathered a half-blown rose, the first on the bush, and offered it to\r\nme.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like this sunrise, Jane? That sky with its high and light\r\nclouds which are sure to melt away as the day waxes warm\xe2\x80\x94this placid\r\nand balmly atmosphere?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do, very much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have passed a strange night, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it has made you look pale\xe2\x80\x94were you afraid when I left you alone\r\nwith Mason?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was afraid of some one coming out of the inner room.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I had fastened the door\xe2\x80\x94I had the key in my pocket: I should have\r\nbeen a careless shepherd if I had left a lamb\xe2\x80\x94my pet lamb\xe2\x80\x94so near a\r\nwolf\xe2\x80\x99s den, unguarded: you were safe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill Grace Poole live here still, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh yes! don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble your head about her\xe2\x80\x94put the thing out of your\r\nthoughts.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet it seems to me your life is hardly secure while she stays.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever fear\xe2\x80\x94I will take care of myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the danger you apprehended last night gone by now, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot vouch for that till Mason is out of England: nor even then.\r\nTo live, for me, Jane, is to stand on a crater-crust which may crack\r\nand spue fire any day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut Mr. Mason seems a man easily led. Your influence, sir, is\r\nevidently potent with him: he will never set you at defiance or\r\nwilfully injure you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no! Mason will not defy me; nor, knowing it, will he hurt me\xe2\x80\x94but,\r\nunintentionally, he might in a moment, by one careless word, deprive\r\nme, if not of life, yet for ever of happiness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him to be cautious, sir: let him know what you fear, and show him\r\nhow to avert the danger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe laughed sardonically, hastily took my hand, and as hastily threw it\r\nfrom him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf I could do that, simpleton, where would the danger be? Annihilated\r\nin a moment. Ever since I have known Mason, I have only had to say to\r\nhim \xe2\x80\x98Do that,\xe2\x80\x99 and the thing has been done. But I cannot give him\r\norders in this case: I cannot say \xe2\x80\x98Beware of harming me, Richard;\xe2\x80\x99 for\r\nit is imperative that I should keep him ignorant that harm to me is\r\npossible. Now you look puzzled; and I will puzzle you further. You are\r\nmy little friend, are you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI like to serve you, sir, and to obey you in all that is right.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely: I see you do. I see genuine contentment in your gait and\r\nmien, your eye and face, when you are helping me and pleasing\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94working for me, and with me, in, as you characteristically say,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98_all that is right_:\xe2\x80\x99 for if I bid you do what you thought wrong,\r\nthere would be no light-footed running, no neat-handed alacrity, no\r\nlively glance and animated complexion. My friend would then turn to me,\r\nquiet and pale, and would say, \xe2\x80\x98No, sir; that is impossible: I cannot\r\ndo it, because it is wrong;\xe2\x80\x99 and would become immutable as a fixed\r\nstar. Well, you too have power over me, and may injure me: yet I dare\r\nnot show you where I am vulnerable, lest, faithful and friendly as you\r\nare, you should transfix me at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you have no more to fear from Mr. Mason than you have from me, sir,\r\nyou are very safe.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod grant it may be so! Here, Jane, is an arbour; sit down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe arbour was an arch in the wall, lined with ivy; it contained a\r\nrustic seat. Mr. Rochester took it, leaving room, however, for me: but\r\nI stood before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthe bench is long enough for two. You don\xe2\x80\x99t hesitate\r\nto take a place at my side, do you? Is that wrong, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI answered him by assuming it: to refuse would, I felt, have been\r\nunwise.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, my little friend, while the sun drinks the dew\xe2\x80\x94while all the\r\nflowers in this old garden awake and expand, and the birds fetch their\r\nyoung ones\xe2\x80\x99 breakfast out of the Thornfield, and the early bees do\r\ntheir first spell of work\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99ll put a case to you, which you must\r\nendeavour to suppose your own: but first, look at me, and tell me you\r\nare at ease, and not fearing that I err in detaining you, or that you\r\nerr in staying.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir; I am content.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell then, Jane, call to aid your fancy:\xe2\x80\x94suppose you were no longer a\r\ngirl well reared and disciplined, but a wild boy indulged from\r\nchildhood upwards; imagine yourself in a remote foreign land; conceive\r\nthat you there commit a capital error, no matter of what nature or from\r\nwhat motives, but one whose consequences must follow you through life\r\nand taint all your existence. Mind, I don\xe2\x80\x99t say a _crime_; I am not\r\nspeaking of shedding of blood or any other guilty act, which might make\r\nthe perpetrator amenable to the law: my word is _error_. The results of\r\nwhat you have done become in time to you utterly insupportable; you\r\ntake measures to obtain relief: unusual measures, but neither unlawful\r\nnor culpable. Still you are miserable; for hope has quitted you on the\r\nvery confines of life: your sun at noon darkens in an eclipse, which\r\nyou feel will not leave it till the time of setting. Bitter and base\r\nassociations have become the sole food of your memory: you wander here\r\nand there, seeking rest in exile: happiness in pleasure\xe2\x80\x94I mean in\r\nheartless, sensual pleasure\xe2\x80\x94such as dulls intellect and blights\r\nfeeling. Heart-weary and soul-withered, you come home after years of\r\nvoluntary banishment: you make a new acquaintance\xe2\x80\x94how or where no\r\nmatter: you find in this stranger much of the good and bright qualities\r\nwhich you have sought for twenty years, and never before encountered;\r\nand they are all fresh, healthy, without soil and without taint. Such\r\nsociety revives, regenerates: you feel better days come back\xe2\x80\x94higher\r\nwishes, purer feelings; you desire to recommence your life, and to\r\nspend what remains to you of days in a way more worthy of an immortal\r\nbeing. To attain this end, are you justified in overleaping an obstacle\r\nof custom\xe2\x80\x94a mere conventional impediment which neither your conscience\r\nsanctifies nor your judgment approves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused for an answer: and what was I to say? Oh, for some good\r\nspirit to suggest a judicious and satisfactory response! Vain\r\naspiration! The west wind whispered in the ivy round me; but no gentle\r\nAriel borrowed its breath as a medium of speech: the birds sang in the\r\ntree-tops; but their song, however sweet, was inarticulate.\r\n\r\nAgain Mr. Rochester propounded his query:\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the wandering and sinful, but now rest-seeking and repentant, man\r\njustified in daring the world\xe2\x80\x99s opinion, in order to attach to him for\r\never this gentle, gracious, genial stranger, thereby securing his own\r\npeace of mind and regeneration of life?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered, \xe2\x80\x9ca wanderer\xe2\x80\x99s repose or a sinner\xe2\x80\x99s reformation\r\nshould never depend on a fellow-creature. Men and women die;\r\nphilosophers falter in wisdom, and Christians in goodness: if any one\r\nyou know has suffered and erred, let him look higher than his equals\r\nfor strength to amend and solace to heal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the instrument\xe2\x80\x94the instrument! God, who does the work, ordains the\r\ninstrument. I have myself\xe2\x80\x94I tell it you without parable\xe2\x80\x94been a worldly,\r\ndissipated, restless man; and I believe I have found the instrument for\r\nmy cure in\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused: the birds went on carolling, the leaves lightly rustling. I\r\nalmost wondered they did not check their songs and whispers to catch\r\nthe suspended revelation; but they would have had to wait many\r\nminutes\xe2\x80\x94so long was the silence protracted. At last I looked up at the\r\ntardy speaker: he was looking eagerly at me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle friend,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, in quite a changed tone\xe2\x80\x94while his face\r\nchanged too, losing all its softness and gravity, and becoming harsh\r\nand sarcastic\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cyou have noticed my tender penchant for Miss Ingram:\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t you think if I married her she would regenerate me with a\r\nvengeance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe got up instantly, went quite to the other end of the walk, and when\r\nhe came back he was humming a tune.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, stopping before me, \xe2\x80\x9cyou are quite pale with\r\nyour vigils: don\xe2\x80\x99t you curse me for disturbing your rest?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCurse you? No, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShake hands in confirmation of the word. What cold fingers! They were\r\nwarmer last night when I touched them at the door of the mysterious\r\nchamber. Jane, when will you watch with me again?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhenever I can be useful, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor instance, the night before I am married! I am sure I shall not be\r\nable to sleep. Will you promise to sit up with me to bear me company?\r\nTo you I can talk of my lovely one: for now you have seen her and know\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99s a rare one, is she not, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA strapper\xe2\x80\x94a real strapper, Jane: big, brown, and buxom; with hair\r\njust such as the ladies of Carthage must have had. Bless me! there\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nDent and Lynn in the stables! Go in by the shrubbery, through that\r\nwicket.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs I went one way, he went another, and I heard him in the yard, saying\r\ncheerfully\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMason got the start of you all this morning; he was gone before\r\nsunrise: I rose at four to see him off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXI\r\n\r\n\r\nPresentiments are strange things! and so are sympathies; and so are\r\nsigns; and the three combined make one mystery to which humanity has\r\nnot yet found the key. I never laughed at presentiments in my life,\r\nbecause I have had strange ones of my own. Sympathies, I believe, exist\r\n(for instance, between far-distant, long-absent, wholly estranged\r\nrelatives asserting, notwithstanding their alienation, the unity of the\r\nsource to which each traces his origin) whose workings baffle mortal\r\ncomprehension. And signs, for aught we know, may be but the sympathies\r\nof Nature with man.\r\n\r\nWhen I was a little girl, only six years old, I one night heard Bessie\r\nLeaven say to Martha Abbot that she had been dreaming about a little\r\nchild; and that to dream of children was a sure sign of trouble, either\r\nto one\xe2\x80\x99s self or one\xe2\x80\x99s kin. The saying might have worn out of my\r\nmemory, had not a circumstance immediately followed which served\r\nindelibly to fix it there. The next day Bessie was sent for home to the\r\ndeathbed of her little sister.\r\n\r\nOf late I had often recalled this saying and this incident; for during\r\nthe past week scarcely a night had gone over my couch that had not\r\nbrought with it a dream of an infant, which I sometimes hushed in my\r\narms, sometimes dandled on my knee, sometimes watched playing with\r\ndaisies on a lawn, or again, dabbling its hands in running water. It\r\nwas a wailing child this night, and a laughing one the next: now it\r\nnestled close to me, and now it ran from me; but whatever mood the\r\napparition evinced, whatever aspect it wore, it failed not for seven\r\nsuccessive nights to meet me the moment I entered the land of slumber.\r\n\r\nI did not like this iteration of one idea\xe2\x80\x94this strange recurrence of\r\none image, and I grew nervous as bedtime approached and the hour of the\r\nvision drew near. It was from companionship with this baby-phantom I\r\nhad been roused on that moonlight night when I heard the cry; and it\r\nwas on the afternoon of the day following I was summoned downstairs by\r\na message that some one wanted me in Mrs. Fairfax\xe2\x80\x99s room. On repairing\r\nthither, I found a man waiting for me, having the appearance of a\r\ngentleman\xe2\x80\x99s servant: he was dressed in deep mourning, and the hat he\r\nheld in his hand was surrounded with a crape band.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI daresay you hardly remember me, Miss,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, rising as I entered;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbut my name is Leaven: I lived coachman with Mrs. Reed when you were\r\nat Gateshead, eight or nine years since, and I live there still.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Robert! how do you do? I remember you very well: you used to give\r\nme a ride sometimes on Miss Georgiana\xe2\x80\x99s bay pony. And how is Bessie?\r\nYou are married to Bessie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Miss: my wife is very hearty, thank you; she brought me another\r\nlittle one about two months since\xe2\x80\x94we have three now\xe2\x80\x94and both mother and\r\nchild are thriving.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd are the family well at the house, Robert?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am sorry I can\xe2\x80\x99t give you better news of them, Miss: they are very\r\nbadly at present\xe2\x80\x94in great trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope no one is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, glancing at his black dress. He too\r\nlooked down at the crape round his hat and replied\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. John died yesterday was a week, at his chambers in London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how does his mother bear it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, you see, Miss Eyre, it is not a common mishap: his life has been\r\nvery wild: these last three years he gave himself up to strange ways,\r\nand his death was shocking.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI heard from Bessie he was not doing well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoing well! He could not do worse: he ruined his health and his estate\r\namongst the worst men and the worst women. He got into debt and into\r\njail: his mother helped him out twice, but as soon as he was free he\r\nreturned to his old companions and habits. His head was not strong: the\r\nknaves he lived amongst fooled him beyond anything I ever heard. He\r\ncame down to Gateshead about three weeks ago and wanted missis to give\r\nup all to him. Missis refused: her means have long been much reduced by\r\nhis extravagance; so he went back again, and the next news was that he\r\nwas dead. How he died, God knows!\xe2\x80\x94they say he killed himself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was silent: the tidings were frightful. Robert Leaven resumed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis had been out of health herself for some time: she had got very\r\nstout, but was not strong with it; and the loss of money and fear of\r\npoverty were quite breaking her down. The information about Mr. John\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndeath and the manner of it came too suddenly: it brought on a stroke.\r\nShe was three days without speaking; but last Tuesday she seemed rather\r\nbetter: she appeared as if she wanted to say something, and kept making\r\nsigns to my wife and mumbling. It was only yesterday morning, however,\r\nthat Bessie understood she was pronouncing your name; and at last she\r\nmade out the words, \xe2\x80\x98Bring Jane\xe2\x80\x94fetch Jane Eyre: I want to speak to\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x99 Bessie is not sure whether she is in her right mind, or means\r\nanything by the words; but she told Miss Reed and Miss Georgiana, and\r\nadvised them to send for you. The young ladies put it off at first; but\r\ntheir mother grew so restless, and said, \xe2\x80\x98Jane, Jane,\xe2\x80\x99 so many times,\r\nthat at last they consented. I left Gateshead yesterday: and if you can\r\nget ready, Miss, I should like to take you back with me early to-morrow\r\nmorning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Robert, I shall be ready: it seems to me that I ought to go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think so too, Miss. Bessie said she was sure you would not refuse:\r\nbut I suppose you will have to ask leave before you can get off?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and I will do it now;\xe2\x80\x9d and having directed him to the servants\xe2\x80\x99\r\nhall, and recommended him to the care of John\xe2\x80\x99s wife, and the\r\nattentions of John himself, I went in search of Mr. Rochester.\r\n\r\nHe was not in any of the lower rooms; he was not in the yard, the\r\nstables, or the grounds. I asked Mrs. Fairfax if she had seen him;\xe2\x80\x94yes:\r\nshe believed he was playing billiards with Miss Ingram. To the\r\nbilliard-room I hastened: the click of balls and the hum of voices\r\nresounded thence; Mr. Rochester, Miss Ingram, the two Misses Eshton,\r\nand their admirers, were all busied in the game. It required some\r\ncourage to disturb so interesting a party; my errand, however, was one\r\nI could not defer, so I approached the master where he stood at Miss\r\nIngram\xe2\x80\x99s side. She turned as I drew near, and looked at me haughtily:\r\nher eyes seemed to demand, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat can the creeping creature want now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand when I said, in a low voice, \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester,\xe2\x80\x9d she made a movement\r\nas if tempted to order me away. I remember her appearance at the\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94it was very graceful and very striking: she wore a morning robe\r\nof sky-blue crape; a gauzy azure scarf was twisted in her hair. She had\r\nbeen all animation with the game, and irritated pride did not lower the\r\nexpression of her haughty lineaments.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes that person want you?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired of Mr. Rochester; and Mr.\r\nRochester turned to see who the \xe2\x80\x9cperson\xe2\x80\x9d was. He made a curious\r\ngrimace\xe2\x80\x94one of his strange and equivocal demonstrations\xe2\x80\x94threw down his\r\ncue and followed me from the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he rested his back against the schoolroom\r\ndoor, which he had shut.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you please, sir, I want leave of absence for a week or two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat to do?\xe2\x80\x94where to go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo see a sick lady who has sent for me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat sick lady?\xe2\x80\x94where does she live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Gateshead; in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c-shire? That is a hundred miles off! Who may she be that sends for\r\npeople to see her that distance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer name is Reed, sir\xe2\x80\x94Mrs. Reed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cReed of Gateshead? There was a Reed of Gateshead, a magistrate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is his widow, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what have you to do with her? Sir George Lynn was\r\ntalking of a Reed of Gateshead yesterday, who, he said, was one of the\r\nveriest rascals on town; and Ingram was mentioning a Georgiana Reed of\r\nthe same place, who was much admired for her beauty a season or two ago\r\nin London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJohn Reed is dead, too, sir: he ruined himself and half-ruined his\r\nfamily, and is supposed to have committed suicide. The news so shocked\r\nhis mother that it brought on an apoplectic attack.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what good can you do her? Nonsense, Jane! I would never think of\r\nrunning a hundred miles to see an old lady who will, perhaps, be dead\r\nbefore you reach her: besides, you say she cast you off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, but that is long ago; and when her circumstances were very\r\ndifferent: I could not be easy to neglect her wishes now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long will you stay?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs short a time as possible, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPromise me only to stay a week\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had better not pass my word: I might be obliged to break it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt all events you _will_ come back: you will not be induced under any\r\npretext to take up a permanent residence with her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no! Ad\xc3\xa8le, as you say, must go to school; and you, of course, must\r\nmarch straight to\xe2\x80\x94the devil?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope not, sir; but I must seek another situation somewhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn course!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, with a twang of voice and a distortion of\r\nfeatures equally fantastic and ludicrous. I wish I had only offered you a sovereign instead of ten\r\npounds. Give me back nine pounds, Jane; I\xe2\x80\x99ve a use for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so have I, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I returned, putting my hands and my purse behind\r\nme. \xe2\x80\x9cI could not spare the money on any account.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle niggard!\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9crefusing me a pecuniary request! I should like\r\nsomething else: a little addition to the rite. If one shook hands, for\r\ninstance; but no\xe2\x80\x94that would not content me either. So you\xe2\x80\x99ll do no more\r\nthan say Farewell, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is enough, sir: as much good-will may be conveyed in one hearty\r\nword as in many.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery likely; but it is blank and cool\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Farewell.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long is he going to stand with his back against that door?\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nasked myself; \xe2\x80\x9cI want to commence my packing.\xe2\x80\x9d The dinner-bell rang,\r\nand suddenly away he bolted, without another syllable: I saw him no\r\nmore during the day, and was off before he had risen in the morning.\r\n\r\nI reached the lodge at Gateshead about five o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon of\r\nthe first of May: I stepped in there before going up to the hall. It\r\nwas very clean and neat: the ornamental windows were hung with little\r\nwhite curtains; the floor was spotless; the grate and fire-irons were\r\nburnished bright, and the fire burnt clear. Bessie sat on the hearth,\r\nnursing her last-born, and Robert and his sister played quietly in a\r\ncorner.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBless you!\xe2\x80\x94I knew you would come!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Leaven, as I\r\nentered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Bessie,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, after I had kissed her; \xe2\x80\x9cand I trust I am not\r\ntoo late. How is Mrs. Reed?\xe2\x80\x94Alive still, I hope.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, she is alive; and more sensible and collected than she was. The\r\ndoctor says she may linger a week or two yet; but he hardly thinks she\r\nwill finally recover.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHas she mentioned me lately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was talking of you only this morning, and wishing you would come,\r\nbut she is sleeping now, or was ten minutes ago, when I was up at the\r\nhouse. She generally lies in a kind of lethargy all the afternoon, and\r\nwakes up about six or seven. Will you rest yourself here an hour, Miss,\r\nand then I will go up with you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nRobert here entered, and Bessie laid her sleeping child in the cradle\r\nand went to welcome him: afterwards she insisted on my taking off my\r\nbonnet and having some tea; for she said I looked pale and tired. I was\r\nglad to accept her hospitality; and I submitted to be relieved of my\r\ntravelling garb just as passively as I used to let her undress me when\r\na child.\r\n\r\nOld times crowded fast back on me as I watched her bustling\r\nabout\xe2\x80\x94setting out the tea-tray with her best china, cutting bread and\r\nbutter, toasting a tea-cake, and, between whiles, giving little Robert\r\nor Jane an occasional tap or push, just as she used to give me in\r\nformer days. Bessie had retained her quick temper as well as her light\r\nfoot and good looks.\r\n\r\nTea ready, I was going to approach the table; but she desired me to sit\r\nstill, quite in her old peremptory tones. I must be served at the\r\nfireside, she said; and she placed before me a little round stand with\r\nmy cup and a plate of toast, absolutely as she used to accommodate me\r\nwith some privately purloined dainty on a nursery chair: and I smiled\r\nand obeyed her as in bygone days.\r\n\r\nShe wanted to know if I was happy at Thornfield Hall, and what sort of\r\na person the mistress was; and when I told her there was only a master,\r\nwhether he was a nice gentleman, and if I liked him. I told her he was\r\nrather an ugly man, but quite a gentleman; and that he treated me\r\nkindly, and I was content. Then I went on to describe to her the gay\r\ncompany that had lately been staying at the house; and to these details\r\nBessie listened with interest: they were precisely of the kind she\r\nrelished.\r\n\r\nIn such conversation an hour was soon gone: Bessie restored to me my\r\nbonnet, &c., and, accompanied by her, I quitted the lodge for the hall.\r\nIt was also accompanied by her that I had, nearly nine years ago,\r\nwalked down the path I was now ascending. On a dark, misty, raw morning\r\nin January, I had left a hostile roof with a desperate and embittered\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x94a sense of outlawry and almost of reprobation\xe2\x80\x94to seek the chilly\r\nharbourage of Lowood: that bourne so far away and unexplored. The same\r\nhostile roof now again rose before me: my prospects were doubtful yet;\r\nand I had yet an aching heart. I still felt as a wanderer on the face\r\nof the earth; but I experienced firmer trust in myself and my own\r\npowers, and less withering dread of oppression. The gaping wound of my\r\nwrongs, too, was now quite healed; and the flame of resentment\r\nextinguished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall go into the breakfast-room first,\xe2\x80\x9d said Bessie, as she\r\npreceded me through the hall; \xe2\x80\x9cthe young ladies will be there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn another moment I was within that apartment. There was every article\r\nof furniture looking just as it did on the morning I was first\r\nintroduced to Mr. Brocklehurst: the very rug he had stood upon still\r\ncovered the hearth. Glancing at the bookcases, I thought I could\r\ndistinguish the two volumes of Bewick\xe2\x80\x99s British Birds occupying their\r\nold place on the third shelf, and Gulliver\xe2\x80\x99s Travels and the Arabian\r\nNights ranged just above. The inanimate objects were not changed; but\r\nthe living things had altered past recognition.\r\n\r\nTwo young ladies appeared before me; one very tall, almost as tall as\r\nMiss Ingram\xe2\x80\x94very thin too, with a sallow face and severe mien. There\r\nwas something ascetic in her look, which was augmented by the extreme\r\nplainness of a straight-skirted, black, stuff dress, a starched linen\r\ncollar, hair combed away from the temples, and the nun-like ornament of\r\na string of ebony beads and a crucifix. This I felt sure was Eliza,\r\nthough I could trace little resemblance to her former self in that\r\nelongated and colourless visage.\r\n\r\nThe other was as certainly Georgiana: but not the Georgiana I\r\nremembered\xe2\x80\x94the slim and fairy-like girl of eleven. This was a\r\nfull-blown, very plump damsel, fair as waxwork, with handsome and\r\nregular features, languishing blue eyes, and ringleted yellow hair. The\r\nhue of her dress was black too; but its fashion was so different from\r\nher sister\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94so much more flowing and becoming\xe2\x80\x94it looked as stylish as\r\nthe other\xe2\x80\x99s looked puritanical.\r\n\r\nIn each of the sisters there was one trait of the mother\xe2\x80\x94and only one;\r\nthe thin and pallid elder daughter had her parent\xe2\x80\x99s Cairngorm eye: the\r\nblooming and luxuriant younger girl had her contour of jaw and\r\nchin\xe2\x80\x94perhaps a little softened, but still imparting an indescribable\r\nhardness to the countenance otherwise so voluptuous and buxom.\r\n\r\nBoth ladies, as I advanced, rose to welcome me, and both addressed me\r\nby the name of \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eyre.\xe2\x80\x9d Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s greeting was delivered in a short,\r\nabrupt voice, without a smile; and then she sat down again, fixed her\r\neyes on the fire, and seemed to forget me. Georgiana added to her \xe2\x80\x9cHow\r\nd\xe2\x80\x99ye do?\xe2\x80\x9d several commonplaces about my journey, the weather, and so\r\non, uttered in rather a drawling tone: and accompanied by sundry\r\nside-glances that measured me from head to foot\xe2\x80\x94now traversing the\r\nfolds of my drab merino pelisse, and now lingering on the plain\r\ntrimming of my cottage bonnet. Young ladies have a remarkable way of\r\nletting you know that they think you a \xe2\x80\x9cquiz\xe2\x80\x9d without actually saying\r\nthe words. A certain superciliousness of look, coolness of manner,\r\nnonchalance of tone, express fully their sentiments on the point,\r\nwithout committing them by any positive rudeness in word or deed.\r\n\r\nA sneer, however, whether covert or open, had now no longer that power\r\nover me it once possessed: as I sat between my cousins, I was surprised\r\nto find how easy I felt under the total neglect of the one and the\r\nsemi-sarcastic attentions of the other\xe2\x80\x94Eliza did not mortify, nor\r\nGeorgiana ruffle me. The fact was, I had other things to think about;\r\nwithin the last few months feelings had been stirred in me so much more\r\npotent than any they could raise\xe2\x80\x94pains and pleasures so much more acute\r\nand exquisite had been excited than any it was in their power to\r\ninflict or bestow\xe2\x80\x94that their airs gave me no concern either for good or\r\nbad.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow is Mrs. Reed?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked soon, looking calmly at Georgiana, who\r\nthought fit to bridle at the direct address, as if it were an\r\nunexpected liberty.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Reed? Ah! mama, you mean; she is extremely poorly: I doubt if you\r\ncan see her to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cyou would just step upstairs and tell her I am come, I\r\nshould be much obliged to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorgiana almost started, and she opened her blue eyes wild and wide.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know she had a particular wish to see me,\xe2\x80\x9d I added, \xe2\x80\x9cand I would not\r\ndefer attending to her desire longer than is absolutely necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMama dislikes being disturbed in an evening,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Eliza. I soon\r\nrose, quietly took off my bonnet and gloves, uninvited, and said I\r\nwould just step out to Bessie\xe2\x80\x94who was, I dared say, in the kitchen\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nask her to ascertain whether Mrs. Reed was disposed to receive me or\r\nnot to-night. I went, and having found Bessie and despatched her on my\r\nerrand, I proceeded to take further measures. It had heretofore been my\r\nhabit always to shrink from arrogance: received as I had been to-day, I\r\nshould, a year ago, have resolved to quit Gateshead the very next\r\nmorning; now, it was disclosed to me all at once that that would be a\r\nfoolish plan. I had taken a journey of a hundred miles to see my aunt,\r\nand I must stay with her till she was better\xe2\x80\x94or dead: as to her\r\ndaughters\xe2\x80\x99 pride or folly, I must put it on one side, make myself\r\nindependent of it. So I addressed the housekeeper; asked her to show me\r\na room, told her I should probably be a visitor here for a week or two,\r\nhad my trunk conveyed to my chamber, and followed it thither myself: I\r\nmet Bessie on the landing.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMissis is awake,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cI have told her you are here: come and\r\nlet us see if she will know you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did not need to be guided to the well-known room, to which I had so\r\noften been summoned for chastisement or reprimand in former days. I\r\nhastened before Bessie; I softly opened the door: a shaded light stood\r\non the table, for it was now getting dark. There was the great\r\nfour-post bed with amber hangings as of old; there the toilet-table,\r\nthe armchair, and the footstool, at which I had a hundred times been\r\nsentenced to kneel, to ask pardon for offences by me uncommitted. I\r\nlooked into a certain corner near, half-expecting to see the slim\r\noutline of a once dreaded switch which used to lurk there, waiting to\r\nleap out imp-like and lace my quivering palm or shrinking neck. I\r\napproached the bed; I opened the curtains and leant over the high-piled\r\npillows.\r\n\r\nWell did I remember Mrs. Reed\xe2\x80\x99s face, and I eagerly sought the familiar\r\nimage. It is a happy thing that time quells the longings of vengeance\r\nand hushes the promptings of rage and aversion. I had left this woman\r\nin bitterness and hate, and I came back to her now with no other\r\nemotion than a sort of ruth for her great sufferings, and a strong\r\nyearning to forget and forgive all injuries\xe2\x80\x94to be reconciled and clasp\r\nhands in amity.\r\n\r\nThe well-known face was there: stern, relentless as ever\xe2\x80\x94there was that\r\npeculiar eye which nothing could melt, and the somewhat raised,\r\nimperious, despotic eyebrow. How often had it lowered on me menace and\r\nhate! and how the recollection of childhood\xe2\x80\x99s terrors and sorrows\r\nrevived as I traced its harsh line now! And yet I stooped down and\r\nkissed her: she looked at me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this Jane Eyre?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Aunt Reed. How are you, dear aunt?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had once vowed that I would never call her aunt again: I thought it\r\nno sin to forget and break that vow now. My fingers had fastened on her\r\nhand which lay outside the sheet: had she pressed mine kindly, I should\r\nat that moment have experienced true pleasure. But unimpressionable\r\nnatures are not so soon softened, nor are natural antipathies so\r\nreadily eradicated. Mrs. Reed took her hand away, and, turning her face\r\nrather from me, she remarked that the night was warm. Again she\r\nregarded me so icily, I felt at once that her opinion of me\xe2\x80\x94her feeling\r\ntowards me\xe2\x80\x94was unchanged and unchangeable. I knew by her stony\r\neye\xe2\x80\x94opaque to tenderness, indissoluble to tears\xe2\x80\x94that she was resolved\r\nto consider me bad to the last; because to believe me good would give\r\nher no generous pleasure: only a sense of mortification.\r\n\r\nI felt pain, and then I felt ire; and then I felt a determination to\r\nsubdue her\xe2\x80\x94to be her mistress in spite both of her nature and her will.\r\nMy tears had risen, just as in childhood: I ordered them back to their\r\nsource. I brought a chair to the bed-head: I sat down and leaned over\r\nthe pillow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou sent for me,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I am here; and it is my intention to\r\nstay till I see how you get on.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, of course! You have seen my daughters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you may tell them I wish you to stay till I can talk some things\r\nover with you I have on my mind: to-night it is too late, and I have a\r\ndifficulty in recalling them. But there was something I wished to\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94let me see\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe wandering look and changed utterance told what wreck had taken\r\nplace in her once vigorous frame. Turning restlessly, she drew the\r\nbedclothes round her; my elbow, resting on a corner of the quilt, fixed\r\nit down: she was at once irritated.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit up!\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cdon\xe2\x80\x99t annoy me with holding the clothes fast. Are\r\nyou Jane Eyre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am Jane Eyre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have had more trouble with that child than any one would believe.\r\nSuch a burden to be left on my hands\xe2\x80\x94and so much annoyance as she\r\ncaused me, daily and hourly, with her incomprehensible disposition, and\r\nher sudden starts of temper, and her continual, unnatural watchings of\r\none\xe2\x80\x99s movements! I declare she talked to me once like something mad, or\r\nlike a fiend\xe2\x80\x94no child ever spoke or looked as she did; I was glad to\r\nget her away from the house. What did they do with her at Lowood? The\r\nfever broke out there, and many of the pupils died. She, however, did\r\nnot die: but I said she did\xe2\x80\x94I wish she had died!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA strange wish, Mrs. Reed; why do you hate her so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had a dislike to her mother always; for she was my husband\xe2\x80\x99s only\r\nsister, and a great favourite with him: he opposed the family\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ndisowning her when she made her low marriage; and when news came of her\r\ndeath, he wept like a simpleton. He would send for the baby; though I\r\nentreated him rather to put it out to nurse and pay for its\r\nmaintenance. I hated it the first time I set my eyes on it\xe2\x80\x94a sickly,\r\nwhining, pining thing! It would wail in its cradle all night long\xe2\x80\x94not\r\nscreaming heartily like any other child, but whimpering and moaning.\r\nReed pitied it; and he used to nurse it and notice it as if it had been\r\nhis own: more, indeed, than he ever noticed his own at that age. He\r\nwould try to make my children friendly to the little beggar: the\r\ndarlings could not bear it, and he was angry with them when they showed\r\ntheir dislike. In his last illness, he had it brought continually to\r\nhis bedside; and but an hour before he died, he bound me by vow to keep\r\nthe creature. I would as soon have been charged with a pauper brat out\r\nof a workhouse: but he was weak, naturally weak. John does not at all\r\nresemble his father, and I am glad of it: John is like me and like my\r\nbrothers\xe2\x80\x94he is quite a Gibson. Oh, I wish he would cease tormenting me\r\nwith letters for money! I have no more money to give him: we are\r\ngetting poor. I must send away half the servants and shut up part of\r\nthe house; or let it off. I can never submit to do that\xe2\x80\x94yet how are we\r\nto get on? Two-thirds of my income goes in paying the interest of\r\nmortgages. John gambles dreadfully, and always loses\xe2\x80\x94poor boy! He is\r\nbeset by sharpers: John is sunk and degraded\xe2\x80\x94his look is frightful\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nfeel ashamed for him when I see him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe was getting much excited. \xe2\x80\x9cI think I had better leave her now,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nsaid I to Bessie, who stood on the other side of the bed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you had, Miss: but she often talks in this way towards\r\nnight\xe2\x80\x94in the morning she is calmer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI rose. \xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Mrs. Reed, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is another thing I wished\r\nto say. He threatens me\xe2\x80\x94he continually threatens me with his own death,\r\nor mine: and I dream sometimes that I see him laid out with a great\r\nwound in his throat, or with a swollen and blackened face. I am come to\r\na strange pass: I have heavy troubles. What is to be done? How is the\r\nmoney to be had?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBessie now endeavoured to persuade her to take a sedative draught: she\r\nsucceeded with difficulty. Soon after, Mrs. Reed grew more composed,\r\nand sank into a dozing state. I then left her.\r\n\r\nMore than ten days elapsed before I had again any conversation with\r\nher. She continued either delirious or lethargic; and the doctor\r\nforbade everything which could painfully excite her. Meantime, I got on\r\nas well as I could with Georgiana and Eliza. They were very cold,\r\nindeed, at first. Eliza would sit half the day sewing, reading, or\r\nwriting, and scarcely utter a word either to me or her sister.\r\nGeorgiana would chatter nonsense to her canary bird by the hour, and\r\ntake no notice of me. But I was determined not to seem at a loss for\r\noccupation or amusement: I had brought my drawing materials with me,\r\nand they served me for both.\r\n\r\nProvided with a case of pencils, and some sheets of paper, I used to\r\ntake a seat apart from them, near the window, and busy myself in\r\nsketching fancy vignettes, representing any scene that happened\r\nmomentarily to shape itself in the ever-shifting kaleidoscope of\r\nimagination: a glimpse of sea between two rocks; the rising moon, and a\r\nship crossing its disk; a group of reeds and water-flags, and a naiad\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nhead, crowned with lotus-flowers, rising out of them; an elf sitting in\r\na hedge-sparrow\xe2\x80\x99s nest, under a wreath of hawthorn-bloom.\r\n\r\nOne morning I fell to sketching a face: what sort of a face it was to\r\nbe, I did not care or know. I took a soft black pencil, gave it a broad\r\npoint, and worked away. Soon I had traced on the paper a broad and\r\nprominent forehead and a square lower outline of visage: that contour\r\ngave me pleasure; my fingers proceeded actively to fill it with\r\nfeatures. Strongly-marked horizontal eyebrows must be traced under that\r\nbrow; then followed, naturally, a well-defined nose, with a straight\r\nridge and full nostrils; then a flexible-looking mouth, by no means\r\nnarrow; then a firm chin, with a decided cleft down the middle of it:\r\nof course, some black whiskers were wanted, and some jetty hair, tufted\r\non the temples, and waved above the forehead. Now for the eyes: I had\r\nleft them to the last, because they required the most careful working.\r\nI drew them large; I shaped them well: the eyelashes I traced long and\r\nsombre; the irids lustrous and large. \xe2\x80\x9cGood! but not quite the thing,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nI thought, as I surveyed the effect: \xe2\x80\x9cthey want more force and spirit;\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand I wrought the shades blacker, that the lights might flash more\r\nbrilliantly\xe2\x80\x94a happy touch or two secured success. There, I had a\r\nfriend\xe2\x80\x99s face under my gaze; and what did it signify that those young\r\nladies turned their backs on me? I looked at it; I smiled at the\r\nspeaking likeness: I was absorbed and content.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that a portrait of some one you know?\xe2\x80\x9d asked Eliza, who had\r\napproached me unnoticed. I responded that it was merely a fancy head,\r\nand hurried it beneath the other sheets. Of course, I lied: it was, in\r\nfact, a very faithful representation of Mr. Rochester. But what was\r\nthat to her, or to any one but myself? Georgiana also advanced to look.\r\nThe other drawings pleased her much, but she called that \xe2\x80\x9can ugly man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nThey both seemed surprised at my skill. I offered to sketch their\r\nportraits; and each, in turn, sat for a pencil outline. Then Georgiana\r\nproduced her album. I promised to contribute a water-colour drawing:\r\nthis put her at once into good humour. She proposed a walk in the\r\ngrounds. Before we had been out two hours, we were deep in a\r\nconfidential conversation: she had favoured me with a description of\r\nthe brilliant winter she had spent in London two seasons ago\xe2\x80\x94of the\r\nadmiration she had there excited\xe2\x80\x94the attention she had received; and I\r\neven got hints of the titled conquest she had made. In the course of\r\nthe afternoon and evening these hints were enlarged on: various soft\r\nconversations were reported, and sentimental scenes represented; and,\r\nin short, a volume of a novel of fashionable life was that day\r\nimprovised by her for my benefit. The communications were renewed from\r\nday to day: they always ran on the same theme\xe2\x80\x94herself, her loves, and\r\nwoes. It was strange she never once adverted either to her mother\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nillness, or her brother\xe2\x80\x99s death, or the present gloomy state of the\r\nfamily prospects. Her mind seemed wholly taken up with reminiscences of\r\npast gaiety, and aspirations after dissipations to come. She passed\r\nabout five minutes each day in her mother\xe2\x80\x99s sick-room, and no more.\r\n\r\nEliza still spoke little: she had evidently no time to talk. I never\r\nsaw a busier person than she seemed to be; yet it was difficult to say\r\nwhat she did: or rather, to discover any result of her diligence. She\r\nhad an alarm to call her up early. I know not how she occupied herself\r\nbefore breakfast, but after that meal she divided her time into regular\r\nportions, and each hour had its allotted task. Three times a day she\r\nstudied a little book, which I found, on inspection, was a Common\r\nPrayer Book. I asked her once what was the great attraction of that\r\nvolume, and she said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe Rubric.\xe2\x80\x9d Three hours she gave to stitching,\r\nwith gold thread, the border of a square crimson cloth, almost large\r\nenough for a carpet. In answer to my inquiries after the use of this\r\narticle, she informed me it was a covering for the altar of a new\r\nchurch lately erected near Gateshead. Two hours she devoted to her\r\ndiary; two to working by herself in the kitchen-garden; and one to the\r\nregulation of her accounts. She seemed to want no company; no\r\nconversation. I believe she was happy in her way: this routine sufficed\r\nfor her; and nothing annoyed her so much as the occurrence of any\r\nincident which forced her to vary its clockwork regularity.\r\n\r\nShe told me one evening, when more disposed to be communicative than\r\nusual, that John\xe2\x80\x99s conduct, and the threatened ruin of the family, had\r\nbeen a source of profound affliction to her: but she had now, she said,\r\nsettled her mind, and formed her resolution. Her own fortune she had\r\ntaken care to secure; and when her mother died\xe2\x80\x94and it was wholly\r\nimprobable, she tranquilly remarked, that she should either recover or\r\nlinger long\xe2\x80\x94she would execute a long-cherished project: seek a\r\nretirement where punctual habits would be permanently secured from\r\ndisturbance, and place safe barriers between herself and a frivolous\r\nworld. I asked if Georgiana would accompany her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course not. Georgiana and she had nothing in common: they never had\r\nhad. She would not be burdened with her society for any consideration.\r\nGeorgiana should take her own course; and she, Eliza, would take hers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nGeorgiana, when not unburdening her heart to me, spent most of her time\r\nin lying on the sofa, fretting about the dulness of the house, and\r\nwishing over and over again that her aunt Gibson would send her an\r\ninvitation up to town. \xe2\x80\x9cIt would be so much better,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cif she\r\ncould only get out of the way for a month or two, till all was over.\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\ndid not ask what she meant by \xe2\x80\x9call being over,\xe2\x80\x9d but I suppose she\r\nreferred to the expected decease of her mother and the gloomy sequel of\r\nfuneral rites. Eliza generally took no more notice of her sister\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nindolence and complaints than if no such murmuring, lounging object had\r\nbeen before her. One day, however, as she put away her account-book and\r\nunfolded her embroidery, she suddenly took her up thus\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGeorgiana, a more vain and absurd animal than you was certainly never\r\nallowed to cumber the earth. You had no right to be born, for you make\r\nno use of life. Instead of living for, in, and with yourself, as a\r\nreasonable being ought, you seek only to fasten your feebleness on some\r\nother person\xe2\x80\x99s strength: if no one can be found willing to burden her\r\nor himself with such a fat, weak, puffy, useless thing, you cry out\r\nthat you are ill-treated, neglected, miserable. Then, too, existence\r\nfor you must be a scene of continual change and excitement, or else the\r\nworld is a dungeon: you must be admired, you must be courted, you must\r\nbe flattered\xe2\x80\x94you must have music, dancing, and society\xe2\x80\x94or you languish,\r\nyou die away. Have you no sense to devise a system which will make you\r\nindependent of all efforts, and all wills, but your own? Take one day;\r\nshare it into sections; to each section apportion its task: leave no\r\nstray unemployed quarters of an hour, ten minutes, five minutes\xe2\x80\x94include\r\nall; do each piece of business in its turn with method, with rigid\r\nregularity. The day will close almost before you are aware it has\r\nbegun; and you are indebted to no one for helping you to get rid of one\r\nvacant moment: you have had to seek no one\xe2\x80\x99s company, conversation,\r\nsympathy, forbearance; you have lived, in short, as an independent\r\nbeing ought to do. Take this advice: the first and last I shall offer\r\nyou; then you will not want me or any one else, happen what may.\r\nNeglect it\xe2\x80\x94go on as heretofore, craving, whining, and idling\xe2\x80\x94and suffer\r\nthe results of your idiocy, however bad and insufferable they may be. I\r\ntell you this plainly; and listen: for though I shall no more repeat\r\nwhat I am now about to say, I shall steadily act on it. After my\r\nmother\xe2\x80\x99s death, I wash my hands of you: from the day her coffin is\r\ncarried to the vault in Gateshead Church, you and I will be as separate\r\nas if we had never known each other.
