You need not think that because we\r\nchanced to be born of the same parents, I shall suffer you to fasten me\r\ndown by even the feeblest claim: I can tell you this\xe2\x80\x94if the whole human\r\nrace, ourselves excepted, were swept away, and we two stood alone on\r\nthe earth, I would leave you in the old world, and betake myself to the\r\nnew.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe closed her lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou might have spared yourself the trouble of delivering that tirade,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nanswered Georgiana. \xe2\x80\x9cEverybody knows you are the most selfish,\r\nheartless creature in existence: and _I_ know your spiteful hatred\r\ntowards me: I have had a specimen of it before in the trick you played\r\nme about Lord Edwin Vere: you could not bear me to be raised above you,\r\nto have a title, to be received into circles where you dare not show\r\nyour face, and so you acted the spy and informer, and ruined my\r\nprospects for ever.\xe2\x80\x9d Georgiana took out her handkerchief and blew her\r\nnose for an hour afterwards; Eliza sat cold, impassable, and\r\nassiduously industrious.\r\n\r\nTrue, generous feeling is made small account of by some, but here were\r\ntwo natures rendered, the one intolerably acrid, the other despicably\r\nsavourless for the want of it. Feeling without judgment is a washy\r\ndraught indeed; but judgment untempered by feeling is too bitter and\r\nhusky a morsel for human deglutition.\r\n\r\nIt was a wet and windy afternoon: Georgiana had fallen asleep on the\r\nsofa over the perusal of a novel; Eliza was gone to attend a\r\nsaint\xe2\x80\x99s-day service at the new church\xe2\x80\x94for in matters of religion she\r\nwas a rigid formalist: no weather ever prevented the punctual discharge\r\nof what she considered her devotional duties; fair or foul, she went to\r\nchurch thrice every Sunday, and as often on week-days as there were\r\nprayers.\r\n\r\nI bethought myself to go upstairs and see how the dying woman sped, who\r\nlay there almost unheeded: the very servants paid her but a remittent\r\nattention: the hired nurse, being little looked after, would slip out\r\nof the room whenever she could. Bessie was faithful; but she had her\r\nown family to mind, and could only come occasionally to the hall. I\r\nfound the sick-room unwatched, as I had expected: no nurse was there;\r\nthe patient lay still, and seemingly lethargic; her livid face sunk in\r\nthe pillows: the fire was dying in the grate. I renewed the fuel,\r\nre-arranged the bedclothes, gazed awhile on her who could not now gaze\r\non me, and then I moved away to the window.\r\n\r\nThe rain beat strongly against the panes, the wind blew tempestuously:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne lies there,\xe2\x80\x9d I thought, \xe2\x80\x9cwho will soon be beyond the war of\r\nearthly elements. Whither will that spirit\xe2\x80\x94now struggling to quit its\r\nmaterial tenement\xe2\x80\x94flit when at length released?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn pondering the great mystery, I thought of Helen Burns, recalled her\r\ndying words\xe2\x80\x94her faith\xe2\x80\x94her doctrine of the equality of disembodied\r\nsouls. I was still listening in thought to her well-remembered\r\ntones\xe2\x80\x94still picturing her pale and spiritual aspect, her wasted face\r\nand sublime gaze, as she lay on her placid deathbed, and whispered her\r\nlonging to be restored to her divine Father\xe2\x80\x99s bosom\xe2\x80\x94when a feeble voice\r\nmurmured from the couch behind: \xe2\x80\x9cWho is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI knew Mrs. Reed had not spoken for days: was she reviving? I went up\r\nto her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is I, Aunt Reed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho\xe2\x80\x94I?\xe2\x80\x9d was her answer. \xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d looking at me with surprise and\r\na sort of alarm, but still not wildly. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite a stranger to\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94where is Bessie?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is at the lodge, aunt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAunt,\xe2\x80\x9d she repeated. \xe2\x80\x9cWho calls me aunt? You are not one of the\r\nGibsons; and yet I know you\xe2\x80\x94that face, and the eyes and forehead, are\r\nquiet familiar to me: you are like\xe2\x80\x94why, you are like Jane Eyre!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said nothing: I was afraid of occasioning some shock by declaring my\r\nidentity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cI am afraid it is a mistake: my thoughts deceive me.\r\nI wished to see Jane Eyre, and I fancy a likeness where none exists:\r\nbesides, in eight years she must be so changed.\xe2\x80\x9d I now gently assured\r\nher that I was the person she supposed and desired me to be: and seeing\r\nthat I was understood, and that her senses were quite collected, I\r\nexplained how Bessie had sent her husband to fetch me from Thornfield.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very ill, I know,\xe2\x80\x9d she said ere long. \xe2\x80\x9cI was trying to turn\r\nmyself a few minutes since, and find I cannot move a limb. It is as\r\nwell I should ease my mind before I die: what we think little of in\r\nhealth, burdens us at such an hour as the present is to me. Is the\r\nnurse here? or is there no one in the room but you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI assured her we were alone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have twice done you a wrong which I regret now. One was in\r\nbreaking the promise which I gave my husband to bring you up as my own\r\nchild; the other\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d she stopped. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter all, it is of no great\r\nimportance, perhaps,\xe2\x80\x9d she murmured to herself: \xe2\x80\x9cand then I may get\r\nbetter; and to humble myself so to her is painful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe made an effort to alter her position, but failed: her face changed;\r\nshe seemed to experience some inward sensation\xe2\x80\x94the precursor, perhaps,\r\nof the last pang.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I must get it over. Eternity is before me: I had better tell\r\nher.\xe2\x80\x94Go to my dressing-case, open it, and take out a letter you will\r\nsee there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI obeyed her directions. \xe2\x80\x9cRead the letter,\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\nIt was short, and thus conceived:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMADAM,\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane\r\nEyre, and to tell me how she is? It is my intention to write shortly\r\nand desire her to come to me at Madeira. Providence has blessed my\r\nendeavours to secure a competency; and as I am unmarried and childless,\r\nI wish to adopt her during my life, and bequeath her at my death\r\nwhatever I may have to leave.\r\n\r\n\r\nI am, Madam, &c., &c.,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJOHN EYRE, Madeira.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was dated three years back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did I never hear of this?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I disliked you too fixedly and thoroughly ever to lend a hand\r\nin lifting you to prosperity. I could not forget your conduct to me,\r\nJane\xe2\x80\x94the fury with which you once turned on me; the tone in which you\r\ndeclared you abhorred me the worst of anybody in the world; the\r\nunchildlike look and voice with which you affirmed that the very\r\nthought of me made you sick, and asserted that I had treated you with\r\nmiserable cruelty. I could not forget my own sensations when you thus\r\nstarted up and poured out the venom of your mind: I felt fear as if an\r\nanimal that I had struck or pushed had looked up at me with human eyes\r\nand cursed me in a man\xe2\x80\x99s voice.\xe2\x80\x94Bring me some water! Oh, make haste!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Mrs. Reed,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as I offered her the draught she required,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthink no more of all this, let it pass away from your mind. Forgive me\r\nfor my passionate language: I was a child then; eight, nine years have\r\npassed since that day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe heeded nothing of what I said; but when she had tasted the water\r\nand drawn breath, she went on thus\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you I could not forget it; and I took my revenge: for you to be\r\nadopted by your uncle, and placed in a state of ease and comfort, was\r\nwhat I could not endure. I wrote to him; I said I was sorry for his\r\ndisappointment, but Jane Eyre was dead: she had died of typhus fever at\r\nLowood. Now act as you please: write and contradict my assertion\xe2\x80\x94expose\r\nmy falsehood as soon as you like. You were born, I think, to be my\r\ntorment: my last hour is racked by the recollection of a deed which,\r\nbut for you, I should never have been tempted to commit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you could but be persuaded to think no more of it, aunt, and to\r\nregard me with kindness and forgiveness\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a very bad disposition,\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cand one to this day I\r\nfeel it impossible to understand: how for nine years you could be\r\npatient and quiescent under any treatment, and in the tenth break out\r\nall fire and violence, I can never comprehend.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy disposition is not so bad as you think: I am passionate, but not\r\nvindictive. Many a time, as a little child, I should have been glad to\r\nlove you if you would have let me; and I long earnestly to be\r\nreconciled to you now: kiss me, aunt.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI approached my cheek to her lips: she would not touch it. She said I\r\noppressed her by leaning over the bed, and again demanded water. As I\r\nlaid her down\xe2\x80\x94for I raised her and supported her on my arm while she\r\ndrank\xe2\x80\x94I covered her ice-cold and clammy hand with mine: the feeble\r\nfingers shrank from my touch\xe2\x80\x94the glazing eyes shunned my gaze.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLove me, then, or hate me, as you will,\xe2\x80\x9d I said at last, \xe2\x80\x9cyou have my\r\nfull and free forgiveness: ask now for God\xe2\x80\x99s, and be at peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nPoor, suffering woman! it was too late for her to make now the effort\r\nto change her habitual frame of mind: living, she had ever hated\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94dying, she must hate me still.\r\n\r\nThe nurse now entered, and Bessie followed. I yet lingered half-an-hour\r\nlonger, hoping to see some sign of amity: but she gave none. She was\r\nfast relapsing into stupor; nor did her mind again rally: at twelve\r\no\xe2\x80\x99clock that night she died. I was not present to close her eyes, nor\r\nwere either of her daughters. They came to tell us the next morning\r\nthat all was over. She was by that time laid out. Eliza and I went to\r\nlook at her: Georgiana, who had burst out into loud weeping, said she\r\ndared not go. There was stretched Sarah Reed\xe2\x80\x99s once robust and active\r\nframe, rigid and still: her eye of flint was covered with its cold lid;\r\nher brow and strong traits wore yet the impress of her inexorable soul.\r\nA strange and solemn object was that corpse to me. I gazed on it with\r\ngloom and pain: nothing soft, nothing sweet, nothing pitying, or\r\nhopeful, or subduing did it inspire; only a grating anguish for _her_\r\nwoes\xe2\x80\x94not _my_ loss\xe2\x80\x94and a sombre tearless dismay at the fearfulness of\r\ndeath in such a form.\r\n\r\nEliza surveyed her parent calmly. After a silence of some minutes she\r\nobserved\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith her constitution she should have lived to a good old age: her\r\nlife was shortened by trouble.\xe2\x80\x9d And then a spasm constricted her mouth\r\nfor an instant: as it passed away she turned and left the room, and so\r\ndid I. Neither of us had dropt a tear.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXII\r\n\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester had given me but one week\xe2\x80\x99s leave of absence: yet a month\r\nelapsed before I quitted Gateshead. I wished to leave immediately after\r\nthe funeral, but Georgiana entreated me to stay till she could get off\r\nto London, whither she was now at last invited by her uncle, Mr.\r\nGibson, who had come down to direct his sister\xe2\x80\x99s interment and settle\r\nthe family affairs. Georgiana said she dreaded being left alone with\r\nEliza; from her she got neither sympathy in her dejection, support in\r\nher fears, nor aid in her preparations; so I bore with her\r\nfeeble-minded wailings and selfish lamentations as well as I could, and\r\ndid my best in sewing for her and packing her dresses. It is true, that\r\nwhile I worked, she would idle; and I thought to myself, \xe2\x80\x9cIf you and I\r\nwere destined to live always together, cousin, we would commence\r\nmatters on a different footing. I should not settle tamely down into\r\nbeing the forbearing party; I should assign you your share of labour,\r\nand compel you to accomplish it, or else it should be left undone: I\r\nshould insist, also, on your keeping some of those drawling,\r\nhalf-insincere complaints hushed in your own breast. It is only because\r\nour connection happens to be very transitory, and comes at a peculiarly\r\nmournful season, that I consent thus to render it so patient and\r\ncompliant on my part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt last I saw Georgiana off; but now it was Eliza\xe2\x80\x99s turn to request me\r\nto stay another week. Her plans required all her time and attention,\r\nshe said; she was about to depart for some unknown bourne; and all day\r\nlong she stayed in her own room, her door bolted within, filling\r\ntrunks, emptying drawers, burning papers, and holding no communication\r\nwith any one. She wished me to look after the house, to see callers,\r\nand answer notes of condolence.\r\n\r\nOne morning she told me I was at liberty. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd,\xe2\x80\x9d she added, \xe2\x80\x9cI am\r\nobliged to you for your valuable services and discreet conduct! There\r\nis some difference between living with such an one as you and with\r\nGeorgiana: you perform your own part in life and burden no one.\r\nTo-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d she continued, \xe2\x80\x9cI set out for the Continent. I shall take\r\nup my abode in a religious house near Lisle\xe2\x80\x94a nunnery you would call\r\nit; there I shall be quiet and unmolested. I shall devote myself for a\r\ntime to the examination of the Roman Catholic dogmas, and to a careful\r\nstudy of the workings of their system: if I find it to be, as I half\r\nsuspect it is, the one best calculated to ensure the doing of all\r\nthings decently and in order, I shall embrace the tenets of Rome and\r\nprobably take the veil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI neither expressed surprise at this resolution nor attempted to\r\ndissuade her from it. \xe2\x80\x9cThe vocation will fit you to a hair,\xe2\x80\x9d I thought:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cmuch good may it do you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen we parted, she said: \xe2\x80\x9cGood-bye, cousin Jane Eyre; I wish you well:\r\nyou have some sense.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI then returned: \xe2\x80\x9cYou are not without sense, cousin Eliza; but what you\r\nhave, I suppose, in another year will be walled up alive in a French\r\nconvent. However, it is not my business, and so it suits you, I don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmuch care.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are in the right,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; and with these words we each went our\r\nseparate way. As I shall not have occasion to refer either to her or\r\nher sister again, I may as well mention here, that Georgiana made an\r\nadvantageous match with a wealthy worn-out man of fashion, and that\r\nEliza actually took the veil, and is at this day superior of the\r\nconvent where she passed the period of her novitiate, and which she\r\nendowed with her fortune.\r\n\r\nHow people feel when they are returning home from an absence, long or\r\nshort, I did not know: I had never experienced the sensation. I had\r\nknown what it was to come back to Gateshead when a child after a long\r\nwalk, to be scolded for looking cold or gloomy; and later, what it was\r\nto come back from church to Lowood, to long for a plenteous meal and a\r\ngood fire, and to be unable to get either. Neither of these returnings\r\nwas very pleasant or desirable: no magnet drew me to a given point,\r\nincreasing in its strength of attraction the nearer I came. The return\r\nto Thornfield was yet to be tried.\r\n\r\nMy journey seemed tedious\xe2\x80\x94very tedious: fifty miles one day, a night\r\nspent at an inn; fifty miles the next day. During the first twelve\r\nhours I thought of Mrs. Reed in her last moments; I saw her disfigured\r\nand discoloured face, and heard her strangely altered voice. I mused on\r\nthe funeral day, the coffin, the hearse, the black train of tenants and\r\nservants\xe2\x80\x94few was the number of relatives\xe2\x80\x94the gaping vault, the silent\r\nchurch, the solemn service. Then I thought of Eliza and Georgiana; I\r\nbeheld one the cynosure of a ball-room, the other the inmate of a\r\nconvent cell; and I dwelt on and analysed their separate peculiarities\r\nof person and character. The evening arrival at the great town of \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\r\nscattered these thoughts; night gave them quite another turn: laid down\r\non my traveller\xe2\x80\x99s bed, I left reminiscence for anticipation.\r\n\r\nI was going back to Thornfield: but how long was I to stay there? Not\r\nlong; of that I was sure. I had heard from Mrs. Fairfax in the interim\r\nof my absence: the party at the hall was dispersed; Mr. Rochester had\r\nleft for London three weeks ago, but he was then expected to return in\r\na fortnight. Mrs. Fairfax surmised that he was gone to make\r\narrangements for his wedding, as he had talked of purchasing a new\r\ncarriage: she said the idea of his marrying Miss Ingram still seemed\r\nstrange to her; but from what everybody said, and from what she had\r\nherself seen, she could no longer doubt that the event would shortly\r\ntake place. \xe2\x80\x9cYou would be strangely incredulous if you did doubt it,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwas my mental comment. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t doubt it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe question followed, \xe2\x80\x9cWhere was I to go?\xe2\x80\x9d I dreamt of Miss Ingram all\r\nthe night: in a vivid morning dream I saw her closing the gates of\r\nThornfield against me and pointing me out another road; and Mr.\r\nRochester looked on with his arms folded\xe2\x80\x94smiling sardonically, as it\r\nseemed, at both her and me.\r\n\r\nI had not notified to Mrs. Fairfax the exact day of my return; for I\r\ndid not wish either car or carriage to meet me at Millcote. I proposed\r\nto walk the distance quietly by myself; and very quietly, after leaving\r\nmy box in the ostler\xe2\x80\x99s care, did I slip away from the George Inn, about\r\nsix o\xe2\x80\x99clock of a June evening, and take the old road to Thornfield: a\r\nroad which lay chiefly through fields, and was now little frequented.\r\n\r\nIt was not a bright or splendid summer evening, though fair and soft:\r\nthe haymakers were at work all along the road; and the sky, though far\r\nfrom cloudless, was such as promised well for the future: its\r\nblue\xe2\x80\x94where blue was visible\xe2\x80\x94was mild and settled, and its cloud strata\r\nhigh and thin. The west, too, was warm: no watery gleam chilled it\xe2\x80\x94it\r\nseemed as if there was a fire lit, an altar burning behind its screen\r\nof marbled vapour, and out of apertures shone a golden redness.\r\n\r\nI felt glad as the road shortened before me: so glad that I stopped\r\nonce to ask myself what that joy meant: and to remind reason that it\r\nwas not to my home I was going, or to a permanent resting-place, or to\r\na place where fond friends looked out for me and waited my arrival.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Fairfax will smile you a calm welcome, to be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said I; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nlittle Ad\xc3\xa8le will clap her hands and jump to see you: but you know very\r\nwell you are thinking of another than they, and that he is not thinking\r\nof you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut what is so headstrong as youth? What so blind as inexperience?\r\nThese affirmed that it was pleasure enough to have the privilege of\r\nagain looking on Mr. Rochester, whether he looked on me or not; and\r\nthey added\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cHasten! hasten! be with him while you may: but a few more\r\ndays or weeks, at most, and you are parted from him for ever!\xe2\x80\x9d And then\r\nI strangled a new-born agony\xe2\x80\x94a deformed thing which I could not\r\npersuade myself to own and rear\xe2\x80\x94and ran on.\r\n\r\nThey are making hay, too, in Thornfield meadows: or rather, the\r\nlabourers are just quitting their work, and returning home with their\r\nrakes on their shoulders, now, at the hour I arrive. I have but a field\r\nor two to traverse, and then I shall cross the road and reach the\r\ngates. How full the hedges are of roses! But I have no time to gather\r\nany; I want to be at the house. I passed a tall briar, shooting leafy\r\nand flowery branches across the path; I see the narrow stile with stone\r\nsteps; and I see\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Rochester sitting there, a book and a pencil in\r\nhis hand; he is writing.\r\n\r\nWell, he is not a ghost; yet every nerve I have is unstrung: for a\r\nmoment I am beyond my own mastery. What does it mean? I did not think I\r\nshould tremble in this way when I saw him, or lose my voice or the\r\npower of motion in his presence. I will go back as soon as I can stir:\r\nI need not make an absolute fool of myself. I know another way to the\r\nhouse. It does not signify if I knew twenty ways; for he has seen me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHillo!\xe2\x80\x9d he cries; and he puts up his book and his pencil. \xe2\x80\x9cThere you\r\nare! Come on, if you please.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI suppose I do come on; though in what fashion I know not; being\r\nscarcely cognisant of my movements, and solicitous only to appear calm;\r\nand, above all, to control the working muscles of my face\xe2\x80\x94which I feel\r\nrebel insolently against my will, and struggle to express what I had\r\nresolved to conceal. But I have a veil\xe2\x80\x94it is down: I may make shift yet\r\nto behave with decent composure.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this is Jane Eyre? Are you coming from Millcote, and on foot?\r\nYes\xe2\x80\x94just one of your tricks: not to send for a carriage, and come\r\nclattering over street and road like a common mortal, but to steal into\r\nthe vicinage of your home along with twilight, just as if you were a\r\ndream or a shade. What the deuce have you done with yourself this last\r\nmonth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have been with my aunt, sir, who is dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA true Janian reply! Good angels be my guard! She comes from the other\r\nworld\xe2\x80\x94from the abode of people who are dead; and tells me so when she\r\nmeets me alone here in the gloaming! If I dared, I\xe2\x80\x99d touch you, to see\r\nif you are substance or shadow, you elf!\xe2\x80\x94but I\xe2\x80\x99d as soon offer to take\r\nhold of a blue _ignis fatuus_ light in a marsh. Truant! truant!\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nadded, when he had paused an instant. \xe2\x80\x9cAbsent from me a whole month,\r\nand forgetting me quite, I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sworn!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI knew there would be pleasure in meeting my master again, even though\r\nbroken by the fear that he was so soon to cease to be my master, and by\r\nthe knowledge that I was nothing to him: but there was ever in Mr.\r\nRochester (so at least I thought) such a wealth of the power of\r\ncommunicating happiness, that to taste but of the crumbs he scattered\r\nto stray and stranger birds like me, was to feast genially. His last\r\nwords were balm: they seemed to imply that it imported something to him\r\nwhether I forgot him or not. And he had spoken of Thornfield as my\r\nhome\xe2\x80\x94would that it were my home!\r\n\r\nHe did not leave the stile, and I hardly liked to ask to go by. I\r\ninquired soon if he had not been to London.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I suppose you found that out by second-sight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMrs. Fairfax told me in a letter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd did she inform you what I went to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, yes, sir! Everybody knew your errand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must see the carriage, Jane, and tell me if you don\xe2\x80\x99t think it\r\nwill suit Mrs. Rochester exactly; and whether she won\xe2\x80\x99t look like Queen\r\nBoadicea, leaning back against those purple cushions. I wish, Jane, I\r\nwere a trifle better adapted to match with her externally. Tell me now,\r\nfairy as you are\xe2\x80\x94can\xe2\x80\x99t you give me a charm, or a philter, or something\r\nof that sort, to make me a handsome man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would be past the power of magic, sir;\xe2\x80\x9d and, in thought, I added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA loving eye is all the charm needed: to such you are handsome enough;\r\nor rather your sternness has a power beyond beauty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester had sometimes read my unspoken thoughts with an acumen to\r\nme incomprehensible: in the present instance he took no notice of my\r\nabrupt vocal response; but he smiled at me with a certain smile he had\r\nof his own, and which he used but on rare occasions. He seemed to think\r\nit too good for common purposes: it was the real sunshine of feeling\xe2\x80\x94he\r\nshed it over me now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPass, Janet,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, making room for me to cross the stile: \xe2\x80\x9cgo up\r\nhome, and stay your weary little wandering feet at a friend\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthreshold.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAll I had now to do was to obey him in silence: no need for me to\r\ncolloquise further. I got over the stile without a word, and meant to\r\nleave him calmly. An impulse held me fast\xe2\x80\x94a force turned me round. I\r\nsaid\xe2\x80\x94or something in me said for me, and in spite of me\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, Mr. Rochester, for your great kindness. I am strangely glad\r\nto get back again to you: and wherever you are is my home\xe2\x80\x94my only\r\nhome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI walked on so fast that even he could hardly have overtaken me had he\r\ntried. Little Ad\xc3\xa8le was half wild with delight when she saw me. Mrs.\r\nFairfax received me with her usual plain friendliness. Leah smiled, and\r\neven Sophie bid me \xe2\x80\x9cbon soir\xe2\x80\x9d with glee. This was very pleasant; there\r\nis no happiness like that of being loved by your fellow-creatures, and\r\nfeeling that your presence is an addition to their comfort.\r\n\r\nI that evening shut my eyes resolutely against the future: I stopped my\r\nears against the voice that kept warning me of near separation and\r\ncoming grief. When tea was over and Mrs. Fairfax had taken her\r\nknitting, and I had assumed a low seat near her, and Ad\xc3\xa8le, kneeling on\r\nthe carpet, had nestled close up to me, and a sense of mutual affection\r\nseemed to surround us with a ring of golden peace, I uttered a silent\r\nprayer that we might not be parted far or soon; but when, as we thus\r\nsat, Mr. Rochester entered, unannounced, and looking at us, seemed to\r\ntake pleasure in the spectacle of a group so amicable\xe2\x80\x94when he said he\r\nsupposed the old lady was all right now that she had got her adopted\r\ndaughter back again, and added that he saw Ad\xc3\xa8le was \xe2\x80\x9cpr\xc3\xaate \xc3\xa0 croquer\r\nsa petite maman Anglaise\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94I half ventured to hope that he would, even\r\nafter his marriage, keep us together somewhere under the shelter of his\r\nprotection, and not quite exiled from the sunshine of his presence.\r\n\r\nA fortnight of dubious calm succeeded my return to Thornfield Hall.\r\nNothing was said of the master\xe2\x80\x99s marriage, and I saw no preparation\r\ngoing on for such an event. Almost every day I asked Mrs. Fairfax if\r\nshe had yet heard anything decided: her answer was always in the\r\nnegative. Once she said she had actually put the question to Mr.\r\nRochester as to when he was going to bring his bride home; but he had\r\nanswered her only by a joke and one of his queer looks, and she could\r\nnot tell what to make of him.\r\n\r\nOne thing specially surprised me, and that was, there were no\r\njourneyings backward and forward, no visits to Ingram Park: to be sure\r\nit was twenty miles off, on the borders of another county; but what was\r\nthat distance to an ardent lover? To so practised and indefatigable a\r\nhorseman as Mr. Rochester, it would be but a morning\xe2\x80\x99s ride. I began to\r\ncherish hopes I had no right to conceive: that the match was broken\r\noff; that rumour had been mistaken; that one or both parties had\r\nchanged their minds. I used to look at my master\xe2\x80\x99s face to see if it\r\nwere sad or fierce; but I could not remember the time when it had been\r\nso uniformly clear of clouds or evil feelings. If, in the moments I and\r\nmy pupil spent with him, I lacked spirits and sank into inevitable\r\ndejection, he became even gay. Never had he called me more frequently\r\nto his presence; never been kinder to me when there\xe2\x80\x94and, alas! never\r\nhad I loved him so well.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIII\r\n\r\n\r\nA splendid Midsummer shone over England: skies so pure, suns so radiant\r\nas were then seen in long succession, seldom favour even singly, our\r\nwave-girt land. It was as if a band of Italian days had come from the\r\nSouth, like a flock of glorious passenger birds, and lighted to rest\r\nthem on the cliffs of Albion. The hay was all got in; the fields round\r\nThornfield were green and shorn; the roads white and baked; the trees\r\nwere in their dark prime; hedge and wood, full-leaved and deeply\r\ntinted, contrasted well with the sunny hue of the cleared meadows\r\nbetween.\r\n\r\nOn Midsummer-eve, Ad\xc3\xa8le, weary with gathering wild strawberries in Hay\r\nLane half the day, had gone to bed with the sun. I watched her drop\r\nasleep, and when I left her, I sought the garden.\r\n\r\nIt was now the sweetest hour of the twenty-four:\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDay its fervid fires\r\nhad wasted,\xe2\x80\x9d and dew fell cool on panting plain and scorched summit.\r\nWhere the sun had gone down in simple state\xe2\x80\x94pure of the pomp of\r\nclouds\xe2\x80\x94spread a solemn purple, burning with the light of red jewel and\r\nfurnace flame at one point, on one hill-peak, and extending high and\r\nwide, soft and still softer, over half heaven. The east had its own\r\ncharm or fine deep blue, and its own modest gem, a rising and solitary\r\nstar: soon it would boast the moon; but she was yet beneath the\r\nhorizon.\r\n\r\nI walked a while on the pavement; but a subtle, well-known scent\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nof a cigar\xe2\x80\x94stole from some window; I saw the library casement open a\r\nhandbreadth; I knew I might be watched thence; so I went apart into the\r\norchard. No nook in the grounds more sheltered and more Eden-like; it\r\nwas full of trees, it bloomed with flowers: a very high wall shut it\r\nout from the court, on one side; on the other, a beech avenue screened\r\nit from the lawn. At the bottom was a sunk fence; its sole separation\r\nfrom lonely fields: a winding walk, bordered with laurels and\r\nterminating in a giant horse-chestnut, circled at the base by a seat,\r\nled down to the fence. Here one could wander unseen. While such\r\nhoney-dew fell, such silence reigned, such gloaming gathered, I felt as\r\nif I could haunt such shade for ever; but in threading the flower and\r\nfruit parterres at the upper part of the enclosure, enticed there by\r\nthe light the now rising moon cast on this more open quarter, my step\r\nis stayed\xe2\x80\x94not by sound, not by sight, but once more by a warning\r\nfragrance.\r\n\r\nSweet-briar and southernwood, jasmine, pink, and rose have long been\r\nyielding their evening sacrifice of incense: this new scent is neither\r\nof shrub nor flower; it is\xe2\x80\x94I know it well\xe2\x80\x94it is Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s cigar.\r\nI look round and I listen. I see trees laden with ripening fruit. I\r\nhear a nightingale warbling in a wood half a mile off; no moving form\r\nis visible, no coming step audible; but that perfume increases: I must\r\nflee. I make for the wicket leading to the shrubbery, and I see Mr.\r\nRochester entering. I step aside into the ivy recess; he will not stay\r\nlong: he will soon return whence he came, and if I sit still he will\r\nnever see me.\r\n\r\nBut no\xe2\x80\x94eventide is as pleasant to him as to me, and this antique garden\r\nas attractive; and he strolls on, now lifting the gooseberry-tree\r\nbranches to look at the fruit, large as plums, with which they are\r\nladen; now taking a ripe cherry from the wall; now stooping towards a\r\nknot of flowers, either to inhale their fragrance or to admire the\r\ndew-beads on their petals. A great moth goes humming by me; it alights\r\non a plant at Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s foot: he sees it, and bends to examine\r\nit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, he has his back towards me,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, \xe2\x80\x9cand he is occupied too;\r\nperhaps, if I walk softly, I can slip away unnoticed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI trode on an edging of turf that the crackle of the pebbly gravel\r\nmight not betray me: he was standing among the beds at a yard or two\r\ndistant from where I had to pass; the moth apparently engaged him. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nshall get by very well,\xe2\x80\x9d I meditated. As I crossed his shadow, thrown\r\nlong over the garden by the moon, not yet risen high, he said quietly,\r\nwithout turning\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, come and look at this fellow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had made no noise: he had not eyes behind\xe2\x80\x94could his shadow feel? I\r\nstarted at first, and then I approached him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLook at his wings,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9che reminds me rather of a West Indian\r\ninsect; one does not often see so large and gay a night-rover in\r\nEngland; there! he is flown.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe moth roamed away. I was sheepishly retreating also; but Mr.\r\nRochester followed me, and when we reached the wicket, he said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTurn back: on so lovely a night it is a shame to sit in the house; and\r\nsurely no one can wish to go to bed while sunset is thus at meeting\r\nwith moonrise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt is one of my faults, that though my tongue is sometimes prompt\r\nenough at an answer, there are times when it sadly fails me in framing\r\nan excuse; and always the lapse occurs at some crisis, when a facile\r\nword or plausible pretext is specially wanted to get me out of painful\r\nembarrassment. I did not like to walk at this hour alone with Mr.\r\nRochester in the shadowy orchard; but I could not find a reason to\r\nallege for leaving him. I followed with lagging step, and thoughts\r\nbusily bent on discovering a means of extrication; but he himself\r\nlooked so composed and so grave also, I became ashamed of feeling any\r\nconfusion: the evil\xe2\x80\x94if evil existent or prospective there was\xe2\x80\x94seemed to\r\nlie with me only; his mind was unconscious and quiet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane,\xe2\x80\x9d he recommenced, as we entered the laurel walk, and slowly\r\nstrayed down in the direction of the sunk fence and the horse-chestnut,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThornfield is a pleasant place in summer, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must have become in some degree attached to the house,\xe2\x80\x94you, who\r\nhave an eye for natural beauties, and a good deal of the organ of\r\nAdhesiveness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am attached to it, indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd though I don\xe2\x80\x99t comprehend how it is, I perceive you have acquired\r\na degree of regard for that foolish little child Ad\xc3\xa8le, too; and even\r\nfor simple dame Fairfax?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir; in different ways, I have an affection for both.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd would be sorry to part with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPity!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, and sighed and paused. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is always the way of events\r\nin this life,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued presently: \xe2\x80\x9cno sooner have you got settled\r\nin a pleasant resting-place, than a voice calls out to you to rise and\r\nmove on, for the hour of repose is expired.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMust I move on, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked. \xe2\x80\x9cMust I leave Thornfield?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you must, Jane. I am sorry, Janet, but I believe indeed you\r\nmust.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was a blow: but I did not let it prostrate me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, I shall be ready when the order to march comes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is come now\xe2\x80\x94I must give it to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you _are_ going to be married, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEx-act-ly\xe2\x80\x94pre-cise-ly: with your usual acuteness, you have hit the\r\nnail straight on the head.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery soon, my\xe2\x80\x94that is, Miss Eyre: and you\xe2\x80\x99ll remember, Jane, the first\r\ntime I, or Rumour, plainly intimated to you that it was my intention to\r\nput my old bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s neck into the sacred noose, to enter into the\r\nholy estate of matrimony\xe2\x80\x94to take Miss Ingram to my bosom, in short\r\n(she\xe2\x80\x99s an extensive armful: but that\xe2\x80\x99s not to the point\xe2\x80\x94one can\xe2\x80\x99t have\r\ntoo much of such a very excellent thing as my beautiful Blanche): well,\r\nas I was saying\xe2\x80\x94listen to me, Jane! You\xe2\x80\x99re not turning your head to\r\nlook after more moths, are you? That was only a lady-clock, child,\r\n\xe2\x80\x98flying away home.\xe2\x80\x99 I wish to remind you that it was you who first said\r\nto me, with that discretion I respect in you\xe2\x80\x94with that foresight,\r\nprudence, and humility which befit your responsible and dependent\r\nposition\xe2\x80\x94that in case I married Miss Ingram, both you and little Ad\xc3\xa8le\r\nhad better trot forthwith. I pass over the sort of slur conveyed in\r\nthis suggestion on the character of my beloved; indeed, when you are\r\nfar away, Janet, I\xe2\x80\x99ll try to forget it: I shall notice only its wisdom;\r\nwhich is such that I have made it my law of action. Ad\xc3\xa8le must go to\r\nschool; and you, Miss Eyre, must get a new situation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir, I will advertise immediately: and meantime, I suppose\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nwas going to say, \xe2\x80\x9cI suppose I may stay here, till I find another\r\nshelter to betake myself to:\xe2\x80\x9d but I stopped, feeling it would not do to\r\nrisk a long sentence, for my voice was not quite under command.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn about a month I hope to be a bridegroom,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Mr. Rochester;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cand in the interim, I shall myself look out for employment and an\r\nasylum for you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, sir; I am sorry to give\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no need to apologise! I consider that when a dependent does her\r\nduty as well as you have done yours, she has a sort of claim upon her\r\nemployer for any little assistance he can conveniently render her;\r\nindeed I have already, through my future mother-in-law, heard of a\r\nplace that I think will suit: it is to undertake the education of the\r\nfive daughters of Mrs. Dionysius O\xe2\x80\x99Gall of Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught,\r\nIreland. You\xe2\x80\x99ll like Ireland, I think: they\xe2\x80\x99re such warm-hearted people\r\nthere, they say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long way off, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo matter\xe2\x80\x94a girl of your sense will not object to the voyage or the\r\ndistance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot the voyage, but the distance: and then the sea is a barrier\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom what, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom England and from Thornfield: and\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFrom _you_, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said this almost involuntarily, and, with as little sanction of free\r\nwill, my tears gushed out. I did not cry so as to be heard, however; I\r\navoided sobbing. The thought of Mrs. O\xe2\x80\x99Gall and Bitternutt Lodge struck\r\ncold to my heart; and colder the thought of all the brine and foam,\r\ndestined, as it seemed, to rush between me and the master at whose side\r\nI now walked, and coldest the remembrance of the wider ocean\xe2\x80\x94wealth,\r\ncaste, custom intervened between me and what I naturally and inevitably\r\nloved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long way,\xe2\x80\x9d I again said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, to be sure; and when you get to Bitternutt Lodge, Connaught,\r\nIreland, I shall never see you again, Jane: that\xe2\x80\x99s morally certain. I\r\nnever go over to Ireland, not having myself much of a fancy for the\r\ncountry. We have been good friends, Jane; have we not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when friends are on the eve of separation, they like to spend the\r\nlittle time that remains to them close to each other. Come! we\xe2\x80\x99ll talk\r\nover the voyage and the parting quietly half-an-hour or so, while the\r\nstars enter into their shining life up in heaven yonder: here is the\r\nchestnut tree: here is the bench at its old roots. Come, we will sit\r\nthere in peace to-night, though we should never more be destined to sit\r\nthere together.\xe2\x80\x9d He seated me and himself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a long way to Ireland, Janet, and I am sorry to send my little\r\nfriend on such weary travels: but if I can\xe2\x80\x99t do better, how is it to be\r\nhelped? Are you anything akin to me, do you think, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI could risk no sort of answer by this time: my heart was still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI sometimes have a queer feeling with regard to\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94especially when you are near me, as now: it is as if I had a string\r\nsomewhere under my left ribs, tightly and inextricably knotted to a\r\nsimilar string situated in the corresponding quarter of your little\r\nframe. And if that boisterous Channel, and two hundred miles or so of\r\nland come broad between us, I am afraid that cord of communion will be\r\nsnapt; and then I\xe2\x80\x99ve a nervous notion I should take to bleeding\r\ninwardly. As for you,\xe2\x80\x94you\xe2\x80\x99d forget me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I _never_ should, sir: you know\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d Impossible to proceed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, do you hear that nightingale singing in the wood? Listen!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIn listening, I sobbed convulsively; for I could repress what I endured\r\nno longer; I was obliged to yield, and I was shaken from head to foot\r\nwith acute distress. When I did speak, it was only to express an\r\nimpetuous wish that I had never been born, or never come to Thornfield.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you are sorry to leave it?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe vehemence of emotion, stirred by grief and love within me, was\r\nclaiming mastery, and struggling for full sway, and asserting a right\r\nto predominate, to overcome, to live, rise, and reign at last: yes,\xe2\x80\x94and\r\nto speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI grieve to leave Thornfield: I love Thornfield:\xe2\x80\x94I love it, because I\r\nhave lived in it a full and delightful life,\xe2\x80\x94momentarily at least. I\r\nhave not been trampled on. I have not been petrified. I have not been\r\nburied with inferior minds, and excluded from every glimpse of\r\ncommunion with what is bright and energetic and high. I have talked,\r\nface to face, with what I reverence, with what I delight in,\xe2\x80\x94with an\r\noriginal, a vigorous, an expanded mind. I have known you, Mr.\r\nRochester; and it strikes me with terror and anguish to feel I\r\nabsolutely must be torn from you for ever. I see the necessity of\r\ndeparture; and it is like looking on the necessity of death.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere do you see the necessity?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked suddenly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere? You, sir, have placed it before me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn what shape?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn the shape of Miss Ingram; a noble and beautiful woman,\xe2\x80\x94your bride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy bride! What bride? I have no bride!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you will have.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes;\xe2\x80\x94I will!\xe2\x80\x94I will!\xe2\x80\x9d He set his teeth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen I must go:\xe2\x80\x94you have said it yourself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo: you must stay! I swear it\xe2\x80\x94and the oath shall be kept.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI tell you I must go!\xe2\x80\x9d I retorted, roused to something like passion.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think I can stay to become nothing to you? Do you think I am an\r\nautomaton?\xe2\x80\x94a machine without feelings? and can bear to have my morsel\r\nof bread snatched from my lips, and my drop of living water dashed from\r\nmy cup? Do you think, because I am poor, obscure, plain, and little, I\r\nam soulless and heartless? You think wrong!\xe2\x80\x94I have as much soul as\r\nyou,\xe2\x80\x94and full as much heart! And if God had gifted me with some beauty\r\nand much wealth, I should have made it as hard for you to leave me, as\r\nit is now for me to leave you. I am not talking to you now through the\r\nmedium of custom, conventionalities, nor even of mortal flesh;\xe2\x80\x94it is my\r\nspirit that addresses your spirit; just as if both had passed through\r\nthe grave, and we stood at God\xe2\x80\x99s feet, equal,\xe2\x80\x94as we are!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs we are!\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cso,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, enclosing me in his\r\narms, gathering me to his breast, pressing his lips on my lips: \xe2\x80\x9cso,\r\nJane!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, so, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I rejoined: \xe2\x80\x9cand yet not so; for you are a married\r\nman\xe2\x80\x94or as good as a married man, and wed to one inferior to you\xe2\x80\x94to one\r\nwith whom you have no sympathy\xe2\x80\x94whom I do not believe you truly love;\r\nfor I have seen and heard you sneer at her. I would scorn such a union:\r\ntherefore I am better than you\xe2\x80\x94let me go!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere, Jane? To Ireland?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94to Ireland. I have spoken my mind, and can go anywhere now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, be still; don\xe2\x80\x99t struggle so, like a wild frantic bird that is\r\nrending its own plumage in its desperation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no bird; and no net ensnares me; I am a free human being with an\r\nindependent will, which I now exert to leave you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother effort set me at liberty, and I stood erect before him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your will shall decide your destiny,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI offer you my\r\nhand, my heart, and a share of all my possessions.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou play a farce, which I merely laugh at.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI ask you to pass through life at my side\xe2\x80\x94to be my second self, and\r\nbest earthly companion.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor that fate you have already made your choice, and must abide by\r\nit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, be still a few moments: you are over-excited: I will be still\r\ntoo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA waft of wind came sweeping down the laurel-walk, and trembled through\r\nthe boughs of the chestnut: it wandered away\xe2\x80\x94away\xe2\x80\x94to an indefinite\r\ndistance\xe2\x80\x94it died. The nightingale\xe2\x80\x99s song was then the only voice of the\r\nhour: in listening to it, I again wept. Mr. Rochester sat quiet,\r\nlooking at me gently and seriously. Some time passed before he spoke;\r\nhe at last said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome to my side, Jane, and let us explain and understand one another.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will never again come to your side: I am torn away now, and cannot\r\nreturn.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Jane, I summon you as my wife: it is you only I intend to marry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was silent: I thought he mocked me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome, Jane\xe2\x80\x94come hither.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour bride stands between us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose, and with a stride reached me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy bride is here,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, again drawing me to him, \xe2\x80\x9cbecause my equal\r\nis here, and my likeness. Jane, will you marry me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill I did not answer, and still I writhed myself from his grasp: for\r\nI was still incredulous.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you doubt me, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEntirely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have no faith in me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a whit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I a liar in your eyes?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked passionately. \xe2\x80\x9cLittle sceptic, you\r\n_shall_ be convinced. What love have I for Miss Ingram? None: and that\r\nyou know. What love has she for me? None: as I have taken pains to\r\nprove: I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was not a third\r\nof what was supposed, and after that I presented myself to see the\r\nresult; it was coldness both from her and her mother. I would not\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncould not\xe2\x80\x94marry Miss Ingram. You\xe2\x80\x94you strange, you almost unearthly\r\nthing!\xe2\x80\x94I love as my own flesh. You\xe2\x80\x94poor and obscure, and small and\r\nplain as you are\xe2\x80\x94I entreat to accept me as a husband.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, me!\xe2\x80\x9d I ejaculated, beginning in his earnestness\xe2\x80\x94and especially\r\nin his incivility\xe2\x80\x94to credit his sincerity: \xe2\x80\x9cme who have not a friend in\r\nthe world but you\xe2\x80\x94if you are my friend: not a shilling but what you\r\nhave given me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, Jane, I must have you for my own\xe2\x80\x94entirely my own. Will you be\r\nmine? Say yes, quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, let me look at your face: turn to the moonlight.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I want to read your countenance\xe2\x80\x94turn!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere! you will find it scarcely more legible than a crumpled,\r\nscratched page. Read on: only make haste, for I suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis face was very much agitated and very much flushed, and there were\r\nstrong workings in the features, and strange gleams in the eyes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Jane, you torture me!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed. \xe2\x80\x9cWith that searching and yet\r\nfaithful and generous look, you torture me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow can I do that? If you are true, and your offer real, my only\r\nfeelings to you must be gratitude and devotion\xe2\x80\x94they cannot torture.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGratitude!\xe2\x80\x9d he ejaculated; and added wildly\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJane accept me quickly.\r\nSay, Edward\xe2\x80\x94give me my name\xe2\x80\x94Edward\xe2\x80\x94I will marry you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you in earnest? Do you truly love me? Do you sincerely wish me to\r\nbe your wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do; and if an oath is necessary to satisfy you, I swear it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen, sir, I will marry you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEdward\xe2\x80\x94my little wife!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDear Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome to me\xe2\x80\x94come to me entirely now,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; and added, in his\r\ndeepest tone, speaking in my ear as his cheek was laid on mine, \xe2\x80\x9cMake\r\nmy happiness\xe2\x80\x94I will make yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod pardon me!\xe2\x80\x9d he subjoined ere long; \xe2\x80\x9cand man meddle not with me: I\r\nhave her, and will hold her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere is no one to meddle, sir. I have no kindred to interfere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94that is the best of it,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. And if I had loved him less I\r\nshould have thought his accent and look of exultation savage; but,\r\nsitting by him, roused from the nightmare of parting\xe2\x80\x94called to the\r\nparadise of union\xe2\x80\x94I thought only of the bliss given me to drink in so\r\nabundant a flow. Again and again he said, \xe2\x80\x9cAre you happy, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nagain and again I answered, \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d After which he murmured, \xe2\x80\x9cIt will\r\natone\xe2\x80\x94it will atone. Have I not found her friendless, and cold, and\r\ncomfortless? Will I not guard, and cherish, and solace her? Is there\r\nnot love in my heart, and constancy in my resolves? It will expiate at\r\nGod\xe2\x80\x99s tribunal. I know my Maker sanctions what I do. For the world\xe2\x80\x99s\r\njudgment\xe2\x80\x94I wash my hands thereof. For man\xe2\x80\x99s opinion\xe2\x80\x94I defy it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut what had befallen the night? The moon was not yet set, and we were\r\nall in shadow: I could scarcely see my master\xe2\x80\x99s face, near as I was.\r\nAnd what ailed the chestnut tree? it writhed and groaned; while wind\r\nroared in the laurel walk, and came sweeping over us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must go in,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester: \xe2\x80\x9cthe weather changes. I could have\r\nsat with thee till morning, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd so,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, \xe2\x80\x9ccould I with you.\xe2\x80\x9d I should have said so,\r\nperhaps, but a livid, vivid spark leapt out of a cloud at which I was\r\nlooking, and there was a crack, a crash, and a close rattling peal; and\r\nI thought only of hiding my dazzled eyes against Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\nThe rain rushed down. He hurried me up the walk, through the grounds,\r\nand into the house; but we were quite wet before we could pass the\r\nthreshold. He was taking off my shawl in the hall, and shaking the\r\nwater out of my loosened hair, when Mrs. Fairfax emerged from her room.\r\nI did not observe her at first, nor did Mr. Rochester. The lamp was\r\nlit. The clock was on the stroke of twelve.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHasten to take off your wet things,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cand before you go,\r\ngood-night\xe2\x80\x94good-night, my darling!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe kissed me repeatedly. When I looked up, on leaving his arms, there\r\nstood the widow, pale, grave, and amazed. I only smiled at her, and ran\r\nupstairs. \xe2\x80\x9cExplanation will do for another time,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I. Still,\r\nwhen I reached my chamber, I felt a pang at the idea she should even\r\ntemporarily misconstrue what she had seen. But joy soon effaced every\r\nother feeling; and loud as the wind blew, near and deep as the thunder\r\ncrashed, fierce and frequent as the lightning gleamed, cataract-like as\r\nthe rain fell during a storm of two hours\xe2\x80\x99 duration, I experienced no\r\nfear and little awe. Mr. Rochester came thrice to my door in the course\r\nof it, to ask if I was safe and tranquil: and that was comfort, that\r\nwas strength for anything.\r\n\r\nBefore I left my bed in the morning, little Ad\xc3\xa8le came running in to\r\ntell me that the great horse-chestnut at the bottom of the orchard had\r\nbeen struck by lightning in the night, and half of it split away.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIV\r\n\r\n\r\nAs I rose and dressed, I thought over what had happened, and wondered\r\nif it were a dream. I could not be certain of the reality till I had\r\nseen Mr. Rochester again, and heard him renew his words of love and\r\npromise.\r\n\r\nWhile arranging my hair, I looked at my face in the glass, and felt it\r\nwas no longer plain: there was hope in its aspect and life in its\r\ncolour; and my eyes seemed as if they had beheld the fount of fruition,\r\nand borrowed beams from the lustrous ripple. I had often been unwilling\r\nto look at my master, because I feared he could not be pleased at my\r\nlook; but I was sure I might lift my face to his now, and not cool his\r\naffection by its expression. I took a plain but clean and light summer\r\ndress from my drawer and put it on: it seemed no attire had ever so\r\nwell become me, because none had I ever worn in so blissful a mood.\r\n\r\nI was not surprised, when I ran down into the hall, to see that a\r\nbrilliant June morning had succeeded to the tempest of the night; and\r\nto feel, through the open glass door, the breathing of a fresh and\r\nfragrant breeze. Nature must be gladsome when I was so happy. A\r\nbeggar-woman and her little boy\xe2\x80\x94pale, ragged objects both\xe2\x80\x94were coming\r\nup the walk, and I ran down and gave them all the money I happened to\r\nhave in my purse\xe2\x80\x94some three or four shillings: good or bad, they must\r\npartake of my jubilee. The rooks cawed, and blither birds sang; but\r\nnothing was so merry or so musical as my own rejoicing heart.\r\n\r\nMrs. Fairfax surprised me by looking out of the window with a sad\r\ncountenance, and saying gravely\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eyre, will you come to\r\nbreakfast?\xe2\x80\x9d During the meal she was quiet and cool: but I could not\r\nundeceive her then. I must wait for my master to give explanations; and\r\nso must she. I ate what I could, and then I hastened upstairs. I met\r\nAd\xc3\xa8le leaving the schoolroom.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere are you going? It is time for lessons.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester has sent me away to the nursery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn there,\xe2\x80\x9d pointing to the apartment she had left; and I went in, and\r\nthere he stood.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCome and bid me good-morning,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. I gladly advanced; and it was\r\nnot merely a cold word now, or even a shake of the hand that I\r\nreceived, but an embrace and a kiss. It seemed natural: it seemed\r\ngenial to be so well loved, so caressed by him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, you look blooming, and smiling, and pretty,\xe2\x80\x9d said he: \xe2\x80\x9ctruly\r\npretty this morning. Is this my pale, little elf? Is this my\r\nmustard-seed? This little sunny-faced girl with the dimpled cheek and\r\nrosy lips; the satin-smooth hazel hair, and the radiant hazel eyes?\xe2\x80\x9d (I\r\nhad green eyes, reader; but you must excuse the mistake: for him they\r\nwere new-dyed, I suppose.)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is Jane Eyre, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSoon to be Jane Rochester,\xe2\x80\x9d he added: \xe2\x80\x9cin four weeks, Janet; not a day\r\nmore. Do you hear that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did, and I could not quite comprehend it: it made me giddy. The\r\nfeeling, the announcement sent through me, was something stronger than\r\nwas consistent with joy\xe2\x80\x94something that smote and stunned: it was, I\r\nthink almost fear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou blushed, and now you are white, Jane: what is that for?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you gave me a new name\xe2\x80\x94Jane Rochester; and it seems so\r\nstrange.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mrs. Rochester,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cyoung Mrs. Rochester\xe2\x80\x94Fairfax\r\nRochester\xe2\x80\x99s girl-bride.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt can never be, sir; it does not sound likely. Human beings never\r\nenjoy complete happiness in this world. I was not born for a different\r\ndestiny to the rest of my species: to imagine such a lot befalling me\r\nis a fairy tale\xe2\x80\x94a day-dream.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich I can and will realise. I shall begin to-day. This morning I\r\nwrote to my banker in London to send me certain jewels he has in his\r\nkeeping,\xe2\x80\x94heirlooms for the ladies of Thornfield. In a day or two I hope\r\nto pour them into your lap: for every privilege, every attention shall\r\nbe yours that I would accord a peer\xe2\x80\x99s daughter, if about to marry her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, sir!\xe2\x80\x94never rain jewels! I don\xe2\x80\x99t like to hear them spoken of.\r\nJewels for Jane Eyre sounds unnatural and strange: I would rather not\r\nhave them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will myself put the diamond chain round your neck, and the circlet\r\non your forehead,\xe2\x80\x94which it will become: for nature, at least, has\r\nstamped her patent of nobility on this brow, Jane; and I will clasp the\r\nbracelets on these fine wrists, and load these fairy-like fingers with\r\nrings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no, sir! think of other subjects, and speak of other things, and\r\nin another strain. Don\xe2\x80\x99t address me as if I were a beauty; I am your\r\nplain, Quakerish governess.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are a beauty in my eyes, and a beauty just after the desire of my\r\nheart,\xe2\x80\x94delicate and a\xc3\xabrial.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPuny and insignificant, you mean. You are dreaming, sir,\xe2\x80\x94or you are\r\nsneering. For God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, don\xe2\x80\x99t be ironical!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will make the world acknowledge you a beauty, too,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on,\r\nwhile I really became uneasy at the strain he had adopted, because I\r\nfelt he was either deluding himself or trying to delude me. \xe2\x80\x9cI will\r\nattire my Jane in satin and lace, and she shall have roses in her hair;\r\nand I will cover the head I love best with a priceless veil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then you won\xe2\x80\x99t know me, sir; and I shall not be your Jane Eyre any\r\nlonger, but an ape in a harlequin\xe2\x80\x99s jacket\xe2\x80\x94a jay in borrowed plumes. I\r\nwould as soon see you, Mr. Rochester, tricked out in stage-trappings,\r\nas myself clad in a court-lady\xe2\x80\x99s robe; and I don\xe2\x80\x99t call you handsome,\r\nsir, though I love you most dearly: far too dearly to flatter you.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t flatter me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pursued his theme, however, without noticing my deprecation. \xe2\x80\x9cThis\r\nvery day I shall take you in the carriage to Millcote, and you must\r\nchoose some dresses for yourself. I told you we shall be married in\r\nfour weeks. The wedding is to take place quietly, in the church down\r\nbelow yonder; and then I shall waft you away at once to town. After a\r\nbrief stay there, I shall bear my treasure to regions nearer the sun:\r\nto French vineyards and Italian plains; and she shall see whatever is\r\nfamous in old story and in modern record: she shall taste, too, of the\r\nlife of cities; and she shall learn to value herself by just comparison\r\nwith others.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShall I travel?\xe2\x80\x94and with you, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall sojourn at Paris, Rome, and Naples: at Florence, Venice, and\r\nVienna: all the ground I have wandered over shall be re-trodden by you:\r\nwherever I stamped my hoof, your sylph\xe2\x80\x99s foot shall step also. Ten\r\nyears since, I flew through Europe half mad; with disgust, hate, and\r\nrage as my companions: now I shall revisit it healed and cleansed, with\r\na very angel as my comforter.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI laughed at him as he said this. \xe2\x80\x9cI am not an angel,\xe2\x80\x9d I asserted; \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nI will not be one till I die: I will be myself. Mr. Rochester, you must\r\nneither expect nor exact anything celestial of me\xe2\x80\x94for you will not get\r\nit, any more than I shall get it of you: which I do not at all\r\nanticipate.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you anticipate of me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFor a little while you will perhaps be as you are now,\xe2\x80\x94a very little\r\nwhile; and then you will turn cool; and then you will be capricious;\r\nand then you will be stern, and I shall have much ado to please you:\r\nbut when you get well used to me, you will perhaps like me\r\nagain,\xe2\x80\x94_like_ me, I say, not _love_ me. I suppose your love will\r\neffervesce in six months, or less. I have observed in books written by\r\nmen, that period assigned as the farthest to which a husband\xe2\x80\x99s ardour\r\nextends. Yet, after all, as a friend and companion, I hope never to\r\nbecome quite distasteful to my dear master.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDistasteful! and like you again! I think I shall like you again, and\r\nyet again: and I will make you confess I do not only _like_, but _love_\r\nyou\xe2\x80\x94with truth, fervour, constancy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet are you not capricious, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo women who please me only by their faces, I am the very devil when I\r\nfind out they have neither souls nor hearts\xe2\x80\x94when they open to me a\r\nperspective of flatness, triviality, and perhaps imbecility,\r\ncoarseness, and ill-temper: but to the clear eye and eloquent tongue,\r\nto the soul made of fire, and the character that bends but does not\r\nbreak\xe2\x80\x94at once supple and stable, tractable and consistent\xe2\x80\x94I am ever\r\ntender and true.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad you ever experience of such a character, sir? Did you ever love\r\nsuch an one?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI love it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut before me: if I, indeed, in any respect come up to your difficult\r\nstandard?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never met your likeness. The old lady had been reading her\r\nmorning portion of Scripture\xe2\x80\x94the Lesson for the day; her Bible lay open\r\nbefore her, and her spectacles were upon it. Her occupation, suspended\r\nby Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s announcement, seemed now forgotten: her eyes, fixed\r\non the blank wall opposite, expressed the surprise of a quiet mind\r\nstirred by unwonted tidings. Seeing me, she roused herself: she made a\r\nsort of effort to smile, and framed a few words of congratulation; but\r\nthe smile expired, and the sentence was abandoned unfinished. She put\r\nup her spectacles, shut the Bible, and pushed her chair back from the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI feel so astonished,\xe2\x80\x9d she began, \xe2\x80\x9cI hardly know what to say to you,\r\nMiss Eyre. Gentlemen in his station are not\r\naccustomed to marry their governesses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was growing truly irritated: happily, Ad\xc3\xa8le ran in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me go,\xe2\x80\x94let me go to Millcote too!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried. \xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester\r\nwon\xe2\x80\x99t: though there is so much room in the new carriage. And her clothes, they will\r\nwear out: how can she get new ones?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester professed to be puzzled. \xe2\x80\x9cHem!\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat would you\r\ndo, Ad\xc3\xa8le? And one could cut a pretty\r\nenough scarf out of a rainbow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is far better as she is,\xe2\x80\x9d concluded Ad\xc3\xa8le, after musing some time:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cbesides, she would get tired of living with only you in the moon. If I\r\nwere mademoiselle, I would never consent to go with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has consented: she has pledged her word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you can\xe2\x80\x99t get her there; there is no road to the moon: it is all\r\nair; and neither you nor she can fly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAd\xc3\xa8le, look at that field.\xe2\x80\x9d We were now outside Thornfield gates, and\r\nbowling lightly along the smooth road to Millcote, where the dust was\r\nwell laid by the thunderstorm, and, where the low hedges and lofty\r\ntimber trees on each side glistened green and rain-refreshed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn that field, Ad\xc3\xa8le, I was walking late one evening about a fortnight\r\nsince\xe2\x80\x94the evening of the day you helped me to make hay in the orchard\r\nmeadows; and, as I was tired with raking swaths, I sat down to rest me\r\non a stile; and there I took out a little book and a pencil, and began\r\nto write about a misfortune that befell me long ago, and a wish I had\r\nfor happy days to come: I was writing away very fast, though daylight\r\nwas fading from the leaf, when something came up the path and stopped\r\ntwo yards off me.
