At that moment I saw the reflection of the visage\r\nand features quite distinctly in the dark oblong glass.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd how were they?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFearful and ghastly to me\xe2\x80\x94oh, sir, I never saw a face like it! It was\r\na discoloured face\xe2\x80\x94it was a savage face. I wish I could forget the roll\r\nof the red eyes and the fearful blackened inflation of the lineaments!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGhosts are usually pale, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis, sir, was purple: the lips were swelled and dark; the brow\r\nfurrowed: the black eyebrows widely raised over the bloodshot eyes.\r\nShall I tell you of what it reminded me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf the foul German spectre\xe2\x80\x94the Vampyre.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh!\xe2\x80\x94what did it do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, it removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and\r\nflinging both on the floor, trampled on them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nIt removed my veil from its gaunt head, rent it in two parts, and\r\nflinging both on the floor, trampled on them\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAfterwards?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt drew aside the window-curtain and looked out; perhaps it saw dawn\r\napproaching, for, taking the candle, it retreated to the door. Just at\r\nmy bedside, the figure stopped: the fiery eyes glared upon me\xe2\x80\x94she\r\nthrust up her candle close to my face, and extinguished it under my\r\neyes. I was aware her lurid visage flamed over mine, and I lost\r\nconsciousness: for the second time in my life\xe2\x80\x94only the second time\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nbecame insensible from terror.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho was with you when you revived?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo one, sir, but the broad day. I rose, bathed my head and face in\r\nwater, drank a long draught; felt that though enfeebled I was not ill,\r\nand determined that to none but you would I impart this vision. Now,\r\nsir, tell me who and what that woman was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe creature of an over-stimulated brain; that is certain. I must be\r\ncareful of you, my treasure: nerves like yours were not made for rough\r\nhandling.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, depend on it, my nerves were not in fault; the thing was real:\r\nthe transaction actually took place.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd your previous dreams, were they real too? Is Thornfield Hall a\r\nruin? Am I severed from you by insuperable obstacles? Am I leaving you\r\nwithout a tear\xe2\x80\x94without a kiss\xe2\x80\x94without a word?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I about to do it? Why, the day is already commenced which is to\r\nbind us indissolubly; and when we are once united, there shall be no\r\nrecurrence of these mental terrors: I guarantee that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMental terrors, sir! I wish I could believe them to be only such: I\r\nwish it more now than ever; since even you cannot explain to me the\r\nmystery of that awful visitant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd since I cannot do it, Jane, it must have been unreal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, sir, when I said so to myself on rising this morning, and when I\r\nlooked round the room to gather courage and comfort from the cheerful\r\naspect of each familiar object in full daylight, there\xe2\x80\x94on the carpet\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nsaw what gave the distinct lie to my hypothesis,\xe2\x80\x94the veil, torn from\r\ntop to bottom in two halves!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt Mr. Rochester start and shudder; he hastily flung his arms round\r\nme. \xe2\x80\x9cThank God!\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cthat if anything malignant did come\r\nnear you last night, it was only the veil that was harmed. Oh, to think\r\nwhat might have happened!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew his breath short, and strained me so close to him, I could\r\nscarcely pant. After some minutes\xe2\x80\x99 silence, he continued, cheerily\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Janet, I\xe2\x80\x99ll explain to you all about it. It was half dream, half\r\nreality. A woman did, I doubt not, enter your room: and that woman\r\nwas\xe2\x80\x94must have been\xe2\x80\x94Grace Poole. You call her a strange being yourself:\r\nfrom all you know, you have reason so to call her\xe2\x80\x94what did she do to\r\nme? what to Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking, you noticed\r\nher entrance and her actions; but feverish, almost delirious as you\r\nwere, you ascribed to her a goblin appearance different from her own:\r\nthe long dishevelled hair, the swelled black face, the exaggerated\r\nstature, were figments of imagination; results of nightmare: the\r\nspiteful tearing of the veil was real: and it is like her. I see you\r\nwould ask why I keep such a woman in my house: when we have been\r\nmarried a year and a day, I will tell you; but not now. Are you\r\nsatisfied, Jane? Do you accept my solution of the mystery?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI reflected, and in truth it appeared to me the only possible one:\r\nsatisfied I was not, but to please him I endeavoured to appear\r\nso\xe2\x80\x94relieved, I certainly did feel; so I answered him with a contented\r\nsmile. And now, as it was long past one, I prepared to leave him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes not Sophie sleep with Ad\xc3\xa8le in the nursery?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, as I lit\r\nmy candle.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is room enough in Ad\xc3\xa8le\xe2\x80\x99s little bed for you. You must share\r\nit with her to-night, Jane: it is no wonder that the incident you have\r\nrelated should make you nervous, and I would rather you did not sleep\r\nalone: promise me to go to the nursery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall be very glad to do so, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd fasten the door securely on the inside. Wake Sophie when you go\r\nupstairs, under pretence of requesting her to rouse you in good time\r\nto-morrow; for you must be dressed and have finished breakfast before\r\neight. And now, no more sombre thoughts: chase dull care away, Janet.\r\nDon\xe2\x80\x99t you hear to what soft whispers the wind has fallen? and there is\r\nno more beating of rain against the window-panes: look here\xe2\x80\x9d (he lifted\r\nup the curtain)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cit is a lovely night!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was. Half heaven was pure and stainless: the clouds, now trooping\r\nbefore the wind, which had shifted to the west, were filing off\r\neastward in long, silvered columns. The moon shone peacefully.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester, gazing inquiringly into my eyes, \xe2\x80\x9chow is my\r\nJanet now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe night is serene, sir; and so am I.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will not dream of separation and sorrow to-night; but of happy\r\nlove and blissful union.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis prediction was but half fulfilled: I did not indeed dream of\r\nsorrow, but as little did I dream of joy; for I never slept at all.\r\nWith little Ad\xc3\xa8le in my arms, I watched the slumber of childhood\xe2\x80\x94so\r\ntranquil, so passionless, so innocent\xe2\x80\x94and waited for the coming day:\r\nall my life was awake and astir in my frame: and as soon as the sun\r\nrose I rose too. I remember Ad\xc3\xa8le clung to me as I left her: I remember\r\nI kissed her as I loosened her little hands from my neck; and I cried\r\nover her with strange emotion, and quitted her because I feared my sobs\r\nwould break her still sound repose. She seemed the emblem of my past\r\nlife; and he, I was now to array myself to meet, the dread, but adored,\r\ntype of my unknown future day.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVI\r\n\r\n\r\nSophie came at seven to dress me: she was very long indeed in\r\naccomplishing her task; so long that Mr. Rochester, grown, I suppose,\r\nimpatient of my delay, sent up to ask why I did not come. She was just\r\nfastening my veil (the plain square of blond after all) to my hair with\r\na brooch; I hurried from under her hands as soon as I could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop!\xe2\x80\x9d she cried in French. \xe2\x80\x9cLook at yourself in the mirror: you have\r\nnot taken one peep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo I turned at the door: I saw a robed and veiled figure, so unlike my\r\nusual self that it seemed almost the image of a stranger. \xe2\x80\x9cJane!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\ncalled a voice, and I hastened down. I was received at the foot of the\r\nstairs by Mr. Rochester.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLingerer!\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cmy brain is on fire with impatience, and you\r\ntarry so long!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took me into the dining-room, surveyed me keenly all over,\r\npronounced me \xe2\x80\x9cfair as a lily, and not only the pride of his life, but\r\nthe desire of his eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d and then telling me he would give me but ten\r\nminutes to eat some breakfast, he rang the bell. One of his lately\r\nhired servants, a footman, answered it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs John getting the carriage ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs the luggage brought down?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are bringing it down, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo you to the church: see if Mr. Wood (the clergyman) and the clerk\r\nare there: return and tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe church, as the reader knows, was but just beyond the gates; the\r\nfootman soon returned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Wood is in the vestry, sir, putting on his surplice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the carriage?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe horses are harnessing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe shall not want it to go to church; but it must be ready the moment\r\nwe return: all the boxes and luggage arranged and strapped on, and the\r\ncoachman in his seat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, are you ready?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI rose. There were no groomsmen, no bridesmaids, no relatives to wait\r\nfor or marshal: none but Mr. Rochester and I. Mrs. Fairfax stood in the\r\nhall as we passed. I would fain have spoken to her, but my hand was\r\nheld by a grasp of iron: I was hurried along by a stride I could hardly\r\nfollow; and to look at Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s face was to feel that not a\r\nsecond of delay would be tolerated for any purpose. I wonder what other\r\nbridegroom ever looked as he did\xe2\x80\x94so bent up to a purpose, so grimly\r\nresolute: or who, under such steadfast brows, ever revealed such\r\nflaming and flashing eyes.\r\n\r\nI know not whether the day was fair or foul; in descending the drive, I\r\ngazed neither on sky nor earth: my heart was with my eyes; and both\r\nseemed migrated into Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s frame. I wanted to see the\r\ninvisible thing on which, as we went along, he appeared to fasten a\r\nglance fierce and fell. I wanted to feel the thoughts whose force he\r\nseemed breasting and resisting.\r\n\r\nAt the churchyard wicket he stopped: he discovered I was quite out of\r\nbreath. \xe2\x80\x9cAm I cruel in my love?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cDelay an instant: lean on\r\nme, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd now I can recall the picture of the grey old house of God rising\r\ncalm before me, of a rook wheeling round the steeple, of a ruddy\r\nmorning sky beyond. I remember something, too, of the green\r\ngrave-mounds; and I have not forgotten, either, two figures of\r\nstrangers straying amongst the low hillocks and reading the mementoes\r\ngraven on the few mossy head-stones. I noticed them, because, as they\r\nsaw us, they passed round to the back of the church; and I doubted not\r\nthey were going to enter by the side-aisle door and witness the\r\nceremony. By Mr. Rochester they were not observed; he was earnestly\r\nlooking at my face, from which the blood had, I daresay, momentarily\r\nfled: for I felt my forehead dewy, and my cheeks and lips cold. When I\r\nrallied, which I soon did, he walked gently with me up the path to the\r\nporch.\r\n\r\nWe entered the quiet and humble temple; the priest waited in his white\r\nsurplice at the lowly altar, the clerk beside him. All was still: two\r\nshadows only moved in a remote corner. My conjecture had been correct:\r\nthe strangers had slipped in before us, and they now stood by the vault\r\nof the Rochesters, their backs towards us, viewing through the rails\r\nthe old time-stained marble tomb, where a kneeling angel guarded the\r\nremains of Damer de Rochester, slain at Marston Moor in the time of the\r\ncivil wars, and of Elizabeth, his wife.\r\n\r\nOur place was taken at the communion rails. Hearing a cautious step\r\nbehind me, I glanced over my shoulder: one of the strangers\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngentleman, evidently\xe2\x80\x94was advancing up the chancel. The service began.\r\nThe explanation of the intent of matrimony was gone through; and then\r\nthe clergyman came a step further forward, and, bending slightly\r\ntowards Mr. Rochester, went on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI require and charge you both (as ye will answer at the dreadful day\r\nof judgment, when the secrets of all hearts shall be disclosed), that\r\nif either of you know any impediment why ye may not lawfully be joined\r\ntogether in matrimony, ye do now confess it; for be ye well assured\r\nthat so many as are coupled together otherwise than God\xe2\x80\x99s Word doth\r\nallow, are not joined together by God, neither is their matrimony\r\nlawful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe paused, as the custom is. When is the pause after that sentence ever\r\nbroken by reply? Not, perhaps, once in a hundred years. And the\r\nclergyman, who had not lifted his eyes from his book, and had held his\r\nbreath but for a moment, was proceeding: his hand was already stretched\r\ntowards Mr. Rochester, as his lips unclosed to ask, \xe2\x80\x9cWilt thou have\r\nthis woman for thy wedded wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94when a distinct and near voice said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe marriage cannot go on: I declare the existence of an impediment.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe clergyman looked up at the speaker and stood mute; the clerk did\r\nthe same; Mr. Rochester moved slightly, as if an earthquake had rolled\r\nunder his feet: taking a firmer footing, and not turning his head or\r\neyes, he said, \xe2\x80\x9cProceed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nProfound silence fell when he had uttered that word, with deep but low\r\nintonation. Presently Mr. Wood said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot proceed without some investigation into what has been\r\nasserted, and evidence of its truth or falsehood.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe ceremony is quite broken off,\xe2\x80\x9d subjoined the voice behind us. \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nam in a condition to prove my allegation: an insuperable impediment to\r\nthis marriage exists.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester heard, but heeded not: he stood stubborn and rigid,\r\nmaking no movement but to possess himself of my hand. What a hot and\r\nstrong grasp he had! and how like quarried marble was his pale, firm,\r\nmassive front at this moment! How his eye shone, still watchful, and\r\nyet wild beneath!\r\n\r\nMr. Wood seemed at a loss. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the nature of the impediment?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nasked. \xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps it may be got over\xe2\x80\x94explained away?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHardly,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer. \xe2\x80\x9cI have called it insuperable, and I speak\r\nadvisedly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe speaker came forward and leaned on the rails. He continued,\r\nuttering each word distinctly, calmly, steadily, but not loudly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt simply consists in the existence of a previous marriage. Mr.\r\nRochester has a wife now living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy nerves vibrated to those low-spoken words as they had never vibrated\r\nto thunder\xe2\x80\x94my blood felt their subtle violence as it had never felt\r\nfrost or fire; but I was collected, and in no danger of swooning. I\r\nlooked at Mr. Rochester: I made him look at me. His whole face was\r\ncolourless rock: his eye was both spark and flint. He disavowed\r\nnothing: he seemed as if he would defy all things. Without speaking,\r\nwithout smiling, without seeming to recognise in me a human being, he\r\nonly twined my waist with his arm and riveted me to his side.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho are you?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked of the intruder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy name is Briggs, a solicitor of \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 Street, London.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you would thrust on me a wife?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would remind you of your lady\xe2\x80\x99s existence, sir, which the law\r\nrecognises, if you do not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFavour me with an account of her\xe2\x80\x94with her name, her parentage, her\r\nplace of abode.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Briggs calmly took a paper from his pocket, and read\r\nout in a sort of official, nasal voice:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98I affirm and can prove that on the 20th of October A.D. \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 (a date of\r\nfifteen years back), Edward Fairfax Rochester, of Thornfield Hall, in\r\nthe county of \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, and of Ferndean Manor, in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire, England, was\r\nmarried to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason, daughter of Jonas Mason,\r\nmerchant, and of Antoinetta his wife, a Creole, at \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 church, Spanish\r\nTown, Jamaica. The record of the marriage will be found in the register\r\nof that church\xe2\x80\x94a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard\r\nMason.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x94if a genuine document\xe2\x80\x94may prove I have been married, but it does\r\nnot prove that the woman mentioned therein as my wife is still living.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was living three months ago,\xe2\x80\x9d returned the lawyer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow do you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have a witness to the fact, whose testimony even you, sir, will\r\nscarcely controvert.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cProduce him\xe2\x80\x94or go to hell.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will produce him first\xe2\x80\x94he is on the spot. Mr. Mason, have the\r\ngoodness to step forward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester, on hearing the name, set his teeth; he experienced, too,\r\na sort of strong convulsive quiver; near to him as I was, I felt the\r\nspasmodic movement of fury or despair run through his frame. The second\r\nstranger, who had hitherto lingered in the background, now drew near; a\r\npale face looked over the solicitor\xe2\x80\x99s shoulder\xe2\x80\x94yes, it was Mason\r\nhimself. Mr. Rochester turned and glared at him. His eye, as I have\r\noften said, was a black eye: it had now a tawny, nay, a bloody light in\r\nits gloom; and his face flushed\xe2\x80\x94olive cheek and hueless forehead\r\nreceived a glow as from spreading, ascending heart-fire: and he\r\nstirred, lifted his strong arm\xe2\x80\x94he could have struck Mason, dashed him\r\non the church-floor, shocked by ruthless blow the breath from his\r\nbody\xe2\x80\x94but Mason shrank away, and cried faintly, \xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d Contempt\r\nfell cool on Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x94his passion died as if a blight had\r\nshrivelled it up: he only asked\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhat have _you_ to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAn inaudible reply escaped Mason\xe2\x80\x99s white lips.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe devil is in it if you cannot answer distinctly. I again demand,\r\nwhat have _you_ to say?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir\xe2\x80\x94sir,\xe2\x80\x9d interrupted the clergyman, \xe2\x80\x9cdo not forget you are in a\r\nsacred place.\xe2\x80\x9d Then addressing Mason, he inquired gently, \xe2\x80\x9cAre you\r\naware, sir, whether or not this gentleman\xe2\x80\x99s wife is still living?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCourage,\xe2\x80\x9d urged the lawyer,\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cspeak out.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is now living at Thornfield Hall,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mason, in more articulate\r\ntones: \xe2\x80\x9cI saw her there last April. I am her brother.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Thornfield Hall!\xe2\x80\x9d ejaculated the clergyman. \xe2\x80\x9cImpossible! I am an\r\nold resident in this neighbourhood, sir, and I never heard of a Mrs.\r\nRochester at Thornfield Hall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI saw a grim smile contort Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s lips, and he muttered\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, by God! I took care that none should hear of it\xe2\x80\x94or of her under\r\nthat name.\xe2\x80\x9d He mused\xe2\x80\x94for ten minutes he held counsel with himself: he\r\nformed his resolve, and announced it\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEnough! all shall bolt out at once, like the bullet from the barrel.\r\nWood, close your book and take off your surplice; John Green (to the\r\nclerk), leave the church: there will be no wedding to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d The man\r\nobeyed.\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester continued, hardily and recklessly: \xe2\x80\x9cBigamy is an ugly\r\nword!\xe2\x80\x94I meant, however, to be a bigamist; but fate has out-manoeuvred\r\nme, or Providence has checked me,\xe2\x80\x94perhaps the last. I am little better\r\nthan a devil at this moment; and, as my pastor there would tell me,\r\ndeserve no doubt the sternest judgments of God, even to the quenchless\r\nfire and deathless worm. Gentlemen, my plan is broken up:\xe2\x80\x94what this\r\nlawyer and his client say is true: I have been married, and the woman\r\nto whom I was married lives! You say you never heard of a Mrs.\r\nRochester at the house up yonder, Wood; but I daresay you have many a\r\ntime inclined your ear to gossip about the mysterious lunatic kept\r\nthere under watch and ward. Some have whispered to you that she is my\r\nbastard half-sister: some, my cast-off mistress. I now inform you that\r\nshe is my wife, whom I married fifteen years ago,\xe2\x80\x94Bertha Mason by name;\r\nsister of this resolute personage, who is now, with his quivering limbs\r\nand white cheeks, showing you what a stout heart men may bear. Cheer\r\nup, Dick!\xe2\x80\x94never fear me!\xe2\x80\x94I\xe2\x80\x99d almost as soon strike a woman as you.\r\nBertha Mason is mad; and she came of a mad family; idiots and maniacs\r\nthrough three generations! Her mother, the Creole, was both a madwoman\r\nand a drunkard!\xe2\x80\x94as I found out after I had wed the daughter: for they\r\nwere silent on family secrets before. Bertha, like a dutiful child,\r\ncopied her parent in both points. I had a charming partner\xe2\x80\x94pure, wise,\r\nmodest: you can fancy I was a happy man. I went through rich scenes!\r\nOh! my experience has been heavenly, if you only knew it! But I owe you\r\nno further explanation. Briggs, Wood, Mason, I invite you all to come\r\nup to the house and visit Mrs. Poole\xe2\x80\x99s patient, and _my wife_! You\r\nshall see what sort of a being I was cheated into espousing, and judge\r\nwhether or not I had a right to break the compact, and seek sympathy\r\nwith something at least human. This girl,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, looking at me,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cknew no more than you, Wood, of the disgusting secret: she thought all\r\nwas fair and legal; and never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into\r\na feigned union with a defrauded wretch, already bound to a bad, mad,\r\nand embruted partner! Come all of you\xe2\x80\x94follow!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill holding me fast, he left the church: the three gentlemen came\r\nafter. At the front door of the hall we found the carriage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake it back to the coach-house, John,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester coolly; \xe2\x80\x9cit\r\nwill not be wanted to-day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAt our entrance, Mrs. Fairfax, Ad\xc3\xa8le, Sophie, Leah, advanced to meet\r\nand greet us.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the right-about\xe2\x80\x94every soul!\xe2\x80\x9d cried the master; \xe2\x80\x9caway with your\r\ncongratulations! Who wants them? Not I!\xe2\x80\x94they are fifteen years too\r\nlate!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe passed on and ascended the stairs, still holding my hand, and still\r\nbeckoning the gentlemen to follow him, which they did. We mounted the\r\nfirst staircase, passed up the gallery, proceeded to the third storey:\r\nthe low, black door, opened by Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s master-key, admitted us\r\nto the tapestried room, with its great bed and its pictorial cabinet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know this place, Mason,\xe2\x80\x9d said our guide; \xe2\x80\x9cshe bit and stabbed you\r\nhere.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe lifted the hangings from the wall, uncovering the second door: this,\r\ntoo, he opened. In a room without a window, there burnt a fire guarded\r\nby a high and strong fender, and a lamp suspended from the ceiling by a\r\nchain. Grace Poole bent over the fire, apparently cooking something in\r\na saucepan. In the deep shade, at the farther end of the room, a figure\r\nran backwards and forwards. What it was, whether beast or human being,\r\none could not, at first sight, tell: it grovelled, seemingly, on all\r\nfours; it snatched and growled like some strange wild animal: but it\r\nwas covered with clothing, and a quantity of dark, grizzled hair, wild\r\nas a mane, hid its head and face.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood-morrow, Mrs. Poole!\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester. \xe2\x80\x9cHow are you? and how is\r\nyour charge to-day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99re tolerable, sir, I thank you,\xe2\x80\x9d replied Grace, lifting the boiling\r\nmess carefully on to the hob: \xe2\x80\x9crather snappish, but not \xe2\x80\x99rageous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA fierce cry seemed to give the lie to her favourable report: the\r\nclothed hyena rose up, and stood tall on its hind-feet.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! sir, she sees you!\xe2\x80\x9d exclaimed Grace: \xe2\x80\x9cyou\xe2\x80\x99d better not stay.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly a few moments, Grace: you must allow me a few moments.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTake care then, sir!\xe2\x80\x94for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake, take care!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe maniac bellowed: she parted her shaggy locks from her visage, and\r\ngazed wildly at her visitors. I recognised well that purple face,\xe2\x80\x94those\r\nbloated features. Mrs. Poole advanced.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cKeep out of the way,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester, thrusting her aside: \xe2\x80\x9cshe\r\nhas no knife now, I suppose, and I\xe2\x80\x99m on my guard.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne never knows what she has, sir: she is so cunning: it is not in\r\nmortal discretion to fathom her craft.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe had better leave her,\xe2\x80\x9d whispered Mason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGo to the devil!\xe2\x80\x9d was his brother-in-law\xe2\x80\x99s recommendation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x99Ware!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Grace. The three gentlemen retreated simultaneously. Mr.\r\nRochester flung me behind him: the lunatic sprang and grappled his\r\nthroat viciously, and laid her teeth to his cheek: they struggled. She\r\nwas a big woman, in stature almost equalling her husband, and corpulent\r\nbesides: she showed virile force in the contest\xe2\x80\x94more than once she\r\nalmost throttled him, athletic as he was. He could have settled her\r\nwith a well-planted blow; but he would not strike: he would only\r\nwrestle. At last he mastered her arms; Grace Poole gave him a cord, and\r\nhe pinioned them behind her: with more rope, which was at hand, he\r\nbound her to a chair. The operation was performed amidst the fiercest\r\nyells and the most convulsive plunges. Mr. Rochester then turned to the\r\nspectators: he looked at them with a smile both acrid and desolate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is _my wife_,\xe2\x80\x9d said he. \xe2\x80\x9cSuch is the sole conjugal embrace I am\r\never to know\xe2\x80\x94such are the endearments which are to solace my leisure\r\nhours! And _this_ is what I wished to have\xe2\x80\x9d (laying his hand on my\r\nshoulder): \xe2\x80\x9cthis young girl, who stands so grave and quiet at the mouth\r\nof hell, looking collectedly at the gambols of a demon, I wanted her\r\njust as a change after that fierce ragout. Wood and Briggs, look at the\r\ndifference! Compare these clear eyes with the red balls yonder\xe2\x80\x94this\r\nface with that mask\xe2\x80\x94this form with that bulk; then judge me, priest of\r\nthe gospel and man of the law, and remember with what judgment ye judge\r\nye shall be judged! Off with you now. I must shut up my prize.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWe all withdrew. Mr. Rochester stayed a moment behind us, to give some\r\nfurther order to Grace Poole. The solicitor addressed me as he\r\ndescended the stair.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou, madam,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9care cleared from all blame: your uncle will be\r\nglad to hear it\xe2\x80\x94if, indeed, he should be still living\xe2\x80\x94when Mr. Mason\r\nreturns to Madeira.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy uncle! What of him? Do you know him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Mason does. Mr. Eyre has been the Funchal correspondent of his\r\nhouse for some years. When your uncle received your letter intimating\r\nthe contemplated union between yourself and Mr. Rochester, Mr. Mason,\r\nwho was staying at Madeira to recruit his health, on his way back to\r\nJamaica, happened to be with him. Mr. Eyre mentioned the intelligence;\r\nfor he knew that my client here was acquainted with a gentleman of the\r\nname of Rochester. Mr. Mason, astonished and distressed as you may\r\nsuppose, revealed the real state of matters. Your uncle, I am sorry to\r\nsay, is now on a sick bed; from which, considering the nature of his\r\ndisease\xe2\x80\x94decline\xe2\x80\x94and the stage it has reached, it is unlikely he will\r\never rise. He could not then hasten to England himself, to extricate\r\nyou from the snare into which you had fallen, but he implored Mr. Mason\r\nto lose no time in taking steps to prevent the false marriage. He\r\nreferred him to me for assistance. I used all despatch, and am thankful\r\nI was not too late: as you, doubtless, must be also. Were I not morally\r\ncertain that your uncle will be dead ere you reach Madeira, I would\r\nadvise you to accompany Mr. Mason back; but as it is, I think you had\r\nbetter remain in England till you can hear further, either from or of\r\nMr. Eyre. Have we anything else to stay for?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired of Mr. Mason.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no\xe2\x80\x94let us be gone,\xe2\x80\x9d was the anxious reply; and without waiting to\r\ntake leave of Mr. Rochester, they made their exit at the hall door. The\r\nclergyman stayed to exchange a few sentences, either of admonition or\r\nreproof, with his haughty parishioner; this duty done, he too departed.\r\n\r\nI heard him go as I stood at the half-open door of my own room, to\r\nwhich I had now withdrawn. The house cleared, I shut myself in,\r\nfastened the bolt that none might intrude, and proceeded\xe2\x80\x94not to weep,\r\nnot to mourn, I was yet too calm for that, but\xe2\x80\x94mechanically to take off\r\nthe wedding dress, and replace it by the stuff gown I had worn\r\nyesterday, as I thought, for the last time. I then sat down: I felt\r\nweak and tired. I leaned my arms on a table, and my head dropped on\r\nthem. And now I thought: till now I had only heard, seen,\r\nmoved\xe2\x80\x94followed up and down where I was led or dragged\xe2\x80\x94watched event\r\nrush on event, disclosure open beyond disclosure: but _now_, _I\r\nthought_.\r\n\r\nThe morning had been a quiet morning enough\xe2\x80\x94all except the brief scene\r\nwith the lunatic: the transaction in the church had not been noisy;\r\nthere was no explosion of passion, no loud altercation, no dispute, no\r\ndefiance or challenge, no tears, no sobs: a few words had been spoken,\r\na calmly pronounced objection to the marriage made; some stern, short\r\nquestions put by Mr. Rochester; answers, explanations given, evidence\r\nadduced; an open admission of the truth had been uttered by my master;\r\nthen the living proof had been seen; the intruders were gone, and all\r\nwas over.\r\n\r\nI was in my own room as usual\xe2\x80\x94just myself, without obvious change:\r\nnothing had smitten me, or scathed me, or maimed me. And yet where was\r\nthe Jane Eyre of yesterday?\xe2\x80\x94where was her life?\xe2\x80\x94where were her\r\nprospects?\r\n\r\nJane Eyre, who had been an ardent, expectant woman\xe2\x80\x94almost a bride, was\r\na cold, solitary girl again: her life was pale; her prospects were\r\ndesolate. A Christmas frost had come at midsummer; a white December\r\nstorm had whirled over June; ice glazed the ripe apples, drifts crushed\r\nthe blowing roses; on hayfield and cornfield lay a frozen shroud: lanes\r\nwhich last night blushed full of flowers, to-day were pathless with\r\nuntrodden snow; and the woods, which twelve hours since waved leafy and\r\nfragrant as groves between the tropics, now spread, waste, wild, and\r\nwhite as pine-forests in wintry Norway. My hopes were all dead\xe2\x80\x94struck\r\nwith a subtle doom, such as, in one night, fell on all the first-born\r\nin the land of Egypt. I looked on my cherished wishes, yesterday so\r\nblooming and glowing; they lay stark, chill, livid corpses that could\r\nnever revive. I looked at my love: that feeling which was my\r\nmaster\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94which he had created; it shivered in my heart, like a\r\nsuffering child in a cold cradle; sickness and anguish had seized it;\r\nit could not seek Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s arms\xe2\x80\x94it could not derive warmth from\r\nhis breast. Oh, never more could it turn to him; for faith was\r\nblighted\xe2\x80\x94confidence destroyed! Mr. Rochester was not to me what he had\r\nbeen; for he was not what I had thought him. I would not ascribe vice\r\nto him; I would not say he had betrayed me; but the attribute of\r\nstainless truth was gone from his idea, and from his presence I must\r\ngo: _that_ I perceived well. When\xe2\x80\x94how\xe2\x80\x94whither, I could not yet discern;\r\nbut he himself, I doubted not, would hurry me from Thornfield. Real\r\naffection, it seemed, he could not have for me; it had been only fitful\r\npassion: that was balked; he would want me no more. I should fear even\r\nto cross his path now: my view must be hateful to him. Oh, how blind\r\nhad been my eyes! How weak my conduct!\r\n\r\nMy eyes were covered and closed: eddying darkness seemed to swim round\r\nme, and reflection came in as black and confused a flow.\r\nSelf-abandoned, relaxed, and effortless, I seemed to have laid me down\r\nin the dried-up bed of a great river; I heard a flood loosened in\r\nremote mountains, and felt the torrent come: to rise I had no will, to\r\nflee I had no strength. I lay faint, longing to be dead. One idea only\r\nstill throbbed life-like within me\xe2\x80\x94a remembrance of God: it begot an\r\nunuttered prayer: these words went wandering up and down in my rayless\r\nmind, as something that should be whispered, but no energy was found to\r\nexpress them\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBe not far from me, for trouble is near: there is none to help.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was near: and as I had lifted no petition to Heaven to avert it\xe2\x80\x94as I\r\nhad neither joined my hands, nor bent my knees, nor moved my lips\xe2\x80\x94it\r\ncame: in full heavy swing the torrent poured over me. The whole\r\nconsciousness of my life lorn, my love lost, my hope quenched, my faith\r\ndeath-struck, swayed full and mighty above me in one sullen mass. That\r\nbitter hour cannot be described: in truth, \xe2\x80\x9cthe waters came into my\r\nsoul; I sank in deep mire: I felt no standing; I came into deep waters;\r\nthe floods overflowed me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVII\r\n\r\n\r\nSome time in the afternoon I raised my head, and looking round and\r\nseeing the western sun gilding the sign of its decline on the wall, I\r\nasked, \xe2\x80\x9cWhat am I to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut the answer my mind gave\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cLeave Thornfield at once\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94was so prompt,\r\nso dread, that I stopped my ears. I said I could not bear such words\r\nnow. \xe2\x80\x9cThat I am not Edward Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s bride is the least part of my\r\nwoe,\xe2\x80\x9d I alleged: \xe2\x80\x9cthat I have wakened out of most glorious dreams, and\r\nfound them all void and vain, is a horror I could bear and master; but\r\nthat I must leave him decidedly, instantly, entirely, is intolerable. I\r\ncannot do it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut, then, a voice within me averred that I could do it and foretold\r\nthat I should do it. I wrestled with my own resolution: I wanted to be\r\nweak that I might avoid the awful passage of further suffering I saw\r\nlaid out for me; and Conscience, turned tyrant, held Passion by the\r\nthroat, told her tauntingly, she had yet but dipped her dainty foot in\r\nthe slough, and swore that with that arm of iron he would thrust her\r\ndown to unsounded depths of agony.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me be torn away, then\xe2\x80\x9d I cried. \xe2\x80\x9cLet another help me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; you shall tear yourself away, none shall help you: you shall\r\nyourself pluck out your right eye; yourself cut off your right hand:\r\nyour heart shall be the victim, and you the priest to transfix it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI rose up suddenly, terror-struck at the solitude which so ruthless a\r\njudge haunted,\xe2\x80\x94at the silence which so awful a voice filled. My head\r\nswam as I stood erect. I perceived that I was sickening from excitement\r\nand inanition; neither meat nor drink had passed my lips that day, for\r\nI had taken no breakfast. And, with a strange pang, I now reflected\r\nthat, long as I had been shut up here, no message had been sent to ask\r\nhow I was, or to invite me to come down: not even little Ad\xc3\xa8le had\r\ntapped at the door; not even Mrs. Fairfax had sought me. \xe2\x80\x9cFriends\r\nalways forget those whom fortune forsakes,\xe2\x80\x9d I murmured, as I undrew the\r\nbolt and passed out. I stumbled over an obstacle: my head was still\r\ndizzy, my sight was dim, and my limbs were feeble. I could not soon\r\nrecover myself. I fell, but not on to the ground: an outstretched arm\r\ncaught me. I looked up\xe2\x80\x94I was supported by Mr. Rochester, who sat in a\r\nchair across my chamber threshold.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou come out at last,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cWell, I have been waiting for you\r\nlong, and listening: yet not one movement have I heard, nor one sob:\r\nfive minutes more of that death-like hush, and I should have forced the\r\nlock like a burglar. So you shun me?\xe2\x80\x94you shut yourself up and grieve\r\nalone! I would rather you had come and upbraided me with vehemence. You\r\nare passionate: I expected a scene of some kind. I was prepared for the\r\nhot rain of tears; only I wanted them to be shed on my breast: now a\r\nsenseless floor has received them, or your drenched handkerchief. But I\r\nerr: you have not wept at all! I see a white cheek and a faded eye, but\r\nno trace of tears. I suppose, then, your heart has been weeping blood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, Jane! not a word of reproach? Nothing bitter\xe2\x80\x94nothing poignant?\r\nNothing to cut a feeling or sting a passion? You sit quietly where I\r\nhave placed you, and regard me with a weary, passive look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I never meant to wound you thus. If the man who had but one\r\nlittle ewe lamb that was dear to him as a daughter, that ate of his\r\nbread and drank of his cup, and lay in his bosom, had by some mistake\r\nslaughtered it at the shambles, he would not have rued his bloody\r\nblunder more than I now rue mine. Will you ever forgive me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReader, I forgave him at the moment and on the spot. There was such\r\ndeep remorse in his eye, such true pity in his tone, such manly energy\r\nin his manner; and besides, there was such unchanged love in his whole\r\nlook and mien\xe2\x80\x94I forgave him all: yet not in words, not outwardly; only\r\nat my heart\xe2\x80\x99s core.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know I am a scoundrel, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d ere long he inquired\r\nwistfully\xe2\x80\x94wondering, I suppose, at my continued silence and tameness,\r\nthe result rather of weakness than of will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen tell me so roundly and sharply\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t spare me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot: I am tired and sick. I want some water.\xe2\x80\x9d He heaved a sort of\r\nshuddering sigh, and taking me in his arms, carried me downstairs. At\r\nfirst I did not know to what room he had borne me; all was cloudy to my\r\nglazed sight: presently I felt the reviving warmth of a fire; for,\r\nsummer as it was, I had become icy cold in my chamber. He put wine to\r\nmy lips; I tasted it and revived; then I ate something he offered me,\r\nand was soon myself. I was in the library\xe2\x80\x94sitting in his chair\xe2\x80\x94he was\r\nquite near. \xe2\x80\x9cIf I could go out of life now, without too sharp a pang,\r\nit would be well for me,\xe2\x80\x9d I thought; \xe2\x80\x9cthen I should not have to make\r\nthe effort of cracking my heart-strings in rending them from among Mr.\r\nRochester\xe2\x80\x99s. I must leave him, it appears. I do not want to leave him\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncannot leave him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow are you now, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMuch better, sir; I shall be well soon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTaste the wine again, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI obeyed him; then he put the glass on the table, stood before me, and\r\nlooked at me attentively. Suddenly he turned away, with an inarticulate\r\nexclamation, full of passionate emotion of some kind; he walked fast\r\nthrough the room and came back; he stooped towards me as if to kiss me;\r\nbut I remembered caresses were now forbidden. I turned my face away and\r\nput his aside.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat!\xe2\x80\x94How is this?\xe2\x80\x9d he exclaimed hastily. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, I know! you won\xe2\x80\x99t kiss\r\nthe husband of Bertha Mason? You consider my arms filled and my\r\nembraces appropriated?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, there is neither room nor claim for me, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy, Jane? I\r\nmust be provided for by a wealthy marriage. He sought me a partner\r\nbetimes. Mr. Mason, a West India planter and merchant, was his old\r\nacquaintance. He was certain his possessions were real and vast: he\r\nmade inquiries. Mr. Mason, he found, had a son and daughter; and he\r\nlearned from him that he could and would give the latter a fortune of\r\nthirty thousand pounds: that sufficed. When I left college, I was sent\r\nout to Jamaica, to espouse a bride already courted for me. My father\r\nsaid nothing about her money; but he told me Miss Mason was the boast\r\nof Spanish Town for her beauty: and this was no lie. I found her a fine\r\nwoman, in the style of Blanche Ingram: tall, dark, and majestic. Her\r\nfamily wished to secure me because I was of a good race; and so did\r\nshe. She\r\nflattered me, and lavishly displayed for my pleasure her charms and\r\naccomplishments. All the men in her circle seemed to admire her and\r\nenvy me. There is no\r\nfolly so besotted that the idiotic rivalries of society, the prurience,\r\nthe rashness, the blindness of youth, will not hurry a man to its\r\ncommission. With less sin I might\r\nhave\xe2\x80\x94But let me remember to whom I am speaking.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy bride\xe2\x80\x99s mother I had never seen: I understood she was dead. What a pigmy intellect she had, and\r\nwhat giant propensities! How fearful were the curses those propensities\r\nentailed on me! Bertha Mason, the true daughter of an infamous mother,\r\ndragged me through all the hideous and degrading agonies which must\r\nattend a man bound to a wife at once intemperate and unchaste.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy brother in the interval was dead, and at the end of the four years\r\nmy father died too.
