Jane, you don\xe2\x80\x99t like my\r\nnarrative; you look almost sick\xe2\x80\x94shall I defer the rest to another day?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir, finish it now; I pity you\xe2\x80\x94I do earnestly pity you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPity, Jane, from some people is a noxious and insulting sort of\r\ntribute, which one is justified in hurling back in the teeth of those\r\nwho offer it; but that is the sort of pity native to callous, selfish\r\nhearts; it is a hybrid, egotistical pain at hearing of woes, crossed\r\nwith ignorant contempt for those who have endured them. But that is not\r\nyour pity, Jane; it is not the feeling of which your whole face is full\r\nat this moment\xe2\x80\x94with which your eyes are now almost overflowing\xe2\x80\x94with\r\nwhich your heart is heaving\xe2\x80\x94with which your hand is trembling in mine.\r\nYour pity, my darling, is the suffering mother of love: its anguish is\r\nthe very natal pang of the divine passion. I accept it, Jane; let the\r\ndaughter have free advent\xe2\x80\x94my arms wait to receive her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, sir, proceed; what did you do when you found she was mad?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I approached the verge of despair; a remnant of self-respect was\r\nall that intervened between me and the gulf. In the eyes of the world,\r\nI was doubtless covered with grimy dishonour; but I resolved to be\r\nclean in my own sight\xe2\x80\x94and to the last I repudiated the contamination of\r\nher crimes, and wrenched myself from connection with her mental\r\ndefects. Still, society associated my name and person with hers; I yet\r\nsaw her and heard her daily: something of her breath (faugh!) mixed\r\nwith the air I breathed; and besides, I remembered I had once been her\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x94that recollection was then, and is now, inexpressibly odious to\r\nme; moreover, I knew that while she lived I could never be the husband\r\nof another and better wife; and, though five years my senior (her\r\nfamily and her father had lied to me even in the particular of her\r\nage), she was likely to live as long as I, being as robust in frame as\r\nshe was infirm in mind. Thus, at the age of twenty-six, I was hopeless.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne night I had been awakened by her yells\xe2\x80\x94(since the medical men had\r\npronounced her mad, she had, of course, been shut up)\xe2\x80\x94it was a fiery\r\nWest Indian night; one of the description that frequently precede the\r\nhurricanes of those climates. Being unable to sleep in bed, I got up\r\nand opened the window. The air was like sulphur-steams\xe2\x80\x94I could find no\r\nrefreshment anywhere. Mosquitoes came buzzing in and hummed sullenly\r\nround the room; the sea, which I could hear from thence, rumbled dull\r\nlike an earthquake\xe2\x80\x94black clouds were casting up over it; the moon was\r\nsetting in the waves, broad and red, like a hot cannon-ball\xe2\x80\x94she threw\r\nher last bloody glance over a world quivering with the ferment of\r\ntempest. I was physically influenced by the atmosphere and scene, and\r\nmy ears were filled with the curses the maniac still shrieked out;\r\nwherein she momentarily mingled my name with such a tone of demon-hate,\r\nwith such language!\xe2\x80\x94no professed harlot ever had a fouler vocabulary\r\nthan she: though two rooms off, I heard every word\xe2\x80\x94the thin partitions\r\nof the West India house opposing but slight obstruction to her wolfish\r\ncries.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98This life,\xe2\x80\x99 said I at last, \xe2\x80\x98is hell: this is the air\xe2\x80\x94those are the\r\nsounds of the bottomless pit! I have a right to deliver myself from it\r\nif I can. The sufferings of this mortal state will leave me with the\r\nheavy flesh that now cumbers my soul. Of the fanatic\xe2\x80\x99s burning eternity\r\nI have no fear: there is not a future state worse than this present\r\none\xe2\x80\x94let me break away, and go home to God!\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI said this whilst I knelt down at, and unlocked a trunk which\r\ncontained a brace of loaded pistols: I meant to shoot myself. I only\r\nentertained the intention for a moment; for, not being insane, the\r\ncrisis of exquisite and unalloyed despair, which had originated the\r\nwish and design of self-destruction, was past in a second.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA wind fresh from Europe blew over the ocean and rushed through the\r\nopen casement: the storm broke, streamed, thundered, blazed, and the\r\nair grew pure. I then framed and fixed a resolution. While I walked\r\nunder the dripping orange-trees of my wet garden, and amongst its\r\ndrenched pomegranates and pine-apples, and while the refulgent dawn of\r\nthe tropics kindled round me\xe2\x80\x94I reasoned thus, Jane\xe2\x80\x94and now listen; for\r\nit was true Wisdom that consoled me in that hour, and showed me the\r\nright path to follow.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sweet wind from Europe was still whispering in the refreshed\r\nleaves, and the Atlantic was thundering in glorious liberty; my heart,\r\ndried up and scorched for a long time, swelled to the tone, and filled\r\nwith living blood\xe2\x80\x94my being longed for renewal\xe2\x80\x94my soul thirsted for a\r\npure draught. I saw hope revive\xe2\x80\x94and felt regeneration possible. From a\r\nflowery arch at the bottom of my garden I gazed over the sea\xe2\x80\x94bluer than\r\nthe sky: the old world was beyond; clear prospects opened thus:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Go,\xe2\x80\x99 said Hope, \xe2\x80\x98and live again in Europe: there it is not known what\r\na sullied name you bear, nor what a filthy burden is bound to you. You\r\nmay take the maniac with you to England; confine her with due\r\nattendance and precautions at Thornfield: then travel yourself to what\r\nclime you will, and form what new tie you like. That woman, who has so\r\nabused your long-suffering, so sullied your name, so outraged your\r\nhonour, so blighted your youth, is not your wife, nor are you her\r\nhusband. See that she is cared for as her condition demands, and you\r\nhave done all that God and humanity require of you. Let her identity,\r\nher connection with yourself, be buried in oblivion: you are bound to\r\nimpart them to no living being. Place her in safety and comfort:\r\nshelter her degradation with secrecy, and leave her.\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI acted precisely on this suggestion. My father and brother had not\r\nmade my marriage known to their acquaintance; because, in the very\r\nfirst letter I wrote to apprise them of the union\xe2\x80\x94having already begun\r\nto experience extreme disgust of its consequences, and, from the family\r\ncharacter and constitution, seeing a hideous future opening to me\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nadded an urgent charge to keep it secret: and very soon the infamous\r\nconduct of the wife my father had selected for me was such as to make\r\nhim blush to own her as his daughter-in-law. Far from desiring to\r\npublish the connection, he became as anxious to conceal it as myself.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo England, then, I conveyed her; a fearful voyage I had with such a\r\nmonster in the vessel. Glad was I when I at last got her to Thornfield,\r\nand saw her safely lodged in that third-storey room, of whose secret\r\ninner cabinet she has now for ten years made a wild beast\xe2\x80\x99s den\xe2\x80\x94a\r\ngoblin\xe2\x80\x99s cell. I had some trouble in finding an attendant for her, as\r\nit was necessary to select one on whose fidelity dependence could be\r\nplaced; for her ravings would inevitably betray my secret: besides, she\r\nhad lucid intervals of days\xe2\x80\x94sometimes weeks\xe2\x80\x94which she filled up with\r\nabuse of me. At last I hired Grace Poole from the Grimbsy Retreat. She\r\nand the surgeon, Carter (who dressed Mason\xe2\x80\x99s wounds that night he was\r\nstabbed and worried), are the only two I have ever admitted to my\r\nconfidence. Mrs. Fairfax may indeed have suspected something, but she\r\ncould have gained no precise knowledge as to facts. Grace has, on the\r\nwhole, proved a good keeper; though, owing partly to a fault of her\r\nown, of which it appears nothing can cure her, and which is incident to\r\nher harassing profession, her vigilance has been more than once lulled\r\nand baffled. The lunatic is both cunning and malignant; she has never\r\nfailed to take advantage of her guardian\xe2\x80\x99s temporary lapses; once to\r\nsecrete the knife with which she stabbed her brother, and twice to\r\npossess herself of the key of her cell, and issue therefrom in the\r\nnight-time. On the first of these occasions, she perpetrated the\r\nattempt to burn me in my bed; on the second, she paid that ghastly\r\nvisit to you. I thank Providence, who watched over you, that she then\r\nspent her fury on your wedding apparel, which perhaps brought back\r\nvague reminiscences of her own bridal days: but on what might have\r\nhappened, I cannot endure to reflect. When I think of the thing which\r\nflew at my throat this morning, hanging its black and scarlet visage\r\nover the nest of my dove, my blood curdles\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, while he paused, \xe2\x80\x9cdid you do when you had\r\nsettled her here? Where did you go?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat did I do, Jane? I transformed myself into a will-o\xe2\x80\x99-the-wisp.\r\nWhere did I go? I pursued wanderings as wild as those of the\r\nMarch-spirit. I sought the Continent, and went devious through all its\r\nlands. My fixed desire was to seek and find a good and intelligent\r\nwoman, whom I could love: a contrast to the fury I left at Thornfield\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you could not marry, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI had determined and was convinced that I could and ought. It was not\r\nmy original intention to deceive, as I have deceived you. I meant to\r\ntell my tale plainly, and make my proposals openly: and it appeared to\r\nme so absolutely rational that I should be considered free to love and\r\nbe loved, I never doubted some woman might be found willing and able to\r\nunderstand my case and accept me, in spite of the curse with which I\r\nwas burdened.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you are inquisitive, Jane, you always make me smile. You open\r\nyour eyes like an eager bird, and make every now and then a restless\r\nmovement, as if answers in speech did not flow fast enough for you, and\r\nyou wanted to read the tablet of one\xe2\x80\x99s heart. But before I go on, tell\r\nme what you mean by your \xe2\x80\x98Well, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 It is a small phrase very\r\nfrequent with you; and which many a time has drawn me on and on through\r\ninterminable talk: I don\xe2\x80\x99t very well know why.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean,\xe2\x80\x94What next? How did you proceed? What came of such an event?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPrecisely! and what do you wish to know now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhether you found any one you liked: whether you asked her to marry\r\nyou; and what she said.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can tell you whether I found any one I liked, and whether I asked\r\nher to marry me: but what she said is yet to be recorded in the book of\r\nFate. For ten long years I roved about, living first in one capital,\r\nthen another: sometimes in St. Petersburg; oftener in Paris;\r\noccasionally in Rome, Naples, and Florence. Provided with plenty of\r\nmoney and the passport of an old name, I could choose my own society:\r\nno circles were closed against me. I sought my ideal of a woman amongst\r\nEnglish ladies, French countesses, Italian signoras, and German\r\ngr\xc3\xa4finnen. I could not find her. Sometimes, for a fleeting moment, I\r\nthought I caught a glance, heard a tone, beheld a form, which announced\r\nthe realisation of my dream: but I was presently undeceived. You are\r\nnot to suppose that I desired perfection, either of mind or person. I\r\nlonged only for what suited me\xe2\x80\x94for the antipodes of the Creole: and I\r\nlonged vainly. Amongst them all I found not one whom, had I been ever\r\nso free, I\xe2\x80\x94warned as I was of the risks, the horrors, the loathings of\r\nincongruous unions\xe2\x80\x94would have asked to marry me. Disappointment made me\r\nreckless. I tried dissipation\xe2\x80\x94never debauchery: that I hated, and hate.\r\nThat was my Indian Messalina\xe2\x80\x99s attribute: rooted disgust at it and her\r\nrestrained me much, even in pleasure. Any enjoyment that bordered on\r\nriot seemed to approach me to her and her vices, and I eschewed it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet I could not live alone; so I tried the companionship of\r\nmistresses. The first I chose was C\xc3\xa9line Varens\xe2\x80\x94another of those steps\r\nwhich make a man spurn himself when he recalls them. You already know\r\nwhat she was, and how my liaison with her terminated. She had two\r\nsuccessors: an Italian, Giacinta, and a German, Clara; both considered\r\nsingularly handsome. What was their beauty to me in a few weeks?\r\nGiacinta was unprincipled and violent: I tired of her in three months.\r\nClara was honest and quiet; but heavy, mindless, and unimpressible: not\r\none whit to my taste. I was glad to give her a sufficient sum to set\r\nher up in a good line of business, and so get decently rid of her. But,\r\nJane, I see by your face you are not forming a very favourable opinion\r\nof me just now. You think me an unfeeling, loose-principled rake: don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nyou?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t like you so well as I have done sometimes, indeed, sir. Did it\r\nnot seem to you in the least wrong to live in that way, first with one\r\nmistress and then another? You talk of it as a mere matter of course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was with me; and I did not like it. It was a grovelling fashion of\r\nexistence: I should never like to return to it. Hiring a mistress is\r\nthe next worse thing to buying a slave: both are often by nature, and\r\nalways by position, inferior: and to live familiarly with inferiors is\r\ndegrading. I now hate the recollection of the time I passed with\r\nC\xc3\xa9line, Giacinta, and Clara.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt the truth of these words; and I drew from them the certain\r\ninference, that if I were so far to forget myself and all the teaching\r\nthat had ever been instilled into me, as\xe2\x80\x94under any pretext\xe2\x80\x94with any\r\njustification\xe2\x80\x94through any temptation\xe2\x80\x94to become the successor of these\r\npoor girls, he would one day regard me with the same feeling which now\r\nin his mind desecrated their memory. I did not give utterance to this\r\nconviction: it was enough to feel it. I impressed it on my heart, that\r\nit might remain there to serve me as aid in the time of trial.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow, Jane, why don\xe2\x80\x99t you say \xe2\x80\x98Well, sir?\xe2\x80\x99 I have not done. You are\r\nlooking grave. You disapprove of me still, I see. But let me come to\r\nthe point. Last January, rid of all mistresses\xe2\x80\x94in a harsh, bitter frame\r\nof mind, the result of a useless, roving, lonely life\xe2\x80\x94corroded with\r\ndisappointment, sourly disposed against all men, and especially against\r\nall _woman_kind (for I began to regard the notion of an intellectual,\r\nfaithful, loving woman as a mere dream), recalled by business, I came\r\nback to England.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn a frosty winter afternoon, I rode in sight of Thornfield Hall.\r\nAbhorred spot! I expected no peace\xe2\x80\x94no pleasure there. On a stile in Hay\r\nLane I saw a quiet little figure sitting by itself. I passed it as\r\nnegligently as I did the pollard willow opposite to it: I had no\r\npresentiment of what it would be to me; no inward warning that the\r\narbitress of my life\xe2\x80\x94my genius for good or evil\xe2\x80\x94waited there in humble\r\nguise. I did not know it, even when, on the occasion of Mesrour\xe2\x80\x99s\r\naccident, it came up and gravely offered me help. Childish and slender\r\ncreature! It seemed as if a linnet had hopped to my foot and proposed\r\nto bear me on its tiny wing. I was surly; but the thing would not go:\r\nit stood by me with strange perseverance, and looked and spoke with a\r\nsort of authority. I must be aided, and by that hand: and aided I was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen once I had pressed the frail shoulder, something new\xe2\x80\x94a fresh sap\r\nand sense\xe2\x80\x94stole into my frame. It was well I had learnt that this elf\r\nmust return to me\xe2\x80\x94that it belonged to my house down below\xe2\x80\x94or I could\r\nnot have felt it pass away from under my hand, and seen it vanish\r\nbehind the dim hedge, without singular regret. I heard you come home\r\nthat night, Jane, though probably you were not aware that I thought of\r\nyou or watched for you. The next day I observed you\xe2\x80\x94myself unseen\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nhalf-an-hour, while you played with Ad\xc3\xa8le in the gallery. It was a\r\nsnowy day, I recollect, and you could not go out of doors. I was in my\r\nroom; the door was ajar: I could both listen and watch. Ad\xc3\xa8le claimed\r\nyour outward attention for a while; yet I fancied your thoughts were\r\nelsewhere: but you were very patient with her, my little Jane; you\r\ntalked to her and amused her a long time. When at last she left you,\r\nyou lapsed at once into deep reverie: you betook yourself slowly to\r\npace the gallery. Now and then, in passing a casement, you glanced out\r\nat the thick-falling snow; you listened to the sobbing wind, and again\r\nyou paced gently on and dreamed. I think those day visions were not\r\ndark: there was a pleasurable illumination in your eye occasionally, a\r\nsoft excitement in your aspect, which told of no bitter, bilious,\r\nhypochondriac brooding: your look revealed rather the sweet musings of\r\nyouth when its spirit follows on willing wings the flight of Hope up\r\nand on to an ideal heaven. The voice of Mrs. Fairfax, speaking to a\r\nservant in the hall, wakened you: and how curiously you smiled to and\r\nat yourself, Janet! There was much sense in your smile: it was very\r\nshrewd, and seemed to make light of your own abstraction. It seemed to\r\nsay\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98My fine visions are all very well, but I must not forget they are\r\nabsolutely unreal. I have a rosy sky and a green flowery Eden in my\r\nbrain; but without, I am perfectly aware, lies at my feet a rough tract\r\nto travel, and around me gather black tempests to encounter.\xe2\x80\x99 You ran\r\ndownstairs and demanded of Mrs. Fairfax some occupation: the weekly\r\nhouse accounts to make up, or something of that sort, I think it was. I\r\nwas vexed with you for getting out of my sight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cImpatiently I waited for evening, when I might summon you to my\r\npresence. An unusual\xe2\x80\x94to me\xe2\x80\x94a perfectly new character I suspected was\r\nyours: I desired to search it deeper and know it better. You entered\r\nthe room with a look and air at once shy and independent: you were\r\nquaintly dressed\xe2\x80\x94much as you are now. I made you talk: ere long I found\r\nyou full of strange contrasts. Your garb and manner were restricted by\r\nrule; your air was often diffident, and altogether that of one refined\r\nby nature, but absolutely unused to society, and a good deal afraid of\r\nmaking herself disadvantageously conspicuous by some solecism or\r\nblunder; yet when addressed, you lifted a keen, a daring, and a glowing\r\neye to your interlocutor\xe2\x80\x99s face: there was penetration and power in\r\neach glance you gave; when plied by close questions, you found ready\r\nand round answers. Very soon you seemed to get used to me: I believe\r\nyou felt the existence of sympathy between you and your grim and cross\r\nmaster, Jane; for it was astonishing to see how quickly a certain\r\npleasant ease tranquillised your manner: snarl as I would, you showed\r\nno surprise, fear, annoyance, or displeasure at my moroseness; you\r\nwatched me, and now and then smiled at me with a simple yet sagacious\r\ngrace I cannot describe. I was at once content and stimulated with what\r\nI saw: I liked what I had seen, and wished to see more. Yet, for a long\r\ntime, I treated you distantly, and sought your company rarely. I was an\r\nintellectual epicure, and wished to prolong the gratification of making\r\nthis novel and piquant acquaintance: besides, I was for a while\r\ntroubled with a haunting fear that if I handled the flower freely its\r\nbloom would fade\xe2\x80\x94the sweet charm of freshness would leave it. I did not\r\nthen know that it was no transitory blossom, but rather the radiant\r\nresemblance of one, cut in an indestructible gem. Moreover, I wished to\r\nsee whether you would seek me if I shunned you\xe2\x80\x94but you did not; you\r\nkept in the schoolroom as still as your own desk and easel; if by\r\nchance I met you, you passed me as soon, and with as little token of\r\nrecognition, as was consistent with respect. Your habitual expression\r\nin those days, Jane, was a thoughtful look; not despondent, for you\r\nwere not sickly; but not buoyant, for you had little hope, and no\r\nactual pleasure. I wondered what you thought of me, or if you ever\r\nthought of me, and resolved to find this out.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI resumed my notice of you. There was something glad in your glance,\r\nand genial in your manner, when you conversed: I saw you had a social\r\nheart; it was the silent schoolroom\xe2\x80\x94it was the tedium of your life\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nmade you mournful. I permitted myself the delight of being kind to you;\r\nkindness stirred emotion soon: your face became soft in expression,\r\nyour tones gentle; I liked my name pronounced by your lips in a\r\ngrateful happy accent. I used to enjoy a chance meeting with you, Jane,\r\nat this time: there was a curious hesitation in your manner: you\r\nglanced at me with a slight trouble\xe2\x80\x94a hovering doubt: you did not know\r\nwhat my caprice might be\xe2\x80\x94whether I was going to play the master and be\r\nstern, or the friend and be benignant. I was now too fond of you often\r\nto simulate the first whim; and, when I stretched my hand out\r\ncordially, such bloom and light and bliss rose to your young, wistful\r\nfeatures, I had much ado often to avoid straining you then and there to\r\nmy heart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t talk any more of those days, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I interrupted, furtively\r\ndashing away some tears from my eyes; his language was torture to me;\r\nfor I knew what I must do\xe2\x80\x94and do soon\xe2\x80\x94and all these reminiscences, and\r\nthese revelations of his feelings only made my work more difficult.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d he returned: \xe2\x80\x9cwhat necessity is there to dwell on the Past,\r\nwhen the Present is so much surer\xe2\x80\x94the Future so much brighter?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI shuddered to hear the infatuated assertion.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou see now how the case stands\xe2\x80\x94do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d he continued. \xe2\x80\x9cAfter a\r\nyouth and manhood passed half in unutterable misery and half in dreary\r\nsolitude, I have for the first time found what I can truly love\xe2\x80\x94I have\r\nfound _you_. You are my sympathy\xe2\x80\x94my better self\xe2\x80\x94my good angel. I am\r\nbound to you with a strong attachment. I think you good, gifted,\r\nlovely: a fervent, a solemn passion is conceived in my heart; it leans\r\nto you, draws you to my centre and spring of life, wraps my existence\r\nabout you, and, kindling in pure, powerful flame, fuses you and me in\r\none.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was because I felt and knew this, that I resolved to marry you. To\r\ntell me that I had already a wife is empty mockery: you know now that I\r\nhad but a hideous demon. I was wrong to attempt to deceive you; but I\r\nfeared a stubbornness that exists in your character. I feared early\r\ninstilled prejudice: I wanted to have you safe before hazarding\r\nconfidences. This was cowardly: I should have appealed to your\r\nnobleness and magnanimity at first, as I do now\xe2\x80\x94opened to you plainly\r\nmy life of agony\xe2\x80\x94described to you my hunger and thirst after a higher\r\nand worthier existence\xe2\x80\x94shown to you, not my _resolution_ (that word is\r\nweak), but my resistless _bent_ to love faithfully and well, where I am\r\nfaithfully and well loved in return. Then I should have asked you to\r\naccept my pledge of fidelity and to give me yours. Jane\xe2\x80\x94give it me\r\nnow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy are you silent, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was experiencing an ordeal: a hand of fiery iron grasped my vitals.\r\nTerrible moment: full of struggle, blackness, burning! Not a human\r\nbeing that ever lived could wish to be loved better than I was loved;\r\nand him who thus loved me I absolutely worshipped: and I must renounce\r\nlove and idol. One drear word comprised my intolerable duty\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cDepart!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, you understand what I want of you? Just this promise\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98I will be\r\nyours, Mr. Rochester.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, I will _not_ be yours.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnother long silence.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane!\xe2\x80\x9d recommenced he, with a gentleness that broke me down with\r\ngrief, and turned me stone-cold with ominous terror\xe2\x80\x94for this still\r\nvoice was the pant of a lion rising\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJane, do you mean to go one way in\r\nthe world, and to let me go another?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane\xe2\x80\x9d (bending towards and embracing me), \xe2\x80\x9cdo you mean it now?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd now?\xe2\x80\x9d softly kissing my forehead and cheek.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do,\xe2\x80\x9d extricating myself from restraint rapidly and completely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, Jane, this is bitter! This\xe2\x80\x94this is wicked. It would not be wicked\r\nto love me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt would to obey you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA wild look raised his brows\xe2\x80\x94crossed his features: he rose; but he\r\nforebore yet. I laid my hand on the back of a chair for support: I\r\nshook, I feared\xe2\x80\x94but I resolved.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOne instant, Jane. Give one glance to my horrible life when you are\r\ngone. All happiness will be torn away with you. What then is left? For\r\na wife I have but the maniac upstairs: as well might you refer me to\r\nsome corpse in yonder churchyard. What shall I do, Jane? Where turn for\r\na companion and for some hope?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo as I do: trust in God and yourself. Believe in heaven. Hope to meet\r\nagain there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you will not yield?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you condemn me to live wretched and to die accursed?\xe2\x80\x9d His voice\r\nrose.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI advise you to live sinless, and I wish you to die tranquil.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen you snatch love and innocence from me? You fling me back on lust\r\nfor a passion\xe2\x80\x94vice for an occupation?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, I no more assign this fate to you than I grasp at it\r\nfor myself. We were born to strive and endure\xe2\x80\x94you as well as I: do so.\r\nYou will forget me before I forget you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou make me a liar by such language: you sully my honour. I declared I\r\ncould not change: you tell me to my face I shall change soon. And what\r\na distortion in your judgment, what a perversity in your ideas, is\r\nproved by your conduct! Is it better to drive a fellow-creature to\r\ndespair than to transgress a mere human law, no man being injured by\r\nthe breach? for you have neither relatives nor acquaintances whom you\r\nneed fear to offend by living with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was true: and while he spoke my very conscience and reason turned\r\ntraitors against me, and charged me with crime in resisting him. They\r\nspoke almost as loud as Feeling: and that clamoured wildly. \xe2\x80\x9cOh,\r\ncomply!\xe2\x80\x9d it said. \xe2\x80\x9cThink of his misery; think of his danger\xe2\x80\x94look at his\r\nstate when left alone; remember his headlong nature; consider the\r\nrecklessness following on despair\xe2\x80\x94soothe him; save him; love him; tell\r\nhim you love him and will be his. Who in the world cares for _you_? or\r\nwho will be injured by what you do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nStill indomitable was the reply\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9c_I_ care for myself. The more\r\nsolitary, the more friendless, the more unsustained I am, the more I\r\nwill respect myself. I will keep the law given by God; sanctioned by\r\nman. I will hold to the principles received by me when I was sane, and\r\nnot mad\xe2\x80\x94as I am now. Laws and principles are not for the times when\r\nthere is no temptation: they are for such moments as this, when body\r\nand soul rise in mutiny against their rigour; stringent are they;\r\ninviolate they shall be. If at my individual convenience I might break\r\nthem, what would be their worth? They have a worth\xe2\x80\x94so I have always\r\nbelieved; and if I cannot believe it now, it is because I am\r\ninsane\xe2\x80\x94quite insane: with my veins running fire, and my heart beating\r\nfaster than I can count its throbs. Preconceived opinions, foregone\r\ndeterminations, are all I have at this hour to stand by: there I plant\r\nmy foot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did. Mr. Rochester, reading my countenance, saw I had done so. His\r\nfury was wrought to the highest: he must yield to it for a moment,\r\nwhatever followed; he crossed the floor and seized my arm and grasped\r\nmy waist. He seemed to devour me with his flaming glance: physically, I\r\nfelt, at the moment, powerless as stubble exposed to the draught and\r\nglow of a furnace: mentally, I still possessed my soul, and with it the\r\ncertainty of ultimate safety. The soul, fortunately, has an\r\ninterpreter\xe2\x80\x94often an unconscious, but still a truthful interpreter\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nthe eye. My eye rose to his; and while I looked in his fierce face I\r\ngave an involuntary sigh; his gripe was painful, and my over-taxed\r\nstrength almost exhausted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, as he ground his teeth, \xe2\x80\x9cnever was anything at once\r\nso frail and so indomitable. A mere reed she feels in my hand!\xe2\x80\x9d (And he\r\nshook me with the force of his hold.) \xe2\x80\x9cI could bend her with my finger\r\nand thumb: and what good would it do if I bent, if I uptore, if I\r\ncrushed her? Consider that eye: consider the resolute, wild, free thing\r\nlooking out of it, defying me, with more than courage\xe2\x80\x94with a stern\r\ntriumph. Whatever I do with its cage, I cannot get at it\xe2\x80\x94the savage,\r\nbeautiful creature! If I tear, if I rend the slight prison, my outrage\r\nwill only let the captive loose. Conqueror I might be of the house; but\r\nthe inmate would escape to heaven before I could call myself possessor\r\nof its clay dwelling-place. And it is you, spirit\xe2\x80\x94with will and energy,\r\nand virtue and purity\xe2\x80\x94that I want: not alone your brittle frame. Of\r\nyourself you could come with soft flight and nestle against my heart,\r\nif you would: seized against your will, you will elude the grasp like\r\nan essence\xe2\x80\x94you will vanish ere I inhale your fragrance. Oh! come, Jane,\r\ncome!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs he said this, he released me from his clutch, and only looked at me.\r\nThe look was far worse to resist than the frantic strain: only an\r\nidiot, however, would have succumbed now. I had dared and baffled his\r\nfury; I must elude his sorrow: I retired to the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are going, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am going, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are leaving me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not come? You will not be my comforter, my rescuer? My deep\r\nlove, my wild woe, my frantic prayer, are all nothing to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat unutterable pathos was in his voice! How hard it was to reiterate\r\nfirmly, \xe2\x80\x9cI am going.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWithdraw, then,\xe2\x80\x94I consent; but remember, you leave me here in anguish.\r\nGo up to your own room; think over all I have said, and, Jane, cast a\r\nglance on my sufferings\xe2\x80\x94think of me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe turned away; he threw himself on his face on the sofa. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, Jane! my\r\nhope\xe2\x80\x94my love\xe2\x80\x94my life!\xe2\x80\x9d broke in anguish from his lips. Then came a\r\ndeep, strong sob.\r\n\r\nI had already gained the door; but, reader, I walked back\xe2\x80\x94walked back\r\nas determinedly as I had retreated. I knelt down by him; I turned his\r\nface from the cushion to me; I kissed his cheek; I smoothed his hair\r\nwith my hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGod bless you, my dear master!\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cGod keep you from harm and\r\nwrong\xe2\x80\x94direct you, solace you\xe2\x80\x94reward you well for your past kindness to\r\nme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLittle Jane\xe2\x80\x99s love would have been my best reward,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cwithout it, my heart is broken. But Jane will give me her love:\r\nyes\xe2\x80\x94nobly, generously.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nUp the blood rushed to his face; forth flashed the fire from his eyes;\r\nerect he sprang; he held his arms out; but I evaded the embrace, and at\r\nonce quitted the room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell!\xe2\x80\x9d was the cry of my heart as I left him. Despair added,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell for ever!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThat night I never thought to sleep; but a slumber fell on me as soon\r\nas I lay down in bed. I was transported in thought to the scenes of\r\nchildhood: I dreamt I lay in the red-room at Gateshead; that the night\r\nwas dark, and my mind impressed with strange fears. The light that long\r\nago had struck me into syncope, recalled in this vision, seemed\r\nglidingly to mount the wall, and tremblingly to pause in the centre of\r\nthe obscured ceiling. I lifted up my head to look: the roof resolved to\r\nclouds, high and dim; the gleam was such as the moon imparts to vapours\r\nshe is about to sever. I watched her come\xe2\x80\x94watched with the strangest\r\nanticipation; as though some word of doom were to be written on her\r\ndisk. She broke forth as never moon yet burst from cloud: a hand first\r\npenetrated the sable folds and waved them away; then, not a moon, but a\r\nwhite human form shone in the azure, inclining a glorious brow\r\nearthward. It gazed and gazed on me. It spoke to my spirit:\r\nimmeasurably distant was the tone, yet so near, it whispered in my\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy daughter, flee temptation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMother, I will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo I answered after I had waked from the trance-like dream. It was yet\r\nnight, but July nights are short: soon after midnight, dawn comes. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\r\ncannot be too early to commence the task I have to fulfil,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I.\r\nI rose: I was dressed; for I had taken off nothing but my shoes. I knew\r\nwhere to find in my drawers some linen, a locket, a ring. In seeking\r\nthese articles, I encountered the beads of a pearl necklace Mr.\r\nRochester had forced me to accept a few days ago. I left that; it was\r\nnot mine: it was the visionary bride\xe2\x80\x99s who had melted in air. The other\r\narticles I made up in a parcel; my purse, containing twenty shillings\r\n(it was all I had), I put in my pocket: I tied on my straw bonnet,\r\npinned my shawl, took the parcel and my slippers, which I would not put\r\non yet, and stole from my room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, kind Mrs. Fairfax!\xe2\x80\x9d I whispered, as I glided past her door.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFarewell, my darling Ad\xc3\xa8le!\xe2\x80\x9d I said, as I glanced towards the nursery.\r\nNo thought could be admitted of entering to embrace her. I had to\r\ndeceive a fine ear: for aught I knew it might now be listening.\r\n\r\nI would have got past Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s chamber without a pause; but my\r\nheart momentarily stopping its beat at that threshold, my foot was\r\nforced to stop also. No sleep was there: the inmate was walking\r\nrestlessly from wall to wall; and again and again he sighed while I\r\nlistened. There was a heaven\xe2\x80\x94a temporary heaven\xe2\x80\x94in this room for me, if\r\nI chose: I had but to go in and to say\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, I will love you and live with you through life till\r\ndeath,\xe2\x80\x9d and a fount of rapture would spring to my lips. I thought of\r\nthis.\r\n\r\nThat kind master, who could not sleep now, was waiting with impatience\r\nfor day. He would send for me in the morning; I should be gone. He\r\nwould have me sought for: vainly. He would feel himself forsaken; his\r\nlove rejected: he would suffer; perhaps grow desperate. I thought of\r\nthis too. My hand moved towards the lock: I caught it back, and glided\r\non.\r\n\r\nDrearily I wound my way downstairs: I knew what I had to do, and I did\r\nit mechanically. I sought the key of the side-door in the kitchen; I\r\nsought, too, a phial of oil and a feather; I oiled the key and the\r\nlock. I got some water, I got some bread: for perhaps I should have to\r\nwalk far; and my strength, sorely shaken of late, must not break down.\r\nAll this I did without one sound. I opened the door, passed out, shut\r\nit softly. Dim dawn glimmered in the yard. The great gates were closed\r\nand locked; but a wicket in one of them was only latched. Through that\r\nI departed: it, too, I shut; and now I was out of Thornfield.\r\n\r\nA mile off, beyond the fields, lay a road which stretched in the\r\ncontrary direction to Millcote; a road I had never travelled, but often\r\nnoticed, and wondered where it led: thither I bent my steps. No\r\nreflection was to be allowed now: not one glance was to be cast back;\r\nnot even one forward. Not one thought was to be given either to the\r\npast or the future. The first was a page so heavenly sweet\xe2\x80\x94so deadly\r\nsad\xe2\x80\x94that to read one line of it would dissolve my courage and break\r\ndown my energy. The last was an awful blank: something like the world\r\nwhen the deluge was gone by.\r\n\r\nI skirted fields, and hedges, and lanes till after sunrise. I believe\r\nit was a lovely summer morning: I know my shoes, which I had put on\r\nwhen I left the house, were soon wet with dew. But I looked neither to\r\nrising sun, nor smiling sky, nor wakening nature. He who is taken out\r\nto pass through a fair scene to the scaffold, thinks not of the flowers\r\nthat smile on his road, but of the block and axe-edge; of the\r\ndisseverment of bone and vein; of the grave gaping at the end: and I\r\nthought of drear flight and homeless wandering\xe2\x80\x94and oh! with agony I\r\nthought of what I left. I could not help it. I thought of him now\xe2\x80\x94in\r\nhis room\xe2\x80\x94watching the sunrise; hoping I should soon come to say I would\r\nstay with him and be his. I longed to be his; I panted to return: it\r\nwas not too late; I could yet spare him the bitter pang of bereavement.\r\nAs yet my flight, I was sure, was undiscovered. I could go back and be\r\nhis comforter\xe2\x80\x94his pride; his redeemer from misery, perhaps from ruin.\r\nOh, that fear of his self-abandonment\xe2\x80\x94far worse than my abandonment\xe2\x80\x94how\r\nit goaded me! It was a barbed arrow-head in my breast; it tore me when\r\nI tried to extract it; it sickened me when remembrance thrust it\r\nfarther in. Birds began singing in brake and copse: birds were faithful\r\nto their mates; birds were emblems of love. What was I? In the midst of\r\nmy pain of heart and frantic effort of principle, I abhorred myself. I\r\nhad no solace from self-approbation: none even from self-respect. I had\r\ninjured\xe2\x80\x94wounded\xe2\x80\x94left my master. I was hateful in my own eyes. Still I\r\ncould not turn, nor retrace one step. God must have led me on. As to my\r\nown will or conscience, impassioned grief had trampled one and stifled\r\nthe other. I was weeping wildly as I walked along my solitary way:\r\nfast, fast I went like one delirious. A weakness, beginning inwardly,\r\nextending to the limbs, seized me, and I fell: I lay on the ground some\r\nminutes, pressing my face to the wet turf. I had some fear\xe2\x80\x94or hope\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nhere I should die: but I was soon up; crawling forwards on my hands and\r\nknees, and then again raised to my feet\xe2\x80\x94as eager and as determined as\r\never to reach the road.\r\n\r\nWhen I got there, I was forced to sit to rest me under the hedge; and\r\nwhile I sat, I heard wheels, and saw a coach come on. I stood up and\r\nlifted my hand; it stopped. I asked where it was going: the driver\r\nnamed a place a long way off, and where I was sure Mr. Rochester had no\r\nconnections. I asked for what sum he would take me there; he said\r\nthirty shillings; I answered I had but twenty; well, he would try to\r\nmake it do. He further gave me leave to get into the inside, as the\r\nvehicle was empty: I entered, was shut in, and it rolled on its way.\r\n\r\nGentle reader, may you never feel what I then felt! May your eyes never\r\nshed such stormy, scalding, heart-wrung tears as poured from mine. May\r\nyou never appeal to Heaven in prayers so hopeless and so agonised as in\r\nthat hour left my lips; for never may you, like me, dread to be the\r\ninstrument of evil to what you wholly love.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXVIII\r\n\r\n\r\nTwo days are passed. It is a summer evening; the coachman has set me\r\ndown at a place called Whitcross; he could take me no farther for the\r\nsum I had given, and I was not possessed of another shilling in the\r\nworld. The coach is a mile off by this time; I am alone. At this moment\r\nI discover that I forgot to take my parcel out of the pocket of the\r\ncoach, where I had placed it for safety; there it remains, there it\r\nmust remain; and now, I am absolutely destitute.\r\n\r\nWhitcross is no town, nor even a hamlet; it is but a stone pillar set\r\nup where four roads meet: whitewashed, I suppose, to be more obvious at\r\na distance and in darkness. Four arms spring from its summit: the\r\nnearest town to which these point is, according to the inscription,\r\ndistant ten miles; the farthest, above twenty. From the well-known\r\nnames of these towns I learn in what county I have lighted; a\r\nnorth-midland shire, dusk with moorland, ridged with mountain: this I\r\nsee. There are great moors behind and on each hand of me; there are\r\nwaves of mountains far beyond that deep valley at my feet. The\r\npopulation here must be thin, and I see no passengers on these roads:\r\nthey stretch out east, west, north, and south\xe2\x80\x94white, broad, lonely;\r\nthey are all cut in the moor, and the heather grows deep and wild to\r\ntheir very verge. Yet a chance traveller might pass by; and I wish no\r\neye to see me now: strangers would wonder what I am doing, lingering\r\nhere at the sign-post, evidently objectless and lost. I might be\r\nquestioned: I could give no answer but what would sound incredible and\r\nexcite suspicion. Not a tie holds me to human society at this\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94not a charm or hope calls me where my fellow-creatures are\xe2\x80\x94none\r\nthat saw me would have a kind thought or a good wish for me. I have no\r\nrelative but the universal mother, Nature: I will seek her breast and\r\nask repose.\r\n\r\nI struck straight into the heath; I held on to a hollow I saw deeply\r\nfurrowing the brown moorside; I waded knee-deep in its dark growth; I\r\nturned with its turnings, and finding a moss-blackened granite crag in\r\na hidden angle, I sat down under it. High banks of moor were about me;\r\nthe crag protected my head: the sky was over that.\r\n\r\nSome time passed before I felt tranquil even here: I had a vague dread\r\nthat wild cattle might be near, or that some sportsman or poacher might\r\ndiscover me. If a gust of wind swept the waste, I looked up, fearing it\r\nwas the rush of a bull; if a plover whistled, I imagined it a man.\r\nFinding my apprehensions unfounded, however, and calmed by the deep\r\nsilence that reigned as evening declined at nightfall, I took\r\nconfidence. As yet I had not thought; I had only listened, watched,\r\ndreaded; now I regained the faculty of reflection.\r\n\r\nWhat was I to do? Where to go? Oh, intolerable questions, when I could\r\ndo nothing and go nowhere!\xe2\x80\x94when a long way must yet be measured by my\r\nweary, trembling limbs before I could reach human habitation\xe2\x80\x94when cold\r\ncharity must be entreated before I could get a lodging: reluctant\r\nsympathy importuned, almost certain repulse incurred, before my tale\r\ncould be listened to, or one of my wants relieved!\r\n\r\nI touched the heath: it was dry, and yet warm with the heat of the\r\nsummer day. I looked at the sky; it was pure: a kindly star twinkled\r\njust above the chasm ridge. The dew fell, but with propitious softness;\r\nno breeze whispered. Nature seemed to me benign and good; I thought she\r\nloved me, outcast as I was; and I, who from man could anticipate only\r\nmistrust, rejection, insult, clung to her with filial fondness.\r\nTo-night, at least, I would be her guest, as I was her child: my mother\r\nwould lodge me without money and without price. I had one morsel of\r\nbread yet: the remnant of a roll I had bought in a town we passed\r\nthrough at noon with a stray penny\xe2\x80\x94my last coin. I saw ripe bilberries\r\ngleaming here and there, like jet beads in the heath: I gathered a\r\nhandful and ate them with the bread. My hunger, sharp before, was, if\r\nnot satisfied, appeased by this hermit\xe2\x80\x99s meal. I said my evening\r\nprayers at its conclusion, and then chose my couch.\r\n\r\n\r\nI said my evening prayers\r\n\r\nBeside the crag the heath was very deep: when I lay down my feet were\r\nburied in it; rising high on each side, it left only a narrow space for\r\nthe night-air to invade. I folded my shawl double, and spread it over\r\nme for a coverlet; a low, mossy swell was my pillow. Thus lodged, I was\r\nnot, at least at the commencement of the night, cold.\r\n\r\nMy rest might have been blissful enough, only a sad heart broke it. It\r\nplained of its gaping wounds, its inward bleeding, its riven chords. It\r\ntrembled for Mr. Rochester and his doom; it bemoaned him with bitter\r\npity; it demanded him with ceaseless longing; and, impotent as a bird\r\nwith both wings broken, it still quivered its shattered pinions in vain\r\nattempts to seek him.\r\n\r\nWorn out with this torture of thought, I rose to my knees. Night was\r\ncome, and her planets were risen: a safe, still night: too serene for\r\nthe companionship of fear. We know that God is everywhere; but\r\ncertainly we feel His presence most when His works are on the grandest\r\nscale spread before us; and it is in the unclouded night-sky, where His\r\nworlds wheel their silent course, that we read clearest His infinitude,\r\nHis omnipotence, His omnipresence. I had risen to my knees to pray for\r\nMr. Rochester. Looking up, I, with tear-dimmed eyes, saw the mighty\r\nMilky-way. Remembering what it was\xe2\x80\x94what countless systems there swept\r\nspace like a soft trace of light\xe2\x80\x94I felt the might and strength of God.\r\nSure was I of His efficiency to save what He had made: convinced I grew\r\nthat neither earth should perish, nor one of the souls it treasured. I\r\nturned my prayer to thanksgiving: the Source of Life was also the\r\nSaviour of spirits. Mr. Rochester was safe: he was God\xe2\x80\x99s, and by God\r\nwould he be guarded. I again nestled to the breast of the hill; and ere\r\nlong in sleep forgot sorrow.\r\n\r\nBut next day, Want came to me pale and bare. Long after the little\r\nbirds had left their nests; long after bees had come in the sweet prime\r\nof day to gather the heath honey before the dew was dried\xe2\x80\x94when the long\r\nmorning shadows were curtailed, and the sun filled earth and sky\xe2\x80\x94I got\r\nup, and I looked round me.\r\n\r\nWhat a still, hot, perfect day! What a golden desert this spreading\r\nmoor! Everywhere sunshine. I wished I could live in it and on it. I saw\r\na lizard run over the crag; I saw a bee busy among the sweet\r\nbilberries. I would fain at the moment have become bee or lizard, that\r\nI might have found fitting nutriment, permanent shelter here. But I was\r\na human being, and had a human being\xe2\x80\x99s wants: I must not linger where\r\nthere was nothing to supply them. I rose; I looked back at the bed I\r\nhad left. Hopeless of the future, I wished but this\xe2\x80\x94that my Maker had\r\nthat night thought good to require my soul of me while I slept; and\r\nthat this weary frame, absolved by death from further conflict with\r\nfate, had now but to decay quietly, and mingle in peace with the soil\r\nof this wilderness. Life, however, was yet in my possession, with all\r\nits requirements, and pains, and responsibilities. The burden must be\r\ncarried; the want provided for; the suffering endured; the\r\nresponsibility fulfilled. I set out.\r\n\r\nWhitcross regained, I followed a road which led from the sun, now\r\nfervent and high. By no other circumstance had I will to decide my\r\nchoice. I walked a long time, and when I thought I had nearly done\r\nenough, and might conscientiously yield to the fatigue that almost\r\noverpowered me\xe2\x80\x94might relax this forced action, and, sitting down on a\r\nstone I saw near, submit resistlessly to the apathy that clogged heart\r\nand limb\xe2\x80\x94I heard a bell chime\xe2\x80\x94a church bell.\r\n\r\nI turned in the direction of the sound, and there, amongst the romantic\r\nhills, whose changes and aspect I had ceased to note an hour ago, I saw\r\na hamlet and a spire. All the valley at my right hand was full of\r\npasture-fields, and cornfields, and wood; and a glittering stream ran\r\nzig-zag through the varied shades of green, the mellowing grain, the\r\nsombre woodland, the clear and sunny lea. Recalled by the rumbling of\r\nwheels to the road before me, I saw a heavily-laden waggon labouring up\r\nthe hill, and not far beyond were two cows and their drover. Human life\r\nand human labour were near. I must struggle on: strive to live and bend\r\nto toil like the rest.\r\n\r\nAbout two o\xe2\x80\x99clock P.M. I entered the village. At the bottom of its one\r\nstreet there was a little shop with some cakes of bread in the window.\r\nI coveted a cake of bread. With that refreshment I could perhaps regain\r\na degree of energy: without it, it would be difficult to proceed. The\r\nwish to have some strength and some vigour returned to me as soon as I\r\nwas amongst my fellow-beings. I felt it would be degrading to faint\r\nwith hunger on the causeway of a hamlet. Had I nothing about me I could\r\noffer in exchange for one of these rolls? I considered. I had a small\r\nsilk handkerchief tied round my throat; I had my gloves. I could hardly\r\ntell how men and women in extremities of destitution proceeded. I did\r\nnot know whether either of these articles would be accepted: probably\r\nthey would not; but I must try.\r\n\r\nI entered the shop: a woman was there. Seeing a respectably-dressed\r\nperson, a lady as she supposed, she came forward with civility. How\r\ncould she serve me? I was seized with shame: my tongue would not utter\r\nthe request I had prepared. I dared not offer her the half-worn gloves,\r\nthe creased handkerchief: besides, I felt it would be absurd. I only\r\nbegged permission to sit down a moment, as I was tired. Disappointed in\r\nthe expectation of a customer, she coolly acceded to my request. She\r\npointed to a seat; I sank into it. I felt sorely urged to weep; but\r\nconscious how unseasonable such a manifestation would be, I restrained\r\nit. Soon I asked her \xe2\x80\x9cif there were any dressmaker or plain-workwoman\r\nin the village?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; two or three. Quite as many as there was employment for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI reflected. I was driven to the point now. I was brought face to face\r\nwith Necessity. I stood in the position of one without a resource,\r\nwithout a friend, without a coin. I must do something. What? I must\r\napply somewhere. Where?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid she know of any place in the neighbourhood where a servant was\r\nwanted?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay; she couldn\xe2\x80\x99t say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat was the chief trade in this place? What did most of the people\r\ndo?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome were farm labourers; a good deal worked at Mr. Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nneedle-factory, and at the foundry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Mr. Oliver employ women?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay; it was men\xe2\x80\x99s work.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what do the women do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI knawn\xe2\x80\x99t,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer. \xe2\x80\x9cSome does one thing, and some another.\r\nPoor folk mun get on as they can.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe seemed to be tired of my questions: and, indeed, what claim had I\r\nto importune her? A neighbour or two came in; my chair was evidently\r\nwanted. I took leave.\r\n\r\nI passed up the street, looking as I went at all the houses to the\r\nright hand and to the left; but I could discover no pretext, nor see an\r\ninducement to enter any. I rambled round the hamlet, going sometimes to\r\na little distance and returning again, for an hour or more. Much\r\nexhausted, and suffering greatly now for want of food, I turned aside\r\ninto a lane and sat down under the hedge. Ere many minutes had elapsed,\r\nI was again on my feet, however, and again searching something\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nresource, or at least an informant. A pretty little house stood at the\r\ntop of the lane, with a garden before it, exquisitely neat and\r\nbrilliantly blooming. I stopped at it. What business had I to approach\r\nthe white door or touch the glittering knocker? In what way could it\r\npossibly be the interest of the inhabitants of that dwelling to serve\r\nme? Yet I drew near and knocked. A mild-looking, cleanly-attired young\r\nwoman opened the door. In such a voice as might be expected from a\r\nhopeless heart and fainting frame\xe2\x80\x94a voice wretchedly low and\r\nfaltering\xe2\x80\x94I asked if a servant was wanted here?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d said she; \xe2\x80\x9cwe do not keep a servant.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you tell me where I could get employment of any kind?\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\ncontinued. \xe2\x80\x9cI am a stranger, without acquaintance in this place. I want\r\nsome work: no matter what.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut it was not her business to think for me, or to seek a place for me:\r\nbesides, in her eyes, how doubtful must have appeared my character,\r\nposition, tale. She shook her head, she \xe2\x80\x9cwas sorry she could give me no\r\ninformation,\xe2\x80\x9d and the white door closed, quite gently and civilly: but\r\nit shut me out. If she had held it open a little longer, I believe I\r\nshould have begged a piece of bread; for I was now brought low.\r\n\r\nI could not bear to return to the sordid village, where, besides, no\r\nprospect of aid was visible. I should have longed rather to deviate to\r\na wood I saw not far off, which appeared in its thick shade to offer\r\ninviting shelter; but I was so sick, so weak, so gnawed with nature\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncravings, instinct kept me roaming round abodes where there was a\r\nchance of food. Solitude would be no solitude\xe2\x80\x94rest no rest\xe2\x80\x94while the\r\nvulture, hunger, thus sank beak and talons in my side.\r\n\r\nI drew near houses; I left them, and came back again, and again I\r\nwandered away: always repelled by the consciousness of having no claim\r\nto ask\xe2\x80\x94no right to expect interest in my isolated lot. Meantime, the\r\nafternoon advanced, while I thus wandered about like a lost and\r\nstarving dog. In crossing a field, I saw the church spire before me: I\r\nhastened towards it. Near the churchyard, and in the middle of a\r\ngarden, stood a well-built though small house, which I had no doubt was\r\nthe parsonage. I remembered that strangers who arrive at a place where\r\nthey have no friends, and who want employment, sometimes apply to the\r\nclergyman for introduction and aid. It is the clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s function to\r\nhelp\xe2\x80\x94at least with advice\xe2\x80\x94those who wished to help themselves. I seemed\r\nto have something like a right to seek counsel here. Renewing then my\r\ncourage, and gathering my feeble remains of strength, I pushed on. I\r\nreached the house, and knocked at the kitchen-door. An old woman\r\nopened: I asked was this the parsonage?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas the clergyman in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould he be in soon?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, he was gone from home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo a distance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot so far\xe2\x80\x94happen three mile. He had been called away by the sudden\r\ndeath of his father: he was at Marsh End now, and would very likely\r\nstay there a fortnight longer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas there any lady of the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay, there was naught but her, and she was housekeeper;\xe2\x80\x9d and of her,\r\nreader, I could not bear to ask the relief for want of which I was\r\nsinking; I could not yet beg; and again I crawled away.\r\n\r\nOnce more I took off my handkerchief\xe2\x80\x94once more I thought of the cakes\r\nof bread in the little shop. Oh, for but a crust! for but one mouthful\r\nto allay the pang of famine! Instinctively I turned my face again to\r\nthe village; I found the shop again, and I went in; and though others\r\nwere there besides the woman I ventured the request\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWould she give me\r\na roll for this handkerchief?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe looked at me with evident suspicion: \xe2\x80\x9cNay, she never sold stuff i\xe2\x80\x99\r\nthat way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAlmost desperate, I asked for half a cake; she again refused. \xe2\x80\x9cHow\r\ncould she tell where I had got the handkerchief?\xe2\x80\x9d she said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould she take my gloves?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo! what could she do with them?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReader, it is not pleasant to dwell on these details. Some say there is\r\nenjoyment in looking back to painful experience past; but at this day I\r\ncan scarcely bear to review the times to which I allude: the moral\r\ndegradation, blent with the physical suffering, form too distressing a\r\nrecollection ever to be willingly dwelt on. I blamed none of those who\r\nrepulsed me. I felt it was what was to be expected, and what could not\r\nbe helped: an ordinary beggar is frequently an object of suspicion; a\r\nwell-dressed beggar inevitably so. To be sure, what I begged was\r\nemployment; but whose business was it to provide me with employment?\r\nNot, certainly, that of persons who saw me then for the first time, and\r\nwho knew nothing about my character. And as to the woman who would not\r\ntake my handkerchief in exchange for her bread, why, she was right, if\r\nthe offer appeared to her sinister or the exchange unprofitable. Let me\r\ncondense now. I am sick of the subject.\r\n\r\nA little before dark I passed a farm-house, at the open door of which\r\nthe farmer was sitting, eating his supper of bread and cheese. I\r\nstopped and said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you give me a piece of bread? for I am very hungry.\xe2\x80\x9d He cast on\r\nme a glance of surprise; but without answering, he cut a thick slice\r\nfrom his loaf, and gave it to me. I imagine he did not think I was a\r\nbeggar, but only an eccentric sort of lady, who had taken a fancy to\r\nhis brown loaf. As soon as I was out of sight of his house, I sat down\r\nand ate it.\r\n\r\nI could not hope to get a lodging under a roof, and sought it in the\r\nwood I have before alluded to. But my night was wretched, my rest\r\nbroken: the ground was damp, the air cold: besides, intruders passed\r\nnear me more than once, and I had again and again to change my\r\nquarters: no sense of safety or tranquillity befriended me. Towards\r\nmorning it rained; the whole of the following day was wet. Do not ask\r\nme, reader, to give a minute account of that day; as before, I sought\r\nwork; as before, I was repulsed; as before, I starved; but once did\r\nfood pass my lips. At the door of a cottage I saw a little girl about\r\nto throw a mess of cold porridge into a pig trough. \xe2\x80\x9cWill you give me\r\nthat?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you give me that?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked\r\n\r\nShe stared at me. \xe2\x80\x9cMother!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a woman wants me\r\nto give her these porridge.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell lass,\xe2\x80\x9d replied a voice within, \xe2\x80\x9cgive it her if she\xe2\x80\x99s a beggar. T\xe2\x80\x99\r\npig doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe girl emptied the stiffened mould into my hand, and I devoured it\r\nravenously.\r\n\r\nAs the wet twilight deepened, I stopped in a solitary bridle-path,\r\nwhich I had been pursuing an hour or more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy strength is quite failing me,\xe2\x80\x9d I said in a soliloquy. \xe2\x80\x9cI feel I\r\ncannot go much farther. Shall I be an outcast again this night? While\r\nthe rain descends so, must I lay my head on the cold, drenched ground?\r\nI fear I cannot do otherwise: for who will receive me? But it will be\r\nvery dreadful, with this feeling of hunger, faintness, chill, and this\r\nsense of desolation\xe2\x80\x94this total prostration of hope. In all likelihood,\r\nthough, I should die before morning. And why cannot I reconcile myself\r\nto the prospect of death? Why do I struggle to retain a valueless life?\r\nBecause I know, or believe, Mr. Rochester is living: and then, to die\r\nof want and cold is a fate to which nature cannot submit passively. Oh,\r\nProvidence! sustain me a little longer! Aid!\xe2\x80\x94direct me!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMy glazed eye wandered over the dim and misty landscape. I saw I had\r\nstrayed far from the village: it was quite out of sight. The very\r\ncultivation surrounding it had disappeared. I had, by cross-ways and\r\nby-paths, once more drawn near the tract of moorland; and now, only a\r\nfew fields, almost as wild and unproductive as the heath from which\r\nthey were scarcely reclaimed, lay between me and the dusky hill.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, I would rather die yonder than in a street or on a frequented\r\nroad,\xe2\x80\x9d I reflected. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd far better that crows and ravens\xe2\x80\x94if any ravens\r\nthere be in these regions\xe2\x80\x94should pick my flesh from my bones, than that\r\nthey should be prisoned in a workhouse coffin and moulder in a pauper\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ngrave.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nTo the hill, then, I turned. I reached it. It remained now only to find\r\na hollow where I could lie down, and feel at least hidden, if not\r\nsecure. But all the surface of the waste looked level. It showed no\r\nvariation but of tint: green, where rush and moss overgrew the marshes;\r\nblack, where the dry soil bore only heath. Dark as it was getting, I\r\ncould still see these changes, though but as mere alternations of light\r\nand shade; for colour had faded with the daylight.\r\n\r\nMy eye still roved over the sullen swell and along the moor-edge,\r\nvanishing amidst the wildest scenery, when at one dim point, far in\r\namong the marshes and the ridges, a light sprang up. \xe2\x80\x9cThat is an _ignis\r\nfatuus_,\xe2\x80\x9d was my first thought; and I expected it would soon vanish. It\r\nburnt on, however, quite steadily, neither receding nor advancing. \xe2\x80\x9cIs\r\nit, then, a bonfire just kindled?\xe2\x80\x9d I questioned. I watched to see\r\nwhether it would spread: but no; as it did not diminish, so it did not\r\nenlarge. \xe2\x80\x9cIt may be a candle in a house,\xe2\x80\x9d I then conjectured; \xe2\x80\x9cbut if\r\nso, I can never reach it. It is much too far away: and were it within a\r\nyard of me, what would it avail? I should but knock at the door to have\r\nit shut in my face.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd I sank down where I stood, and hid my face against the ground. I\r\nlay still a while: the night-wind swept over the hill and over me, and\r\ndied moaning in the distance; the rain fell fast, wetting me afresh to\r\nthe skin. Could I but have stiffened to the still frost\xe2\x80\x94the friendly\r\nnumbness of death\xe2\x80\x94it might have pelted on; I should not have felt it;\r\nbut my yet living flesh shuddered at its chilling influence. I rose ere\r\nlong.\r\n\r\nThe light was yet there, shining dim but constant through the rain. I\r\ntried to walk again: I dragged my exhausted limbs slowly towards it. It\r\nled me aslant over the hill, through a wide bog, which would have been\r\nimpassable in winter, and was splashy and shaking even now, in the\r\nheight of summer. Here I fell twice; but as often I rose and rallied my\r\nfaculties. This light was my forlorn hope: I must gain it.\r\n\r\nHaving crossed the marsh, I saw a trace of white over the moor. I\r\napproached it; it was a road or a track: it led straight up to the\r\nlight, which now beamed from a sort of knoll, amidst a clump of\r\ntrees\xe2\x80\x94firs, apparently, from what I could distinguish of the character\r\nof their forms and foliage through the gloom. My star vanished as I\r\ndrew near: some obstacle had intervened between me and it. I put out my\r\nhand to feel the dark mass before me: I discriminated the rough stones\r\nof a low wall\xe2\x80\x94above it, something like palisades, and within, a high\r\nand prickly hedge. I groped on. Again a whitish object gleamed before\r\nme: it was a gate\xe2\x80\x94a wicket; it moved on its hinges as I touched it. On\r\neach side stood a sable bush\xe2\x80\x94holly or yew.\r\n\r\nEntering the gate and passing the shrubs, the silhouette of a house\r\nrose to view, black, low, and rather long; but the guiding light shone\r\nnowhere. All was obscurity. Were the inmates retired to rest? I feared\r\nit must be so. In seeking the door, I turned an angle: there shot out\r\nthe friendly gleam again, from the lozenged panes of a very small\r\nlatticed window, within a foot of the ground, made still smaller by the\r\ngrowth of ivy or some other creeping plant, whose leaves clustered\r\nthick over the portion of the house wall in which it was set. The\r\naperture was so screened and narrow, that curtain or shutter had been\r\ndeemed unnecessary; and when I stooped down and put aside the spray of\r\nfoliage shooting over it, I could see all within. I could see clearly a\r\nroom with a sanded floor, clean scoured; a dresser of walnut, with\r\npewter plates ranged in rows, reflecting the redness and radiance of a\r\nglowing peat-fire. I could see a clock, a white deal table, some\r\nchairs. The candle, whose ray had been my beacon, burnt on the table;\r\nand by its light an elderly woman, somewhat rough-looking, but\r\nscrupulously clean, like all about her, was knitting a stocking.\r\n\r\nI noticed these objects cursorily only\xe2\x80\x94in them there was nothing\r\nextraordinary. A group of more interest appeared near the hearth,\r\nsitting still amidst the rosy peace and warmth suffusing it. Two young,\r\ngraceful women\xe2\x80\x94ladies in every point\xe2\x80\x94sat, one in a low rocking-chair,\r\nthe other on a lower stool; both wore deep mourning of crape and\r\nbombazeen, which sombre garb singularly set off very fair necks and\r\nfaces: a large old pointer dog rested its massive head on the knee of\r\none girl\xe2\x80\x94in the lap of the other was cushioned a black cat.\r\n\r\nA strange place was this humble kitchen for such occupants! Who were\r\nthey? They could not be the daughters of the elderly person at the\r\ntable; for she looked like a rustic, and they were all delicacy and\r\ncultivation. I had nowhere seen such faces as theirs: and yet, as I\r\ngazed on them, I seemed intimate with every lineament. I cannot call\r\nthem handsome\xe2\x80\x94they were too pale and grave for the word: as they each\r\nbent over a book, they looked thoughtful almost to severity. A stand\r\nbetween them supported a second candle and two great volumes, to which\r\nthey frequently referred, comparing them, seemingly, with the smaller\r\nbooks they held in their hands, like people consulting a dictionary to\r\naid them in the task of translation. This scene was as silent as if all\r\nthe figures had been shadows and the firelit apartment a picture: so\r\nhushed was it, I could hear the cinders fall from the grate, the clock\r\ntick in its obscure corner; and I even fancied I could distinguish the\r\nclick-click of the woman\xe2\x80\x99s knitting-needles. When, therefore, a voice\r\nbroke the strange stillness at last, it was audible enough to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cListen, Diana,\xe2\x80\x9d said one of the absorbed students; \xe2\x80\x9cFranz and old\r\nDaniel are together in the night-time, and Franz is telling a dream\r\nfrom which he has awakened in terror\xe2\x80\x94listen!\xe2\x80\x9d And in a low voice she\r\nread something, of which not one word was intelligible to me; for it\r\nwas in an unknown tongue\xe2\x80\x94neither French nor Latin. Whether it were\r\nGreek or German I could not tell.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is strong,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, when she had finished: \xe2\x80\x9cI relish it.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nother girl, who had lifted her head to listen to her sister, repeated,\r\nwhile she gazed at the fire, a line of what had been read. At a later\r\nday, I knew the language and the book; therefore, I will here quote the\r\nline: though, when I first heard it, it was only like a stroke on\r\nsounding brass to me\xe2\x80\x94conveying no meaning:\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98Da trat hervor Einer, anzusehen wie die Sternen Nacht.\xe2\x80\x99 Good! good!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe exclaimed, while her dark and deep eye sparkled. \xe2\x80\x9cThere you have a\r\ndim and mighty archangel fitly set before you! The line is worth a\r\nhundred pages of fustian. \xe2\x80\x98Ich w\xc3\xa4ge die Gedanken in der Schale meines\r\nZornes und die Werke mit dem Gewichte meines Grimms.\xe2\x80\x99 I like it!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBoth were again silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs there ony country where they talk i\xe2\x80\x99 that way?\xe2\x80\x9d asked the old\r\nwoman, looking up from her knitting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Hannah\xe2\x80\x94a far larger country than England, where they talk in no\r\nother way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, for sure case, I knawn\xe2\x80\x99t how they can understand t\xe2\x80\x99 one t\xe2\x80\x99other:\r\nand if either o\xe2\x80\x99 ye went there, ye could tell what they said, I guess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe could probably tell something of what they said, but not all\xe2\x80\x94for we\r\nare not as clever as you think us, Hannah. We don\xe2\x80\x99t speak German, and\r\nwe cannot read it without a dictionary to help us.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what good does it do you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe mean to teach it some time\xe2\x80\x94or at least the elements, as they say;\r\nand then we shall get more money than we do now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVarry like: but give ower studying; ye\xe2\x80\x99ve done enough for to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI think we have: at least I\xe2\x80\x99m tired. Mary, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMortally: after all, it\xe2\x80\x99s tough work fagging away at a language with\r\nno master but a lexicon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is, especially such a language as this crabbed but glorious\r\nDeutsch. I wonder when St. John will come home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSurely he will not be long now: it is just ten (looking at a little\r\ngold watch she drew from her girdle). It rains fast, Hannah: will you\r\nhave the goodness to look at the fire in the parlour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe woman rose: she opened a door, through which I dimly saw a passage:\r\nsoon I heard her stir a fire in an inner room; she presently came back.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh, childer!\xe2\x80\x9d said she, \xe2\x80\x9cit fair troubles me to go into yond\xe2\x80\x99 room\r\nnow: it looks so lonesome wi\xe2\x80\x99 the chair empty and set back in a\r\ncorner.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe wiped her eyes with her apron: the two girls, grave before, looked\r\nsad now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut he is in a better place,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Hannah: \xe2\x80\x9cwe shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t wish him\r\nhere again. And then, nobody need to have a quieter death nor he had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou say he never mentioned us?\xe2\x80\x9d inquired one of the ladies.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe hadn\xe2\x80\x99t time, bairn: he was gone in a minute, was your father. He\r\nhad been a bit ailing like the day before, but naught to signify; and\r\nwhen Mr. St. John asked if he would like either o\xe2\x80\x99 ye to be sent for,\r\nhe fair laughed at him. He began again with a bit of a heaviness in his\r\nhead the next day\xe2\x80\x94that is, a fortnight sin\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x94and he went to sleep and\r\nniver wakened: he wor a\xe2\x80\x99most stark when your brother went into t\xe2\x80\x99\r\nchamber and fand him. Ah, childer! that\xe2\x80\x99s t\xe2\x80\x99 last o\xe2\x80\x99 t\xe2\x80\x99 old stock\xe2\x80\x94for\r\nye and Mr. St. John is like of different soart to them \xe2\x80\x99at\xe2\x80\x99s gone; for\r\nall your mother wor mich i\xe2\x80\x99 your way, and a\xe2\x80\x99most as book-learned. She\r\nwor the pictur\xe2\x80\x99 o\xe2\x80\x99 ye, Mary: Diana is more like your father.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought them so similar I could not tell where the old servant (for\r\nsuch I now concluded her to be) saw the difference. Both were fair\r\ncomplexioned and slenderly made; both possessed faces full of\r\ndistinction and intelligence. One, to be sure, had hair a shade darker\r\nthan the other, and there was a difference in their style of wearing\r\nit; Mary\xe2\x80\x99s pale brown locks were parted and braided smooth: Diana\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nduskier tresses covered her neck with thick curls. The clock struck\r\nten.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99ll want your supper, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Hannah; \xe2\x80\x9cand so will Mr.\r\nSt. John when he comes in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd she proceeded to prepare the meal. The ladies rose; they seemed\r\nabout to withdraw to the parlour. Till this moment, I had been so\r\nintent on watching them, their appearance and conversation had excited\r\nin me so keen an interest, I had half-forgotten my own wretched\r\nposition: now it recurred to me. More desolate, more desperate than\r\never, it seemed from contrast. And how impossible did it appear to\r\ntouch the inmates of this house with concern on my behalf; to make them\r\nbelieve in the truth of my wants and woes\xe2\x80\x94to induce them to vouchsafe a\r\nrest for my wanderings! As I groped out the door, and knocked at it\r\nhesitatingly, I felt that last idea to be a mere chimera. Hannah\r\nopened.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you want?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired, in a voice of surprise, as she\r\nsurveyed me by the light of the candle she held.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMay I speak to your mistresses?\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had better tell me what you have to say to them. Where do you come\r\nfrom?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am a stranger.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is your business here at this hour?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI want a night\xe2\x80\x99s shelter in an out-house or anywhere, and a morsel of\r\nbread to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDistrust, the very feeling I dreaded, appeared in Hannah\xe2\x80\x99s face. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll\r\ngive you a piece of bread,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, after a pause; \xe2\x80\x9cbut we can\xe2\x80\x99t take\r\nin a vagrant to lodge. It isn\xe2\x80\x99t likely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo let me speak to your mistresses.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, not I. What can they do for you? You should not be roving about\r\nnow; it looks very ill.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where shall I go if you drive me away? What shall I do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I\xe2\x80\x99ll warrant you know where to go and what to do. Mind you don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\ndo wrong, that\xe2\x80\x99s all. Here is a penny; now go\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA penny cannot feed me, and I have no strength to go farther. Don\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nshut the door:\xe2\x80\x94oh, don\xe2\x80\x99t, for God\xe2\x80\x99s sake!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI must; the rain is driving in\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell the young ladies. Let me see them\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed, I will not. You are not what you ought to be, or you wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t\r\nmake such a noise. Move off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I must die if I am turned away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot you. If you\xe2\x80\x99ve any\r\nfollowers\xe2\x80\x94housebreakers or such like\xe2\x80\x94anywhere near, you may tell them\r\nwe are not by ourselves in the house; we have a gentleman, and dogs,\r\nand guns.\xe2\x80\x9d Here the honest but inflexible servant clapped the door to\r\nand bolted it within.\r\n\r\nThis was the climax. A pang of exquisite suffering\xe2\x80\x94a throe of true\r\ndespair\xe2\x80\x94rent and heaved my heart. Worn out, indeed, I was; not another\r\nstep could I stir. I sank on the wet doorstep: I groaned\xe2\x80\x94I wrung my\r\nhands\xe2\x80\x94I wept in utter anguish. Oh, this spectre of death! Oh, this last\r\nhour, approaching in such horror! Alas, this isolation\xe2\x80\x94this banishment\r\nfrom my kind! Not only the anchor of hope, but the footing of fortitude\r\nwas gone\xe2\x80\x94at least for a moment; but the last I soon endeavoured to\r\nregain.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can but die,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cand I believe in God. Let me try to wait His\r\nwill in silence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThese words I not only thought, but uttered; and thrusting back all my\r\nmisery into my heart, I made an effort to compel it to remain\r\nthere\xe2\x80\x94dumb and still.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAll men must die,\xe2\x80\x9d said a voice quite close at hand; \xe2\x80\x9cbut all are not\r\ncondemned to meet a lingering and premature doom, such as yours would\r\nbe if you perished here of want.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho or what speaks?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, terrified at the unexpected sound, and\r\nincapable now of deriving from any occurrence a hope of aid. A form was\r\nnear\xe2\x80\x94what form, the pitch-dark night and my enfeebled vision prevented\r\nme from distinguishing.
