With a loud long knock, the new-comer appealed\r\nto the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it you, Mr. St. John?\xe2\x80\x9d cried Hannah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94yes; open quickly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, how wet and cold you must be, such a wild night as it is! Come\r\nin\xe2\x80\x94your sisters are quite uneasy about you, and I believe there are bad\r\nfolks about. There has been a beggar-woman\xe2\x80\x94I declare she is not gone\r\nyet!\xe2\x80\x94laid down there. Get up! for shame! Move off, I say!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHush, Hannah! I have a word to say to the woman. You have done your\r\nduty in excluding, now let me do mine in admitting her. I was near, and\r\nlistened to both you and her. I think this is a peculiar case\xe2\x80\x94I must at\r\nleast examine into it. Young woman, rise, and pass before me into the\r\nhouse.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nHush, Hannah; I have a word to say to the woman\r\n\r\nWith difficulty I obeyed him. Presently I stood within that clean,\r\nbright kitchen\xe2\x80\x94on the very hearth\xe2\x80\x94trembling, sickening; conscious of an\r\naspect in the last degree ghastly, wild, and weather-beaten. The two\r\nladies, their brother, Mr. St. John, the old servant, were all gazing\r\nat me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. John, who is it?\xe2\x80\x9d I heard one ask.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI cannot tell: I found her at the door,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe does look white,\xe2\x80\x9d said Hannah.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs white as clay or death,\xe2\x80\x9d was responded. \xe2\x80\x9cShe will fall: let her\r\nsit.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd indeed my head swam: I dropped, but a chair received me. I still\r\npossessed my senses, though just now I could not speak.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps a little water would restore her. Hannah, fetch some. But she\r\nis worn to nothing. How very thin, and how very bloodless!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA mere spectre!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs she ill, or only famished?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFamished, I think. Hannah, is that milk? Give it me, and a piece of\r\nbread.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDiana (I knew her by the long curls which I saw drooping between me and\r\nthe fire as she bent over me) broke some bread, dipped it in milk, and\r\nput it to my lips. Her face was near mine: I saw there was pity in it,\r\nand I felt sympathy in her hurried breathing. In her simple words, too,\r\nthe same balm-like emotion spoke: \xe2\x80\x9cTry to eat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94try,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mary gently; and Mary\xe2\x80\x99s hand removed my sodden\r\nbonnet and lifted my head. I tasted what they offered me: feebly at\r\nfirst, eagerly soon.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot too much at first\xe2\x80\x94restrain her,\xe2\x80\x9d said the brother; \xe2\x80\x9cshe has had\r\nenough.\xe2\x80\x9d And he withdrew the cup of milk and the plate of bread.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little more, St. John\xe2\x80\x94look at the avidity in her eyes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more at present, sister. Try if she can speak now\xe2\x80\x94ask her her\r\nname.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt I could speak, and I answered\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cMy name is Jane Elliott.\xe2\x80\x9d Anxious\r\nas ever to avoid discovery, I had before resolved to assume an _alias_.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where do you live? Where are your friends?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was silent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan we send for any one you know?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI shook my head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat account can you give of yourself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSomehow, now that I had once crossed the threshold of this house, and\r\nonce was brought face to face with its owners, I felt no longer\r\noutcast, vagrant, and disowned by the wide world. I dared to put off\r\nthe mendicant\xe2\x80\x94to resume my natural manner and character. I began once\r\nmore to know myself; and when Mr. St. John demanded an account\xe2\x80\x94which at\r\npresent I was far too weak to render\xe2\x80\x94I said after a brief pause\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSir, I can give you no details to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut what, then,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdo you expect me to do for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied. My strength sufficed for but short answers. Diana\r\ntook the word\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean,\xe2\x80\x9d she asked, \xe2\x80\x9cthat we have now given you what aid you\r\nrequire? and that we may dismiss you to the moor and the rainy night?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI looked at her. She had, I thought, a remarkable countenance, instinct\r\nboth with power and goodness. I took sudden courage. Answering her\r\ncompassionate gaze with a smile, I said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI will trust you. If I were a\r\nmasterless and stray dog, I know that you would not turn me from your\r\nhearth to-night: as it is, I really have no fear. Do with me and for me\r\nas you like; but excuse me from much discourse\xe2\x80\x94my breath is short\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nfeel a spasm when I speak.\xe2\x80\x9d All three surveyed me, and all three were\r\nsilent.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHannah,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. St. John, at last, \xe2\x80\x9clet her sit there at present,\r\nand ask her no questions; in ten minutes more, give her the remainder\r\nof that milk and bread. Mary and Diana, let us go into the parlour and\r\ntalk the matter over.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey withdrew. Very soon one of the ladies returned\xe2\x80\x94I could not tell\r\nwhich. A kind of pleasant stupor was stealing over me as I sat by the\r\ngenial fire. In an undertone she gave some directions to Hannah. Ere\r\nlong, with the servant\xe2\x80\x99s aid, I contrived to mount a staircase; my\r\ndripping clothes were removed; soon a warm, dry bed received me. I\r\nthanked God\xe2\x80\x94experienced amidst unutterable exhaustion a glow of\r\ngrateful joy\xe2\x80\x94and slept.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXIX\r\n\r\n\r\nThe recollection of about three days and nights succeeding this is very\r\ndim in my mind. I can recall some sensations felt in that interval; but\r\nfew thoughts framed, and no actions performed. I knew I was in a small\r\nroom and in a narrow bed. To that bed I seemed to have grown; I lay on\r\nit motionless as a stone; and to have torn me from it would have been\r\nalmost to kill me. I took no note of the lapse of time\xe2\x80\x94of the change\r\nfrom morning to noon, from noon to evening. I observed when any one\r\nentered or left the apartment: I could even tell who they were; I could\r\nunderstand what was said when the speaker stood near to me; but I could\r\nnot answer; to open my lips or move my limbs was equally impossible.\r\nHannah, the servant, was my most frequent visitor. Her coming disturbed\r\nme. I had a feeling that she wished me away: that she did not\r\nunderstand me or my circumstances; that she was prejudiced against me.\r\nDiana and Mary appeared in the chamber once or twice a day. They would\r\nwhisper sentences of this sort at my bedside\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very well we took her in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; she would certainly have been found dead at the door in the\r\nmorning had she been left out all night. I wonder what she has gone\r\nthrough?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrange hardships, I imagine\xe2\x80\x94poor, emaciated, pallid wanderer!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is not an uneducated person, I should think, by her manner of\r\nspeaking; her accent was quite pure; and the clothes she took off,\r\nthough splashed and wet, were little worn and fine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has a peculiar face; fleshless and haggard as it is, I rather like\r\nit; and when in good health and animated, I can fancy her physiognomy\r\nwould be agreeable.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nNever once in their dialogues did I hear a syllable of regret at the\r\nhospitality they had extended to me, or of suspicion of, or aversion\r\nto, myself. I was comforted.\r\n\r\nMr. St. John came but once: he looked at me, and said my state of\r\nlethargy was the result of reaction from excessive and protracted\r\nfatigue. He pronounced it needless to send for a doctor: nature, he was\r\nsure, would manage best, left to herself. He said every nerve had been\r\noverstrained in some way, and the whole system must sleep torpid a\r\nwhile. There was no disease. He imagined my recovery would be rapid\r\nenough when once commenced. These opinions he delivered in a few words,\r\nin a quiet, low voice; and added, after a pause, in the tone of a man\r\nlittle accustomed to expansive comment, \xe2\x80\x9cRather an unusual physiognomy;\r\ncertainly, not indicative of vulgarity or degradation.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFar otherwise,\xe2\x80\x9d responded Diana. \xe2\x80\x9cTo speak truth, St. John, my heart\r\nrather warms to the poor little soul. I wish we may be able to benefit\r\nher permanently.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is hardly likely,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply. \xe2\x80\x9cYou will find she is some\r\nyoung lady who has had a misunderstanding with her friends, and has\r\nprobably injudiciously left them. We may, perhaps, succeed in restoring\r\nher to them, if she is not obstinate: but I trace lines of force in her\r\nface which make me sceptical of her tractability.\xe2\x80\x9d He stood considering\r\nme some minutes; then added, \xe2\x80\x9cShe looks sensible, but not at all\r\nhandsome.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe is so ill, St. John.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIll or well, she would always be plain. The grace and harmony of\r\nbeauty are quite wanting in those features.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOn the third day I was better; on the fourth, I could speak, move, rise\r\nin bed, and turn. Hannah had brought me some gruel and dry toast,\r\nabout, as I supposed, the dinner-hour. I had eaten with relish: the\r\nfood was good\xe2\x80\x94void of the feverish flavour which had hitherto poisoned\r\nwhat I had swallowed. When she left me, I felt comparatively strong and\r\nrevived: ere long satiety of repose and desire for action stirred me. I\r\nwished to rise; but what could I put on? Only my damp and bemired\r\napparel; in which I had slept on the ground and fallen in the marsh. I\r\nfelt ashamed to appear before my benefactors so clad. I was spared the\r\nhumiliation.\r\n\r\nOn a chair by the bedside were all my own things, clean and dry. My\r\nblack silk frock hung against the wall. The traces of the bog were\r\nremoved from it; the creases left by the wet smoothed out: it was quite\r\ndecent. My very shoes and stockings were purified and rendered\r\npresentable. There were the means of washing in the room, and a comb\r\nand brush to smooth my hair. After a weary process, and resting every\r\nfive minutes, I succeeded in dressing myself. My clothes hung loose on\r\nme; for I was much wasted, but I covered deficiencies with a shawl, and\r\nonce more, clean and respectable looking\xe2\x80\x94no speck of the dirt, no trace\r\nof the disorder I so hated, and which seemed so to degrade me, left\xe2\x80\x94I\r\ncrept down a stone staircase with the aid of the banisters, to a narrow\r\nlow passage, and found my way presently to the kitchen.\r\n\r\nIt was full of the fragrance of new bread and the warmth of a generous\r\nfire. Hannah was baking. Prejudices, it is well known, are most\r\ndifficult to eradicate from the heart whose soil has never been\r\nloosened or fertilised by education: they grow there, firm as weeds\r\namong stones. Hannah had been cold and stiff, indeed, at the first:\r\nlatterly she had begun to relent a little; and when she saw me come in\r\ntidy and well-dressed, she even smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, you have got up!\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are better, then. You may sit\r\nyou down in my chair on the hearthstone, if you will.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe pointed to the rocking-chair: I took it. She bustled about,\r\nexamining me every now and then with the corner of her eye. Turning to\r\nme, as she took some loaves from the oven, she asked bluntly\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ever go a-begging afore you came here?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI was indignant for a moment; but remembering that anger was out of the\r\nquestion, and that I had indeed appeared as a beggar to her, I answered\r\nquietly, but still not without a certain marked firmness\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are mistaken in supposing me a beggar. I am no beggar; any more\r\nthan yourself or your young ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a pause she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI dunnut understand that: you\xe2\x80\x99ve like no\r\nhouse, nor no brass, I guess?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe want of house or brass (by which I suppose you mean money) does\r\nnot make a beggar in your sense of the word.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you book-learned?\xe2\x80\x9d she inquired presently.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, very.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ve never been to a boarding-school?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was at a boarding-school eight years.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe opened her eyes wide. \xe2\x80\x9cWhatever cannot ye keep yourself for, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have kept myself; and, I trust, shall keep myself again. What are\r\nyou going to do with these gooseberries?\xe2\x80\x9d I inquired, as she brought\r\nout a basket of the fruit.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMak\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x99em into pies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive them to me and I\xe2\x80\x99ll pick them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay; I dunnut want ye to do nought.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I must do something. Let me have them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe consented; and she even brought me a clean towel to spread over my\r\ndress, \xe2\x80\x9clest,\xe2\x80\x9d as she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI should mucky it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYe\xe2\x80\x99ve not been used to sarvant\xe2\x80\x99s wark, I see by your hands,\xe2\x80\x9d she\r\nremarked. \xe2\x80\x9cHappen ye\xe2\x80\x99ve been a dressmaker?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, you are wrong. And now, never mind what I have been: don\xe2\x80\x99t trouble\r\nyour head further about me; but tell me the name of the house where we\r\nare.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome calls it Marsh End, and some calls it Moor House.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the gentleman who lives here is called Mr. St. John?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNay; he doesn\xe2\x80\x99t live here: he is only staying a while. When he is at\r\nhome, he is in his own parish at Morton.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat village a few miles off?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what is he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is a parson.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI remembered the answer of the old housekeeper at the parsonage, when I\r\nhad asked to see the clergyman. \xe2\x80\x9cThis, then, was his father\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nresidence?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye; old Mr. Rivers lived here, and his father, and grandfather, and\r\ngurt (great) grandfather afore him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe name, then, of that gentleman, is Mr. St. John Rivers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAye; St. John is like his kirstened name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd his sisters are called Diana and Mary Rivers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTheir father is dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead three weeks sin\xe2\x80\x99 of a stroke.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey have no mother?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe mistress has been dead this mony a year.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you lived with the family long?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve lived here thirty year. I nursed them all three.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat proves you must have been an honest and faithful servant. I will\r\nsay so much for you, though you have had the incivility to call me a\r\nbeggar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe again regarded me with a surprised stare. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nwas quite mista\xe2\x80\x99en in my thoughts of you: but there is so mony cheats\r\ngoes about, you mun forgie me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd though,\xe2\x80\x9d I continued, rather severely, \xe2\x80\x9cyou wished to turn me from\r\nthe door, on a night when you should not have shut out a dog.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, it was hard: but what can a body do? I thought more o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99\r\nchilder nor of mysel: poor things! They\xe2\x80\x99ve like nobody to tak\xe2\x80\x99 care on\r\n\xe2\x80\x99em but me. I\xe2\x80\x99m like to look sharpish.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI maintained a grave silence for some minutes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou munnut think too hardly of me,\xe2\x80\x9d she again remarked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I do think hardly of you,\xe2\x80\x9d I said; \xe2\x80\x9cand I\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you why\xe2\x80\x94not so\r\nmuch because you refused to give me shelter, or regarded me as an\r\nimpostor, as because you just now made it a species of reproach that I\r\nhad no \xe2\x80\x98brass\xe2\x80\x99 and no house. Some of the best people that ever lived\r\nhave been as destitute as I am; and if you are a Christian, you ought\r\nnot to consider poverty a crime.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo more I ought,\xe2\x80\x9d said she: \xe2\x80\x9cMr. St. John tells me so too; and I see I\r\nwor wrang\xe2\x80\x94but I\xe2\x80\x99ve clear a different notion on you now to what I had.\r\nYou look a raight down dacent little crater.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat will do\xe2\x80\x94I forgive you now. Shake hands.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe put her floury and horny hand into mine; another and heartier smile\r\nillumined her rough face, and from that moment we were friends.\r\n\r\nHannah was evidently fond of talking. While I picked the fruit, and she\r\nmade the paste for the pies, she proceeded to give me sundry details\r\nabout her deceased master and mistress, and \xe2\x80\x9cthe childer,\xe2\x80\x9d as she\r\ncalled the young people.\r\n\r\nOld Mr. Rivers, she said, was a plain man enough, but a gentleman, and\r\nof as ancient a family as could be found. Marsh End had belonged to the\r\nRivers ever since it was a house: and it was, she affirmed, \xe2\x80\x9caboon two\r\nhundred year old\xe2\x80\x94for all it looked but a small, humble place, naught to\r\ncompare wi\xe2\x80\x99 Mr. Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s grand hall down i\xe2\x80\x99 Morton Vale. But she could\r\nremember Bill Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s father a journeyman needlemaker; and th\xe2\x80\x99 Rivers\r\nwor gentry i\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 owd days o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 Henrys, as onybody might see by\r\nlooking into th\xe2\x80\x99 registers i\xe2\x80\x99 Morton Church vestry.\xe2\x80\x9d Still, she\r\nallowed, \xe2\x80\x9cthe owd maister was like other folk\xe2\x80\x94naught mich out o\xe2\x80\x99 t\xe2\x80\x99\r\ncommon way: stark mad o\xe2\x80\x99 shooting, and farming, and sich like.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nmistress was different. She was a great reader, and studied a deal; and\r\nthe \xe2\x80\x9cbairns\xe2\x80\x9d had taken after her. There was nothing like them in these\r\nparts, nor ever had been; they had liked learning, all three, almost\r\nfrom the time they could speak; and they had always been \xe2\x80\x9cof a mak\xe2\x80\x99 of\r\ntheir own.\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. St. John, when he grew up, would go to college and be a\r\nparson; and the girls, as soon as they left school, would seek places\r\nas governesses: for they had told her their father had some years ago\r\nlost a great deal of money by a man he had trusted turning bankrupt;\r\nand as he was now not rich enough to give them fortunes, they must\r\nprovide for themselves. They had lived very little at home for a long\r\nwhile, and were only come now to stay a few weeks on account of their\r\nfather\xe2\x80\x99s death; but they did so like Marsh End and Morton, and all\r\nthese moors and hills about. They had been in London, and many other\r\ngrand towns; but they always said there was no place like home; and\r\nthen they were so agreeable with each other\xe2\x80\x94never fell out nor\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthreaped.\xe2\x80\x9d She did not know where there was such a family for being\r\nunited.\r\n\r\nHaving finished my task of gooseberry picking, I asked where the two\r\nladies and their brother were now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGone over to Morton for a walk; but they would be back in half-an-hour\r\nto tea.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThey returned within the time Hannah had allotted them: they entered by\r\nthe kitchen door. Mr. St. John, when he saw me, merely bowed and passed\r\nthrough; the two ladies stopped: Mary, in a few words, kindly and\r\ncalmly expressed the pleasure she felt in seeing me well enough to be\r\nable to come down; Diana took my hand: she shook her head at me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should have waited for my leave to descend,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou still\r\nlook very pale\xe2\x80\x94and so thin! Poor child!\xe2\x80\x94poor girl!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDiana had a voice toned, to my ear, like the cooing of a dove. She\r\npossessed eyes whose gaze I delighted to encounter. Her whole face\r\nseemed to me full of charm. Mary\xe2\x80\x99s countenance was equally\r\nintelligent\xe2\x80\x94her features equally pretty; but her expression was more\r\nreserved, and her manners, though gentle, more distant. Diana looked\r\nand spoke with a certain authority: she had a will, evidently. It was\r\nmy nature to feel pleasure in yielding to an authority supported like\r\nhers, and to bend, where my conscience and self-respect permitted, to\r\nan active will.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what business have you here?\xe2\x80\x9d she continued. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is not your\r\nplace. Mary and I sit in the kitchen sometimes, because at home we like\r\nto be free, even to license\xe2\x80\x94but you are a visitor, and must go into the\r\nparlour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am very well here.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all, with Hannah bustling about and covering you with flour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBesides, the fire is too hot for you,\xe2\x80\x9d interposed Mary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be sure,\xe2\x80\x9d added her sister. \xe2\x80\x9cCome, you must be obedient.\xe2\x80\x9d And still\r\nholding my hand she made me rise, and led me into the inner room.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSit there,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, placing me on the sofa, \xe2\x80\x9cwhile we take our\r\nthings off and get the tea ready; it is another privilege we exercise\r\nin our little moorland home\xe2\x80\x94to prepare our own meals when we are so\r\ninclined, or when Hannah is baking, brewing, washing, or ironing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe closed the door, leaving me solus with Mr. St. John, who sat\r\nopposite, a book or newspaper in his hand. I examined first, the\r\nparlour, and then its occupant.\r\n\r\nThe parlour was rather a small room, very plainly furnished, yet\r\ncomfortable, because clean and neat. The old-fashioned chairs were very\r\nbright, and the walnut-wood table was like a looking-glass. A few\r\nstrange, antique portraits of the men and women of other days decorated\r\nthe stained walls; a cupboard with glass doors contained some books and\r\nan ancient set of china. There was no superfluous ornament in the\r\nroom\xe2\x80\x94not one modern piece of furniture, save a brace of workboxes and a\r\nlady\xe2\x80\x99s desk in rosewood, which stood on a side-table:\r\neverything\xe2\x80\x94including the carpet and curtains\xe2\x80\x94looked at once well worn\r\nand well saved.\r\n\r\nMr. St. John\xe2\x80\x94sitting as still as one of the dusty pictures on the\r\nwalls, keeping his eyes fixed on the page he perused, and his lips\r\nmutely sealed\xe2\x80\x94was easy enough to examine. Had he been a statue instead\r\nof a man, he could not have been easier. He was young\xe2\x80\x94perhaps from\r\ntwenty-eight to thirty\xe2\x80\x94tall, slender; his face riveted the eye; it was\r\nlike a Greek face, very pure in outline: quite a straight, classic\r\nnose; quite an Athenian mouth and chin. It is seldom, indeed, an\r\nEnglish face comes so near the antique models as did his. He might well\r\nbe a little shocked at the irregularity of my lineaments, his own being\r\nso harmonious. His eyes were large and blue, with brown lashes; his\r\nhigh forehead, colourless as ivory, was partially streaked over by\r\ncareless locks of fair hair.\r\n\r\nThis is a gentle delineation, is it not, reader? Yet he whom it\r\ndescribes scarcely impressed one with the idea of a gentle, a yielding,\r\nan impressible, or even of a placid nature. Quiescent as he now sat,\r\nthere was something about his nostril, his mouth, his brow, which, to\r\nmy perceptions, indicated elements within either restless, or hard, or\r\neager. He did not speak to me one word, nor even direct to me one\r\nglance, till his sisters returned. Diana, as she passed in and out, in\r\nthe course of preparing tea, brought me a little cake, baked on the top\r\nof the oven.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cEat that now,\xe2\x80\x9d she said: \xe2\x80\x9cyou must be hungry. Hannah says you have had\r\nnothing but some gruel since breakfast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI did not refuse it, for my appetite was awakened and keen. Mr. Rivers\r\nnow closed his book, approached the table, and, as he took a seat,\r\nfixed his blue pictorial-looking eyes full on me. There was an\r\nunceremonious directness, a searching, decided steadfastness in his\r\ngaze now, which told that intention, and not diffidence, had hitherto\r\nkept it averted from the stranger.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are very hungry,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d It is my way\xe2\x80\x94it always was my way, by instinct\xe2\x80\x94ever to\r\nmeet the brief with brevity, the direct with plainness.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is well for you that a low fever has forced you to abstain for the\r\nlast three days: there would have been danger in yielding to the\r\ncravings of your appetite at first. Now you may eat, though still not\r\nimmoderately.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI trust I shall not eat long at your expense, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d was my very\r\nclumsily-contrived, unpolished answer.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo,\xe2\x80\x9d he said coolly: \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you have indicated to us the residence of\r\nyour friends, we can write to them, and you may be restored to home.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat, I must plainly tell you, is out of my power to do; being\r\nabsolutely without home and friends.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe three looked at me, but not distrustfully; I felt there was no\r\nsuspicion in their glances: there was more of curiosity. I speak\r\nparticularly of the young ladies. St. John\xe2\x80\x99s eyes, though clear enough\r\nin a literal sense, in a figurative one were difficult to fathom. He\r\nseemed to use them rather as instruments to search other people\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nthoughts, than as agents to reveal his own: the which combination of\r\nkeenness and reserve was considerably more calculated to embarrass than\r\nto encourage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you mean to say,\xe2\x80\x9d he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cthat you are completely isolated from\r\nevery connection?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do. Not a tie links me to any living thing: not a claim do I possess\r\nto admittance under any roof in England.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA most singular position at your age!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere I saw his glance directed to my hands, which were folded on the\r\ntable before me. I wondered what he sought there: his words soon\r\nexplained the quest.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have never been married? You are a spinster?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDiana laughed. \xe2\x80\x9cWhy, she can\xe2\x80\x99t be above seventeen or eighteen years\r\nold, St. John,\xe2\x80\x9d said she.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am near nineteen: but I am not married. No.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt a burning glow mount to my face; for bitter and agitating\r\nrecollections were awakened by the allusion to marriage. They all saw\r\nthe embarrassment and the emotion. Diana and Mary relieved me by\r\nturning their eyes elsewhere than to my crimsoned visage; but the\r\ncolder and sterner brother continued to gaze, till the trouble he had\r\nexcited forced out tears as well as colour.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere did you last reside?\xe2\x80\x9d he now asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are too inquisitive, St. John,\xe2\x80\x9d murmured Mary in a low voice; but\r\nhe leaned over the table and required an answer by a second firm and\r\npiercing look.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe name of the place where, and of the person with whom I lived, is\r\nmy secret,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied concisely.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich, if you like, you have, in my opinion, a right to keep, both\r\nfrom St. John and every other questioner,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked Diana.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet if I know nothing about you or your history, I cannot help you,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nhe said. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd you need help, do you not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI need it, and I seek it so far, sir, that some true philanthropist\r\nwill put me in the way of getting work which I can do, and the\r\nremuneration for which will keep me, if but in the barest necessaries\r\nof life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know not whether I am a true philanthropist; yet I am willing to aid\r\nyou to the utmost of my power in a purpose so honest. First, then, tell\r\nme what you have been accustomed to do, and what you _can_ do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had now swallowed my tea. I was mightily refreshed by the beverage;\r\nas much so as a giant with wine: it gave new tone to my unstrung\r\nnerves, and enabled me to address this penetrating young judge\r\nsteadily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rivers,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, turning to him, and looking at him, as he looked\r\nat me, openly and without diffidence, \xe2\x80\x9cyou and your sisters have done\r\nme a great service\xe2\x80\x94the greatest man can do his fellow-being; you have\r\nrescued me, by your noble hospitality, from death. This benefit\r\nconferred gives you an unlimited claim on my gratitude, and a claim, to\r\na certain extent, on my confidence. I will tell you as much of the\r\nhistory of the wanderer you have harboured, as I can tell without\r\ncompromising my own peace of mind\xe2\x80\x94my own security, moral and physical,\r\nand that of others.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am an orphan, the daughter of a clergyman. My parents died before I\r\ncould know them. I was brought up a dependent; educated in a charitable\r\ninstitution. I will even tell you the name of the establishment, where\r\nI passed six years as a pupil, and two as a teacher\xe2\x80\x94Lowood Orphan\r\nAsylum, \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire: you will have heard of it, Mr. Rivers?\xe2\x80\x94the Rev. Robert\r\nBrocklehurst is the treasurer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard of Mr. Brocklehurst, and I have seen the school.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI left Lowood nearly a year since to become a private governess. I\r\nobtained a good situation, and was happy. This place I was obliged to\r\nleave four days before I came here. The reason of my departure I cannot\r\nand ought not to explain: it would be useless, dangerous, and would\r\nsound incredible. No blame attached to me: I am as free from\r\nculpability as any one of you three. Miserable I am, and must be for a\r\ntime; for the catastrophe which drove me from a house I had found a\r\nparadise was of a strange and direful nature. I observed but two points\r\nin planning my departure\xe2\x80\x94speed, secrecy: to secure these, I had to\r\nleave behind me everything I possessed except a small parcel; which, in\r\nmy hurry and trouble of mind, I forgot to take out of the coach that\r\nbrought me to Whitcross. To this neighbourhood, then, I came, quite\r\ndestitute. I slept two nights in the open air, and wandered about two\r\ndays without crossing a threshold: but twice in that space of time did\r\nI taste food; and it was when brought by hunger, exhaustion, and\r\ndespair almost to the last gasp, that you, Mr. Rivers, forbade me to\r\nperish of want at your door, and took me under the shelter of your\r\nroof. I know all your sisters have done for me since\xe2\x80\x94for I have not\r\nbeen insensible during my seeming torpor\xe2\x80\x94and I owe to their\r\nspontaneous, genuine, genial compassion as large a debt as to your\r\nevangelical charity.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t make her talk any more now, St. John,\xe2\x80\x9d said Diana, as I paused;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cshe is evidently not yet fit for excitement. Come to the sofa and sit\r\ndown now, Miss Elliott.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI gave an involuntary half start at hearing the _alias_: I had\r\nforgotten my new name. Mr. Rivers, whom nothing seemed to escape,\r\nnoticed it at once.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said your name was Jane Elliott?\xe2\x80\x9d he observed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did say so; and it is the name by which I think it expedient to be\r\ncalled at present, but it is not my real name, and when I hear it, it\r\nsounds strange to me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour real name you will not give?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo: I fear discovery above all things; and whatever disclosure would\r\nlead to it, I avoid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite right, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said Diana. \xe2\x80\x9cNow do, brother, let her\r\nbe at peace a while.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut when St. John had mused a few moments he recommenced as\r\nimperturbably and with as much acumen as ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would not like to be long dependent on our hospitality\xe2\x80\x94you would\r\nwish, I see, to dispense as soon as may be with my sisters\xe2\x80\x99 compassion,\r\nand, above all, with my _charity_ (I am quite sensible of the\r\ndistinction drawn, nor do I resent it\xe2\x80\x94it is just): you desire to be\r\nindependent of us?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do: I have already said so. Show me how to work, or how to seek\r\nwork: that is all I now ask; then let me go, if it be but to the\r\nmeanest cottage; but till then, allow me to stay here: I dread another\r\nessay of the horrors of homeless destitution.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed you _shall_ stay here,\xe2\x80\x9d said Diana, putting her white hand on\r\nmy head. \xe2\x80\x9cYou _shall_,\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Mary, in the tone of undemonstrative\r\nsincerity which seemed natural to her.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy sisters, you see, have a pleasure in keeping you,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. St.\r\nJohn, \xe2\x80\x9cas they would have a pleasure in keeping and cherishing a\r\nhalf-frozen bird, some wintry wind might have driven through their\r\ncasement. _I_ feel more inclination to put you in the way of keeping\r\nyourself, and shall endeavour to do so; but observe, my sphere is\r\nnarrow. I am but the incumbent of a poor country parish: my aid must be\r\nof the humblest sort. And if you are inclined to despise the day of\r\nsmall things, seek some more efficient succour than such as I can\r\noffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe has already said that she is willing to do anything honest she\r\n_can_ do,\xe2\x80\x9d answered Diana for me; \xe2\x80\x9cand you know, St. John, she has no\r\nchoice of helpers: she is forced to put up with such crusty people as\r\nyou.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will be a dressmaker; I will be a plain-workwoman; I will be a\r\nservant, a nurse-girl, if I can be no better,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRight,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. St. John, quite coolly. \xe2\x80\x9cIf such is your spirit, I\r\npromise to aid you, in my own time and way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe now resumed the book with which he had been occupied before tea. I\r\nsoon withdrew, for I had talked as much, and sat up as long, as my\r\npresent strength would permit.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXX\r\n\r\n\r\nThe more I knew of the inmates of Moor House, the better I liked them.\r\nIn a few days I had so far recovered my health that I could sit up all\r\nday, and walk out sometimes. I could join with Diana and Mary in all\r\ntheir occupations; converse with them as much as they wished, and aid\r\nthem when and where they would allow me. There was a reviving pleasure\r\nin this intercourse, of a kind now tasted by me for the first time\xe2\x80\x94the\r\npleasure arising from perfect congeniality of tastes, sentiments, and\r\nprinciples.\r\n\r\nI liked to read what they liked to read: what they enjoyed, delighted\r\nme; what they approved, I reverenced. They loved their sequestered\r\nhome. I, too, in the grey, small, antique structure, with its low roof,\r\nits latticed casements, its mouldering walls, its avenue of aged\r\nfirs\xe2\x80\x94all grown aslant under the stress of mountain winds; its garden,\r\ndark with yew and holly\xe2\x80\x94and where no flowers but of the hardiest\r\nspecies would bloom\xe2\x80\x94found a charm both potent and permanent. They clung\r\nto the purple moors behind and around their dwelling\xe2\x80\x94to the hollow vale\r\ninto which the pebbly bridle-path leading from their gate descended,\r\nand which wound between fern-banks first, and then amongst a few of the\r\nwildest little pasture-fields that ever bordered a wilderness of heath,\r\nor gave sustenance to a flock of grey moorland sheep, with their little\r\nmossy-faced lambs:\xe2\x80\x94they clung to this scene, I say, with a perfect\r\nenthusiasm of attachment. I could comprehend the feeling, and share\r\nboth its strength and truth. I saw the fascination of the locality. I\r\nfelt the consecration of its loneliness: my eye feasted on the outline\r\nof swell and sweep\xe2\x80\x94on the wild colouring communicated to ridge and dell\r\nby moss, by heath-bell, by flower-sprinkled turf, by brilliant bracken,\r\nand mellow granite crag. These details were just to me what they were\r\nto them\xe2\x80\x94so many pure and sweet sources of pleasure. The strong blast\r\nand the soft breeze; the rough and the halcyon day; the hours of\r\nsunrise and sunset; the moonlight and the clouded night, developed for\r\nme, in these regions, the same attraction as for them\xe2\x80\x94wound round my\r\nfaculties the same spell that entranced theirs.\r\n\r\nIndoors we agreed equally well. They were both more accomplished and\r\nbetter read than I was; but with eagerness I followed in the path of\r\nknowledge they had trodden before me. I devoured the books they lent\r\nme: then it was full satisfaction to discuss with them in the evening\r\nwhat I had perused during the day. Thought fitted thought; opinion met\r\nopinion: we coincided, in short, perfectly.\r\n\r\nIf in our trio there was a superior and a leader, it was Diana.\r\nPhysically, she far excelled me: she was handsome; she was vigorous. In\r\nher animal spirits there was an affluence of life and certainty of\r\nflow, such as excited my wonder, while it baffled my comprehension. I\r\ncould talk a while when the evening commenced, but the first gush of\r\nvivacity and fluency gone, I was fain to sit on a stool at Diana\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nfeet, to rest my head on her knee, and listen alternately to her and\r\nMary, while they sounded thoroughly the topic on which I had but\r\ntouched. Diana offered to teach me German. I liked to learn of her: I\r\nsaw the part of instructress pleased and suited her; that of scholar\r\npleased and suited me no less. Our natures dovetailed: mutual\r\naffection\xe2\x80\x94of the strongest kind\xe2\x80\x94was the result. They discovered I could\r\ndraw: their pencils and colour-boxes were immediately at my service. My\r\nskill, greater in this one point than theirs, surprised and charmed\r\nthem. Mary would sit and watch me by the hour together: then she would\r\ntake lessons; and a docile, intelligent, assiduous pupil she made. Thus\r\noccupied, and mutually entertained, days passed like hours, and weeks\r\nlike days.\r\n\r\nAs to Mr. St John, the intimacy which had arisen so naturally and\r\nrapidly between me and his sisters did not extend to him. One reason of\r\nthe distance yet observed between us was, that he was comparatively\r\nseldom at home: a large proportion of his time appeared devoted to\r\nvisiting the sick and poor among the scattered population of his\r\nparish.\r\n\r\nNo weather seemed to hinder him in these pastoral excursions: rain or\r\nfair, he would, when his hours of morning study were over, take his\r\nhat, and, followed by his father\xe2\x80\x99s old pointer, Carlo, go out on his\r\nmission of love or duty\xe2\x80\x94I scarcely know in which light he regarded it.\r\nSometimes, when the day was very unfavourable, his sisters would\r\nexpostulate. He would then say, with a peculiar smile, more solemn than\r\ncheerful\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd if I let a gust of wind or a sprinkling of rain turn me aside from\r\nthese easy tasks, what preparation would such sloth be for the future I\r\npropose to myself?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nDiana and Mary\xe2\x80\x99s general answer to this question was a sigh, and some\r\nminutes of apparently mournful meditation.\r\n\r\nBut besides his frequent absences, there was another barrier to\r\nfriendship with him: he seemed of a reserved, an abstracted, and even\r\nof a brooding nature. Zealous in his ministerial labours, blameless in\r\nhis life and habits, he yet did not appear to enjoy that mental\r\nserenity, that inward content, which should be the reward of every\r\nsincere Christian and practical philanthropist. Often, of an evening,\r\nwhen he sat at the window, his desk and papers before him, he would\r\ncease reading or writing, rest his chin on his hand, and deliver\r\nhimself up to I know not what course of thought; but that it was\r\nperturbed and exciting might be seen in the frequent flash and\r\nchangeful dilation of his eye.\r\n\r\nI think, moreover, that Nature was not to him that treasury of delight\r\nit was to his sisters. He expressed once, and but once in my hearing, a\r\nstrong sense of the rugged charm of the hills, and an inborn affection\r\nfor the dark roof and hoary walls he called his home; but there was\r\nmore of gloom than pleasure in the tone and words in which the\r\nsentiment was manifested; and never did he seem to roam the moors for\r\nthe sake of their soothing silence\xe2\x80\x94never seek out or dwell upon the\r\nthousand peaceful delights they could yield.\r\n\r\nIncommunicative as he was, some time elapsed before I had an\r\nopportunity of gauging his mind. I first got an idea of its calibre\r\nwhen I heard him preach in his own church at Morton. I wish I could\r\ndescribe that sermon: but it is past my power. I cannot even render\r\nfaithfully the effect it produced on me.\r\n\r\nIt began calm\xe2\x80\x94and indeed, as far as delivery and pitch of voice went,\r\nit was calm to the end: an earnestly felt, yet strictly restrained zeal\r\nbreathed soon in the distinct accents, and prompted the nervous\r\nlanguage. This grew to force\xe2\x80\x94compressed, condensed, controlled. The\r\nheart was thrilled, the mind astonished, by the power of the preacher:\r\nneither were softened. Throughout there was a strange bitterness; an\r\nabsence of consolatory gentleness; stern allusions to Calvinistic\r\ndoctrines\xe2\x80\x94election, predestination, reprobation\xe2\x80\x94were frequent; and each\r\nreference to these points sounded like a sentence pronounced for doom.\r\nWhen he had done, instead of feeling better, calmer, more enlightened\r\nby his discourse, I experienced an inexpressible sadness; for it seemed\r\nto me\xe2\x80\x94I know not whether equally so to others\xe2\x80\x94that the eloquence to\r\nwhich I had been listening had sprung from a depth where lay turbid\r\ndregs of disappointment\xe2\x80\x94where moved troubling impulses of insatiate\r\nyearnings and disquieting aspirations. I was sure St. John\r\nRivers\xe2\x80\x94pure-lived, conscientious, zealous as he was\xe2\x80\x94had not yet found\r\nthat peace of God which passeth all understanding: he had no more found\r\nit, I thought, than had I with my concealed and racking regrets for my\r\nbroken idol and lost elysium\xe2\x80\x94regrets to which I have latterly avoided\r\nreferring, but which possessed me and tyrannised over me ruthlessly.\r\n\r\nMeantime a month was gone. Diana and Mary were soon to leave Moor\r\nHouse, and return to the far different life and scene which awaited\r\nthem, as governesses in a large, fashionable, south-of-England city,\r\nwhere each held a situation in families by whose wealthy and haughty\r\nmembers they were regarded only as humble dependents, and who neither\r\nknew nor sought out their innate excellences, and appreciated only\r\ntheir acquired accomplishments as they appreciated the skill of their\r\ncook or the taste of their waiting-woman. Mr. St. John had said nothing\r\nto me yet about the employment he had promised to obtain for me; yet it\r\nbecame urgent that I should have a vocation of some kind. One morning,\r\nbeing left alone with him a few minutes in the parlour, I ventured to\r\napproach the window-recess\xe2\x80\x94which his table, chair, and desk consecrated\r\nas a kind of study\xe2\x80\x94and I was going to speak, though not very well\r\nknowing in what words to frame my inquiry\xe2\x80\x94for it is at all times\r\ndifficult to break the ice of reserve glassing over such natures as\r\nhis\xe2\x80\x94when he saved me the trouble by being the first to commence a\r\ndialogue.\r\n\r\nLooking up as I drew near\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cYou have a question to ask of me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; I wish to know whether you have heard of any service I can offer\r\nmyself to undertake?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI found or devised something for you three weeks ago; but as you\r\nseemed both useful and happy here\xe2\x80\x94as my sisters had evidently become\r\nattached to you, and your society gave them unusual pleasure\xe2\x80\x94I deemed\r\nit inexpedient to break in on your mutual comfort till their\r\napproaching departure from Marsh End should render yours necessary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd they will go in three days now?\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; and when they go, I shall return to the parsonage at Morton:\r\nHannah will accompany me; and this old house will be shut up.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI waited a few moments, expecting he would go on with the subject first\r\nbroached: but he seemed to have entered another train of reflection:\r\nhis look denoted abstraction from me and my business. I was obliged to\r\nrecall him to a theme which was of necessity one of close and anxious\r\ninterest to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the employment you had in view, Mr. Rivers? I hope this delay\r\nwill not have increased the difficulty of securing it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no; since it is an employment which depends only on me to give,\r\nand you to accept.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe again paused: there seemed a reluctance to continue. I grew\r\nimpatient: a restless movement or two, and an eager and exacting glance\r\nfastened on his face, conveyed the feeling to him as effectually as\r\nwords could have done, and with less trouble.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou need be in no hurry to hear,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9clet me frankly tell you, I\r\nhave nothing eligible or profitable to suggest. Before I explain,\r\nrecall, if you please, my notice, clearly given, that if I helped you,\r\nit must be as the blind man would help the lame. I am poor; for I find\r\nthat, when I have paid my father\xe2\x80\x99s debts, all the patrimony remaining\r\nto me will be this crumbling grange, the row of scathed firs behind,\r\nand the patch of moorish soil, with the yew-trees and holly-bushes in\r\nfront. I am obscure: Rivers is an old name; but of the three sole\r\ndescendants of the race, two earn the dependent\xe2\x80\x99s crust among\r\nstrangers, and the third considers himself an alien from his native\r\ncountry\xe2\x80\x94not only for life, but in death. Yes, and deems, and is bound\r\nto deem, himself honoured by the lot, and aspires but after the day\r\nwhen the cross of separation from fleshly ties shall be laid on his\r\nshoulders, and when the Head of that church-militant of whose humblest\r\nmembers he is one, shall give the word, \xe2\x80\x98Rise, follow Me!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. John said these words as he pronounced his sermons, with a quiet,\r\ndeep voice; with an unflushed cheek, and a coruscating radiance of\r\nglance. He resumed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd since I am myself poor and obscure, I can offer you but a service\r\nof poverty and obscurity. _You_ may even think it degrading\xe2\x80\x94for I see\r\nnow your habits have been what the world calls refined: your tastes\r\nlean to the ideal, and your society has at least been amongst the\r\neducated; but _I_ consider that no service degrades which can better\r\nour race. I hold that the more arid and unreclaimed the soil where the\r\nChristian labourer\xe2\x80\x99s task of tillage is appointed him\xe2\x80\x94the scantier the\r\nmeed his toil brings\xe2\x80\x94the higher the honour. His, under such\r\ncircumstances, is the destiny of the pioneer; and the first pioneers of\r\nthe Gospel were the Apostles\xe2\x80\x94their captain was Jesus, the Redeemer,\r\nHimself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d I said, as he again paused\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cproceed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked at me before he proceeded: indeed, he seemed leisurely to\r\nread my face, as if its features and lines were characters on a page.\r\nThe conclusions drawn from this scrutiny he partially expressed in his\r\nsucceeding observations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI believe you will accept the post I offer you,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand hold it\r\nfor a while: not permanently, though: any more than I could permanently\r\nkeep the narrow and narrowing\xe2\x80\x94the tranquil, hidden office of English\r\ncountry incumbent; for in your nature is an alloy as detrimental to\r\nrepose as that in mine, though of a different kind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo explain,\xe2\x80\x9d I urged, when he halted once more.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will; and you shall hear how poor the proposal is,\xe2\x80\x94how trivial\xe2\x80\x94how\r\ncramping. I shall not stay long at Morton, now that my father is dead,\r\nand that I am my own master. I shall leave the place probably in the\r\ncourse of a twelve-month; but while I do stay, I will exert myself to\r\nthe utmost for its improvement. Morton, when I came to it two years\r\nago, had no school: the children of the poor were excluded from every\r\nhope of progress. I established one for boys: I mean now to open a\r\nsecond school for girls. I have hired a building for the purpose, with\r\na cottage of two rooms attached to it for the mistress\xe2\x80\x99s house. Her\r\nsalary will be thirty pounds a year: her house is already furnished,\r\nvery simply, but sufficiently, by the kindness of a lady, Miss Oliver;\r\nthe only daughter of the sole rich man in my parish\xe2\x80\x94Mr. Oliver, the\r\nproprietor of a needle-factory and iron-foundry in the valley. The same\r\nlady pays for the education and clothing of an orphan from the\r\nworkhouse, on condition that she shall aid the mistress in such menial\r\noffices connected with her own house and the school as her occupation\r\nof teaching will prevent her having time to discharge in person. Will\r\nyou be this mistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe put the question rather hurriedly; he seemed half to expect an\r\nindignant, or at least a disdainful rejection of the offer: not knowing\r\nall my thoughts and feelings, though guessing some, he could not tell\r\nin what light the lot would appear to me. In truth it was humble\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nthen it was sheltered, and I wanted a safe asylum: it was plodding\xe2\x80\x94but\r\nthen, compared with that of a governess in a rich house, it was\r\nindependent; and the fear of servitude with strangers entered my soul\r\nlike iron: it was not ignoble\xe2\x80\x94not unworthy\xe2\x80\x94not mentally degrading, I\r\nmade my decision.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank you for the proposal, Mr. Rivers, and I accept it with all my\r\nheart.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you comprehend me?\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a village school: your\r\nscholars will be only poor girls\xe2\x80\x94cottagers\xe2\x80\x99 children\xe2\x80\x94at the best,\r\nfarmers\xe2\x80\x99 daughters. Knitting, sewing, reading, writing, ciphering, will\r\nbe all you will have to teach. What will you do with your\r\naccomplishments? What, with the largest portion of your\r\nmind\xe2\x80\x94sentiments\xe2\x80\x94tastes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSave them till they are wanted. They will keep.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know what you undertake, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe now smiled: and not a bitter or a sad smile, but one well pleased\r\nand deeply gratified.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd when will you commence the exercise of your function?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will go to my house to-morrow, and open the school, if you like,\r\nnext week.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well: so be it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe rose and walked through the room. Standing still, he again looked at\r\nme. He shook his head.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you disapprove of, Mr. Rivers?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou will not stay at Morton long: no, no!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? What is your reason for saying so?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI read it in your eye; it is not of that description which promises\r\nthe maintenance of an even tenor in life.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am not ambitious.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe started at the word \xe2\x80\x9cambitious.\xe2\x80\x9d He repeated, \xe2\x80\x9cNo. What made you\r\nthink of ambition? Who is ambitious? I know I am: but how did you find\r\nit out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was speaking of myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you are not ambitious, you are\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d He paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was going to say, impassioned: but perhaps you would have\r\nmisunderstood the word, and been displeased. I mean, that human\r\naffections and sympathies have a most powerful hold on you. I am sure\r\nyou cannot long be content to pass your leisure in solitude, and to\r\ndevote your working hours to a monotonous labour wholly void of\r\nstimulus: any more than I can be content,\xe2\x80\x9d he added, with emphasis, \xe2\x80\x9cto\r\nlive here buried in morass, pent in with mountains\xe2\x80\x94my nature, that God\r\ngave me, contravened; my faculties, heaven-bestowed, paralysed\xe2\x80\x94made\r\nuseless. You hear now how I contradict myself. I, who preached\r\ncontentment with a humble lot, and justified the vocation even of\r\nhewers of wood and drawers of water in God\xe2\x80\x99s service\xe2\x80\x94I, His ordained\r\nminister, almost rave in my restlessness. Well, propensities and\r\nprinciples must be reconciled by some means.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe left the room. In this brief hour I had learnt more of him than in\r\nthe whole previous month: yet still he puzzled me.\r\n\r\nDiana and Mary Rivers became more sad and silent as the day approached\r\nfor leaving their brother and their home. They both tried to appear as\r\nusual; but the sorrow they had to struggle against was one that could\r\nnot be entirely conquered or concealed. Diana intimated that this would\r\nbe a different parting from any they had ever yet known. It would\r\nprobably, as far as St. John was concerned, be a parting for years: it\r\nmight be a parting for life.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe will sacrifice all to his long-framed resolves,\xe2\x80\x9d she said: \xe2\x80\x9cnatural\r\naffection and feelings more potent still. St. John looks quiet, Jane;\r\nbut he hides a fever in his vitals. You would think him gentle, yet in\r\nsome things he is inexorable as death; and the worst of it is, my\r\nconscience will hardly permit me to dissuade him from his severe\r\ndecision: certainly, I cannot for a moment blame him for it. It is\r\nright, noble, Christian: yet it breaks my heart!\xe2\x80\x9d And the tears gushed\r\nto her fine eyes. Mary bent her head low over her work.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe are now without father: we shall soon be without home and brother,\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe murmured.\r\n\r\nAt that moment a little accident supervened, which seemed decreed by\r\nfate purposely to prove the truth of the adage, that \xe2\x80\x9cmisfortunes never\r\ncome singly,\xe2\x80\x9d and to add to their distresses the vexing one of the slip\r\nbetween the cup and the lip. St. John passed the window reading a\r\nletter. He entered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOur uncle John is dead,\xe2\x80\x9d said he.\r\n\r\nBoth the sisters seemed struck: not shocked or appalled; the tidings\r\nappeared in their eyes rather momentous than afflicting.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead?\xe2\x80\x9d repeated Diana.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe riveted a searching gaze on her brother\xe2\x80\x99s face. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nshe demanded, in a low voice.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat then, Die?\xe2\x80\x9d he replied, maintaining a marble immobility of\r\nfeature. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat then? Why\xe2\x80\x94nothing. Read.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe threw the letter into her lap. She glanced over it, and handed it to\r\nMary. Mary perused it in silence, and returned it to her brother. All\r\nthree looked at each other, and all three smiled\xe2\x80\x94a dreary, pensive\r\nsmile enough.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAmen! We can yet live,\xe2\x80\x9d said Diana at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt any rate, it makes us no worse off than we were before,\xe2\x80\x9d remarked\r\nMary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly it forces rather strongly on the mind the picture of what _might\r\nhave been_,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rivers, \xe2\x80\x9cand contrasts it somewhat too vividly\r\nwith what _is_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe folded the letter, locked it in his desk, and again went out.\r\n\r\nFor some minutes no one spoke. Diana then turned to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, you will wonder at us and our mysteries,\xe2\x80\x9d she said, \xe2\x80\x9cand think\r\nus hard-hearted beings not to be more moved at the death of so near a\r\nrelation as an uncle; but we have never seen him or known him. He was\r\nmy mother\xe2\x80\x99s brother. My father and he quarrelled long ago. It was by\r\nhis advice that my father risked most of his property in the\r\nspeculation that ruined him. Mutual recrimination passed between them:\r\nthey parted in anger, and were never reconciled. My uncle engaged\r\nafterwards in more prosperous undertakings: it appears he realised a\r\nfortune of twenty thousand pounds. He was never married, and had no\r\nnear kindred but ourselves and one other person, not more closely\r\nrelated than we. My father always cherished the idea that he would\r\natone for his error by leaving his possessions to us; that letter\r\ninforms us that he has bequeathed every penny to the other relation,\r\nwith the exception of thirty guineas, to be divided between St. John,\r\nDiana, and Mary Rivers, for the purchase of three mourning rings. He\r\nhad a right, of course, to do as he pleased: and yet a momentary damp\r\nis cast on the spirits by the receipt of such news. Mary and I would\r\nhave esteemed ourselves rich with a thousand pounds each; and to St.\r\nJohn such a sum would have been valuable, for the good it would have\r\nenabled him to do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis explanation given, the subject was dropped, and no further\r\nreference made to it by either Mr. Rivers or his sisters. The next day\r\nI left Marsh End for Morton. The day after, Diana and Mary quitted it\r\nfor distant B\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. In a week, Mr. Rivers and Hannah repaired to the\r\nparsonage: and so the old grange was abandoned.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXI\r\n\r\n\r\nMy home, then, when I at last find a home,\xe2\x80\x94is a cottage; a little room\r\nwith whitewashed walls and a sanded floor, containing four painted\r\nchairs and a table, a clock, a cupboard, with two or three plates and\r\ndishes, and a set of tea-things in delf. Above, a chamber of the same\r\ndimensions as the kitchen, with a deal bedstead and chest of drawers;\r\nsmall, yet too large to be filled with my scanty wardrobe: though the\r\nkindness of my gentle and generous friends has increased that, by a\r\nmodest stock of such things as are necessary.\r\n\r\nIt is evening. I have dismissed, with the fee of an orange, the little\r\norphan who serves me as a handmaid. I am sitting alone on the hearth.\r\nThis morning, the village school opened. I had twenty scholars. But\r\nthree of the number can read: none write or cipher. Several knit, and a\r\nfew sew a little. They speak with the broadest accent of the district.\r\nAt present, they and I have a difficulty in understanding each other\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlanguage. Some of them are unmannered, rough, intractable, as well as\r\nignorant; but others are docile, have a wish to learn, and evince a\r\ndisposition that pleases me. I must not forget that these coarsely-clad\r\nlittle peasants are of flesh and blood as good as the scions of\r\ngentlest genealogy; and that the germs of native excellence,\r\nrefinement, intelligence, kind feeling, are as likely to exist in their\r\nhearts as in those of the best-born. My duty will be to develop these\r\ngerms: surely I shall find some happiness in discharging that office.\r\nMuch enjoyment I do not expect in the life opening before me: yet it\r\nwill, doubtless, if I regulate my mind, and exert my powers as I ought,\r\nyield me enough to live on from day to day.\r\n\r\nWas I very gleeful, settled, content, during the hours I passed in\r\nyonder bare, humble schoolroom this morning and afternoon? Not to\r\ndeceive myself, I must reply\xe2\x80\x94No: I felt desolate to a degree. I\r\nfelt\xe2\x80\x94yes, idiot that I am\xe2\x80\x94I felt degraded. I doubted I had taken a step\r\nwhich sank instead of raising me in the scale of social existence. I\r\nwas weakly dismayed at the ignorance, the poverty, the coarseness of\r\nall I heard and saw round me. But let me not hate and despise myself\r\ntoo much for these feelings; I know them to be wrong\xe2\x80\x94that is a great\r\nstep gained; I shall strive to overcome them. To-morrow, I trust, I\r\nshall get the better of them partially; and in a few weeks, perhaps,\r\nthey will be quite subdued. In a few months, it is possible, the\r\nhappiness of seeing progress, and a change for the better in my\r\nscholars may substitute gratification for disgust.\r\n\r\nMeantime, let me ask myself one question\xe2\x80\x94Which is better?\xe2\x80\x94To have\r\nsurrendered to temptation; listened to passion; made no painful\r\neffort\xe2\x80\x94no struggle;\xe2\x80\x94but to have sunk down in the silken snare; fallen\r\nasleep on the flowers covering it; wakened in a southern clime, amongst\r\nthe luxuries of a pleasure villa: to have been now living in France,\r\nMr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s mistress; delirious with his love half my time\xe2\x80\x94for he\r\nwould\xe2\x80\x94oh, yes, he would have loved me well for a while. He _did_ love\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94no one will ever love me so again. I shall never more know the sweet\r\nhomage given to beauty, youth, and grace\xe2\x80\x94for never to any one else\r\nshall I seem to possess these charms. He was fond and proud of me\xe2\x80\x94it is\r\nwhat no man besides will ever be.\xe2\x80\x94But where am I wandering, and what am\r\nI saying, and above all, feeling? Whether is it better, I ask, to be a\r\nslave in a fool\xe2\x80\x99s paradise at Marseilles\xe2\x80\x94fevered with delusive bliss\r\none hour\xe2\x80\x94suffocating with the bitterest tears of remorse and shame the\r\nnext\xe2\x80\x94or to be a village-schoolmistress, free and honest, in a breezy\r\nmountain nook in the healthy heart of England?\r\n\r\nYes; I feel now that I was right when I adhered to principle and law,\r\nand scorned and crushed the insane promptings of a frenzied moment. God\r\ndirected me to a correct choice: I thank His providence for the\r\nguidance!\r\n\r\nHaving brought my eventide musings to this point, I rose, went to my\r\ndoor, and looked at the sunset of the harvest-day, and at the quiet\r\nfields before my cottage, which, with the school, was distant half a\r\nmile from the village. The birds were singing their last strains\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe air was mild, the dew was balm.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nWhile I looked, I thought myself happy, and was surprised to find\r\nmyself ere long weeping\xe2\x80\x94and why? For the doom which had reft me from\r\nadhesion to my master: for him I was no more to see; for the desperate\r\ngrief and fatal fury\xe2\x80\x94consequences of my departure\xe2\x80\x94which might now,\r\nperhaps, be dragging him from the path of right, too far to leave hope\r\nof ultimate restoration thither. At this thought, I turned my face\r\naside from the lovely sky of eve and lonely vale of Morton\xe2\x80\x94I say\r\n_lonely_, for in that bend of it visible to me there was no building\r\napparent save the church and the parsonage, half-hid in trees, and,\r\nquite at the extremity, the roof of Vale Hall, where the rich Mr.\r\nOliver and his daughter lived. I hid my eyes, and leant my head against\r\nthe stone frame of my door; but soon a slight noise near the wicket\r\nwhich shut in my tiny garden from the meadow beyond it made me look up.\r\nA dog\xe2\x80\x94old Carlo, Mr. Rivers\xe2\x80\x99 pointer, as I saw in a moment\xe2\x80\x94was pushing\r\nthe gate with his nose, and St. John himself leant upon it with folded\r\narms; his brow knit, his gaze, grave almost to displeasure, fixed on\r\nme. I asked him to come in.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, I cannot stay; I have only brought you a little parcel my sisters\r\nleft for you. I think it contains a colour-box, pencils, and paper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI approached to take it: a welcome gift it was. He examined my face, I\r\nthought, with austerity, as I came near: the traces of tears were\r\ndoubtless very visible upon it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you found your first day\xe2\x80\x99s work harder than you expected?\xe2\x80\x9d he\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, no! On the contrary, I think in time I shall get on with my\r\nscholars very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut perhaps your accommodations\xe2\x80\x94your cottage\xe2\x80\x94your furniture\xe2\x80\x94have\r\ndisappointed your expectations? They are, in truth, scanty enough;\r\nbut\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d I interrupted\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy cottage is clean and weather-proof; my furniture sufficient and\r\ncommodious. All I see has made me thankful, not despondent. I am not\r\nabsolutely such a fool and sensualist as to regret the absence of a\r\ncarpet, a sofa, and silver plate; besides, five weeks ago I had\r\nnothing\xe2\x80\x94I was an outcast, a beggar, a vagrant; now I have acquaintance,\r\na home, a business. I wonder at the goodness of God; the generosity of\r\nmy friends; the bounty of my lot. I do not repine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you feel solitude an oppression? The little house there behind you\r\nis dark and empty.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have hardly had time yet to enjoy a sense of tranquillity, much less\r\nto grow impatient under one of loneliness.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well; I hope you feel the content you express: at any rate, your\r\ngood sense will tell you that it is too soon yet to yield to the\r\nvacillating fears of Lot\xe2\x80\x99s wife. What you had left before I saw you, of\r\ncourse I do not know; but I counsel you to resist firmly every\r\ntemptation which would incline you to look back: pursue your present\r\ncareer steadily, for some months at least.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is what I mean to do,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered. St. John continued\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is hard work to control the workings of inclination and turn the\r\nbent of nature; but that it may be done, I know from experience. God\r\nhas given us, in a measure, the power to make our own fate; and when\r\nour energies seem to demand a sustenance they cannot get\xe2\x80\x94when our will\r\nstrains after a path we may not follow\xe2\x80\x94we need neither starve from\r\ninanition, nor stand still in despair: we have but to seek another\r\nnourishment for the mind, as strong as the forbidden food it longed to\r\ntaste\xe2\x80\x94and perhaps purer; and to hew out for the adventurous foot a road\r\nas direct and broad as the one Fortune has blocked up against us, if\r\nrougher than it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA year ago I was myself intensely miserable, because I thought I had\r\nmade a mistake in entering the ministry: its uniform duties wearied me\r\nto death. I burnt for the more active life of the world\xe2\x80\x94for the more\r\nexciting toils of a literary career\xe2\x80\x94for the destiny of an artist,\r\nauthor, orator; anything rather than that of a priest: yes, the heart\r\nof a politician, of a soldier, of a votary of glory, a lover of renown,\r\na luster after power, beat under my curate\xe2\x80\x99s surplice. I considered; my\r\nlife was so wretched, it must be changed, or I must die. After a season\r\nof darkness and struggling, light broke and relief fell: my cramped\r\nexistence all at once spread out to a plain without bounds\xe2\x80\x94my powers\r\nheard a call from heaven to rise, gather their full strength, spread\r\ntheir wings, and mount beyond ken. God had an errand for me; to bear\r\nwhich afar, to deliver it well, skill and strength, courage and\r\neloquence, the best qualifications of soldier, statesman, and orator,\r\nwere all needed: for these all centre in the good missionary.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA missionary I resolved to be. From that moment my state of mind\r\nchanged; the fetters dissolved and dropped from every faculty, leaving\r\nnothing of bondage but its galling soreness\xe2\x80\x94which time only can heal.\r\nMy father, indeed, imposed the determination, but since his death, I\r\nhave not a legitimate obstacle to contend with; some affairs settled, a\r\nsuccessor for Morton provided, an entanglement or two of the feelings\r\nbroken through or cut asunder\xe2\x80\x94a last conflict with human weakness, in\r\nwhich I know I shall overcome, because I have vowed that I _will_\r\novercome\xe2\x80\x94and I leave Europe for the East.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe said this, in his peculiar, subdued, yet emphatic voice; looking,\r\nwhen he had ceased speaking, not at me, but at the setting sun, at\r\nwhich I looked too. Both he and I had our backs towards the path\r\nleading up the field to the wicket. We had heard no step on that\r\ngrass-grown track; the water running in the vale was the one lulling\r\nsound of the hour and scene; we might well then start when a gay voice,\r\nsweet as a silver bell, exclaimed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood evening, Mr. Rivers. And good evening, old Carlo. Your dog is\r\nquicker to recognise his friends than you are, sir; he pricked his ears\r\nand wagged his tail when I was at the bottom of the field, and you have\r\nyour back towards me now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt was true. Though Mr. Rivers had started at the first of those\r\nmusical accents, as if a thunderbolt had split a cloud over his head,\r\nhe stood yet, at the close of the sentence, in the same attitude in\r\nwhich the speaker had surprised him\xe2\x80\x94his arm resting on the gate, his\r\nface directed towards the west. He turned at last, with measured\r\ndeliberation. A vision, as it seemed to me, had risen at his side.\r\nThere appeared, within three feet of him, a form clad in pure white\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nyouthful, graceful form: full, yet fine in contour; and when, after\r\nbending to caress Carlo, it lifted up its head, and threw back a long\r\nveil, there bloomed under his glance a face of perfect beauty. Perfect\r\nbeauty is a strong expression; but I do not retrace or qualify it: as\r\nsweet features as ever the temperate clime of Albion moulded; as pure\r\nhues of rose and lily as ever her humid gales and vapoury skies\r\ngenerated and screened, justified, in this instance, the term. No charm\r\nwas wanting, no defect was perceptible; the young girl had regular and\r\ndelicate lineaments; eyes shaped and coloured as we see them in lovely\r\npictures, large, and dark, and full; the long and shadowy eyelash which\r\nencircles a fine eye with so soft a fascination; the pencilled brow\r\nwhich gives such clearness; the white smooth forehead, which adds such\r\nrepose to the livelier beauties of tint and ray; the cheek oval, fresh,\r\nand smooth; the lips, fresh too, ruddy, healthy, sweetly formed; the\r\neven and gleaming teeth without flaw; the small dimpled chin; the\r\nornament of rich, plenteous tresses\xe2\x80\x94all advantages, in short, which,\r\ncombined, realise the ideal of beauty, were fully hers. I wondered, as\r\nI looked at this fair creature: I admired her with my whole heart.\r\nNature had surely formed her in a partial mood; and, forgetting her\r\nusual stinted step-mother dole of gifts, had endowed this, her darling,\r\nwith a grand-dame\xe2\x80\x99s bounty.\r\n\r\nWhat did St. John Rivers think of this earthly angel? I naturally asked\r\nmyself that question as I saw him turn to her and look at her; and, as\r\nnaturally, I sought the answer to the inquiry in his countenance. He\r\nhad already withdrawn his eye from the Peri, and was looking at a\r\nhumble tuft of daisies which grew by the wicket.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA lovely evening, but late for you to be out alone,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, as he\r\ncrushed the snowy heads of the closed flowers with his foot.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I only came home from S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d (she mentioned the name of a large town\r\nsome twenty miles distant) \xe2\x80\x9cthis afternoon. Papa told me you had opened\r\nyour school, and that the new mistress was come; and so I put on my\r\nbonnet after tea, and ran up the valley to see her: this is she?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\npointing to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. John.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you think you shall like Morton?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked of me, with a direct\r\nand na\xc3\xafve simplicity of tone and manner, pleasing, if child-like.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI hope I shall. I have many inducements to do so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you find your scholars as attentive as you expected?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you like your house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery much.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave I furnished it nicely?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery nicely, indeed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd made a good choice of an attendant for you in Alice Wood?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have indeed. She is teachable and handy.\xe2\x80\x9d (This then, I thought,\r\nis Miss Oliver, the heiress; favoured, it seems, in the gifts of\r\nfortune, as well as in those of nature! What happy combination of the\r\nplanets presided over her birth, I wonder?)\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall come up and help you to teach sometimes,\xe2\x80\x9d she added. \xe2\x80\x9cIt will\r\nbe a change for me to visit you now and then; and I like a change. Mr.\r\nRivers, I have been _so_ gay during my stay at S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Last night, or\r\nrather this morning, I was dancing till two o\xe2\x80\x99clock. The \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94th regiment\r\nare stationed there since the riots; and the officers are the most\r\nagreeable men in the world: they put all our young knife-grinders and\r\nscissor merchants to shame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nIt seemed to me that Mr. St. John\xe2\x80\x99s under lip protruded, and his upper\r\nlip curled a moment. His mouth certainly looked a good deal compressed,\r\nand the lower part of his face unusually stern and square, as the\r\nlaughing girl gave him this information. He lifted his gaze, too, from\r\nthe daisies, and turned it on her. An unsmiling, a searching, a meaning\r\ngaze it was. She answered it with a second laugh, and laughter well\r\nbecame her youth, her roses, her dimples, her bright eyes.\r\n\r\nAs he stood, mute and grave, she again fell to caressing Carlo. \xe2\x80\x9cPoor\r\nCarlo loves me,\xe2\x80\x9d said she. \xe2\x80\x9c_He_ is not stern and distant to his\r\nfriends; and if he could speak, he would not be silent.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAs she patted the dog\xe2\x80\x99s head, bending with native grace before his\r\nyoung and austere master, I saw a glow rise to that master\xe2\x80\x99s face. I\r\nsaw his solemn eye melt with sudden fire, and flicker with resistless\r\nemotion. Flushed and kindled thus, he looked nearly as beautiful for a\r\nman as she for a woman. His chest heaved once, as if his large heart,\r\nweary of despotic constriction, had expanded, despite the will, and\r\nmade a vigorous bound for the attainment of liberty. But he curbed it,\r\nI think, as a resolute rider would curb a rearing steed. He responded\r\nneither by word nor movement to the gentle advances made him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPapa says you never come to see us now,\xe2\x80\x9d continued Miss Oliver,\r\nlooking up. \xe2\x80\x9cYou are quite a stranger at Vale Hall. He is alone this\r\nevening, and not very well: will you return with me and visit him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not a seasonable hour to intrude on Mr. Oliver,\xe2\x80\x9d answered St.\r\nJohn.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot a seasonable hour! But I declare it is. It is just the hour when\r\npapa most wants company: when the works are closed and he has no\r\nbusiness to occupy him. Now, Mr. Rivers, _do_ come. Why are you so very\r\nshy, and so very sombre?\xe2\x80\x9d She filled up the hiatus his silence left by\r\na reply of her own.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI forgot!\xe2\x80\x9d she exclaimed, shaking her beautiful curled head, as if\r\nshocked at herself. \xe2\x80\x9cI am so giddy and thoughtless! _Do_ excuse me. It\r\nhad slipped my memory that you have good reasons to be indisposed for\r\njoining in my chatter. Diana and Mary have left you, and Moor House is\r\nshut up, and you are so lonely. I am sure I pity you. Do come and see\r\npapa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot to-night, Miss Rosamond, not to-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMr. St. John spoke almost like an automaton: himself only knew the\r\neffort it cost him thus to refuse.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, if you are so obstinate, I will leave you; for I dare not stay\r\nany longer: the dew begins to fall. Good evening!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe held out her hand. He just touched it. \xe2\x80\x9cGood evening!\xe2\x80\x9d he repeated,\r\nin a voice low and hollow as an echo. She turned, but in a moment\r\nreturned.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAre you well?\xe2\x80\x9d she asked. Well might she put the question: his face\r\nwas blanched as her gown.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite well,\xe2\x80\x9d he enunciated; and, with a bow, he left the gate. She\r\nwent one way; he another. She turned twice to gaze after him as she\r\ntripped fairy-like down the field; he, as he strode firmly across,\r\nnever turned at all.\r\n\r\nThis spectacle of another\xe2\x80\x99s suffering and sacrifice rapt my thoughts\r\nfrom exclusive meditation on my own.
