Diana Rivers had designated her\r\nbrother \xe2\x80\x9cinexorable as death.\xe2\x80\x9d She had not exaggerated.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXII\r\n\r\n\r\nI continued the labours of the village-school as actively and\r\nfaithfully as I could. It was truly hard work at first. Some time\r\nelapsed before, with all my efforts, I could comprehend my scholars and\r\ntheir nature. Wholly untaught, with faculties quite torpid, they seemed\r\nto me hopelessly dull; and, at first sight, all dull alike: but I soon\r\nfound I was mistaken. There was a difference amongst them as amongst\r\nthe educated; and when I got to know them, and they me, this difference\r\nrapidly developed itself. Their amazement at me, my language, my rules,\r\nand ways, once subsided, I found some of these heavy-looking, gaping\r\nrustics wake up into sharp-witted girls enough. Many showed themselves\r\nobliging, and amiable too; and I discovered amongst them not a few\r\nexamples of natural politeness, and innate self-respect, as well as of\r\nexcellent capacity, that won both my goodwill and my admiration. These\r\nsoon took a pleasure in doing their work well, in keeping their persons\r\nneat, in learning their tasks regularly, in acquiring quiet and orderly\r\nmanners. The rapidity of their progress, in some instances, was even\r\nsurprising; and an honest and happy pride I took in it: besides, I\r\nbegan personally to like some of the best girls; and they liked me. I\r\nhad amongst my scholars several farmers\xe2\x80\x99 daughters: young women grown,\r\nalmost. These could already read, write, and sew; and to them I taught\r\nthe elements of grammar, geography, history, and the finer kinds of\r\nneedlework. I found estimable characters amongst them\xe2\x80\x94characters\r\ndesirous of information and disposed for improvement\xe2\x80\x94with whom I passed\r\nmany a pleasant evening hour in their own homes. Their parents then\r\n(the farmer and his wife) loaded me with attentions. There was an\r\nenjoyment in accepting their simple kindness, and in repaying it by a\r\nconsideration\xe2\x80\x94a scrupulous regard to their feelings\xe2\x80\x94to which they were\r\nnot, perhaps, at all times accustomed, and which both charmed and\r\nbenefited them; because, while it elevated them in their own eyes, it\r\nmade them emulous to merit the deferential treatment they received.\r\n\r\nI felt I became a favourite in the neighbourhood. Whenever I went out,\r\nI heard on all sides cordial salutations, and was welcomed with\r\nfriendly smiles. To live amidst general regard, though it be but the\r\nregard of working people, is like \xe2\x80\x9csitting in sunshine, calm and\r\nsweet;\xe2\x80\x9d serene inward feelings bud and bloom under the ray. At this\r\nperiod of my life, my heart far oftener swelled with thankfulness than\r\nsank with dejection: and yet, reader, to tell you all, in the midst of\r\nthis calm, this useful existence\xe2\x80\x94after a day passed in honourable\r\nexertion amongst my scholars, an evening spent in drawing or reading\r\ncontentedly alone\xe2\x80\x94I used to rush into strange dreams at night: dreams\r\nmany-coloured, agitated, full of the ideal, the stirring, the\r\nstormy\xe2\x80\x94dreams where, amidst unusual scenes, charged with adventure,\r\nwith agitating risk and romantic chance, I still again and again met\r\nMr. Rochester, always at some exciting crisis; and then the sense of\r\nbeing in his arms, hearing his voice, meeting his eye, touching his\r\nhand and cheek, loving him, being loved by him\xe2\x80\x94the hope of passing a\r\nlifetime at his side, would be renewed, with all its first force and\r\nfire. Then I awoke. Then I recalled where I was, and how situated. Then\r\nI rose up on my curtainless bed, trembling and quivering; and then the\r\nstill, dark night witnessed the convulsion of despair, and heard the\r\nburst of passion. By nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock the next morning I was punctually\r\nopening the school; tranquil, settled, prepared for the steady duties\r\nof the day.\r\n\r\nRosamond Oliver kept her word in coming to visit me. Her call at the\r\nschool was generally made in the course of her morning ride. She would\r\ncanter up to the door on her pony, followed by a mounted livery\r\nservant. Anything more exquisite than her appearance, in her purple\r\nhabit, with her Amazon\xe2\x80\x99s cap of black velvet placed gracefully above\r\nthe long curls that kissed her cheek and floated to her shoulders, can\r\nscarcely be imagined: and it was thus she would enter the rustic\r\nbuilding, and glide through the dazzled ranks of the village children.\r\nShe generally came at the hour when Mr. Rivers was engaged in giving\r\nhis daily catechising lesson. Keenly, I fear, did the eye of the\r\nvisitress pierce the young pastor\xe2\x80\x99s heart. A sort of instinct seemed to\r\nwarn him of her entrance, even when he did not see it; and when he was\r\nlooking quite away from the door, if she appeared at it, his cheek\r\nwould glow, and his marble-seeming features, though they refused to\r\nrelax, changed indescribably, and in their very quiescence became\r\nexpressive of a repressed fervour, stronger than working muscle or\r\ndarting glance could indicate.\r\n\r\nOf course, she knew her power: indeed, he did not, because he could\r\nnot, conceal it from her. In spite of his Christian stoicism, when she\r\nwent up and addressed him, and smiled gaily, encouragingly, even fondly\r\nin his face, his hand would tremble and his eye burn. He seemed to say,\r\nwith his sad and resolute look, if he did not say it with his lips, \xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nlove you, and I know you prefer me. It is not despair of success that\r\nkeeps me dumb. If I offered my heart, I believe you would accept it.\r\nBut that heart is already laid on a sacred altar: the fire is arranged\r\nround it. It will soon be no more than a sacrifice consumed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd then she would pout like a disappointed child; a pensive cloud\r\nwould soften her radiant vivacity; she would withdraw her hand hastily\r\nfrom his, and turn in transient petulance from his aspect, at once so\r\nheroic and so martyr-like. St. John, no doubt, would have given the\r\nworld to follow, recall, retain her, when she thus left him; but he\r\nwould not give one chance of heaven, nor relinquish, for the elysium of\r\nher love, one hope of the true, eternal Paradise. Besides, he could not\r\nbind all that he had in his nature\xe2\x80\x94the rover, the aspirant, the poet,\r\nthe priest\xe2\x80\x94in the limits of a single passion. He could not\xe2\x80\x94he would\r\nnot\xe2\x80\x94renounce his wild field of mission warfare for the parlours and the\r\npeace of Vale Hall. I learnt so much from himself in an inroad I once,\r\ndespite his reserve, had the daring to make on his confidence.\r\n\r\nMiss Oliver already honoured me with frequent visits to my cottage. I\r\nhad learnt her whole character, which was without mystery or disguise:\r\nshe was coquettish but not heartless; exacting, but not worthlessly\r\nselfish. She had been indulged from her birth, but was not absolutely\r\nspoilt. She was hasty, but good-humoured; vain (she could not help it,\r\nwhen every glance in the glass showed her such a flush of loveliness),\r\nbut not affected; liberal-handed; innocent of the pride of wealth;\r\ningenuous; sufficiently intelligent; gay, lively, and unthinking: she\r\nwas very charming, in short, even to a cool observer of her own sex\r\nlike me; but she was not profoundly interesting or thoroughly\r\nimpressive. A very different sort of mind was hers from that, for\r\ninstance, of the sisters of St. John. Still, I liked her almost as I\r\nliked my pupil Ad\xc3\xa8le; except that, for a child whom we have watched\r\nover and taught, a closer affection is engendered than we can give an\r\nequally attractive adult acquaintance.\r\n\r\nShe had taken an amiable caprice to me. She said I was like Mr. Rivers,\r\nonly, certainly, she allowed, \xe2\x80\x9cnot one-tenth so handsome, though I was\r\na nice neat little soul enough, but he was an angel.\xe2\x80\x9d I was, however,\r\ngood, clever, composed, and firm, like him. I was a _lusus natur\xc3\xa6_, she\r\naffirmed, as a village schoolmistress: she was sure my previous\r\nhistory, if known, would make a delightful romance.\r\n\r\nOne evening, while, with her usual child-like activity, and thoughtless\r\nyet not offensive inquisitiveness, she was rummaging the cupboard and\r\nthe table-drawer of my little kitchen, she discovered first two French\r\nbooks, a volume of Schiller, a German grammar and dictionary, and then\r\nmy drawing-materials and some sketches, including a pencil-head of a\r\npretty little cherub-like girl, one of my scholars, and sundry views\r\nfrom nature, taken in the Vale of Morton and on the surrounding moors.\r\nShe was first transfixed with surprise, and then electrified with\r\ndelight.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHad I done these pictures? Did I know French and German? What a\r\nlove\xe2\x80\x94what a miracle I was! I drew better than her master in the first\r\nschool in S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. Would I sketch a portrait of her, to show to papa?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith pleasure,\xe2\x80\x9d I replied; and I felt a thrill of artist-delight at\r\nthe idea of copying from so perfect and radiant a model. She had then\r\non a dark-blue silk dress; her arms and her neck were bare; her only\r\nornament was her chestnut tresses, which waved over her shoulders with\r\nall the wild grace of natural curls. I took a sheet of fine card-board,\r\nand drew a careful outline. I promised myself the pleasure of colouring\r\nit; and, as it was getting late then, I told her she must come and sit\r\nanother day.\r\n\r\nShe made such a report of me to her father, that Mr. Oliver himself\r\naccompanied her next evening\xe2\x80\x94a tall, massive-featured, middle-aged, and\r\ngrey-headed man, at whose side his lovely daughter looked like a bright\r\nflower near a hoary turret. He appeared a taciturn, and perhaps a proud\r\npersonage; but he was very kind to me. The sketch of Rosamond\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nportrait pleased him highly: he said I must make a finished picture of\r\nit. He insisted, too, on my coming the next day to spend the evening at\r\nVale Hall.\r\n\r\nI went. I found it a large, handsome residence, showing abundant\r\nevidences of wealth in the proprietor. Rosamond was full of glee and\r\npleasure all the time I stayed. Her father was affable; and when he\r\nentered into conversation with me after tea, he expressed in strong\r\nterms his approbation of what I had done in Morton school, and said he\r\nonly feared, from what he saw and heard, I was too good for the place,\r\nand would soon quit it for one more suitable.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed,\xe2\x80\x9d cried Rosamond, \xe2\x80\x9cshe is clever enough to be a governess in a\r\nhigh family, papa.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI thought I would far rather be where I am than in any high family in\r\nthe land. Mr. Oliver spoke of Mr. Rivers\xe2\x80\x94of the Rivers family\xe2\x80\x94with\r\ngreat respect. He said it was a very old name in that neighbourhood;\r\nthat the ancestors of the house were wealthy; that all Morton had once\r\nbelonged to them; that even now he considered the representative of\r\nthat house might, if he liked, make an alliance with the best. He\r\naccounted it a pity that so fine and talented a young man should have\r\nformed the design of going out as a missionary; it was quite throwing a\r\nvaluable life away. It appeared, then, that her father would throw no\r\nobstacle in the way of Rosamond\xe2\x80\x99s union with St. John. Mr. Oliver\r\nevidently regarded the young clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s good birth, old name, and\r\nsacred profession as sufficient compensation for the want of fortune.\r\n\r\nIt was the 5th of November, and a holiday. My little servant, after\r\nhelping me to clean my house, was gone, well satisfied with the fee of\r\na penny for her aid. All about me was spotless and bright\xe2\x80\x94scoured\r\nfloor, polished grate, and well-rubbed chairs. I had also made myself\r\nneat, and had now the afternoon before me to spend as I would.\r\n\r\nThe translation of a few pages of German occupied an hour; then I got\r\nmy palette and pencils, and fell to the more soothing, because easier\r\noccupation, of completing Rosamond Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s miniature. The head was\r\nfinished already: there was but the background to tint and the drapery\r\nto shade off; a touch of carmine, too, to add to the ripe lips\xe2\x80\x94a soft\r\ncurl here and there to the tresses\xe2\x80\x94a deeper tinge to the shadow of the\r\nlash under the azured eyelid. I was absorbed in the execution of these\r\nnice details, when, after one rapid tap, my door unclosed, admitting\r\nSt. John Rivers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am come to see how you are spending your holiday,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cNot, I\r\nhope, in thought? No, that is well: while you draw you will not feel\r\nlonely. You see, I mistrust you still, though you have borne up\r\nwonderfully so far. I have brought you a book for evening solace,\xe2\x80\x9d and\r\nhe laid on the table a new publication\xe2\x80\x94a poem: one of those genuine\r\nproductions so often vouchsafed to the fortunate public of those\r\ndays\xe2\x80\x94the golden age of modern literature. Alas! the readers of our era\r\nare less favoured. But courage! I will not pause either to accuse or\r\nrepine. I know poetry is not dead, nor genius lost; nor has Mammon\r\ngained power over either, to bind or slay: they will both assert their\r\nexistence, their presence, their liberty and strength again one day.\r\nPowerful angels, safe in heaven! they smile when sordid souls triumph,\r\nand feeble ones weep over their destruction. Poetry destroyed? Genius\r\nbanished? No! Mediocrity, no: do not let envy prompt you to the\r\nthought. No; they not only live, but reign and redeem: and without\r\ntheir divine influence spread everywhere, you would be in hell\xe2\x80\x94the hell\r\nof your own meanness.\r\n\r\nWhile I was eagerly glancing at the bright pages of \xe2\x80\x9cMarmion\xe2\x80\x9d (for\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMarmion\xe2\x80\x9d it was), St. John stooped to examine my drawing. His tall\r\nfigure sprang erect again with a start: he said nothing. I looked up at\r\nhim: he shunned my eye. I knew his thoughts well, and could read his\r\nheart plainly; at the moment I felt calmer and cooler than he: I had\r\nthen temporarily the advantage of him, and I conceived an inclination\r\nto do him some good, if I could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith all his firmness and self-control,\xe2\x80\x9d thought I, \xe2\x80\x9che tasks himself\r\ntoo far: locks every feeling and pang within\xe2\x80\x94expresses, confesses,\r\nimparts nothing. I am sure it would benefit him to talk a little about\r\nthis sweet Rosamond, whom he thinks he ought not to marry: I will make\r\nhim talk.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI said first, \xe2\x80\x9cTake a chair, Mr. Rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d But he answered, as he always\r\ndid, that he could not stay. \xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d I responded, mentally, \xe2\x80\x9cstand\r\nif you like; but you shall not go just yet, I am determined: solitude\r\nis at least as bad for you as it is for me. I\xe2\x80\x99ll try if I cannot\r\ndiscover the secret spring of your confidence, and find an aperture in\r\nthat marble breast through which I can shed one drop of the balm of\r\nsympathy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs this portrait like?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked bluntly.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLike! Like whom? I did not observe it closely.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou did, Mr. Rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe almost started at my sudden and strange abruptness: he looked at me\r\nastonished. \xe2\x80\x9cOh, that is nothing yet,\xe2\x80\x9d I muttered within. \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t mean\r\nto be baffled by a little stiffness on your part; I\xe2\x80\x99m prepared to go to\r\nconsiderable lengths.\xe2\x80\x9d I continued, \xe2\x80\x9cYou observed it closely and\r\ndistinctly; but I have no objection to your looking at it again,\xe2\x80\x9d and I\r\nrose and placed it in his hand.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA well-executed picture,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cvery soft, clear colouring; very\r\ngraceful and correct drawing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes; I know all that. But what of the resemblance? Who is it\r\nlike?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nMastering some hesitation, he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cMiss Oliver, I presume.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course. And now, sir, to reward you for the accurate guess, I will\r\npromise to paint you a careful and faithful duplicate of this very\r\npicture, provided you admit that the gift would be acceptable to you. I\r\ndon\xe2\x80\x99t wish to throw away my time and trouble on an offering you would\r\ndeem worthless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe continued to gaze at the picture: the longer he looked, the firmer\r\nhe held it, the more he seemed to covet it. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is like!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured;\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cthe eye is well managed: the colour, light, expression, are perfect.\r\nIt smiles!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWould it comfort, or would it wound you to have a similar painting?\r\nTell me that. When you are at Madagascar, or at the Cape, or in India,\r\nwould it be a consolation to have that memento in your possession? or\r\nwould the sight of it bring recollections calculated to enervate and\r\ndistress?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe now furtively raised his eyes: he glanced at me, irresolute,\r\ndisturbed: he again surveyed the picture.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat I should like to have it is certain: whether it would be\r\njudicious or wise is another question.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSince I had ascertained that Rosamond really preferred him, and that\r\nher father was not likely to oppose the match, I\xe2\x80\x94less exalted in my\r\nviews than St. John\xe2\x80\x94had been strongly disposed in my own heart to\r\nadvocate their union. It seemed to me that, should he become the\r\npossessor of Mr. Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s large fortune, he might do as much good with\r\nit as if he went and laid his genius out to wither, and his strength to\r\nwaste, under a tropical sun. With this persuasion I now answered\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs far as I can see, it would be wiser and more judicious if you were\r\nto take to yourself the original at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBy this time he had sat down: he had laid the picture on the table\r\nbefore him, and with his brow supported on both hands, hung fondly over\r\nit. I discerned he was now neither angry nor shocked at my audacity. I\r\nsaw even that to be thus frankly addressed on a subject he had deemed\r\nunapproachable\xe2\x80\x94to hear it thus freely handled\xe2\x80\x94was beginning to be felt\r\nby him as a new pleasure\xe2\x80\x94an unhoped-for relief. Reserved people often\r\nreally need the frank discussion of their sentiments and griefs more\r\nthan the expansive. The sternest-seeming stoic is human after all; and\r\nto \xe2\x80\x9cburst\xe2\x80\x9d with boldness and good-will into \xe2\x80\x9cthe silent sea\xe2\x80\x9d of their\r\nsouls is often to confer on them the first of obligations.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe likes you, I am sure,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, as I stood behind his chair, \xe2\x80\x9cand\r\nher father respects you. Moreover, she is a sweet girl\xe2\x80\x94rather\r\nthoughtless; but you would have sufficient thought for both yourself\r\nand her. You ought to marry her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Does_ she like me?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly; better than she likes any one else. She talks of you\r\ncontinually: there is no subject she enjoys so much or touches upon so\r\noften.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is very pleasant to hear this,\xe2\x80\x9d he said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cvery: go on for another\r\nquarter of an hour.\xe2\x80\x9d And he actually took out his watch and laid it\r\nupon the table to measure the time.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut where is the use of going on,\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, \xe2\x80\x9cwhen you are probably\r\npreparing some iron blow of contradiction, or forging a fresh chain to\r\nfetter your heart?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDon\xe2\x80\x99t imagine such hard things. Fancy me yielding and melting, as I am\r\ndoing: human love rising like a freshly opened fountain in my mind and\r\noverflowing with sweet inundation all the field I have so carefully and\r\nwith such labour prepared\xe2\x80\x94so assiduously sown with the seeds of good\r\nintentions, of self-denying plans. And now it is deluged with a\r\nnectarous flood\xe2\x80\x94the young germs swamped\xe2\x80\x94delicious poison cankering\r\nthem: now I see myself stretched on an ottoman in the drawing-room at\r\nVale Hall at my bride Rosamond Oliver\xe2\x80\x99s feet: she is talking to me with\r\nher sweet voice\xe2\x80\x94gazing down on me with those eyes your skilful hand has\r\ncopied so well\xe2\x80\x94smiling at me with these coral lips. She is mine\xe2\x80\x94I am\r\nhers\xe2\x80\x94this present life and passing world suffice to me. Hush! say\r\nnothing\xe2\x80\x94my heart is full of delight\xe2\x80\x94my senses are entranced\xe2\x80\x94let the\r\ntime I marked pass in peace.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI humoured him: the watch ticked on: he breathed fast and low: I stood\r\nsilent. Amidst this hush the quartet sped; he replaced the watch, laid\r\nthe picture down, rose, and stood on the hearth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat little space was given to delirium and delusion.\r\nI rested my temples on the breast of temptation, and put my neck\r\nvoluntarily under her yoke of flowers; I tasted her cup. The pillow was\r\nburning: there is an asp in the garland: the wine has a bitter taste:\r\nher promises are hollow\xe2\x80\x94her offers false: I see and know all this.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI gazed at him in wonder.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is strange,\xe2\x80\x9d pursued he, \xe2\x80\x9cthat while I love Rosamond Oliver so\r\nwildly\xe2\x80\x94with all the intensity, indeed, of a first passion, the object\r\nof which is exquisitely beautiful, graceful, fascinating\xe2\x80\x94I experience\r\nat the same time a calm, unwarped consciousness that she would not make\r\nme a good wife; that she is not the partner suited to me; that I should\r\ndiscover this within a year after marriage; and that to twelve months\xe2\x80\x99\r\nrapture would succeed a lifetime of regret. This I know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStrange indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d I could not help ejaculating.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhile something in me,\xe2\x80\x9d he went on, \xe2\x80\x9cis acutely sensible to her\r\ncharms, something else is as deeply impressed with her defects: they\r\nare such that she could sympathise in nothing I aspired to\xe2\x80\x94co-operate\r\nin nothing I undertook. Rosamond a sufferer, a labourer, a female\r\napostle? Rosamond a missionary\xe2\x80\x99s wife? No!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you need not be a missionary. You might relinquish that scheme.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRelinquish! What! my vocation? My great work? My foundation laid on\r\nearth for a mansion in heaven? My hopes of being numbered in the band\r\nwho have merged all ambitions in the glorious one of bettering their\r\nrace\xe2\x80\x94of carrying knowledge into the realms of ignorance\xe2\x80\x94of substituting\r\npeace for war\xe2\x80\x94freedom for bondage\xe2\x80\x94religion for superstition\xe2\x80\x94the hope of\r\nheaven for the fear of hell? Must I relinquish that? It is dearer than\r\nthe blood in my veins. It is what I have to look forward to, and to\r\nlive for.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAfter a considerable pause, I said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Miss Oliver? Are her\r\ndisappointment and sorrow of no interest to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Oliver is ever surrounded by suitors and flatterers: in less than\r\na month, my image will be effaced from her heart. She will forget me;\r\nand will marry, probably, some one who will make her far happier than I\r\nshould do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak coolly enough; but you suffer in the conflict. You are\r\nwasting away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. If I get a little thin, it is with anxiety about my prospects, yet\r\nunsettled\xe2\x80\x94my departure, continually procrastinated. Only this morning,\r\nI received intelligence that the successor, whose arrival I have been\r\nso long expecting, cannot be ready to replace me for three months to\r\ncome yet; and perhaps the three months may extend to six.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou tremble and become flushed whenever Miss Oliver enters the\r\nschoolroom.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain the surprised expression crossed his face. He had not imagined\r\nthat a woman would dare to speak so to a man. For me, I felt at home in\r\nthis sort of discourse. I could never rest in communication with\r\nstrong, discreet, and refined minds, whether male or female, till I had\r\npassed the outworks of conventional reserve, and crossed the threshold\r\nof confidence, and won a place by their heart\xe2\x80\x99s very hearthstone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou _are_ original,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cand not timid. There is something brave\r\nin your spirit, as well as penetrating in your eye; but allow me to\r\nassure you that you partially misinterpret my emotions. You think them\r\nmore profound and potent than they are. You give me a larger allowance\r\nof sympathy than I have a just claim to. When I colour, and when I\r\nshake before Miss Oliver, I do not pity myself. I scorn the weakness. I\r\nknow it is ignoble: a mere fever of the flesh: not, I declare, the\r\nconvulsion of the soul. _That_ is just as fixed as a rock, firm set in\r\nthe depths of a restless sea. Know me to be what I am\xe2\x80\x94a cold hard man.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI smiled incredulously.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have taken my confidence by storm,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued, \xe2\x80\x9cand now it is\r\nmuch at your service. I am simply, in my original state\xe2\x80\x94stripped of\r\nthat blood-bleached robe with which Christianity covers human\r\ndeformity\xe2\x80\x94a cold, hard, ambitious man. Natural affection only, of all\r\nthe sentiments, has permanent power over me. Reason, and not feeling,\r\nis my guide; my ambition is unlimited: my desire to rise higher, to do\r\nmore than others, insatiable. I honour endurance, perseverance,\r\nindustry, talent; because these are the means by which men achieve\r\ngreat ends and mount to lofty eminence. I watch your career with\r\ninterest, because I consider you a specimen of a diligent, orderly,\r\nenergetic woman: not because I deeply compassionate what you have gone\r\nthrough, or what you still suffer.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would describe yourself as a mere pagan philosopher,\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. There is this difference between me and deistic philosophers: I\r\nbelieve; and I believe the Gospel. You missed your epithet. I am not a\r\npagan, but a Christian philosopher\xe2\x80\x94a follower of the sect of Jesus. As\r\nHis disciple I adopt His pure, His merciful, His benignant doctrines. I\r\nadvocate them: I am sworn to spread them. Won in youth to religion, she\r\nhas cultivated my original qualities thus:\xe2\x80\x94From the minute germ,\r\nnatural affection, she has developed the overshadowing tree,\r\nphilanthropy. From the wild stringy root of human uprightness, she has\r\nreared a due sense of the Divine justice. Of the ambition to win power\r\nand renown for my wretched self, she has formed the ambition to spread\r\nmy Master\xe2\x80\x99s kingdom; to achieve victories for the standard of the\r\ncross. So much has religion done for me; turning the original materials\r\nto the best account; pruning and training nature. But she could not\r\neradicate nature: nor will it be eradicated \xe2\x80\x98till this mortal shall put\r\non immortality.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHaving said this, he took his hat, which lay on the table beside my\r\npalette. Once more he looked at the portrait.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe _is_ lovely,\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is well named the Rose of the\r\nWorld, indeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd may I not paint one like it for you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Cui bono_? No.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe drew over the picture the sheet of thin paper on which I was\r\naccustomed to rest my hand in painting, to prevent the cardboard from\r\nbeing sullied. What he suddenly saw on this blank paper, it was\r\nimpossible for me to tell; but something had caught his eye. He took it\r\nup with a snatch; he looked at the edge; then shot a glance at me,\r\ninexpressibly peculiar, and quite incomprehensible: a glance that\r\nseemed to take and make note of every point in my shape, face, and\r\ndress; for it traversed all, quick, keen as lightning. His lips parted,\r\nas if to speak: but he checked the coming sentence, whatever it was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNothing in the world,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply; and, replacing the paper, I saw\r\nhim dexterously tear a narrow slip from the margin. It disappeared in\r\nhis glove; and, with one hasty nod and \xe2\x80\x9cgood-afternoon,\xe2\x80\x9d he vanished.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell!\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed, using an expression of the district, \xe2\x80\x9cthat caps\r\nthe globe, however!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI, in my turn, scrutinised the paper; but saw nothing on it save a few\r\ndingy stains of paint where I had tried the tint in my pencil. I\r\npondered the mystery a minute or two; but finding it insolvable, and\r\nbeing certain it could not be of much moment, I dismissed, and soon\r\nforgot it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIII\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen Mr. St. John went, it was beginning to snow; the whirling storm\r\ncontinued all night. The next day a keen wind brought fresh and\r\nblinding falls; by twilight the valley was drifted up and almost\r\nimpassable. I had closed my shutter, laid a mat to the door to prevent\r\nthe snow from blowing in under it, trimmed my fire, and after sitting\r\nnearly an hour on the hearth listening to the muffled fury of the\r\ntempest, I lit a candle, took down \xe2\x80\x9cMarmion,\xe2\x80\x9d and beginning\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDay set on Norham\xe2\x80\x99s castled steep,\r\nAnd Tweed\xe2\x80\x99s fair river broad and deep,\r\n    And Cheviot\xe2\x80\x99s mountains lone;\r\nThe massive towers, the donjon keep,\r\nThe flanking walls that round them sweep,\r\n    In yellow lustre shone\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\r\nI soon forgot storm in music.\r\n\r\nI heard a noise: the wind, I thought, shook the door. No; it was St.\r\nJohn Rivers, who, lifting the latch, came in out of the frozen\r\nhurricane\xe2\x80\x94the howling darkness\xe2\x80\x94and stood before me: the cloak that\r\ncovered his tall figure all white as a glacier. I was almost in\r\nconsternation, so little had I expected any guest from the blocked-up\r\nvale that night.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAny ill news?\xe2\x80\x9d I demanded. \xe2\x80\x9cHas anything happened?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. How very easily alarmed you are!\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, removing his cloak\r\nand hanging it up against the door, towards which he again coolly\r\npushed the mat which his entrance had deranged. He stamped the snow\r\nfrom his boots.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI shall sully the purity of your floor,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cbut you must excuse\r\nme for once.\xe2\x80\x9d Then he approached the fire. \xe2\x80\x9cI have had hard work to get\r\nhere, I assure you,\xe2\x80\x9d he observed, as he warmed his hands over the\r\nflame. \xe2\x80\x9cOne drift took me up to the waist; happily the snow is quite\r\nsoft yet.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut why are you come?\xe2\x80\x9d I could not forbear saying.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRather an inhospitable question to put to a visitor; but since you ask\r\nit, I answer simply to have a little talk with you; I got tired of my\r\nmute books and empty rooms. Besides, since yesterday I have experienced\r\nthe excitement of a person to whom a tale has been half-told, and who\r\nis impatient to hear the sequel.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe sat down. I recalled his singular conduct of yesterday, and really I\r\nbegan to fear his wits were touched. If he were insane, however, his\r\nwas a very cool and collected insanity: I had never seen that\r\nhandsome-featured face of his look more like chiselled marble than it\r\ndid just now, as he put aside his snow-wet hair from his forehead and\r\nlet the firelight shine free on his pale brow and cheek as pale, where\r\nit grieved me to discover the hollow trace of care or sorrow now so\r\nplainly graved. I waited, expecting he would say something I could at\r\nleast comprehend; but his hand was now at his chin, his finger on his\r\nlip: he was thinking. It struck me that his hand looked wasted like his\r\nface. A perhaps uncalled-for gush of pity came over my heart: I was\r\nmoved to say\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI wish Diana or Mary would come and live with you: it is too bad that\r\nyou should be quite alone; and you are recklessly rash about your own\r\nhealth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all,\xe2\x80\x9d said he: \xe2\x80\x9cI care for myself when necessary. I am well\r\nnow. What do you see amiss in me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThis was said with a careless, abstracted indifference, which showed\r\nthat my solicitude was, at least in his opinion, wholly superfluous. I\r\nwas silenced.\r\n\r\nHe still slowly moved his finger over his upper lip, and still his eye\r\ndwelt dreamily on the glowing grate; thinking it urgent to say\r\nsomething, I asked him presently if he felt any cold draught from the\r\ndoor, which was behind him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, no!\xe2\x80\x9d he responded shortly and somewhat testily.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d I reflected, \xe2\x80\x9cif you won\xe2\x80\x99t talk, you may be still; I\xe2\x80\x99ll let you\r\nalone now, and return to my book.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSo I snuffed the candle and resumed the perusal of \xe2\x80\x9cMarmion.\xe2\x80\x9d He soon\r\nstirred; my eye was instantly drawn to his movements; he only took out\r\na morocco pocket-book, thence produced a letter, which he read in\r\nsilence, folded it, put it back, relapsed into meditation. It was vain\r\nto try to read with such an inscrutable fixture before me; nor could I,\r\nin impatience, consent to be dumb; he might rebuff me if he liked, but\r\ntalk I would.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you heard from Diana and Mary lately?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot since the letter I showed you a week ago.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere has not been any change made about your own arrangements? You\r\nwill not be summoned to leave England sooner than you expected?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI fear not, indeed: such chance is too good to befall me.\xe2\x80\x9d Baffled so\r\nfar, I changed my ground. I bethought myself to talk about the school\r\nand my scholars.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary Garrett\xe2\x80\x99s mother is better, and Mary came back to the school this\r\nmorning, and I shall have four new girls next week from the Foundry\r\nClose\xe2\x80\x94they would have come to-day but for the snow.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndeed!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Oliver pays for two.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoes he?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe means to give the whole school a treat at Christmas.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWas it your suggestion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhose, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis daughter\xe2\x80\x99s, I think.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is like her: she is so good-natured.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain came the blank of a pause: the clock struck eight strokes. It\r\naroused him; he uncrossed his legs, sat erect, turned to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave your book a moment, and come a little nearer the fire,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nWondering, and of my wonder finding no end, I complied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHalf-an-hour ago,\xe2\x80\x9d he pursued, \xe2\x80\x9cI spoke of my impatience to hear the\r\nsequel of a tale: on reflection, I find the matter will be better\r\nmanaged by my assuming the narrator\xe2\x80\x99s part, and converting you into a\r\nlistener. Before commencing, it is but fair to warn you that the story\r\nwill sound somewhat hackneyed in your ears; but stale details often\r\nregain a degree of freshness when they pass through new lips. For the\r\nrest, whether trite or novel, it is short.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty years ago, a poor curate\xe2\x80\x94never mind his name at this\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x94fell in love with a rich man\xe2\x80\x99s daughter; she fell in love with\r\nhim, and married him, against the advice of all her friends, who\r\nconsequently disowned her immediately after the wedding. Before two\r\nyears passed, the rash pair were both dead, and laid quietly side by\r\nside under one slab. (I have seen their grave; it formed part of the\r\npavement of a huge churchyard surrounding the grim, soot-black old\r\ncathedral of an overgrown manufacturing town in \xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94shire.) They left a\r\ndaughter, which, at its very birth, Charity received in her lap\xe2\x80\x94cold as\r\nthat of the snow-drift I almost stuck fast in to-night. Charity carried\r\nthe friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations; it\r\nwas reared by an aunt-in-law, called (I come to names now) Mrs. Reed of\r\nGateshead. You start\xe2\x80\x94did you hear a noise? I daresay it is only a rat\r\nscrambling along the rafters of the adjoining schoolroom: it was a barn\r\nbefore I had it repaired and altered, and barns are generally haunted\r\nby rats.\xe2\x80\x94To proceed. Mrs. Reed kept the orphan ten years: whether it\r\nwas happy or not with her, I cannot say, never having been told; but at\r\nthe end of that time she transferred it to a place you know\xe2\x80\x94being no\r\nother than Lowood School, where you so long resided yourself. It seems\r\nher career there was very honourable: from a pupil, she became a\r\nteacher, like yourself\xe2\x80\x94really it strikes me there are parallel points\r\nin her history and yours\xe2\x80\x94she left it to be a governess: there, again,\r\nyour fates were analogous; she undertook the education of the ward of a\r\ncertain Mr. Rochester.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rivers!\xe2\x80\x9d I interrupted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI can guess your feelings,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cbut restrain them for a while: I\r\nhave nearly finished; hear me to the end. Of Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s character\r\nI know nothing, but the one fact that he professed to offer honourable\r\nmarriage to this young girl, and that at the very altar she discovered\r\nhe had a wife yet alive, though a lunatic. What his subsequent conduct\r\nand proposals were is a matter of pure conjecture; but when an event\r\ntranspired which rendered inquiry after the governess necessary, it was\r\ndiscovered she was gone\xe2\x80\x94no one could tell when, where, or how. She had\r\nleft Thornfield Hall in the night; every research after her course had\r\nbeen vain: the country had been scoured far and wide; no vestige of\r\ninformation could be gathered respecting her. Yet that she should be\r\nfound is become a matter of serious urgency: advertisements have been\r\nput in all the papers; I myself have received a letter from one Mr.\r\nBriggs, a solicitor, communicating the details I have just imparted. Is\r\nit not an odd tale?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust tell me this,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cand since you know so much, you surely\r\n_can_ tell it me\xe2\x80\x94what of Mr. Rochester? How and where is he? What is he\r\ndoing? Is he well?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am ignorant of all concerning Mr. Rochester: the letter never\r\nmentions him but to narrate the fraudulent and illegal attempt I have\r\nadverted to. You should rather ask the name of the governess\xe2\x80\x94the nature\r\nof the event which requires her appearance.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid no one go to Thornfield Hall, then? Did no one see Mr. Rochester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI suppose not.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut they wrote to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did he say? Who has his letters?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Briggs intimates that the answer to his application was not from\r\nMr. Rochester, but from a lady: it is signed \xe2\x80\x98Alice Fairfax.\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI felt cold and dismayed: my worst fears then were probably true: he\r\nhad in all probability left England and rushed in reckless desperation\r\nto some former haunt on the Continent. And what opiate for his severe\r\nsufferings\xe2\x80\x94what object for his strong passions\xe2\x80\x94had he sought there? I\r\ndared not answer the question. Oh, my poor master\xe2\x80\x94once almost my\r\nhusband\xe2\x80\x94whom I had often called \xe2\x80\x9cmy dear Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe must have been a bad man,\xe2\x80\x9d observed Mr. Rivers.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou don\xe2\x80\x99t know him\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t pronounce an opinion upon him,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, with\r\nwarmth.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery well,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered quietly: \xe2\x80\x9cand indeed my head is otherwise\r\noccupied than with him: I have my tale to finish. Since you won\xe2\x80\x99t ask\r\nthe governess\xe2\x80\x99s name, I must tell it of my own accord. Stay! I have it\r\nhere\xe2\x80\x94it is always more satisfactory to see important points written\r\ndown, fairly committed to black and white.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAnd the pocket-book was again deliberately produced, opened, sought\r\nthrough; from one of its compartments was extracted a shabby slip of\r\npaper, hastily torn off: I recognised in its texture and its stains of\r\nultra-marine, and lake, and vermillion, the ravished margin of the\r\nportrait-cover. He got up, held it close to my eyes: and I read, traced\r\nin Indian ink, in my own handwriting, the words \xe2\x80\x9cJANE EYRE\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94the work\r\ndoubtless of some moment of abstraction.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBriggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre:\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cthe advertisements\r\ndemanded a Jane Eyre: I knew a Jane Elliott.\xe2\x80\x94I confess I had my\r\nsuspicions, but it was only yesterday afternoon they were at once\r\nresolved into certainty. You own the name and renounce the _alias_?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94yes; but where is Mr. Briggs? He perhaps knows more of Mr.\r\nRochester than you do.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBriggs is in London. I should doubt his knowing anything at all about\r\nMr. Rochester; it is not in Mr. Rochester he is interested. Meantime,\r\nyou forget essential points in pursuing trifles: you do not inquire why\r\nMr. Briggs sought after you\xe2\x80\x94what he wanted with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, what did he want?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMerely to tell you that your uncle, Mr. Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that\r\nhe has left you all his property, and that you are now rich\xe2\x80\x94merely\r\nthat\xe2\x80\x94nothing more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI!\xe2\x80\x94rich?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, you, rich\xe2\x80\x94quite an heiress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSilence succeeded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou must prove your identity of course,\xe2\x80\x9d resumed St. John presently:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9ca step which will offer no difficulties; you can then enter on\r\nimmediate possession. Your fortune is vested in the English funds;\r\nBriggs has the will and the necessary documents.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere was a new card turned up! It is a fine thing, reader, to be lifted\r\nin a moment from indigence to wealth\xe2\x80\x94a very fine thing; but not a\r\nmatter one can comprehend, or consequently enjoy, all at once. And then\r\nthere are other chances in life far more thrilling and rapture-giving:\r\n_this_ is solid, an affair of the actual world, nothing ideal about it:\r\nall its associations are solid and sober, and its manifestations are\r\nthe same. One does not jump, and spring, and shout hurrah! at hearing\r\none has got a fortune; one begins to consider responsibilities, and to\r\nponder business; on a base of steady satisfaction rise certain grave\r\ncares, and we contain ourselves, and brood over our bliss with a solemn\r\nbrow.\r\n\r\nBesides, the words Legacy, Bequest, go side by side with the words,\r\nDeath, Funeral. My uncle I had heard was dead\xe2\x80\x94my only relative; ever\r\nsince being made aware of his existence, I had cherished the hope of\r\none day seeing him: now, I never should. And then this money came only\r\nto me: not to me and a rejoicing family, but to my isolated self. It\r\nwas a grand boon doubtless; and independence would be glorious\xe2\x80\x94yes, I\r\nfelt that\xe2\x80\x94_that_ thought swelled my heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou unbend your forehead at last,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rivers. \xe2\x80\x9cI thought Medusa\r\nhad looked at you, and that you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you\r\nwill ask how much you are worth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow much am I worth?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, a trifle! Nothing of course to speak of\xe2\x80\x94twenty thousand pounds, I\r\nthink they say\xe2\x80\x94but what is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTwenty thousand pounds?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHere was a new stunner\xe2\x80\x94I had been calculating on four or five thousand.\r\nThis news actually took my breath for a moment: Mr. St. John, whom I\r\nhad never heard laugh before, laughed now.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cif you had committed a murder, and I had told you\r\nyour crime was discovered, you could scarcely look more aghast.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a large sum\xe2\x80\x94don\xe2\x80\x99t you think there is a mistake?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo mistake at all.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you have read the figures wrong\xe2\x80\x94it may be two thousand!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is written in letters, not figures,\xe2\x80\x94twenty thousand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI again felt rather like an individual of but average gastronomical\r\npowers sitting down to feast alone at a table spread with provisions\r\nfor a hundred. Mr. Rivers rose now and put his cloak on.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf it were not such a very wild night,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI would send Hannah\r\ndown to keep you company: you look too desperately miserable to be left\r\nalone. But Hannah, poor woman! could not stride the drifts so well as\r\nI: her legs are not quite so long: so I must e\xe2\x80\x99en leave you to your\r\nsorrows. Good-night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe was lifting the latch: a sudden thought occurred to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cStop one minute!\xe2\x80\x9d I cried.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt puzzles me to know why Mr. Briggs wrote to you about me; or how he\r\nknew you, or could fancy that you, living in such an out-of-the-way\r\nplace, had the power to aid in my discovery.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! I am a clergyman,\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cand the clergy are often appealed to\r\nabout odd matters.\xe2\x80\x9d Again the latch rattled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; that does not satisfy me!\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed: and indeed there was\r\nsomething in the hasty and unexplanatory reply which, instead of\r\nallaying, piqued my curiosity more than ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a very strange piece of business,\xe2\x80\x9d I added; \xe2\x80\x9cI must know more\r\nabout it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnother time.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo; to-night!\xe2\x80\x94to-night!\xe2\x80\x9d and as he turned from the door, I placed\r\nmyself between it and him. He looked rather embarrassed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou certainly shall not go till you have told me all,\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather not just now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall!\xe2\x80\x94you must!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI would rather Diana or Mary informed you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nOf course these objections wrought my eagerness to a climax: gratified\r\nit must be, and that without delay; and I told him so.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut I apprised you that I was a hard man,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cdifficult to\r\npersuade.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd I am a hard woman,\xe2\x80\x94impossible to put off.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd I am a hard woman,\xe2\x80\x94impossible to put off\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd then,\xe2\x80\x9d he pursued, \xe2\x80\x9cI am cold: no fervour infects me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhereas I am hot, and fire dissolves ice. The blaze there has thawed\r\nall the snow from your cloak; by the same token, it has streamed on to\r\nmy floor, and made it like a trampled street. As you hope ever to be\r\nforgiven, Mr. Rivers, the high crime and misdemeanour of spoiling a\r\nsanded kitchen, tell me what I wish to know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, then,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cI yield; if not to your earnestness, to your\r\nperseverance: as stone is worn by continual dropping. Besides, you must\r\nknow some day,\xe2\x80\x94as well now as later. Your name is Jane Eyre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course: that was all settled before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are not, perhaps, aware that I am your namesake?\xe2\x80\x94that I was\r\nchristened St. John Eyre Rivers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, indeed! I remember now seeing the letter E. comprised in your\r\ninitials written in books you have at different times lent me; but I\r\nnever asked for what name it stood. But what then? Surely\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI stopped: I could not trust myself to entertain, much less to express,\r\nthe thought that rushed upon me\xe2\x80\x94that embodied itself,\xe2\x80\x94that, in a\r\nsecond, stood out a strong, solid probability. Circumstances knit\r\nthemselves, fitted themselves, shot into order: the chain that had been\r\nlying hitherto a formless lump of links was drawn out straight,\xe2\x80\x94every\r\nring was perfect, the connection complete. I knew, by instinct, how the\r\nmatter stood, before St. John had said another word; but I cannot\r\nexpect the reader to have the same intuitive perception, so I must\r\nrepeat his explanation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy mother\xe2\x80\x99s name was Eyre; she had two brothers; one a clergyman, who\r\nmarried Miss Jane Reed, of Gateshead; the other, John Eyre, Esq.,\r\nmerchant, late of Funchal, Madeira. Mr. Briggs, being Mr. Eyre\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsolicitor, wrote to us last August to inform us of our uncle\xe2\x80\x99s death,\r\nand to say that he had left his property to his brother the clergyman\xe2\x80\x99s\r\norphan daughter, overlooking us, in consequence of a quarrel, never\r\nforgiven, between him and my father. He wrote again a few weeks since,\r\nto intimate that the heiress was lost, and asking if we knew anything\r\nof her. A name casually written on a slip of paper has enabled me to\r\nfind her out. You know the rest.\xe2\x80\x9d Again he was going, but I set my back\r\nagainst the door.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo let me speak,\xe2\x80\x9d I said; \xe2\x80\x9clet me have one moment to draw breath and\r\nreflect.\xe2\x80\x9d I paused\xe2\x80\x94he stood before me, hat in hand, looking composed\r\nenough. I resumed\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour mother was my father\xe2\x80\x99s sister?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy aunt, consequently?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe bowed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy uncle John was your uncle John? It seemed I had found a brother: one I could be proud\r\nof,\xe2\x80\x94one I could love; and two sisters, whose qualities were such, that,\r\nwhen I knew them but as mere strangers, they had inspired me with\r\ngenuine affection and admiration. The two girls, on whom, kneeling down\r\non the wet ground, and looking through the low, latticed window of Moor\r\nHouse kitchen, I had gazed with so bitter a mixture of interest and\r\ndespair, were my near kinswomen; and the young and stately gentleman\r\nwho had found me almost dying at his threshold was my blood relation.\r\nGlorious discovery to a lonely wretch! This was wealth indeed!\xe2\x80\x94wealth\r\nto the heart!\xe2\x80\x94a mine of pure, genial affections. This was a blessing,\r\nbright, vivid, and exhilarating;\xe2\x80\x94not like the ponderous gift of gold:\r\nrich and welcome enough in its way, but sobering from its weight. I now\r\nclapped my hands in sudden joy\xe2\x80\x94my pulse bounded, my veins thrilled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, I am glad!\xe2\x80\x94I am glad!\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed.\r\n\r\nSt. John smiled. \xe2\x80\x9cDid I not say you neglected essential points to\r\npursue trifles?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked. \xe2\x80\x9cYou were serious when I told you you had\r\ngot a fortune; and now, for a matter of no moment, you are excited.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat _can_ you mean? It may be of no moment to you; you have sisters\r\nand don\xe2\x80\x99t care for a cousin; but I had nobody; and now three\r\nrelations,\xe2\x80\x94or two, if you don\xe2\x80\x99t choose to be counted,\xe2\x80\x94are born into my\r\nworld full-grown. I say again, I am glad!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI walked fast through the room: I stopped, half suffocated with the\r\nthoughts that rose faster than I could receive, comprehend, settle\r\nthem:\xe2\x80\x94thoughts of what might, could, would, and should be, and that ere\r\nlong. I looked at the blank wall: it seemed a sky thick with ascending\r\nstars,\xe2\x80\x94every one lit me to a purpose or delight. Those who had saved my\r\nlife, whom, till this hour, I had loved barrenly, I could now benefit.\r\nThey were under a yoke,\xe2\x80\x94I could free them: they were scattered,\xe2\x80\x94I could\r\nreunite them: the independence, the affluence which was mine, might be\r\ntheirs too. Were we not four? Twenty thousand pounds shared equally\r\nwould be five thousand each, justice\xe2\x80\x94enough and to spare: justice would\r\nbe done,\xe2\x80\x94mutual happiness secured. Now the wealth did not weigh on me:\r\nnow it was not a mere bequest of coin,\xe2\x80\x94it was a legacy of life, hope,\r\nenjoyment.\r\n\r\nHow I looked while these ideas were taking my spirit by storm, I cannot\r\ntell; but I perceived soon that Mr. Rivers had placed a chair behind\r\nme, and was gently attempting to make me sit down on it. He also\r\nadvised me to be composed; I scorned the insinuation of helplessness\r\nand distraction, shook off his hand, and began to walk about again.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWrite to Diana and Mary to-morrow,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cand tell them to come\r\nhome directly. Diana said they would both consider themselves rich with\r\na thousand pounds, so with five thousand they will do very well.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell me where I can get you a glass of water,\xe2\x80\x9d said St. John; \xe2\x80\x9cyou\r\nmust really make an effort to tranquillise your feelings.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense! and what sort of an effect will the bequest have on you?\r\nWill it keep you in England, induce you to marry Miss Oliver, and\r\nsettle down like an ordinary mortal?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou wander: your head becomes confused. I have been too abrupt in\r\ncommunicating the news; it has excited you beyond your strength.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rivers! you quite put me out of patience: I am rational enough; it\r\nis you who misunderstand, or rather who affect to misunderstand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps, if you explained yourself a little more fully, I should\r\ncomprehend better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cExplain! What is there to explain? You cannot fail to see that twenty\r\nthousand pounds, the sum in question, divided equally between the\r\nnephew and three nieces of our uncle, will give five thousand to each?\r\nWhat I want is, that you should write to your sisters and tell them of\r\nthe fortune that has accrued to them.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo you, you mean.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have intimated my view of the case: I am incapable of taking any\r\nother. I am not brutally selfish, blindly unjust, or fiendishly\r\nungrateful. Besides, I am resolved I will have a home and connections.\r\nI like Moor House, and I will live at Moor House; I like Diana and\r\nMary, and I will attach myself for life to Diana and Mary. It would\r\nplease and benefit me to have five thousand pounds; it would torment\r\nand oppress me to have twenty thousand; which, moreover, could never be\r\nmine in justice, though it might in law. I abandon to you, then, what\r\nis absolutely superfluous to me. Let there be no opposition, and no\r\ndiscussion about it; let us agree amongst each other, and decide the\r\npoint at once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis is acting on first impulses; you must take days to consider such\r\na matter, ere your word can be regarded as valid.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! if all you doubt is my sincerity, I am easy: you see the justice\r\nof the case?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI _do_ see a certain justice; but it is contrary to all custom.\r\nBesides, the entire fortune is your right: my uncle gained it by his\r\nown efforts; he was free to leave it to whom he would: he left it to\r\nyou. After all, justice permits you to keep it: you may, with a clear\r\nconscience, consider it absolutely your own.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWith me,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9cit is fully as much a matter of feeling as of\r\nconscience: I must indulge my feelings; I so seldom have had an\r\nopportunity of doing so. I never had a home, I never had brothers\r\nor sisters; I must and will have them now: you are not reluctant to\r\nadmit me and own me, are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I will be your brother\xe2\x80\x94my sisters will be your sisters\xe2\x80\x94without\r\nstipulating for this sacrifice of your just rights.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBrother? Famous equality and fraternisation!\r\nClose union! Intimate attachment!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut, Jane, your aspirations after family ties and domestic happiness\r\nmay be realised otherwise than by the means you contemplate: you may\r\nmarry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNonsense, again! I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to marry, and never shall marry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is saying too much: such hazardous affirmations are a proof of\r\nthe excitement under which you labour.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is not saying too much: I know what I feel, and how averse are my\r\ninclinations to the bare thought of marriage. You too have principle and mind: your\r\ntastes and habits resemble Diana\xe2\x80\x99s and Mary\xe2\x80\x99s; your presence is always\r\nagreeable to me; in your conversation I have already for some time\r\nfound a salutary solace. I feel I can easily and naturally make room in\r\nmy heart for you, as my third and youngest sister.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you: that contents me for to-night. Now you had better go; for\r\nif you stay longer, you will perhaps irritate me afresh by some\r\nmistrustful scruple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd the school, Miss Eyre? It must now be shut up, I suppose?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo. I will retain my post of mistress till you get a substitute.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe smiled approbation: we shook hands, and he took leave.\r\n\r\nI need not narrate in detail the further struggles I had, and arguments\r\nI used, to get matters regarding the legacy settled as I wished. My\r\ntask was a very hard one; but, as I was absolutely resolved\xe2\x80\x94as my\r\ncousins saw at length that my mind was really and immutably fixed on\r\nmaking a just division of the property\xe2\x80\x94as they must in their own hearts\r\nhave felt the equity of the intention; and must, besides, have been\r\ninnately conscious that in my place they would have done precisely what\r\nI wished to do\xe2\x80\x94they yielded at length so far as to consent to put the\r\naffair to arbitration. The judges chosen were Mr. Oliver and an able\r\nlawyer: both coincided in my opinion: I carried my point. The\r\ninstruments of transfer were drawn out: St. John, Diana, Mary, and I,\r\neach became possessed of a competency.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXIV\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was near Christmas by the time all was settled: the season of\r\ngeneral holiday approached. I now closed Morton school, taking care\r\nthat the parting should not be barren on my side. Good fortune opens\r\nthe hand as well as the heart wonderfully; and to give somewhat when we\r\nhave largely received, is but to afford a vent to the unusual\r\nebullition of the sensations. I had long felt with pleasure that many\r\nof my rustic scholars liked me, and when we parted, that consciousness\r\nwas confirmed: they manifested their affection plainly and strongly.\r\nDeep was my gratification to find I had really a place in their\r\nunsophisticated hearts: I promised them that never a week should pass\r\nin future that I did not visit them, and give them an hour\xe2\x80\x99s teaching\r\nin their school.\r\n\r\nMr. Rivers came up as, having seen the classes, now numbering sixty\r\ngirls, file out before me, and locked the door, I stood with the key in\r\nmy hand, exchanging a few words of special farewell with some\r\nhalf-dozen of my best scholars: as decent, respectable, modest, and\r\nwell-informed young women as could be found in the ranks of the British\r\npeasantry. And that is saying a great deal; for after all, the British\r\npeasantry are the best taught, best mannered, most self-respecting of\r\nany in Europe: since those days I have seen paysannes and B\xc3\xa4uerinnen;\r\nand the best of them seemed to me ignorant, coarse, and besotted,\r\ncompared with my Morton girls.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you consider you have got your reward for a season of exertion?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nasked Mr. Rivers, when they were gone. \xe2\x80\x9cDoes not the consciousness of\r\nhaving done some real good in your day and generation give pleasure?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDoubtless.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you have only toiled a few months! Would not a life devoted to the\r\ntask of regenerating your race be well spent?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes,\xe2\x80\x9d I said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut I could not go on for ever so: I want to enjoy my\r\nown faculties as well as to cultivate those of other people. I must\r\nenjoy them now; don\xe2\x80\x99t recall either my mind or body to the school; I am\r\nout of it and disposed for full holiday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked grave. \xe2\x80\x9cWhat now? What sudden eagerness is this you evince?\r\nWhat are you going to do?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo be active: as active as I can. And first I must beg you to set\r\nHannah at liberty, and get somebody else to wait on you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you want her?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, to go with me to Moor House. Diana and Mary will be at home in a\r\nweek, and I want to have everything in order against their arrival.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI understand. I thought you were for flying off on some excursion. It\r\nis better so: Hannah shall go with you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell her to be ready by to-morrow then; and here is the schoolroom\r\nkey: I will give you the key of my cottage in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe took it. \xe2\x80\x9cYou give it up very gleefully,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t quite\r\nunderstand your light-heartedness, because I cannot tell what\r\nemployment you propose to yourself as a substitute for the one you are\r\nrelinquishing. What aim, what purpose, what ambition in life have you\r\nnow?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy first aim will be to _clean down_ (do you comprehend the full force\r\nof the expression?)\xe2\x80\x94to _clean down_ Moor House from chamber to cellar;\r\nmy next to rub it up with bees-wax, oil, and an indefinite number of\r\ncloths, till it glitters again; my third, to arrange every chair,\r\ntable, bed, carpet, with mathematical precision; afterwards I shall go\r\nnear to ruin you in coals and peat to keep up good fires in every room;\r\nand lastly, the two days preceding that on which your sisters are\r\nexpected will be devoted by Hannah and me to such a beating of eggs,\r\nsorting of currants, grating of spices, compounding of Christmas cakes,\r\nchopping up of materials for mince-pies, and solemnising of other\r\nculinary rites, as words can convey but an inadequate notion of to the\r\nuninitiated like you. My purpose, in short, is to have all things in an\r\nabsolutely perfect state of readiness for Diana and Mary before next\r\nThursday; and my ambition is to give them a beau-ideal of a welcome\r\nwhen they come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSt. John smiled slightly: still he was dissatisfied.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is all very well for the present,\xe2\x80\x9d said he; \xe2\x80\x9cbut seriously, I trust\r\nthat when the first flush of vivacity is over, you will look a little\r\nhigher than domestic endearments and household joys.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe best things the world has!\xe2\x80\x9d I interrupted.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Jane, no: this world is not the scene of fruition; do not attempt\r\nto make it so: nor of rest; do not turn slothful.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean, on the contrary, to be busy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I excuse you for the present: two months\xe2\x80\x99 grace I allow you for\r\nthe full enjoyment of your new position, and for pleasing yourself with\r\nthis late-found charm of relationship; but _then_, I hope you will\r\nbegin to look beyond Moor House and Morton, and sisterly society, and\r\nthe selfish calm and sensual comfort of civilised affluence. I hope\r\nyour energies will then once more trouble you with their strength.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI looked at him with surprise. \xe2\x80\x9cSt. John,\xe2\x80\x9d I said, \xe2\x80\x9cI think you are\r\nalmost wicked to talk so. I am disposed to be as content as a queen,\r\nand you try to stir me up to restlessness! To what end?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the end of turning to profit the talents which God has committed to\r\nyour keeping; and of which He will surely one day demand a strict\r\naccount. Jane, I shall watch you closely and anxiously\xe2\x80\x94I warn you of\r\nthat. And try to restrain the disproportionate fervour with which you\r\nthrow yourself into commonplace home pleasures. Don\xe2\x80\x99t cling so\r\ntenaciously to ties of the flesh; save your constancy and ardour for an\r\nadequate cause; forbear to waste them on trite transient objects. Do\r\nyou hear, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; just as if you were speaking Greek. I feel I have adequate cause\r\nto be happy, and I _will_ be happy. Goodbye!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHappy at Moor House I was, and hard I worked; and so did Hannah: she\r\nwas charmed to see how jovial I could be amidst the bustle of a house\r\nturned topsy-turvy\xe2\x80\x94how I could brush, and dust, and clean, and cook.\r\nAnd really, after a day or two of confusion worse confounded, it was\r\ndelightful by degrees to invoke order from the chaos ourselves had\r\nmade. I had previously taken a journey to S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 to purchase some new\r\nfurniture: my cousins having given me _carte blanche_ to effect what\r\nalterations I pleased, and a sum having been set aside for that\r\npurpose. The ordinary sitting-room and bedrooms I left much as they\r\nwere: for I knew Diana and Mary would derive more pleasure from seeing\r\nagain the old homely tables, and chairs, and beds, than from the\r\nspectacle of the smartest innovations. Still some novelty was\r\nnecessary, to give to their return the piquancy with which I wished it\r\nto be invested. Dark handsome new carpets and curtains, an arrangement\r\nof some carefully selected antique ornaments in porcelain and bronze,\r\nnew coverings, and mirrors, and dressing-cases, for the toilet tables,\r\nanswered the end: they looked fresh without being glaring. A spare\r\nparlour and bedroom I refurnished entirely, with old mahogany and\r\ncrimson upholstery: I laid canvas on the passage, and carpets on the\r\nstairs. When all was finished, I thought Moor House as complete a model\r\nof bright modest snugness within, as it was, at this season, a specimen\r\nof wintry waste and desert dreariness without.\r\n\r\nThe eventful Thursday at length came. They were expected about dark,\r\nand ere dusk fires were lit upstairs and below; the kitchen was in\r\nperfect trim; Hannah and I were dressed, and all was in readiness.\r\n\r\nSt. John arrived first. I had entreated him to keep quite clear of the\r\nhouse till everything was arranged: and, indeed, the bare idea of the\r\ncommotion, at once sordid and trivial, going on within its walls\r\nsufficed to scare him to estrangement. He found me in the kitchen,\r\nwatching the progress of certain cakes for tea, then baking.\r\nApproaching the hearth, he asked, \xe2\x80\x9cIf I was at last satisfied with\r\nhousemaid\xe2\x80\x99s work?\xe2\x80\x9d I answered by inviting him to accompany me on a\r\ngeneral inspection of the result of my labours. With some difficulty, I\r\ngot him to make the tour of the house. He just looked in at the doors I\r\nopened; and when he had wandered upstairs and downstairs, he said I\r\nmust have gone through a great deal of fatigue and trouble to have\r\neffected such considerable changes in so short a time: but not a\r\nsyllable did he utter indicating pleasure in the improved aspect of his\r\nabode.\r\n\r\nThis silence damped me. I thought perhaps the alterations had disturbed\r\nsome old associations he valued. I inquired whether this was the case:\r\nno doubt in a somewhat crest-fallen tone.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNot at all; he had, on the contrary, remarked that I had scrupulously\r\nrespected every association: he feared, indeed, I must have bestowed\r\nmore thought on the matter than it was worth. How many minutes, for\r\ninstance, had I devoted to studying the arrangement of this very\r\nroom?\xe2\x80\x94By-the-bye, could I tell him where such a book was?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI showed him the volume on the shelf: he took it down, and withdrawing\r\nto his accustomed window recess, he began to read it.\r\n\r\nNow, I did not like this, reader. St. John was a good man; but I began\r\nto feel he had spoken truth of himself when he said he was hard and\r\ncold. The humanities and amenities of life had no attraction for\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94its peaceful enjoyments no charm. Literally, he lived only to\r\naspire\xe2\x80\x94after what was good and great, certainly; but still he would\r\nnever rest, nor approve of others resting round him. As I looked at his\r\nlofty forehead, still and pale as a white stone\xe2\x80\x94at his fine lineaments\r\nfixed in study\xe2\x80\x94I comprehended all at once that he would hardly make a\r\ngood husband: that it would be a trying thing to be his wife. I\r\nunderstood, as by inspiration, the nature of his love for Miss Oliver;\r\nI agreed with him that it was but a love of the senses. I comprehended\r\nhow he should despise himself for the feverish influence it exercised\r\nover him; how he should wish to stifle and destroy it; how he should\r\nmistrust its ever conducting permanently to his happiness or hers. I\r\nsaw he was of the material from which nature hews her heroes\xe2\x80\x94Christian\r\nand Pagan\xe2\x80\x94her lawgivers, her statesmen, her conquerors: a steadfast\r\nbulwark for great interests to rest upon; but, at the fireside, too\r\noften a cold cumbrous column, gloomy and out of place.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis parlour is not his sphere,\xe2\x80\x9d I reflected: \xe2\x80\x9cthe Himalayan ridge or\r\nCaffre bush, even the plague-cursed Guinea Coast swamp would suit him\r\nbetter. Well may he eschew the calm of domestic life; it is not his\r\nelement: there his faculties stagnate\xe2\x80\x94they cannot develop or appear to\r\nadvantage. It is in scenes of strife and danger\xe2\x80\x94where courage is\r\nproved, and energy exercised, and fortitude tasked\xe2\x80\x94that he will speak\r\nand move, the leader and superior. A merry child would have the\r\nadvantage of him on this hearth. He is right to choose a missionary\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ncareer\xe2\x80\x94I see it now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey are coming! they are coming!\xe2\x80\x9d cried Hannah, throwing open the\r\nparlour door. At the same moment old Carlo barked joyfully. Out I ran.\r\nIt was now dark; but a rumbling of wheels was audible. Hannah soon had\r\na lantern lit. The vehicle had stopped at the wicket; the driver opened\r\nthe door: first one well-known form, then another, stepped out. In a\r\nminute I had my face under their bonnets, in contact first with Mary\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nsoft cheek, then with Diana\xe2\x80\x99s flowing curls. They laughed\xe2\x80\x94kissed\r\nme\xe2\x80\x94then Hannah: patted Carlo, who was half wild with delight; asked\r\neagerly if all was well; and being assured in the affirmative, hastened\r\ninto the house.\r\n\r\nThey were stiff with their long and jolting drive from Whitcross, and\r\nchilled with the frosty night air; but their pleasant countenances\r\nexpanded to the cheerful firelight. While the driver and Hannah brought\r\nin the boxes, they demanded St. John. At this moment he advanced from\r\nthe parlour. They both threw their arms round his neck at once. He gave\r\neach one quiet kiss, said in a low tone a few words of welcome, stood a\r\nwhile to be talked to, and then, intimating that he supposed they would\r\nsoon rejoin him in the parlour, withdrew there as to a place of refuge.\r\n\r\nI had lit their candles to go upstairs, but Diana had first to give\r\nhospitable orders respecting the driver; this done, both followed me.\r\nThey were delighted with the renovation and decorations of their rooms;\r\nwith the new drapery, and fresh carpets, and rich tinted china vases:\r\nthey expressed their gratification ungrudgingly. I had the pleasure of\r\nfeeling that my arrangements met their wishes exactly, and that what I\r\nhad done added a vivid charm to their joyous return home.\r\n\r\nSweet was that evening. My cousins, full of exhilaration, were so\r\neloquent in narrative and comment, that their fluency covered St.\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s taciturnity: he was sincerely glad to see his sisters; but in\r\ntheir glow of fervour and flow of joy he could not sympathise. The\r\nevent of the day\xe2\x80\x94that is, the return of Diana and Mary\xe2\x80\x94pleased him; but\r\nthe accompaniments of that event, the glad tumult, the garrulous glee\r\nof reception irked him: I saw he wished the calmer morrow was come. In\r\nthe very meridian of the night\xe2\x80\x99s enjoyment, about an hour after tea, a\r\nrap was heard at the door. Hannah entered with the intimation that \xe2\x80\x9ca\r\npoor lad was come, at that unlikely time, to fetch Mr. Rivers to see\r\nhis mother, who was drawing away.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere does she live, Hannah?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cClear up at Whitcross Brow, almost four miles off, and moor and moss\r\nall the way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTell him I will go.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m sure, sir, you had better not. It\xe2\x80\x99s the worst road to travel after\r\ndark that can be: there\xe2\x80\x99s no track at all over the bog. And then it is\r\nsuch a bitter night\xe2\x80\x94the keenest wind you ever felt. You had better send\r\nword, sir, that you will be there in the morning.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nBut he was already in the passage, putting on his cloak; and without\r\none objection, one murmur, he departed. It was then nine o\xe2\x80\x99clock: he\r\ndid not return till midnight. Starved and tired enough he was: but he\r\nlooked happier than when he set out. He had performed an act of duty;\r\nmade an exertion; felt his own strength to do and deny, and was on\r\nbetter terms with himself.\r\n\r\nI am afraid the whole of the ensuing week tried his patience. It was\r\nChristmas week: we took to no settled employment, but spent it in a\r\nsort of merry domestic dissipation. The air of the moors, the freedom\r\nof home, the dawn of prosperity, acted on Diana and Mary\xe2\x80\x99s spirits like\r\nsome life-giving elixir: they were gay from morning till noon, and from\r\nnoon till night. They could always talk; and their discourse, witty,\r\npithy, original, had such charms for me, that I preferred listening to,\r\nand sharing in it, to doing anything else. St. John did not rebuke our\r\nvivacity; but he escaped from it: he was seldom in the house; his\r\nparish was large, the population scattered, and he found daily business\r\nin visiting the sick and poor in its different districts.\r\n\r\nOne morning at breakfast, Diana, after looking a little pensive for\r\nsome minutes, asked him, \xe2\x80\x9cIf his plans were yet unchanged.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cUnchanged and unchangeable,\xe2\x80\x9d was the reply. And he proceeded to inform\r\nus that his departure from England was now definitively fixed for the\r\nensuing year.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd Rosamond Oliver?\xe2\x80\x9d suggested Mary, the words seeming to escape her\r\nlips involuntarily: for no sooner had she uttered them, than she made a\r\ngesture as if wishing to recall them. St. John had a book in his\r\nhand\xe2\x80\x94it was his unsocial custom to read at meals\xe2\x80\x94he closed it, and\r\nlooked up.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRosamond Oliver,\xe2\x80\x9d said he, \xe2\x80\x9cis about to be married to Mr. Granby, one\r\nof the best connected and most estimable residents in S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94, grandson and\r\nheir to Sir Frederic Granby: I had the intelligence from her father\r\nyesterday.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHis sisters looked at each other and at me; we all three looked at him:\r\nhe was serene as glass.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe match must have been got up hastily,\xe2\x80\x9d said Diana: \xe2\x80\x9cthey cannot\r\nhave known each other long.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut two months: they met in October at the county ball at S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94. But\r\nwhere there are no obstacles to a union, as in the present case, where\r\nthe connection is in every point desirable, delays are unnecessary:\r\nthey will be married as soon as S\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x94 Place, which Sir Frederic gives up\r\nto them, can be refitted for their reception.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe first time I found St. John alone after this communication, I felt\r\ntempted to inquire if the event distressed him: but he seemed so little\r\nto need sympathy, that, so far from venturing to offer him more, I\r\nexperienced some shame at the recollection of what I had already\r\nhazarded. Besides, I was out of practice in talking to him: his reserve\r\nwas again frozen over, and my frankness was congealed beneath it.
