Winter snows, I thought, had drifted through that void\r\narch, winter rains beaten in at those hollow casements; for, amidst the\r\ndrenched piles of rubbish, spring had cherished vegetation: grass and\r\nweed grew here and there between the stones and fallen rafters. And oh!\r\nwhere meantime was the hapless owner of this wreck? In what land? Under\r\nwhat auspices? My eye involuntarily wandered to the grey church tower\r\nnear the gates, and I asked, \xe2\x80\x9cIs he with Damer de Rochester, sharing\r\nthe shelter of his narrow marble house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSome answer must be had to these questions. I could find it nowhere but\r\nat the inn, and thither, ere long, I returned. The host himself brought\r\nmy breakfast into the parlour. I requested him to shut the door and sit\r\ndown: I had some questions to ask him. But when he complied, I scarcely\r\nknew how to begin; such horror had I of the possible answers. And yet\r\nthe spectacle of desolation I had just left prepared me in a measure\r\nfor a tale of misery. The host was a respectable-looking, middle-aged\r\nman.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know Thornfield Hall, of course?\xe2\x80\x9d I managed to say at last.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; I lived there once.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you?\xe2\x80\x9d Not in my time, I thought: you are a stranger to me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was the late Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s butler,\xe2\x80\x9d he added.\r\n\r\nThe late! I seem to have received, with full force, the blow I had been\r\ntrying to evade.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe late!\xe2\x80\x9d I gasped. \xe2\x80\x9cIs he dead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI mean the present gentleman, Mr. Edward\xe2\x80\x99s father,\xe2\x80\x9d he explained. I\r\nbreathed again: my blood resumed its flow. Fully assured by these words\r\nthat Mr. Edward\xe2\x80\x94_my_ Mr. Rochester (God bless him, wherever he\r\nwas!)\xe2\x80\x94was at least alive: was, in short, \xe2\x80\x9cthe present gentleman.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nGladdening words! It seemed I could hear all that was to come\xe2\x80\x94whatever\r\nthe disclosures might be\xe2\x80\x94with comparative tranquillity. Since he was\r\nnot in the grave, I could bear, I thought, to learn that he was at the\r\nAntipodes.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Mr. Rochester living at Thornfield Hall now?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked, knowing, of\r\ncourse, what the answer would be, but yet desirous of deferring the\r\ndirect question as to where he really was.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x94oh, no! No one is living there. I suppose you are a stranger\r\nin these parts, or you would have heard what happened last\r\nautumn,\xe2\x80\x94Thornfield Hall is quite a ruin: it was burnt down just about\r\nharvest-time. A dreadful calamity! such an immense quantity of valuable\r\nproperty destroyed: hardly any of the furniture could be saved. The\r\nfire broke out at dead of night, and before the engines arrived from\r\nMillcote, the building was one mass of flame. It was a terrible\r\nspectacle: I witnessed it myself.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt dead of night!\xe2\x80\x9d I muttered. Yes, that was ever the hour of fatality\r\nat Thornfield. \xe2\x80\x9cWas it known how it originated?\xe2\x80\x9d I demanded.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThey guessed, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: they guessed. Indeed, I should say it was\r\nascertained beyond a doubt. You are not perhaps aware,\xe2\x80\x9d he continued,\r\nedging his chair a little nearer the table, and speaking low, \xe2\x80\x9cthat\r\nthere was a lady\xe2\x80\x94a\xe2\x80\x94a lunatic, kept in the house?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI have heard something of it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe was kept in very close confinement, ma\xe2\x80\x99am; people even for some\r\nyears was not absolutely certain of her existence. No one saw her: they\r\nonly knew by rumour that such a person was at the Hall; and who or what\r\nshe was it was difficult to conjecture. They said Mr. Edward had\r\nbrought her from abroad, and some believed she had been his mistress.\r\nBut a queer thing happened a year since\xe2\x80\x94a very queer thing.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI feared now to hear my own story. I endeavoured to recall him to the\r\nmain fact.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this lady?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis lady, ma\xe2\x80\x99am,\xe2\x80\x9d he answered, \xe2\x80\x9cturned out to be Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nwife! The discovery was brought about in the strangest way. There was a\r\nyoung lady, a governess at the Hall, that Mr. Rochester fell in\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut the fire,\xe2\x80\x9d I suggested.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m coming to that, ma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x94that Mr. Edward fell in love with. The\r\nservants say they never saw anybody so much in love as he was: he was\r\nafter her continually. They used to watch him\xe2\x80\x94servants will, you know,\r\nma\xe2\x80\x99am\xe2\x80\x94and he set store on her past everything: for all, nobody but him\r\nthought her so very handsome. She was a little small thing, they say,\r\nalmost like a child. I never saw her myself; but I\xe2\x80\x99ve heard Leah, the\r\nhouse-maid, tell of her. Leah liked her well enough. Mr. Rochester was\r\nabout forty, and this governess not twenty; and you see, when gentlemen\r\nof his age fall in love with girls, they are often like as if they were\r\nbewitched. Well, he would marry her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall tell me this part of the story another time,\xe2\x80\x9d I said; \xe2\x80\x9cbut\r\nnow I have a particular reason for wishing to hear all about the fire.\r\nWas it suspected that this lunatic, Mrs. Rochester, had any hand in\r\nit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou\xe2\x80\x99ve hit it, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: it\xe2\x80\x99s quite certain that it was her, and nobody\r\nbut her, that set it going. She had a woman to take care of her called\r\nMrs. Poole\xe2\x80\x94an able woman in her line, and very trustworthy, but for one\r\nfault\xe2\x80\x94a fault common to a deal of them nurses and matrons\xe2\x80\x94_she kept a\r\nprivate bottle of gin by her_, and now and then took a drop over-much.\r\nIt is excusable, for she had a hard life of it: but still it was\r\ndangerous; for when Mrs. Poole was fast asleep after the gin and water,\r\nthe mad lady, who was as cunning as a witch, would take the keys out of\r\nher pocket, let herself out of her chamber, and go roaming about the\r\nhouse, doing any wild mischief that came into her head. They say she\r\nhad nearly burnt her husband in his bed once: but I don\xe2\x80\x99t know about\r\nthat. However, on this night, she set fire first to the hangings of the\r\nroom next her own, and then she got down to a lower storey, and made\r\nher way to the chamber that had been the governess\xe2\x80\x99s\xe2\x80\x94(she was like as\r\nif she knew somehow how matters had gone on, and had a spite at\r\nher)\xe2\x80\x94and she kindled the bed there; but there was nobody sleeping in\r\nit, fortunately. The governess had run away two months before; and for\r\nall Mr. Rochester sought her as if she had been the most precious thing\r\nhe had in the world, he never could hear a word of her; and he grew\r\nsavage\xe2\x80\x94quite savage on his disappointment: he never was a wild man, but\r\nhe got dangerous after he lost her. He would be alone, too. He sent\r\nMrs. Fairfax, the housekeeper, away to her friends at a distance; but\r\nhe did it handsomely, for he settled an annuity on her for life: and\r\nshe deserved it\xe2\x80\x94she was a very good woman. Miss Ad\xc3\xa8le, a ward he had,\r\nwas put to school. He broke off acquaintance with all the gentry, and\r\nshut himself up like a hermit at the Hall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat! did he not leave England?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLeave England? Bless you, no! He would not cross the door-stones of\r\nthe house, except at night, when he walked just like a ghost about the\r\ngrounds and in the orchard as if he had lost his senses\xe2\x80\x94which it is my\r\nopinion he had; for a more spirited, bolder, keener gentleman than he\r\nwas before that midge of a governess crossed him, you never saw, ma\xe2\x80\x99am.\r\nHe was not a man given to wine, or cards, or racing, as some are, and\r\nhe was not so very handsome; but he had a courage and a will of his\r\nown, if ever man had. I knew him from a boy, you see: and for my part,\r\nI have often wished that Miss Eyre had been sunk in the sea before she\r\ncame to Thornfield Hall.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThen Mr. Rochester was at home when the fire broke out?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, indeed was he; and he went up to the attics when all was burning\r\nabove and below, and got the servants out of their beds and helped them\r\ndown himself, and went back to get his mad wife out of her cell. And\r\nthen they called out to him that she was on the roof, where she was\r\nstanding, waving her arms, above the battlements, and shouting out till\r\nthey could hear her a mile off: I saw her and heard her with my own\r\neyes. She was a big woman, and had long black hair: we could see it\r\nstreaming against the flames as she stood. I witnessed, and several\r\nmore witnessed, Mr. Rochester ascend through the sky-light on to the\r\nroof; we heard him call \xe2\x80\x98Bertha!\xe2\x80\x99 We saw him approach her; and then,\r\nma\xe2\x80\x99am, she yelled and gave a spring, and the next minute she lay\r\nsmashed on the pavement.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nThe next minute she lay smashed on the pavement\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDead! Ay, dead as the stones on which her brains and blood were\r\nscattered.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGood God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou may well say so, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: it was frightful!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe shuddered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd afterwards?\xe2\x80\x9d I urged.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, afterwards the house was burnt to the ground: there are\r\nonly some bits of walls standing now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWere any other lives lost?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94perhaps it would have been better if there had.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat do you mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPoor Mr. Edward!\xe2\x80\x9d he ejaculated, \xe2\x80\x9cI little thought ever to have seen\r\nit! Some say it was a just judgment on him for keeping his first\r\nmarriage secret, and wanting to take another wife while he had one\r\nliving: but I pity him, for my part.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou said he was alive?\xe2\x80\x9d I exclaimed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, yes: he is alive; but many think he had better be dead.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy? How?\xe2\x80\x9d My blood was again running cold. \xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he?\xe2\x80\x9d I demanded.\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he in England?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAy\xe2\x80\x94ay\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s in England; he can\xe2\x80\x99t get out of England, I fancy\xe2\x80\x94he\xe2\x80\x99s a\r\nfixture now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhat agony was this! And the man seemed resolved to protract it.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is stone-blind,\xe2\x80\x9d he said at last. \xe2\x80\x9cYes, he is stone-blind, is Mr.\r\nEdward.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had dreaded worse. I had dreaded he was mad. I summoned strength to\r\nask what had caused this calamity.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt was all his own courage, and a body may say, his kindness, in a\r\nway, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: he wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t leave the house till every one else was out\r\nbefore him. As he came down the great staircase at last, after Mrs.\r\nRochester had flung herself from the battlements, there was a great\r\ncrash\xe2\x80\x94all fell. He was taken out from under the ruins, alive, but sadly\r\nhurt: a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him partly; but one\r\neye was knocked out, and one hand so crushed that Mr. Carter, the\r\nsurgeon, had to amputate it directly. The other eye inflamed: he lost\r\nthe sight of that also. He is now helpless, indeed\xe2\x80\x94blind and a\r\ncripple.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is he? Where does he now live?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAt Ferndean, a manor-house on a farm he has, about thirty miles off:\r\nquite a desolate spot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is with him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOld John and his wife: he would have none else. He is quite broken\r\ndown, they say.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you any sort of conveyance?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe have a chaise, ma\xe2\x80\x99am, a very handsome chaise.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet it be got ready instantly; and if your post-boy can drive me to\r\nFerndean before dark this day, I\xe2\x80\x99ll pay both you and him twice the hire\r\nyou usually demand.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVII\r\n\r\n\r\nThe manor-house of Ferndean was a building of considerable antiquity,\r\nmoderate size, and no architectural pretensions, deep buried in a wood.\r\nI had heard of it before. Mr. Rochester often spoke of it, and\r\nsometimes went there. His father had purchased the estate for the sake\r\nof the game covers. He would have let the house, but could find no\r\ntenant, in consequence of its ineligible and insalubrious site.\r\nFerndean then remained uninhabited and unfurnished, with the exception\r\nof some two or three rooms fitted up for the accommodation of the\r\nsquire when he went there in the season to shoot.\r\n\r\nTo this house I came just ere dark on an evening marked by the\r\ncharacteristics of sad sky, cold gale, and continued small penetrating\r\nrain. The last mile I performed on foot, having dismissed the chaise\r\nand driver with the double remuneration I had promised. Even when\r\nwithin a very short distance of the manor-house, you could see nothing\r\nof it, so thick and dark grew the timber of the gloomy wood about it.\r\nIron gates between granite pillars showed me where to enter, and\r\npassing through them, I found myself at once in the twilight of\r\nclose-ranked trees. There was a grass-grown track descending the forest\r\naisle between hoar and knotty shafts and under branched arches. I\r\nfollowed it, expecting soon to reach the dwelling; but it stretched on\r\nand on, it wound far and farther: no sign of habitation or grounds was\r\nvisible.\r\n\r\nI thought I had taken a wrong direction and lost my way. The darkness\r\nof natural as well as of sylvan dusk gathered over me. I looked round\r\nin search of another road. There was none: all was interwoven stem,\r\ncolumnar trunk, dense summer foliage\xe2\x80\x94no opening anywhere.\r\n\r\nI proceeded: at last my way opened, the trees thinned a little;\r\npresently I beheld a railing, then the house\xe2\x80\x94scarce, by this dim light,\r\ndistinguishable from the trees; so dank and green were its decaying\r\nwalls. Entering a portal, fastened only by a latch, I stood amidst a\r\nspace of enclosed ground, from which the wood swept away in a\r\nsemicircle. There were no flowers, no garden-beds; only a broad\r\ngravel-walk girdling a grass-plat, and this set in the heavy frame of\r\nthe forest. The house presented two pointed gables in its front; the\r\nwindows were latticed and narrow: the front door was narrow too, one\r\nstep led up to it. The whole looked, as the host of the Rochester Arms\r\nhad said, \xe2\x80\x9cquite a desolate spot.\xe2\x80\x9d It was as still as a church on a\r\nweek-day: the pattering rain on the forest leaves was the only sound\r\naudible in its vicinage.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan there be life here?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\nYes, life of some kind there was; for I heard a movement\xe2\x80\x94that narrow\r\nfront-door was unclosing, and some shape was about to issue from the\r\ngrange.\r\n\r\nIt opened slowly: a figure came out into the twilight and stood on the\r\nstep; a man without a hat: he stretched forth his hand as if to feel\r\nwhether it rained. Dusk as it was, I had recognised him\xe2\x80\x94it was my\r\nmaster, Edward Fairfax Rochester, and no other.\r\n\r\nI stayed my step, almost my breath, and stood to watch him\xe2\x80\x94to examine\r\nhim, myself unseen, and alas! to him invisible. It was a sudden\r\nmeeting, and one in which rapture was kept well in check by pain. I had\r\nno difficulty in restraining my voice from exclamation, my step from\r\nhasty advance.\r\n\r\nHis form was of the same strong and stalwart contour as ever: his port\r\nwas still erect, his hair was still raven black; nor were his features\r\naltered or sunk: not in one year\xe2\x80\x99s space, by any sorrow, could his\r\nathletic strength be quelled or his vigorous prime blighted. But in his\r\ncountenance I saw a change: that looked desperate and brooding\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nreminded me of some wronged and fettered wild beast or bird, dangerous\r\nto approach in his sullen woe. The caged eagle, whose gold-ringed eyes\r\ncruelty has extinguished, might look as looked that sightless Samson.\r\n\r\nAnd, reader, do you think I feared him in his blind ferocity?\xe2\x80\x94if you\r\ndo, you little know me. A soft hope blent with my sorrow that soon I\r\nshould dare to drop a kiss on that brow of rock, and on those lips so\r\nsternly sealed beneath it: but not yet. I would not accost him yet.\r\n\r\nHe descended the one step, and advanced slowly and gropingly towards\r\nthe grass-plat. Where was his daring stride now? Then he paused, as if\r\nhe knew not which way to turn. He lifted his hand and opened his\r\neyelids; gazed blank, and with a straining effort, on the sky, and\r\ntoward the amphitheatre of trees: one saw that all to him was void\r\ndarkness. He stretched his right hand (the left arm, the mutilated one,\r\nhe kept hidden in his bosom); he seemed to wish by touch to gain an\r\nidea of what lay around him: he met but vacancy still; for the trees\r\nwere some yards off where he stood. He relinquished the endeavour,\r\nfolded his arms, and stood quiet and mute in the rain, now falling fast\r\non his uncovered head. At this moment John approached him from some\r\nquarter.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you take my arm, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d he said; \xe2\x80\x9cthere is a heavy shower coming\r\non: had you not better go in?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cLet me alone,\xe2\x80\x9d was the answer.\r\n\r\nJohn withdrew without having observed me. Mr. Rochester now tried to\r\nwalk about: vainly,\xe2\x80\x94all was too uncertain. He groped his way back to\r\nthe house, and, re-entering it, closed the door.\r\n\r\nI now drew near and knocked: John\xe2\x80\x99s wife opened for me. \xe2\x80\x9cMary,\xe2\x80\x9d I said,\r\n\xe2\x80\x9chow are you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nShe started as if she had seen a ghost: I calmed her. To her hurried\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it really you, miss, come at this late hour to this lonely place?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nI answered by taking her hand; and then I followed her into the\r\nkitchen, where John now sat by a good fire. I explained to them, in few\r\nwords, that I had heard all which had happened since I left Thornfield,\r\nand that I was come to see Mr. Rochester. I asked John to go down to\r\nthe turn-pike-house, where I had dismissed the chaise, and bring my\r\ntrunk, which I had left there: and then, while I removed my bonnet and\r\nshawl, I questioned Mary as to whether I could be accommodated at the\r\nManor House for the night; and finding that arrangements to that\r\neffect, though difficult, would not be impossible, I informed her I\r\nshould stay. Just at this moment the parlour-bell rang.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you go in,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, \xe2\x80\x9ctell your master that a person wishes to\r\nspeak to him, but do not give my name.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t think he will see you,\xe2\x80\x9d she answered; \xe2\x80\x9che refuses everybody.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nWhen she returned, I inquired what he had said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are to send in your name and your business,\xe2\x80\x9d she replied. She then\r\nproceeded to fill a glass with water, and place it on a tray, together\r\nwith candles.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs that what he rang for?\xe2\x80\x9d I asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes: he always has candles brought in at dark, though he is blind.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive the tray to me; I will carry it in.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI took it from her hand: she pointed me out the parlour door. The tray\r\nshook as I held it; the water spilt from the glass; my heart struck my\r\nribs loud and fast. Mary opened the door for me, and shut it behind me.\r\n\r\nThis parlour looked gloomy: a neglected handful of fire burnt low in\r\nthe grate; and, leaning over it, with his head supported against the\r\nhigh, old-fashioned mantelpiece, appeared the blind tenant of the room.\r\nHis old dog, Pilot, lay on one side, removed out of the way, and coiled\r\nup as if afraid of being inadvertently trodden upon. Pilot pricked up\r\nhis ears when I came in: then he jumped up with a yelp and a whine, and\r\nbounded towards me: he almost knocked the tray from my hands. I set it\r\non the table; then patted him, and said softly, \xe2\x80\x9cLie down!\xe2\x80\x9d Mr.\r\nRochester turned mechanically to _see_ what the commotion was: but as\r\nhe _saw_ nothing, he returned and sighed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGive me the water, Mary,\xe2\x80\x9d he said.\r\n\r\nI approached him with the now only half-filled glass; Pilot followed\r\nme, still excited.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat is the matter?\xe2\x80\x9d he inquired.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDown, Pilot!\xe2\x80\x9d I again said. He checked the water on its way to his\r\nlips, and seemed to listen: he drank, and put the glass down. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is\r\nyou, Mary, is it not?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary is in the kitchen,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered.\r\n\r\nHe put out his hand with a quick gesture, but not seeing where I stood,\r\nhe did not touch me. \xe2\x80\x9cWho is this? Who is this?\xe2\x80\x9d he demanded, trying,\r\nas it seemed, to _see_ with those sightless eyes\xe2\x80\x94unavailing and\r\ndistressing attempt! \xe2\x80\x9cAnswer me\xe2\x80\x94speak again!\xe2\x80\x9d he ordered, imperiously\r\nand aloud.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWill you have a little more water, sir? I spilt half of what was in\r\nthe glass,\xe2\x80\x9d I said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c_Who_ is it? _What_ is it? Who speaks?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPilot knows me, and John and Mary know I am here. I came only this\r\nevening,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cGreat God!\xe2\x80\x94what delusion has come over me? What sweet madness has\r\nseized me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo delusion\xe2\x80\x94no madness: your mind, sir, is too strong for delusion,\r\nyour health too sound for frenzy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd where is the speaker? Is it only a voice? Oh! I _cannot_ see, but\r\nI must feel, or my heart will stop and my brain burst. Whatever\xe2\x80\x94whoever\r\nyou are\xe2\x80\x94be perceptible to the touch or I cannot live!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe groped; I arrested his wandering hand, and prisoned it in both mine.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHer very fingers!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried; \xe2\x80\x9cher small, slight fingers! If so there\r\nmust be more of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe muscular hand broke from my custody; my arm was seized, my\r\nshoulder\xe2\x80\x94neck\xe2\x80\x94waist\xe2\x80\x94I was entwined and gathered to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it Jane? _What_ is it? This is her shape\xe2\x80\x94this is her size\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd this her voice,\xe2\x80\x9d I added. \xe2\x80\x9cShe is all here: her heart, too. God\r\nbless you, sir! I am glad to be so near you again.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane Eyre!\xe2\x80\x94Jane Eyre,\xe2\x80\x9d was all he said.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy dear master,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered, \xe2\x80\x9cI am Jane Eyre: I have found you out\xe2\x80\x94I\r\nam come back to you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIn truth?\xe2\x80\x94in the flesh? My living Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou touch me, sir,\xe2\x80\x94you hold me, and fast enough: I am not cold like a\r\ncorpse, nor vacant like air, am I?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy living darling! These are certainly her limbs, and these her\r\nfeatures; but I cannot be so blest, after all my misery. It is a dream;\r\nsuch dreams as I have had at night when I have clasped her once more to\r\nmy heart, as I do now; and kissed her, as thus\xe2\x80\x94and felt that she loved\r\nme, and trusted that she would not leave me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich I never will, sir, from this day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNever will, says the vision? But I always woke and found it an empty\r\nmockery; and I was desolate and abandoned\xe2\x80\x94my life dark, lonely,\r\nhopeless\xe2\x80\x94my soul athirst and forbidden to drink\xe2\x80\x94my heart famished and\r\nnever to be fed. Gentle, soft dream, nestling in my arms now, you will\r\nfly, too, as your sisters have all fled before you: but kiss me before\r\nyou go\xe2\x80\x94embrace me, Jane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, sir\xe2\x80\x94and there!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\nI pressed my lips to his once brilliant and now rayless eyes\xe2\x80\x94I swept\r\nhis hair from his brow, and kissed that too. He suddenly seemed to\r\narouse himself: the conviction of the reality of all this seized him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is you\xe2\x80\x94is it, Jane? You are come back to me then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you do not lie dead in some ditch under some stream? And you are\r\nnot a pining outcast amongst strangers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, sir! I am an independent woman now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIndependent! What do you mean, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy uncle in Madeira is dead, and he left me five thousand pounds.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! this is practical\xe2\x80\x94this is real!\xe2\x80\x9d he cried: \xe2\x80\x9cI should never dream\r\nthat. Besides, there is that peculiar voice of hers, so animating and\r\npiquant, as well as soft: it cheers my withered heart; it puts life\r\ninto it.\xe2\x80\x94What, Janet! Are you an independent woman? A rich woman?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cQuite rich, sir. If you won\xe2\x80\x99t let me live with you, I can build a\r\nhouse of my own close up to your door, and you may come and sit in my\r\nparlour when you want company of an evening.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut as you are rich, Jane, you have now, no doubt, friends who will\r\nlook after you, and not suffer you to devote yourself to a blind\r\nlameter like me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI told you I am independent, sir, as well as rich: I am my own\r\nmistress.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you will stay with me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCertainly\xe2\x80\x94unless you object. I will be your neighbour, your nurse,\r\nyour housekeeper. I find you lonely: I will be your companion\xe2\x80\x94to read\r\nto you, to walk with you, to sit with you, to wait on you, to be eyes\r\nand hands to you. Cease to look so melancholy, my dear master; you\r\nshall not be left desolate, so long as I live.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe replied not: he seemed serious\xe2\x80\x94abstracted; he sighed; he half-opened\r\nhis lips as if to speak: he closed them again. I felt a little\r\nembarrassed. Perhaps I had too rashly over-leaped conventionalities;\r\nand he, like St. John, saw impropriety in my inconsiderateness. I had\r\nindeed made my proposal from the idea that he wished and would ask me\r\nto be his wife: an expectation, not the less certain because\r\nunexpressed, had buoyed me up, that he would claim me at once as his\r\nown. But no hint to that effect escaping him and his countenance\r\nbecoming more overcast, I suddenly remembered that I might have been\r\nall wrong, and was perhaps playing the fool unwittingly; and I began\r\ngently to withdraw myself from his arms\xe2\x80\x94but he eagerly snatched me\r\ncloser.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo\xe2\x80\x94no\xe2\x80\x94Jane; you must not go. No\xe2\x80\x94I have touched you, heard you, felt\r\nthe comfort of your presence\xe2\x80\x94the sweetness of your consolation: I\r\ncannot give up these joys. I have little left in myself\xe2\x80\x94I must have\r\nyou. The world may laugh\xe2\x80\x94may call me absurd, selfish\xe2\x80\x94but it does not\r\nsignify. My very soul demands you: it will be satisfied, or it will\r\ntake deadly vengeance on its frame.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, sir, I will stay with you: I have said so.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes\xe2\x80\x94but you understand one thing by staying with me; and I understand\r\nanother. You, perhaps, could make up your mind to be about my hand and\r\nchair\xe2\x80\x94to wait on me as a kind little nurse (for you have an\r\naffectionate heart and a generous spirit, which prompt you to make\r\nsacrifices for those you pity), and that ought to suffice for me no\r\ndoubt. I suppose I should now entertain none but fatherly feelings for\r\nyou: do you think so? Come\xe2\x80\x94tell me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will think what you like, sir: I am content to be only your nurse,\r\nif you think it better.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you cannot always be my nurse, Janet: you are young\xe2\x80\x94you must marry\r\none day.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t care about being married.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou should care, Janet: if I were what I once was, I would try to make\r\nyou care\xe2\x80\x94but\xe2\x80\x94a sightless block!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe relapsed again into gloom. I, on the contrary, became more cheerful,\r\nand took fresh courage: these last words gave me an insight as to where\r\nthe difficulty lay; and as it was no difficulty with me, I felt quite\r\nrelieved from my previous embarrassment. I resumed a livelier vein of\r\nconversation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is time some one undertook to rehumanise you,\xe2\x80\x9d said I, parting his\r\nthick and long uncut locks; \xe2\x80\x9cfor I see you are being metamorphosed into\r\na lion, or something of that sort. You have a \xe2\x80\x98faux air\xe2\x80\x99 of\r\nNebuchadnezzar in the fields about you, that is certain: your hair\r\nreminds me of eagles\xe2\x80\x99 feathers; whether your nails are grown like\r\nbirds\xe2\x80\x99 claws or not, I have not yet noticed.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOn this arm, I have neither hand nor nails,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, drawing the\r\nmutilated limb from his breast, and showing it to me. \xe2\x80\x9cIt is a mere\r\nstump\xe2\x80\x94a ghastly sight! Don\xe2\x80\x99t you think so, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a pity to see it; and a pity to see your eyes\xe2\x80\x94and the scar of\r\nfire on your forehead: and the worst of it is, one is in danger of\r\nloving you too well for all this; and making too much of you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thought you would be revolted, Jane, when you saw my arm, and my\r\ncicatrised visage.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you? Don\xe2\x80\x99t tell me so\xe2\x80\x94lest I should say something disparaging to\r\nyour judgment. Now, let me leave you an instant, to make a better fire,\r\nand have the hearth swept up. Can you tell when there is a good fire?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; with the right eye I see a glow\xe2\x80\x94a ruddy haze.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd you see the candles?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery dimly\xe2\x80\x94each is a luminous cloud.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCan you see me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, my fairy: but I am only too thankful to hear and feel you.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhen do you take supper?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never take supper.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut you shall have some to-night. I am hungry: so are you, I daresay,\r\nonly you forget.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nSummoning Mary, I soon had the room in more cheerful order: I prepared\r\nhim, likewise, a comfortable repast. My spirits were excited, and with\r\npleasure and ease I talked to him during supper, and for a long time\r\nafter. There was no harassing restraint, no repressing of glee and\r\nvivacity with him; for with him I was at perfect ease, because I knew I\r\nsuited him; all I said or did seemed either to console or revive him.\r\nDelightful consciousness! It brought to life and light my whole nature:\r\nin his presence I thoroughly lived; and he lived in mine. Blind as he\r\nwas, smiles played over his face, joy dawned on his forehead: his\r\nlineaments softened and warmed.\r\n\r\nAfter supper, he began to ask me many questions, of where I had been,\r\nwhat I had been doing, how I had found him out; but I gave him only\r\nvery partial replies: it was too late to enter into particulars that\r\nnight. Besides, I wished to touch no deep-thrilling chord\xe2\x80\x94to open no\r\nfresh well of emotion in his heart: my sole present aim was to cheer\r\nhim. Cheered, as I have said, he was: and yet but by fits. If a\r\nmoment\xe2\x80\x99s silence broke the conversation, he would turn restless, touch\r\nme, then say, \xe2\x80\x9cJane.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are altogether a human being, Jane? You are certain of that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nYou are altogether a human being, Jane? You are certain of that?\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI conscientiously believe so, Mr. Rochester.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet how, on this dark and doleful evening, could you so suddenly rise\r\non my lone hearth? I stretched my hand to take a glass of water from a\r\nhireling, and it was given me by you: I asked a question, expecting\r\nJohn\xe2\x80\x99s wife to answer me, and your voice spoke at my ear.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I had come in, in Mary\xe2\x80\x99s stead, with the tray.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd there is enchantment in the very hour I am now spending with you.\r\nWho can tell what a dark, dreary, hopeless life I have dragged on for\r\nmonths past? Doing nothing, expecting nothing; merging night in day;\r\nfeeling but the sensation of cold when I let the fire go out, of hunger\r\nwhen I forgot to eat: and then a ceaseless sorrow, and, at times, a\r\nvery delirium of desire to behold my Jane again. Yes: for her\r\nrestoration I longed, far more than for that of my lost sight. How can\r\nit be that Jane is with me, and says she loves me? Will she not depart\r\nas suddenly as she came? To-morrow, I fear I shall find her no more.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA commonplace, practical reply, out of the train of his own disturbed\r\nideas, was, I was sure, the best and most reassuring for him in this\r\nframe of mind. I passed my finger over his eyebrows, and remarked that\r\nthey were scorched, and that I would apply something which would make\r\nthem grow as broad and black as ever.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere is the use of doing me good in any way, beneficent spirit, when,\r\nat some fatal moment, you will again desert me\xe2\x80\x94passing like a shadow,\r\nwhither and how to me unknown, and for me remaining afterwards\r\nundiscoverable?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you a pocket-comb about you, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat for, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust to comb out this shaggy black mane. I find you rather alarming,\r\nwhen I examine you close at hand: you talk of my being a fairy, but I\r\nam sure, you are more like a brownie.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAm I hideous, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cVery, sir: you always were, you know.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHumph! The wickedness has not been taken out of you, wherever you have\r\nsojourned.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYet I have been with good people; far better than you: a hundred times\r\nbetter people; possessed of ideas and views you never entertained in\r\nyour life: quite more refined and exalted.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho the deuce have you been with?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIf you twist in that way you will make me pull the hair out of your\r\nhead; and then I think you will cease to entertain doubts of my\r\nsubstantiality.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho have you been with, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou shall not get it out of me to-night, sir; you must wait till\r\nto-morrow; to leave my tale half told, will, you know, be a sort of\r\nsecurity that I shall appear at your breakfast table to finish it. By\r\nthe bye, I must mind not to rise on your hearth with only a glass of\r\nwater then: I must bring an egg at the least, to say nothing of fried\r\nham.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou mocking changeling\xe2\x80\x94fairy-born and human-bred! You make me feel as\r\nI have not felt these twelve months. If Saul could have had you for his\r\nDavid, the evil spirit would have been exorcised without the aid of the\r\nharp.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThere, sir, you are redd up and made decent. Now I\xe2\x80\x99ll leave you: I\r\nhave been travelling these last three days, and I believe I am tired.\r\nGood night.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJust one word, Jane: were there only ladies in the house where you\r\nhave been?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI laughed and made my escape, still laughing as I ran upstairs. \xe2\x80\x9cA good\r\nidea!\xe2\x80\x9d I thought with glee. \xe2\x80\x9cI see I have the means of fretting him out\r\nof his melancholy for some time to come.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nVery early the next morning I heard him up and astir, wandering from\r\none room to another. As soon as Mary came down I heard the question:\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs Miss Eyre here?\xe2\x80\x9d Then: \xe2\x80\x9cWhich room did you put her into? Was it\r\ndry? Is she up? Go and ask if she wants anything; and when she will\r\ncome down.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI came down as soon as I thought there was a prospect of breakfast.\r\nEntering the room very softly, I had a view of him before he discovered\r\nmy presence. It was mournful, indeed, to witness the subjugation of\r\nthat vigorous spirit to a corporeal infirmity. He sat in his\r\nchair\xe2\x80\x94still, but not at rest: expectant evidently; the lines of now\r\nhabitual sadness marking his strong features. His countenance reminded\r\none of a lamp quenched, waiting to be re-lit\xe2\x80\x94and alas! it was not\r\nhimself that could now kindle the lustre of animated expression: he was\r\ndependent on another for that office! I had meant to be gay and\r\ncareless, but the powerlessness of the strong man touched my heart to\r\nthe quick: still I accosted him with what vivacity I could.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is a bright, sunny morning, sir,\xe2\x80\x9d I said. \xe2\x80\x9cThe rain is over and\r\ngone, and there is a tender shining after it: you shall have a walk\r\nsoon.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had wakened the glow: his features beamed.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh, you are indeed there, my skylark! Come to me. You are not gone:\r\nnot vanished? I heard one of your kind an hour ago, singing high over\r\nthe wood: but its song had no music for me, any more than the rising\r\nsun had rays. All the melody on earth is concentrated in my Jane\xe2\x80\x99s\r\ntongue to my ear (I am glad it is not naturally a silent one): all the\r\nsunshine I can feel is in her presence.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThe water stood in my eyes to hear this avowal of his dependence; just\r\nas if a royal eagle, chained to a perch, should be forced to entreat a\r\nsparrow to become its purveyor. But I would not be lachrymose: I dashed\r\noff the salt drops, and busied myself with preparing breakfast.\r\n\r\nMost of the morning was spent in the open air. I led him out of the wet\r\nand wild wood into some cheerful fields: I described to him how\r\nbrilliantly green they were; how the flowers and hedges looked\r\nrefreshed; how sparklingly blue was the sky. I sought a seat for him in\r\na hidden and lovely spot, a dry stump of a tree; nor did I refuse to\r\nlet him, when seated, place me on his knee. Why should I, when both he\r\nand I were happier near than apart? Pilot lay beside us: all was quiet.\r\nHe broke out suddenly while clasping me in his arms\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cCruel, cruel deserter! Oh, Jane, what did I feel when I discovered you\r\nhad fled from Thornfield, and when I could nowhere find you; and, after\r\nexamining your apartment, ascertained that you had taken no money, nor\r\nanything which could serve as an equivalent! A pearl necklace I had\r\ngiven you lay untouched in its little casket; your trunks were left\r\ncorded and locked as they had been prepared for the bridal tour. What\r\ncould my darling do, I asked, left destitute and penniless? And what\r\ndid she do? Let me hear now.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThus urged, I began the narrative of my experience for the last year. I\r\nsoftened considerably what related to the three days of wandering and\r\nstarvation, because to have told him all would have been to inflict\r\nunnecessary pain: the little I did say lacerated his faithful heart\r\ndeeper than I wished.\r\n\r\nI should not have left him thus, he said, without any means of making\r\nmy way: I should have told him my intention. I should have confided in\r\nhim: he would never have forced me to be his mistress. Violent as he\r\nhad seemed in his despair, he, in truth, loved me far too well and too\r\ntenderly to constitute himself my tyrant: he would have given me half\r\nhis fortune, without demanding so much as a kiss in return, rather than\r\nI should have flung myself friendless on the wide world. I had endured,\r\nhe was certain, more than I had confessed to him.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, whatever my sufferings had been, they were very short,\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nanswered: and then I proceeded to tell him how I had been received at\r\nMoor House; how I had obtained the office of schoolmistress, &c. The\r\naccession of fortune, the discovery of my relations, followed in due\r\norder. Of course, St. John Rivers\xe2\x80\x99 name came in frequently in the\r\nprogress of my tale. When I had done, that name was immediately taken\r\nup.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThis St. John, then, is your cousin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou have spoken of him often: do you like him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe was a very good man, sir; I could not help liking him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good man. Does that mean a respectable well-conducted man of fifty?\r\nOr what does it mean?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt John was only twenty-nine, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9c\xe2\x80\x98_Jeune encore_,\xe2\x80\x99 as the French say. Is he a person of low stature,\r\nphlegmatic, and plain. A person whose goodness consists rather in his\r\nguiltlessness of vice, than in his prowess in virtue.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is untiringly active. Great and exalted deeds are what he lives to\r\nperform.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBut his brain? That is probably rather soft? He means well: but you\r\nshrug your shoulders to hear him talk?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe talks little, sir: what he does say is ever to the point. His brain\r\nis first-rate, I should think not impressible, but vigorous.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs he an able man, then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly able.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA thoroughly educated man?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. John is an accomplished and profound scholar.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis manners, I think, you said are not to your taste?\xe2\x80\x94priggish and\r\nparsonic?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never mentioned his manners; but, unless I had a very bad taste,\r\nthey must suit it; they are polished, calm, and gentlemanlike.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHis appearance,\xe2\x80\x94I forget what description you gave of his\r\nappearance;\xe2\x80\x94a sort of raw curate, half strangled with his white\r\nneckcloth, and stilted up on his thick-soled high-lows, eh?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. John dresses well. He is a handsome man: tall, fair, with blue\r\neyes, and a Grecian profile.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n(Aside.) \xe2\x80\x9cDamn him!\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x94(To me.) \xe2\x80\x9cDid you like him, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, Mr. Rochester, I liked him: but you asked me that before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI perceived, of course, the drift of my interlocutor. Jealousy had got\r\nhold of him: she stung him; but the sting was salutary: it gave him\r\nrespite from the gnawing fang of melancholy. I would not, therefore,\r\nimmediately charm the snake.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cPerhaps you would rather not sit any longer on my knee, Miss Eyre?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nwas the next somewhat unexpected observation.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy not, Mr. Rochester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe picture you have just drawn is suggestive of a rather too\r\noverwhelming contrast. Your words have delineated very prettily a\r\ngraceful Apollo: he is present to your imagination,\xe2\x80\x94tall, fair,\r\nblue-eyed, and with a Grecian profile. Your eyes dwell on a Vulcan,\xe2\x80\x94a\r\nreal blacksmith, brown, broad-shouldered: and blind and lame into the\r\nbargain.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI never thought of it, before; but you certainly are rather like\r\nVulcan, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWell, you can leave me, ma\xe2\x80\x99am: but before you go\xe2\x80\x9d (and he retained me\r\nby a firmer grasp than ever), \xe2\x80\x9cyou will be pleased just to answer me a\r\nquestion or two.\xe2\x80\x9d He paused.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat questions, Mr. Rochester?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen followed this cross-examination.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSt. John made you schoolmistress of Morton before he knew you were his\r\ncousin?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou would often see him? He would visit the school sometimes?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDaily.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would approve of your plans, Jane? I know they would be clever, for\r\nyou are a talented creature!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe approved of them\xe2\x80\x94yes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe would discover many things in you he could not have expected to\r\nfind? Some of your accomplishments are not ordinary.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI don\xe2\x80\x99t know about that.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou had a little cottage near the school, you say: did he ever come\r\nthere to see you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNow and then?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf an evening?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnce or twice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHow long did you reside with him and his sisters after the cousinship\r\nwas discovered?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFive months.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid Rivers spend much time with the ladies of his family?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; the back parlour was both his study and ours: he sat near the\r\nwindow, and we by the table.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he study much?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA good deal.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHindostanee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd what did you do meantime?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI learnt German, at first.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he teach you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe did not understand German.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid he teach you nothing?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA little Hindostanee.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cRivers taught you Hindostanee?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd his sisters also?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOnly me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you ask to learn?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe wished to teach you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA second pause.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhy did he wish it? Of what use could Hindostanee be to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe intended me to go with him to India.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! here I reach the root of the matter. He wanted you to marry him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe asked me to marry him.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat is a fiction\xe2\x80\x94an impudent invention to vex me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI beg your pardon, it is the literal truth: he asked me more than\r\nonce, and was as stiff about urging his point as ever you could be.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMiss Eyre, I repeat it, you can leave me. How often am I to say the\r\nsame thing? Why do you remain pertinaciously perched on my knee, when I\r\nhave given you notice to quit?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause I am comfortable there.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cNo, Jane, you are not comfortable there, because your heart is not\r\nwith me: it is with this cousin\xe2\x80\x94this St. John. Oh, till this moment, I\r\nthought my little Jane was all mine! I had a belief she loved me even\r\nwhen she left me: that was an atom of sweet in much bitter. Long as we\r\nhave been parted, hot tears as I have wept over our separation, I never\r\nthought that while I was mourning her, she was loving another! But it\r\nis useless grieving. Jane, leave me: go and marry Rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShake me off, then, sir,\xe2\x80\x94push me away, for I\xe2\x80\x99ll not leave you of my\r\nown accord.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane, I ever like your tone of voice: it still renews hope, it sounds\r\nso truthful. When I hear it, it carries me back a year. I forget that\r\nyou have formed a new tie. But I am not a fool\xe2\x80\x94go\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhere must I go, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYour own way\xe2\x80\x94with the husband you have chosen.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWho is that?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou know\xe2\x80\x94this St. John Rivers.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHe is not my husband, nor ever will be. He does not love me: I do not\r\nlove him. He loves (as he _can_ love, and that is not as you love) a\r\nbeautiful young lady called Rosamond. He wanted to marry me only\r\nbecause he thought I should make a suitable missionary\xe2\x80\x99s wife, which\r\nshe would not have done. He is good and great, but severe; and, for me,\r\ncold as an iceberg. He is not like you, sir: I am not happy at his\r\nside, nor near him, nor with him. He has no indulgence for me\xe2\x80\x94no\r\nfondness. He sees nothing attractive in me; not even youth\xe2\x80\x94only a few\r\nuseful mental points.\xe2\x80\x94Then I must leave you, sir, to go to him?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI shuddered involuntarily, and clung instinctively closer to my blind\r\nbut beloved master. He smiled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhat, Jane! Is this true? Is such really the state of matters between\r\nyou and Rivers?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAbsolutely, sir! Oh, you need not be jealous! I wanted to tease you a\r\nlittle to make you less sad: I thought anger would be better than\r\ngrief. But if you wish me to love you, could you but see how much I\r\n_do_ love you, you would be proud and content. All my heart is yours,\r\nsir: it belongs to you; and with you it would remain, were fate to\r\nexile the rest of me from your presence for ever.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain, as he kissed me, painful thoughts darkened his aspect.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMy seared vision! My crippled strength!\xe2\x80\x9d he murmured regretfully.\r\n\r\nI caressed, in order to soothe him. I knew of what he was thinking, and\r\nwanted to speak for him, but dared not. As he turned aside his face a\r\nminute, I saw a tear slide from under the sealed eyelid, and trickle\r\ndown the manly cheek. My heart swelled.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI am no better than the old lightning-struck chestnut-tree in\r\nThornfield orchard,\xe2\x80\x9d he remarked ere long. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd what right would that\r\nruin have to bid a budding woodbine cover its decay with freshness?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou are no ruin, sir\xe2\x80\x94no lightning-struck tree: you are green and\r\nvigorous. Plants will grow about your roots, whether you ask them or\r\nnot, because they take delight in your bountiful shadow; and as they\r\ngrow they will lean towards you, and wind round you, because your\r\nstrength offers them so safe a prop.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nAgain he smiled: I gave him comfort.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou speak of friends, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d he asked.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, of friends,\xe2\x80\x9d I answered rather hesitatingly: for I knew I meant\r\nmore than friends, but could not tell what other word to employ. He\r\nhelped me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAh! Jane. But I want a wife.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you, sir?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes: is it news to you?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOf course: you said nothing about it before.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIs it unwelcome news?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThat depends on circumstances, sir\xe2\x80\x94on your choice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich you shall make for me, Jane. I will abide by your decision.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cChoose then, sir\xe2\x80\x94_her who loves you best_.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI will at least choose\xe2\x80\x94_her I love best_. Jane, will you marry me?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA poor blind man, whom you will have to lead about by the hand?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cA crippled man, twenty years older than you, whom you will have to\r\nwait on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTruly, Jane?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMost truly, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cOh! my darling! God bless you and reward you!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, if ever I did a good deed in my life\xe2\x80\x94if ever I thought\r\na good thought\xe2\x80\x94if ever I prayed a sincere and blameless prayer\xe2\x80\x94if ever\r\nI wished a righteous wish,\xe2\x80\x94I am rewarded now. To be your wife is, for\r\nme, to be as happy as I can be on earth.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cBecause you delight in sacrifice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSacrifice! What do I sacrifice? Famine for food, expectation for\r\ncontent. To be privileged to put my arms round what I value\xe2\x80\x94to press my\r\nlips to what I love\xe2\x80\x94to repose on what I trust: is that to make a\r\nsacrifice? If so, then certainly I delight in sacrifice.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd to bear with my infirmities, Jane: to overlook my deficiencies.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWhich are none, sir, to me. I love you better now, when I can really\r\nbe useful to you, than I did in your state of proud independence, when\r\nyou disdained every part but that of the giver and protector.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHitherto I have hated to be helped\xe2\x80\x94to be led: henceforth, I feel I\r\nshall hate it no more. I did not like to put my hand into a hireling\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nbut it is pleasant to feel it circled by Jane\xe2\x80\x99s little fingers. I\r\npreferred utter loneliness to the constant attendance of servants; but\r\nJane\xe2\x80\x99s soft ministry will be a perpetual joy. Jane suits me: do I suit\r\nher?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cTo the finest fibre of my nature, sir.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe case being so, we have nothing in the world to wait for: we must\r\nbe married instantly.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe looked and spoke with eagerness: his old impetuosity was rising.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe must become one flesh without any delay, Jane: there is but the\r\nlicence to get\xe2\x80\x94then we marry.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMr. Rochester, I have just discovered the sun is far declined from its\r\nmeridian, and Pilot is actually gone home to his dinner. Let me look at\r\nyour watch.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cFasten it into your girdle, Janet, and keep it henceforward: I have no\r\nuse for it.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cIt is nearly four o\xe2\x80\x99clock in the afternoon, sir. Don\xe2\x80\x99t you feel\r\nhungry?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe third day from this must be our wedding-day, Jane. Never mind fine\r\nclothes and jewels, now: all that is not worth a fillip.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThe sun has dried up all the rain-drops, sir. The breeze is still: it\r\nis quite hot.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDo you know, Jane, I have your little pearl necklace at this moment\r\nfastened round my bronze scrag under my cravat? I have worn it since\r\nthe day I lost my only treasure, as a memento of her.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cWe will go home through the wood: that will be the shadiest way.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe pursued his own thoughts without heeding me.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cJane! you think me, I daresay, an irreligious dog: but my heart swells\r\nwith gratitude to the beneficent God of this earth just now. He sees\r\nnot as man sees, but far clearer: judges not as man judges, but far\r\nmore wisely. I did wrong: I would have sullied my innocent\r\nflower\xe2\x80\x94breathed guilt on its purity: the Omnipotent snatched it from\r\nme. I, in my stiff-necked rebellion, almost cursed the dispensation:\r\ninstead of bending to the decree, I defied it. Divine justice pursued\r\nits course; disasters came thick on me: I was forced to pass through\r\nthe valley of the shadow of death. _His_ chastisements are mighty; and\r\none smote me which has humbled me for ever. You know I was proud of my\r\nstrength: but what is it now, when I must give it over to foreign\r\nguidance, as a child does its weakness? Of late, Jane\xe2\x80\x94only\xe2\x80\x94only of\r\nlate\xe2\x80\x94I began to see and acknowledge the hand of God in my doom. I began\r\nto experience remorse, repentance; the wish for reconcilement to my\r\nMaker. I began sometimes to pray: very brief prayers they were, but\r\nvery sincere.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cSome days since: nay, I can number them\xe2\x80\x94four; it was last Monday\r\nnight, a singular mood came over me: one in which grief replaced\r\nfrenzy\xe2\x80\x94sorrow, sullenness. I had long had the impression that since I\r\ncould nowhere find you, you must be dead. Late that night\xe2\x80\x94perhaps it\r\nmight be between eleven and twelve o\xe2\x80\x99clock\xe2\x80\x94ere I retired to my dreary\r\nrest, I supplicated God, that, if it seemed good to Him, I might soon\r\nbe taken from this life, and admitted to that world to come, where\r\nthere was still hope of rejoining Jane.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI was in my own room, and sitting by the window, which was open: it\r\nsoothed me to feel the balmy night-air; though I could see no stars and\r\nonly by a vague, luminous haze, knew the presence of a moon. I longed\r\nfor thee, Janet! Oh, I longed for thee both with soul and flesh! I\r\nasked of God, at once in anguish and humility, if I had not been long\r\nenough desolate, afflicted, tormented; and might not soon taste bliss\r\nand peace once more. That I merited all I endured, I acknowledged\xe2\x80\x94that\r\nI could scarcely endure more, I pleaded; and the alpha and omega of my\r\nheart\xe2\x80\x99s wishes broke involuntarily from my lips in the words\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Jane!\r\nJane! Jane!\xe2\x80\x99\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cDid you speak these words aloud?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI did, Jane. If any listener had heard me, he would have thought me\r\nmad: I pronounced them with such frantic energy.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd it was last Monday night, somewhere near midnight?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYes; but the time is of no consequence: what followed is the strange\r\npoint. You will think me superstitious,\xe2\x80\x94some superstition I have in my\r\nblood, and always had: nevertheless, this is true\xe2\x80\x94true at least it is\r\nthat I heard what I now relate.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAs I exclaimed \xe2\x80\x98Jane! Jane! Jane!\xe2\x80\x99 a voice\xe2\x80\x94I cannot tell whence the\r\nvoice came, but I know whose voice it was\xe2\x80\x94replied, \xe2\x80\x98I am coming: wait\r\nfor me;\xe2\x80\x99 and a moment after, went whispering on the wind the\r\nwords\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x98Where are you?\xe2\x80\x99\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ll tell you, if I can, the idea, the picture these words opened to\r\nmy mind: yet it is difficult to express what I want to express.\r\nFerndean is buried, as you see, in a heavy wood, where sound falls\r\ndull, and dies unreverberating. \xe2\x80\x98Where are you?\xe2\x80\x99 seemed spoken amongst\r\nmountains; for I heard a hill-sent echo repeat the words. Cooler and\r\nfresher at the moment the gale seemed to visit my brow: I could have\r\ndeemed that in some wild, lone scene, I and Jane were meeting. In\r\nspirit, I believe we must have met. You no doubt were, at that hour, in\r\nunconscious sleep, Jane: perhaps your soul wandered from its cell to\r\ncomfort mine; for those were your accents\xe2\x80\x94as certain as I live\xe2\x80\x94they\r\nwere yours!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nReader, it was on Monday night\xe2\x80\x94near midnight\xe2\x80\x94that I too had received\r\nthe mysterious summons: those were the very words by which I replied to\r\nit. I listened to Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s narrative, but made no disclosure in\r\nreturn. The coincidence struck me as too awful and inexplicable to be\r\ncommunicated or discussed. If I told anything, my tale would be such as\r\nmust necessarily make a profound impression on the mind of my hearer:\r\nand that mind, yet from its sufferings too prone to gloom, needed not\r\nthe deeper shade of the supernatural. I kept these things then, and\r\npondered them in my heart.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cYou cannot now wonder,\xe2\x80\x9d continued my master, \xe2\x80\x9cthat when you rose upon\r\nme so unexpectedly last night, I had difficulty in believing you any\r\nother than a mere voice and vision, something that would melt to\r\nsilence and annihilation, as the midnight whisper and mountain echo had\r\nmelted before. Now, I thank God! I know it to be otherwise. Yes, I\r\nthank God!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHe put me off his knee, rose, and reverently lifting his hat from his\r\nbrow, and bending his sightless eyes to the earth, he stood in mute\r\ndevotion. Only the last words of the worship were audible.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI thank my Maker, that, in the midst of judgment, he has remembered\r\nmercy. I humbly entreat my Redeemer to give me strength to lead\r\nhenceforth a purer life than I have done hitherto!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nThen he stretched his hand out to be led. I took that dear hand, held\r\nit a moment to my lips, then let it pass round my shoulder: being so\r\nmuch lower of stature than he, I served both for his prop and guide. We\r\nentered the wood, and wended homeward.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nCHAPTER XXXVIII\xe2\x80\x94CONCLUSION\r\n\r\n\r\nReader, I married him. A quiet wedding we had: he and I, the parson and\r\nclerk, were alone present. When we got back from church, I went into\r\nthe kitchen of the manor-house, where Mary was cooking the dinner and\r\nJohn cleaning the knives, and I said\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cMary, I have been married to Mr. Rochester this morning.\xe2\x80\x9d The\r\nhousekeeper and her husband were both of that decent phlegmatic order\r\nof people, to whom one may at any time safely communicate a remarkable\r\npiece of news without incurring the danger of having one\xe2\x80\x99s ears pierced\r\nby some shrill ejaculation, and subsequently stunned by a torrent of\r\nwordy wonderment. Mary did look up, and she did stare at me: the ladle\r\nwith which she was basting a pair of chickens roasting at the fire, did\r\nfor some three minutes hang suspended in air; and for the same space of\r\ntime John\xe2\x80\x99s knives also had rest from the polishing process: but Mary,\r\nbending again over the roast, said only\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cHave you, Miss? Well, for sure!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nA short time after she pursued\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI seed you go out with the master, but\r\nI didn\xe2\x80\x99t know you were gone to church to be wed;\xe2\x80\x9d and she basted away.\r\nJohn, when I turned to him, was grinning from ear to ear.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cI telled Mary how it would be,\xe2\x80\x9d he said: \xe2\x80\x9cI knew what Mr. Edward\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n(John was an old servant, and had known his master when he was the\r\ncadet of the house, therefore, he often gave him his Christian name)\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cI\r\nknew what Mr. Edward would do; and I was certain he would not wait long\r\nneither: and he\xe2\x80\x99s done right, for aught I know. I wish you joy, Miss!\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nand he politely pulled his forelock.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cThank you, John. Mr. Rochester told me to give you and Mary this.\xe2\x80\x9d I\r\nput into his hand a five-pound note. Without waiting to hear more, I\r\nleft the kitchen. In passing the door of that sanctum some time after,\r\nI caught the words\xe2\x80\x94\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe\xe2\x80\x99ll happen do better for him nor ony o\xe2\x80\x99 t\xe2\x80\x99 grand ladies.\xe2\x80\x9d And\r\nagain, \xe2\x80\x9cIf she ben\xe2\x80\x99t one o\xe2\x80\x99 th\xe2\x80\x99 handsomest, she\xe2\x80\x99s noan fa\xc3\xa2l and varry\r\ngood-natured; and i\xe2\x80\x99 his een she\xe2\x80\x99s fair beautiful, onybody may see\r\nthat.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI wrote to Moor House and to Cambridge immediately, to say what I had\r\ndone: fully explaining also why I had thus acted. Diana and Mary\r\napproved the step unreservedly. Diana announced that she would just\r\ngive me time to get over the honeymoon, and then she would come and see\r\nme.\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cShe had better not wait till then, Jane,\xe2\x80\x9d said Mr. Rochester, when I\r\nread her letter to him; \xe2\x80\x9cif she does, she will be too late, for our\r\nhoneymoon will shine our life long: its beams will only fade over your\r\ngrave or mine.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nHow St. John received the news, I don\xe2\x80\x99t know: he never answered the\r\nletter in which I communicated it: yet six months after he wrote to me,\r\nwithout, however, mentioning Mr. Rochester\xe2\x80\x99s name or alluding to my\r\nmarriage. His letter was then calm, and, though very serious, kind. He\r\nhas maintained a regular, though not frequent, correspondence ever\r\nsince: he hopes I am happy, and trusts I am not of those who live\r\nwithout God in the world, and only mind earthly things.\r\n\r\nYou have not quite forgotten little Ad\xc3\xa8le, have you, reader? I had not;\r\nI soon asked and obtained leave of Mr. Rochester, to go and see her at\r\nthe school where he had placed her. Her frantic joy at beholding me\r\nagain moved me much. She looked pale and thin: she said she was not\r\nhappy. I found the rules of the establishment were too strict, its\r\ncourse of study too severe for a child of her age: I took her home with\r\nme. I meant to become her governess once more, but I soon found this\r\nimpracticable; my time and cares were now required by another\xe2\x80\x94my\r\nhusband needed them all. So I sought out a school conducted on a more\r\nindulgent system, and near enough to permit of my visiting her often,\r\nand bringing her home sometimes. I took care she should never want for\r\nanything that could contribute to her comfort: she soon settled in her\r\nnew abode, became very happy there, and made fair progress in her\r\nstudies. As she grew up, a sound English education corrected in a great\r\nmeasure her French defects; and when she left school, I found in her a\r\npleasing and obliging companion: docile, good-tempered, and\r\nwell-principled. By her grateful attention to me and mine, she has long\r\nsince well repaid any little kindness I ever had it in my power to\r\noffer her.\r\n\r\nMy tale draws to its close: one word respecting my experience of\r\nmarried life, and one brief glance at the fortunes of those whose names\r\nhave most frequently recurred in this narrative, and I have done.\r\n\r\nI have now been married ten years. I know what it is to live entirely\r\nfor and with what I love best on earth. I hold myself supremely\r\nblest\xe2\x80\x94blest beyond what language can express; because I am my husband\xe2\x80\x99s\r\nlife as fully as he is mine. No woman was ever nearer to her mate than\r\nI am: ever more absolutely bone of his bone and flesh of his flesh. I\r\nknow no weariness of my Edward\xe2\x80\x99s society: he knows none of mine, any\r\nmore than we each do of the pulsation of the heart that beats in our\r\nseparate bosoms; consequently, we are ever together. To be together is\r\nfor us to be at once as free as in solitude, as gay as in company. We\r\ntalk, I believe, all day long: to talk to each other is but a more\r\nanimated and an audible thinking. All my confidence is bestowed on him,\r\nall his confidence is devoted to me; we are precisely suited in\r\ncharacter\xe2\x80\x94perfect concord is the result.\r\n\r\nMr. Rochester continued blind the first two years of our union; perhaps\r\nit was that circumstance that drew us so very near\xe2\x80\x94that knit us so very\r\nclose: for I was then his vision, as I am still his right hand.\r\nLiterally, I was (what he often called me) the apple of his eye. He saw\r\nnature\xe2\x80\x94he saw books through me; and never did I weary of gazing for his\r\nbehalf, and of putting into words the effect of field, tree, town,\r\nriver, cloud, sunbeam\xe2\x80\x94of the landscape before us; of the weather round\r\nus\xe2\x80\x94and impressing by sound on his ear what light could no longer stamp\r\non his eye. Never did I weary of reading to him; never did I weary of\r\nconducting him where he wished to go: of doing for him what he wished\r\nto be done. And there was a pleasure in my services, most full, most\r\nexquisite, even though sad\xe2\x80\x94because he claimed these services without\r\npainful shame or damping humiliation. He loved me so truly, that he\r\nknew no reluctance in profiting by my attendance: he felt I loved him\r\nso fondly, that to yield that attendance was to indulge my sweetest\r\nwishes.\r\n\r\nOne morning at the end of the two years, as I was writing a letter to\r\nhis dictation, he came and bent over me, and said\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cJane, have you a\r\nglittering ornament round your neck?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\nI had a gold watch-chain: I answered \xe2\x80\x9cYes.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\xe2\x80\x9cAnd have you a pale blue dress on?\xe2\x80\x9d\r\n\r\n\r\nAnd have you a pale blue dress on?\r\n\r\nI had. He informed me then, that for some time he had fancied the\r\nobscurity clouding one eye was becoming less dense; and that now he was\r\nsure of it.\r\n\r\nHe and I went up to London. He had the advice of an eminent oculist;\r\nand he eventually recovered the sight of that one eye. He cannot now\r\nsee very distinctly: he cannot read or write much; but he can find his\r\nway without being led by the hand: the sky is no longer a blank to\r\nhim\xe2\x80\x94the earth no longer a void. When his first-born was put into his\r\narms, he could see that the boy had inherited his own eyes, as they\r\nonce were\xe2\x80\x94large, brilliant, and black. On that occasion, he again, with\r\na full heart, acknowledged that God had tempered judgment with mercy.\r\n\r\nMy Edward and I, then, are happy: and the more so, because those we\r\nmost love are happy likewise. Diana and Mary Rivers are both married:\r\nalternately, once every year, they come to see us, and we go to see\r\nthem. Diana\xe2\x80\x99s husband is a captain in the navy, a gallant officer and a\r\ngood man. Mary\xe2\x80\x99s is a clergyman, a college friend of her brother\xe2\x80\x99s,\r\nand, from his attainments and principles, worthy of the connection.\r\nBoth Captain Fitzjames and Mr. Wharton love their wives, and are loved\r\nby them.\r\n\r\nAs to St. John Rivers, he left England: he went to India. He entered on\r\nthe path he had marked for himself; he pursues it still. A more\r\nresolute, indefatigable pioneer never wrought amidst rocks and dangers.\r\nFirm, faithful, and devoted, full of energy, and zeal, and truth, he\r\nlabours for his race; he clears their painful way to improvement; he\r\nhews down like a giant the prejudices of creed and caste that encumber\r\nit. He may be stern; he may be exacting; he may be ambitious yet; but\r\nhis is the sternness of the warrior Greatheart, who guards his pilgrim\r\nconvoy from the onslaught of Apollyon. His is the exaction of the\r\napostle, who speaks but for Christ, when he says\xe2\x80\x94\xe2\x80\x9cWhosoever will come\r\nafter me, let him deny himself, and take up his cross and follow me.\xe2\x80\x9d\r\nHis is the ambition of the high master-spirit, which aims to fill a\r\nplace in the first rank of those who are redeemed from the earth\xe2\x80\x94who\r\nstand without fault before the throne of God, who share the last mighty\r\nvictories of the Lamb, who are called, and chosen, and faithful.\r\n\r\nSt. John is unmarried: he never will marry now. Himself has hitherto\r\nsufficed to the toil, and the toil draws near its close: his glorious\r\nsun hastens to its setting. The last letter I received from him drew\r\nfrom my eyes human tears, and yet filled my heart with divine joy: he\r\nanticipated his sure reward, his incorruptible crown. I know that a\r\nstranger\xe2\x80\x99s hand will write to me next, to say that the good and\r\nfaithful servant has been called at length into the joy of his Lord.\r\nAnd why weep for this? No fear of death will darken St. John\xe2\x80\x99s last\r\nhour: his mind will be unclouded, his heart will be undaunted, his hope\r\nwill be sure, his faith steadfast.
